HEADLINE: What Was Said on President's Visit to Maine

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"President Begins a Campaign to Avoid Losses for the Democratic Party in November" (news article, Sept. 6), your report on the President's Labor Day visit to Maine, contained factual errors. 
 You quote me as saying that under President Clinton's leadership economic growth has soared and more jobs have been generated than under "the two previous Republican Presidents put together."
But you left out an important part of my statement.
What I said (transcribed from a videotape of the event) was that under President Clinton's leadership more jobs have been created than "in the previous five years of Republican Presidents put together."
By omitting my reference to "the previous five years," you transformed a correct statement into one that is incorrect.
You also state that my remarks were "drafted by the White House." My remarks were extemporaneous. I had no text or notes. I did not discuss my remarks beforehand with anyone, inside or outside the White House.
 
GEORGE J. MITCHELL
U.S. Senator from Maine
Washington, Sept. 7, 1994

HEADLINE: In Baptist Talk, Clinton Stresses Moral Themes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 9

 BODY:
President Clinton told black Baptists at a convention today that government alone could not halt the decline in social and moral standards. He said that far too many young women are having abortions, and that only caring adults can rescue inner-city children, adding that it was time for Americans to revive faith in themselves -- and in him as well.
The remarks, in part a reprise of speeches about personal responsibility, sounded a familiar note that White House officials said was not intended to bolster the President's campaign-season credentials as a moderate Democratic leader. But, they said, he will probably repeat the theme through the November elections. 
 Mr. Clinton said, for instance, that black politicians should set aside their reservations about the crime legislation, which increases penalties that some black lawmakers have complained would fall most disproportionately heavily on blacks.
"Every time you look at the evening news," he said, "there's another funeral. And there's a disproportionate number of black kids lying in those pine boxes, too. And that's wrong, that's what's really wrong, and we have got to find a way -- imperfect though it is -- to get all the Americans together with all their different perspectives, and move forward on this issue because if people are not safe, we're in trouble."
The President's address at the annual meeting of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A., the world's largest organization of black Baptists, was billed as a lecture on the need for all Americans to play a role in repairing the nation's social fabric. And Mr. Clinton spoke long and passionately about what he said was every citizen's responsibility to ensure a safe and moral upbringing for all children.
The speech also sounded a lot like one on "family values" that Dan Quayle, a possible Republican candidate for President in 1996, delivered on Thursday in San Francisco. The White House said that was a coincidence, and Mr. Clinton's press spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said the President "agreed with many elements" of Mr. Quayle's speech.
Mr. Clinton began by discussing his own declining political fortunes, seeming to suggest that the recent drop in his public approval rating was tied not to his Administration's policies but to Americans' cynicism and fear of the future.
Citing a newspaper columnist who he said had written that "people are still mad at the President" despite relatively good times, Mr. Clinton said the problem was akin to that of a man whose riches had not made him content.
 
'Why Aren't We Happier?'
 "Well, that's kind of what's going on in our country today," he said. "We still haven't quite got the rhythm right, so that even though we are facing a lot of our most profound problems, and even though we are clearly making progress in areas too long ignored, which many of you have mentioned here, we have to say what is the real deal here? Why aren't we happier about it?"
The President suggested three reasons: public worries about the nation's future now that the cold war is over; an attitude "that seems to glorify the negative, the cynical," and an array of genuinely pressing problems, like crime, unemployment and broken homes.
Mr. Clinton said he still believed the Federal Government could resolve such problems, and he listed initiatives that he called evidence of his commitment, including the crime legislation recently enacted, tax breaks for inner-city businesses, changes in welfare, and greater spending on education and child health care.
 
Appeal to Blacks
 But his broader theme was that problems would never be solved unless ordinary people acknowledged their duty to find solutions on their own. And he made a particular appeal to his audience to help black Americans shed attitudes that he said hindered the search.
In unusually blunt language, Mr. Clinton urged blacks and whites to adopt a new and less tolerant attitude toward illegitimacy, abortion and single parenthood.
Noting that 4 in 10 children are born to unwed mothers, the President said Americans were "raising a whole generation of children who aren't sure they're the most important person in the world to anybody."
"That is a disaster," he said. "It is wrong. And someone has to say again: 'It is simply not right. You shouldn't have a baby before you're ready, and you shouldn't have a baby when you're not married. You just have to stop it.' We've got to turn it around."
The President was equally critical of the rate of abortions, which end 27 percent of all pregnancies. "I don't care what your position is, whether you're pro-choice or anti," he said. "That's too many."
Later, Mr. Clinton said the last thing he sought was to stigmatize children of unwed mothers. "I know not everybody's going to be in a stable, traditional family like you see on one of those 1950 sitcoms," he said. "But we'd be better off if more people were.
"I was raised by a wonderful mother who worked, who cared for me, who was a widow when I was born, went through a difficult marriage, and at least every now and then I find somebody that thinks I turned out all right."
Mr. Clinton struck many of the same chords as Mr. Quayle, who had accused the entertainment industry, politicians and the church of fostering an "ethical chaos" that is leaving children without any bedrock of moral values.
Without mentioning Mr. Quayle by name, the President said today that people should pay attention to anyone who preached against the decline in values, "whether they are our allies or our adversaries."

HEADLINE: CUBA VOWS TO END EXODUS IN RETURN FOR A RISE IN VISAS

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Cuba and the United States reached an agreement today under which Havana pledged to stop its citizens from fleeing the country for Florida aboard makeshift rafts and small boats. In return, Washington promised to accept at least 20,000 new Cuban immigrants each year.
But the 30,000 Cuban refugees who have already fled the island, most of whom are housed at the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay or at camps in Panama, appear to be the big losers under the new agreement. American officials, briefing reporters on the results of the eight days of negotiation, indicated that the Cubans in Guantanamo and Panama would not be permitted to move ahead of applicants now in Cuba. 
 American officials said the United States would not accept them while they are in these camps and added that while they could stay there as long as they wished or seek asylum elsewhere, they must return to Cuba and apply for immigrant visas in the normal way if they wish to come to the United States. Cuba has agreed to receive Cubans now in the so-called safe havens of Guantanamo and Panama.
Reflecting the poor state of relations between Cuba and the United States, the communique announcing the accord was drafted in correct but chilly language. It said the two sides had "mutual interest in normalizing migration procedures and agreed to take measures to insure that migration between the two countries is safe, legal and orderly."
In the first step toward fulfilling the terms of the accord, Cuba announced this evening that it would stop further departures from mid-day Tuesday, even if force had to be used. The statement said Cubans had 72 hours from mid-day Saturday to clear up rafts or raft material gathered on beaches.
President Fidel Castro of Cuba has insisted that the cause of the sudden surge of boat people to the United States -- the largest since 1980 -- was the economic boycott of Cuba by the United States, and he wanted the talks in New York to cover the ending of the embargo. But American officials insisted that the talks be limited to migration, and it was uncertain what Mr. Castro had achieved.
In Washington, Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff said the crisis was resolved because of "the quick and decisive action" of President Clinton, who made it clear that boat people would not be permitted to land in the United States, but rather would be sent to "safe havens." On overall Cuban-American relations, Mr. Tarnoff insisted that Cuba first had to make a transition to democracy.
"It will not hasten political and economic reform in Cuba for the United States to negotiate the terms and conditions of change in that country with its unelected Government, over the heads of the Cuban people," he said.
Nevertheless, this was the most significant accord between the two counties since the Carter Administration negotiated an anti-hijacking accord in the 1970's and agreed to set up quasi-embassies known as interest sections in Havana and Washington.
In addition to the 20,000 new immigrant visas it has agreed to grant each year, the Clinton Administration also expects to issue entry visas for 500 close relatives of Cubans already living in this country.
And as an exceptional one-year measure, the United States will grant entry to all Cubans living in Cuba who are now on the visa waiting list. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Michael M. Skol, who led the American negotiating team, said some 19,000 Cubans were on this list, although he expects only 4,000 to 6,000 of them to seek visas.
In total, Mr. Skol said that between 24,500 and 26,500 Cuban refugees were likely to gain entry to the United States over the coming year. Last year about 2,700 Cubans qualified as legal immigrants.
In a statement issued in New Orleans, Mr. Clinton said today's accord would "help insure that the massive flow of dangerous and illegal migration will be replaced by a safer, legal and more orderly process." The settlement, he added, was a "fair, good agreement, good for the United States."
At a news conference at the United States mission to the United Nations, where the accord was wrapped up today, Mr. Skol insisted that the United States had refused to even discuss the trade embargo against Cuba, let alone promise any easing of it.
But Cuba made clear at the start of the talks that it wanted the Administration to set a date for talks on easing the 32-year-old embargo in return for a new migration agreement, arguing that the hardship the blockade causes forces people to flee the country.
The text of the agreement makes no mention of economic issues, although the United States promised "to take effective measures" to stop aircraft or boat hijackings by Cubans fleeing their island.
Today's accord thus appears to give Mr. Castro very little since it fails to commit the Administration even to hold talks about the embargo, as Cuba wanted, or relax the additional restrictions Mr. Clinton imposed earlier this summer when he made it harder for Cuban Americans to visit the island or send money to relatives there.
"Castro miscalculated," said Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs. "He gets nothing out of this except an end to damaging publicity about the boat people. Since the Administration has not relaxed the new restrictions on remittances and charter flights, Castro's worse off."
Cuba committed itself "to take effective measures in every way it possibly can to prevent unsafe departures, using mainly persuasive methods," the agreement states.
"We expect a dramatic reduction in departures" Mr. Skol said, adding that the Administration also expected Cuba "to take humane measures to stop the outflow."
The round of Cuban-American migration talks that ended today is the 13th the two sides have held since they signed their 1984 immigration pact, under which the United States agreed to take up to 20,000 immigrants annually, although in practice it has tended to admit far fewer.
 
Ceiling Becomes Floor
 Under the new accord, this 20,000 ceiling on Cuban immigration in effect becomes a floor, although total immigration is still capped at 27,845 by an immigration law restricting nationals of individual foreign countries to no more than 7 percent of all immigrant visas issued each year.
If fewer than 20,000 Cuban applicants qualify for immigrant visas in any one year because they lack relatives in America or needed skills, Attorney General Janet Reno has undertaken to use her emergency powers to admit enough to bring the total up to that figure.
In Washington, Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner Doris Meissner said at a news conference that about 5,000 of the planned intake of 20,000 this year were likely to be political refugees and 2,000 to 3,000 more their close dependents.
She predicted that the Administration would issue an additional 3,000 normal immigrant visas to qualifying Cubans. The Attorney General would then use her authority to admit a further 9,000 to 10,000.

HEADLINE: Baseball's Owners Reject Players' Bid To Tax Rich Clubs

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Bud Selig, baseball's acting commissioner, joined the negotiations on the 29th day of the players' strike yesterday, and joined his bargaining team in rejecting the players' proposed plan for taxing clubs' revenues and payrolls. The move seemed to dampen the chances for a quick agreement in the dispute that has shut down baseball since Aug. 11.
But Mr. Selig did not call off the rest of the season on the day he had set as a deadline for doing so. And he did meet secretly with the players' labor leader, prompting speculation that the two sides could yet reach a season-saving settlement. 
 Mr. Selig's secret session with Donald Fehr, the union chief, was one of the signs that participants in the talks pointed to as examples that maybe, just maybe, something is coming that could produce an agreement.
"What they haven't done is say they're going home," Mr. Fehr said after the brief meeting with Mr. Selig. "They're not ready to write the season off yet. That's encouraging."
It was positive, too, that members of the negotiating teams scheduled two parallel meetings for today, one on the core economic issues and one on all other elements of the expired collective bargaining agreement.
And last night Mr. Fehr's brother, Steve, a lawyer who works for the union, spoke with Jerry McMorris the owner of the Colorado Rockies, whose behind-the-scenes efforts got the two sides talking.
The players' tax plan emerged from conversations union officials had had with Mr. McMorris.
The hopeful signs were not apparent in the public comments of Mr. Selig and Mr. Fehr. The owners rejected the players' concept for a tax on payrolls and revenues, which the union presented Thursday night in an effort to steer the owners away from their insistence on a salary cap, while still addressing their concerns over cost control.
In separate news conferences late yesterday afternoon, Mr. Selig and Mr. Fehr each railed at the other side.
But privately, the postures were different, and the public pronouncements didn't prevent Mr. Selig and Mr. Fehr from sneaking off to another room at the Hotel Inter-Continental after the news conferences for their secret session. Interestingly, Paul Molitor, a former longtime member of the Milwaukee Brewers, Mr. Selig's team, was among others who also attended the meeting. Mr. Selig is very fond of Mr. Molitor.
Union people, who have lengthy experience in baseball work stoppages, offered glimpses of what they thought they saw in the main bargaining session that lasted less than an hour.
One person said Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, gave his "stock salary-cap speech, but his heart didn't seem to be in it."
 
'I Like Your Plan'
 John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, another said, commented to someone in the union, "I like your plan, but we're not yet there."
Others said there were subtle suggestions from management representatives that the union shouldn't get excited about what they might hear in the news conference. And, finally, a union lawyer said, "If it's as bad as it looks, why isn't he calling off the season?"
Mr. Selig, who did not return repeated telephone calls seeking the management view of these reports, had said a week earlier that yesterday would be the deadline by which the two sides would have to be in substantive negotiations or face losing the rest of the regular season and post-season. He said playing the World Series without a meaningful end of the season -- two weeks, at least -- would be a farce.
When Mr. Selig was asked about the deadline at his news conference yesterday, he said: "I've said all week long that common sense should prevail. We'll have no announcement on the season until very early next week."
Later, he explained: "I'm very patient, very cautious. You want to bend over backwards to try to do this thing in an orderly way. It's late on a Friday afternoon." Still later, he said he really wasn't pushing back the deadline.
 
No Talks Scheduled
 He also said no talks were scheduled this weekend, then went off and met with Mr. Fehr.
"That's where the real negotiations are going to take place -- in a small room, not in a big room," said Brett Butler of the Los Angeles Dodgers. He was not talking specifically of the secret session taking place at that moment, but of his negotiating experiences in general.
"It seems like we go through this posturing every time and things are said," Mr. Butler added. "But things happen in a small room. I wouldn't be surprised if something can't be done. With Bud Selig being here, there's a possibility."
Even so, in their public comments, Mr. Selig and Mr. Ravitch dismissed the union's concept that would transfer about $50 million from higher-revenue clubs to lower-revenue clubs. The union offered its plan as an alternative to the owners' proposal for putting a cap on players' salaries, which they say they need to hold down spiraling costs and help low-revenue clubs compete. The players rejected the cap as a means of artificially holding down salaries.
 
'Unresponsive' Proposal
 "Unfortunately," Mr. Selig said, "in our judgment that proposal was unresponsive to the long-term interests of baseball and the concerns we have been asking the union for a long time to address."
Mr. Ravitch reiterated Mr. Selig's assessment, but embellished his criticism of the plan by saying it did not deal with "the question of players' salaries, the relationship between players' salaries and industry revenue" and did not put a "restraint on the growth of player salaries."
The players' concept is three-pronged. It calls for an increase in division of gate receipts with visiting teams to 25 percent (from 20 percent in the American League and 43 cents a ticket, or less than 5 percent, in the National); a tax on the payrolls of the 16 teams with the highest payrolls, and a tax on the 16 teams with the highest revenues. Those wouldn't necessarily be the same 16 teams.
The union estimates that the change in gate-receipt sharing would produce $15 million to $20 million. To determine the rate of tax to assess payrolls and revenues, union officials worked backward from their desire to produce $10 million from the payroll levy and $20 million from the revenue levy.
They arrived at these taxes for last season and this season:
1993 -- 1.46 percent on payrolls, 1.58 percent on revenues.
1994 -- 1.51 percent on payrolls, 1.64 percent on revenues.
The money would go from the top 16 teams in each of those categories to the 10 clubs with the lowest revenues. Two clubs would remain neutral, neither paying the tax nor receiving money.
 
A Temporary Tax
 The union suggested that no team receive money for more than two successive seasons and that the tax system eventually be phased out. It suggested part of future expansion fees could take the place of the tax money.
"It should be temporary because the focus shouldn't be on sharing revenue but on working together to grow it," one union official said.
But the owners turned down the plan, saying they would decide how to share their revenue.
"It was clear a salary cap is still their primary consideration," Mr. Fehr said. "No salary cap in the plan, no artificial restraint to take player salaries below the market level, so they weren't interested. There's no clearer indication why there is a strike almost a month old. They're stuck on the same thing. It apparently doesn't matter what the nature of the proposal is unless it destroys the free-market system and holds down salaries."
Not all of the clubs were happy with the way their negotiators treated the players' plan.
"We have heard nothing from the people in New York," a high-ranking official of one club said. "I've talked to three clubs, and no one's seen anything. We're all trying to figure out what it's going to cost us. The only thing we have to go on is what we've seen in the newspapers."
Mr. Selig angrily said that all of the clubs had been informed. "They weren't informed earlier because we were running computer runs," he said.

HEADLINE: REPORT ON PRICES RENEWS CONCERNS OF MORE INFLATION

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Producer prices rose a surprising six-tenths of a percent in August, the biggest monthly rise in nearly four years. The spurt in prices fanned fears that inflation, which has been below 3 percent for three years, is speeding up.
The surge in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which measures price changes at the nation's farms and factories, made another interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve more likely this fall. It also sent stock and bond prices tumbling. [Page 37.] And economists scurried back to their computers to take another look at their relatively sanguine inflation forecasts for next year. 
 To many business people, investors and analysts, the August rise looked as if it could be the first sign of the rising inflation that the Fed is trying so hard to avert. The August jump follows an increase of five-tenths of a percent in July and leaves the producer price index up at a compound annual rate of 2.9 percent through August, compared with 0.2 percent in the period a year earlier.
"I'm personally surprised that it's taken this long to show," said Brad Roller, president of Sweiger Coil Systems, a Cleveland manufacturer.
Yesterday's report from the Labor Department showed that the sharpest increases in the producer index were for energy and food. But prices for many other goods, from clothing to cars, also rose significantly. Excluding the volatile food and energy categories, prices at the producer level rose four-tenths of a percent.
"The key question is whether such pricing pressures will continue," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch. "But, clearly, inflation risks are rising."
Despite the fact that inflation has been well behaved at the consumer level and virtually flat at the wholesale level for much of the year, the Fed has raised interest rates five times, citing concern that inflationary pressures would build up as the economic expansion rolled on.
But it can take six months to a year for interest rate increases to slow growth enough to restrain price increases. So inflation could rise in the months ahead until the full effects of the Fed's rate increases are felt.
But no one is talking about a return to the old days of high inflation. Many economists are expecting the pickup in consumer prices over the next year to push inflation to somewhere between 3 and 4 percent. The latest survey of the National Association of Business Economists sees a 3.5 percent inflation rate for next year.
The head of President Clinton's National Economic Council, Robert E. Rubin, said, "I think we're on track with the projections we've had," which show inflation of 3.2 percent next year.
"The economy is growing," he added. "It may be slowing down at bit. And there are efforts to get price increases, but for the most part they just aren't taking hold except at very moderate levels."
 
 
Confidence in the Fed
 One reason many analysts are confident that inflation is not taking off is that they believe the Federal Reserve will keep raising short-term interest rates until it is certain that inflation is in check.
After the Fed raised its target for short-term rates by half a point in August, to 4.75 percent, most analysts thought the central bank would wait until after the November elections before acting again, so it would have time to gauge the impact of its earlier moves on the economy and on inflation. Some analysts even thought that rate increase might be the Fed's last for some time.
But some analysts think the unexpectedly large jump in producer prices last month -- especially if it is clear that the increases are passed on to consumers -- will prompt the Fed to act when its policy-making group meets later this month. But most say they still think the Fed will wait until November or December.
Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers. The Producer Price Index would include, for instance, the price a paper company charges for the newsprint that it sells to a newspaper.
Some economists noted that some of the August price rises were clearly one-time events. Food prices rose seven-tenths of a percent, pushed up by a big jump in beef and fish prices. And gasoline prices jumped 6.8 percent after surging 8 percent in July. An upbeat crop outlook and softer crude oil prices suggest that these increases are unlikely to continue.
In addition, a speeding up in producer prices does not always translate into a speeding up of overall inflation, and besides, monthly price data are, by their nature, volatile. The August report on consumer prices is due out on Tuesday.
But few dismissed yesterday's report as a pure anomaly. The big rise in car prices paid by dealers, seven-tenths of a percent, seems to reflect strong sales and tight inventories. And the prices of many semi-finished goods that manufacturers buy, including metal parts, chemicals and fabrics, have been rising briskly for months.
That inflation pressures could be building does, in fact, seem surprising in some ways. Consider some of the standard indicators: hourly compensation for workers has been rising at the slowest rate in 13 years, barely over 3 percent in the last year. Meanwhile, despite a slip this spring, productivity -- the amount each worker produces in an hour -- was up a solid 2.6 percent from a year earlier. And an overhaul of the health care system, which most economists thought would add a few tenths to the inflation rate, does not seem likely to take place this year.
The two strongest reasons to worry that the August rise may be a prelude to inflation creeping higher are these: business and consumer expectations and the Fed's generosity earlier in the recovery.
Most economists now know that inflation is as much a matter of psychology -- and what investors, business people and workers think the monetary authorities will tolerate -- as it is a matter of fundamentals like factory capacity or the unemployment rate.
 
 
Businesses Are Raising Prices
 While there are still plenty of discounting and special incentives, there are signs that more and more businesses believe that they can make higher prices stick. Since May, for example, the National Association of Purchasing Management has been reporting that more than 70 percent of its members are raising prices.
Further, before its recent series of rate increases, the central bank pumped a lot of money into the economy for a very long time. For example, bank reserves, the raw material of the money supply, grew at double-digit annual rates from 1991 to 1993.

HEADLINE: Cuba's Hidden Gain

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Sept. 9

 BODY:
To judge from everything the Cuban Government has said in recent weeks, the agreement it signed with the United States today in New York to stop the flow of undocumented migrants cannot possibly work.
President Fidel Castro is obliged under the accord to try to keep his countrymen from fleeing by sea. But what he received in return -- mainly an assurance that at least 20,000 Cubans wishing to immigrate to the United States will be granted visas each year -- falls so far short of what Cuban officials say is needed to halt the flood as to raise questions about whether they have a vested interest in the deal's failure. 
 Throughout the negotiations, the United States refused to discuss what Cuba insists is the essential source of the migration problem: the embargo that the United States has kept on the island's economy for 32 years and toughened over the last 2.
Yet the talks themselves, and the exodus of migrants that prompted them, brought Havana a greater American hearing than it had received in years for its argument that the embargo is a counterproductive vestige of the cold war.
 
A Secret Promise?
 "Although the blockade continues and although a hostile policy toward us persists, the truth is that as of tonight, in one area, in one zone of the relationship between the two countries, we have achieved normalcy," Cuba's chief negotiator in the talks, Ricardo Alarcon said in an interview on Cuban state television. "It has been demonstrated that Cuba and the United States can reach agreement."
For the first time, the United States also formally committed itself under the agreement to "oppose and impede" the violent hijackings of planes and boats by Cubans fleeing the island. Coming after the Clinton Administration's reversal on Aug. 19 of the longstanding American policy of accepting all Cubans leaving the island, Mr. Alarcon said the measure represented confirmation of a "180-degree change" in a United States policy that encouraged illegal immigration in the past.
Still, so limited was Mr. Castro's apparent pay-off that some diplomats speculated that Cuba might have received a secret promise to discuss the embargo at a later point, perhaps after mid-term elections in the United States in November.
The State Department spokesman, Mike McCurry, said this afternoon in Washington that such talks would be conditioned on the emergence of "a pattern of political and economic reform" in Cuba.
That has long been the Clinton Administration's policy. But what such a pattern would look like has never been set out in any sort of definitive way. It could be that if Mr. Castro showed a new willingness to let Cuba's small and weak dissident movement organize and express itself more freely, the United States would find a reason to assess such moves generously.
 
Talks in Spain
 Some Cuban officials appear to believe that deep changes will have to be made simply to keep the economy from collapse. Diplomats also speculated that talks on Wednesday and Thursday in Spain between the Cuban Foreign Minister and mainstream, anti-Castro Cuban exiles from Miami could pave the way for meetings between Cuban officials and dissidents on the island.
Mr. Castro's consistent antipathy toward both capitalism and the dissidents leaves many experts on Cuba skeptical. But the flight of some 30,000 refugees from the island since last month and the events that prompted the Government to allow it -- the group hijackings of several state-owned boats and a riot against the security forces in Havana on Aug. 5 -- appears to have left more Cubans believing that change will have to come, one way or another.
Many analysts of Cuban politics have argued that Mr. Castro would be loathe to make significant political and economic changes at a time when they could be seen as concessions to an unyielding American policy.
Under the agreement, Cuba said it would do everything it can to stop illegal immigration to the United States but pledged to use primarily "persuasive methods."
Many diplomats and other observers voice skepticism that the Cuban Government will be able to stop the flow of refugees from the island without significant economic changes and perhaps political ones as well.
 
Scrutiny of U.S. Blockade
 Privately, several Cuban officials said they do not foresee great difficulty in reimposing police restrictions on people leaving the country by raft, so long as they are accompanied by a continued refusal by the Clinton Administration to accept the refugees in the United States. But if a heightened flow of refugees survives implementation of the New York accord, it could merely strengthen Mr. Castro's hand.
Even if they fail to convince the outside world that what they call the American "blockade" is driving the refugees, Cuban officials have already managed during the last month to force the United States to reconsider the policy in a way that it had not done since the Cold War ended.

The Economy
 Producer prices surged at a surprisingly sharp pace. The Government said that the Producer Price Index rose six-tenths of a percent in August. Stock and bond markets tumbled as the higher-than-expected rise looked as if it could be the first sign of the rising inflation that the Federal Reserve was trying to avert. [Page 1.]
 
International
 The Clinton Administration may hold off on "fast track" powers it wanted to help negotiate future trade agreements. The Administration had sought to include in a bill approving the new GATT accord a provision renewing the President's authority to submit trade accords to the House and Senate for a single vote in each chamber with no amendments allowed. But the Administration is now considering postponing the provision for this year in an effort to win approval now for the GATT agreement. [37.]
South America is undergoing a social security revolution as millions of workers turn from state pension systems to open privately administered individual retirement accounts. [37.]
 Mexico sent a two-part signal when it seized a powerful financial group and issued a warrant for its chairman: that the old ways of doing business persisted to a degree, but that the Government was willing to prosecute corruption. News Analysis. [37.]

Your Money

HEADLINE: Israeli-P.L.O. Squabble Delays Aid for Arabs

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 9

 BODY:
A much anticipated meeting of donor countries that could have freed $160 million in aid to the Palestinians was canceled today after negotiators for the Palestine Liberation Organization and Israel argued over the status of Jerusalem.
Announcing the cancellation, the World Bank, which had organized the meeting, expressed "deep disappointment at the way things have evolved." The donor countries were ready to disburse some of the $2.4 billion they had pledged to Palestinians for projects in the Gaza Strip and Jericho during the next five years. 
 Israel rejected proposals by the P.L.O. to finance institutions in mainly Arab East Jerusalem, which the Palestinians have vowed to make their capital; Israel has always maintained that Jerusalem will remain united as its capital.
 
Money for Social Projects
 Israeli officials argued that financing institutions in East Jerusalem would circumvent an accord reached last year by the P.L.O. and Israel to negotiate the final status of the city only after self-rule had been introduced over a three-year period.
In a news conference at the World Bank headquarters in Paris, Nabil Shaath, the chief Palestinian negotiator, said the P.L.O. had assigned only $4 million of the anticipated $160 million in aid to East Jerusalem, largely to maintain Palestinian social services.
"I can understand the Israeli position if we were putting army barracks or police stations in Jerusalem," Mr. Shaath said. "but we only wanted to repair schools and hospitals. Our minimum request is that Israel cannot practice a veto on that."
World Bank officials and representatives of many of the donor countries were baffled by the debacle. Israel and the Palestinians have been urging the international community for months to speed up disbursement of the $2.4 billion in pledged funds.
The United States, Japan, the 12-nation European Union and Norway are among the countries that have made pledges.
Mr. Shaath said that so far the P.L.O. had received less than $80 million in aid. It will be several more weeks before another meeting is convened by the World Bank.
 
Rebuke by the World Bank
 "If we are to move forward on the all-important economic agenda, we cannot allow such meetings that are expected to mobilize and coordinate aid to the Palestinians to be derailed by the two main parties bringing their political differences to the table," said the World Bank's vice president for the Middle East and North Africa, Caio Koch-Weser, in an unusually sharp statement.
The delay can only worsen the cash crisis faced by the P.L.O., which is already unable to cover running expenses like police salaries in Gaza and Jericho. The Palestinians have just negotiated an agreement with Israel to take on responsibility for the Palestinian schools and hospitals in the West Bank, which makes its immediate needs even more critical.
During the last three months, Jerusalem has often emerged as a point of contention, with the P.L.O. seeking to underline its influence over Palestinian institutions there and Israel emphasizing its domination of all areas of city management, including the mostly Arab eastern sector.
Mr. Arafat's concern was heightened by Israel's repeated invitations to King Hussein of Jordan to visit Jerusalem and its resistance to Mr. Arafat's efforts to get there before the king did.
It is not clear if or when the two parties will be able to solve their latest dispute and clear the way for a meeting of the donors. But Mr. Shaath insisted that despite the harmful delay, "we couldn't possibly have been seen as compromising our position on Jerusalem as a price for continuing the donor program."

HEADLINE: Beliefs;
An evangelical intellectual finds a kind of heresy in evangelicalism's neglect of the mind.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Evangelical Christians in the United States have suffered their share of scandals. But perhaps the biggest scandal has nothing to do with Elmer Gantry-like antics, sexual or financial. It is what Mark A. Noll, a highly regarded historian of American religion and himself an evangelical Christian, calls "the scandal of the evangelical mind."
At least a fourth of the people in the United States classify themselves in surveys as evangelical Christians. The group is probably the largest, certainly the most religiously active and potentially the most politically powerful religious force in the nation. And yet, Professor Noll says, evangelicals have let their religious tradition sink into intellectual penury, largely bereft of the kind of vigorous intellectual life that would engage their faith with the whole array of modern learning and artistic expression. 
 In his new book, "The Scandal of the Evangelical Mind" (William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company), he writes that the scandal "is that there is not much of an evangelical mind." Evangelicals, he says, sponsor dozens of seminaries, scores of colleges and hundreds of radio and television outlets but have not one research university and nor one journal that deals with modern culture and current events on the level of The Atlantic or The New York Review of Books.
Mr. Noll, the McManis Professor of Christian Thought at the evangelical Wheaton College in Illinois, says in a preface to the book that he wrote as "a wounded lover." He describes himself "as one who is in love with the life of the mind but who has also been drawn to faith in Christ through the love of evangelical Protestants."
In fact, Professor Noll is something of a contradiction to his own thesis; he is part of an evangelical intellectual revival that has been quietly growing for several decades.
Last week, for example, when the American Political Science Association held its annual convention in New York, the discussion from the floor in both a session dealing with religion and politics and a session on religion and the news media was dominated by evangelical scholars. Indeed, much of the best empirical research on the intersection of religion and politics is being done by evangelical political scientists.
Evangelicals are now a strong presence in the field of Constitutional law and First Amendment studies. In important areas of philosophy today, there is "something of a Christian academic boom," Professor Noll notes, with evangelicals setting the agenda. Evangelical historians like himself are at the forefront of American religious history.
Yet exceptions like these only underline the evangelical absence from the front lines of intellectual life and the arts. Professor Noll says it need not be so. And as a historian he knows it was not always the case. Between the American Revolution and the Civil War, evangelicalism took to its heart many of the new nation's most advanced ideas.
It appropriated for its own purposes much of the Enlightenment's view of human nature, scientific knowledge and moral philosophy. It took advantage of separation of church and state. It embraced democracy and the open economy to create a broad synthesis of American and Christian values.
After the Civil War, the world changed while evangelicalism did not. The genius of evangelical culture was "affectional and organizational," Professor Noll writes. It harnessed new technologies to the service of its revivals, but it was intellectually unprepared for the challenges of secular science, Biblical criticism, social Darwinism and the new professional and monied elites who took over social leadership from the clergy.
The stage was set for what Professor Noll bluntly calls the "intellectual disaster of fundamentalism." Fundamentalism hardened evangelicalism's emphasis on the authority of the Bible into a strict theory of literal interpretation, a preoccupation with apocalyptic prophecies and a fierce concern with keeping true believers uncontaminated by others.
Although much of evangelical America is now "post-fundamentalist," he says, it suffers from lingering habits of anti-intellectualism and of using the Bible as a data bank of detailed information rather than for spiritual guidance and rejuvenation. Under fundamentalist midwifery, he writes, "the evangelical community gave birth to virtually no insights into how, under God, the natural world proceeded, how human societies worked, why human nature acted the way it did, or what constituted the blessings and perils of culture."
Professor Noll is saddened by the lack of influence in American life that this failure has meant, but his ultimate objection is theological and religious. He is quick to acknowledge that scholarship is not more important than sanctity, but he still argues that it is sinful, and a kind of heresy, for evangelical Christianity not to honor God's creation with study and contemplation.
The book is filled with appreciation for the strengths of evangelicalism -- its activism, its populism, its practical bent, its sense of spiritual urgency and its tenacity about its distinctive beliefs. But these virtues, Professor Noll writes, must be balanced with less black-and-white thinking, with more attention to the essentials common to Christians through the ages.
For non-evangelicals, the stakes may be different but they are not minor. Evangelical America has awakened from its long political slumber, as the religious right will not let anyone forget. The quality of public life -- society's capacity to engage highly combustible moral issues with any degree of nuance and reflectiveness -- will inevitably depend heavily on the intellectual resources that evangelical Christianity can bring to the discussion.

HEADLINE: Quiet Revolution in Latin Pensions

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
Faced with aging populations and bankrupt state pension systems, South America is undergoing a social security revolution as millions of workers open privately administered individual retirement accounts.
It is a revolution that bears economic and political consequences similar to the mass privatizations undertaken by Margaret Thatcher in Britain in the 1980's. In one generation, waves of workers from Bogota to Buenos Aires are being transformed from victims of state pension bureaucracies to active participants in national capital markets. 
 "We are turning all Bolivians into capitalists," Bolivia's President, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, says of his plan to distribute shares in privatized state companies to retirement accounts held by all adult Bolivians.
To judge by the experience of Chile, where the private pension system has been around longer than anywhere else in South America, workers are retiring with far more money than they did under the state-run system.
 
Private Funds Adopted
 Attracted by Chile's success, Argentina, Colombia and Peru have in the last year adopted private pension funds as equal alternatives to state systems. Bolivia's program is to start next year and Paraguay plans to follow suit soon.
Sensing opportunity, American life insurance companies and banks are moving to set up investment funds for pensioners in much of South America. Among American insurance companies, Metropolitan Life and New York Life have moved into Argentina; Aetna Life and Casualty is in Peru and Chile, and American International Group has started funds in Argentina, Chile and Peru.
American banks establishing South American pension funds include Bankers Trust in Chile, Bank of America in Peru, Bank of Boston in Argentina, and Citibank in Argentina, Chile, Colombia and Peru.
In South American countries that have adopted the private system, workers may switch all their compulsory retirement wage deductions from the state system to an individual retirement account. They then control the investment of that money.
While formulas vary, the countries require a fairly conservative investment mix for the funds investing retirement money, weighting government bonds over common stocks, corporate debt and mortgage-backed securities. Investment overseas is limited to less than 5 percent.
With strict rules limiting commissions and operating fees, fund administrators in much of South America may not see a return on their investments for five years.
The private pension systems have emerged as South American countries abandon the "pay as you go" social security administrations copied in the 1940's from the United States. Using last month's contributions to pay this month's pensions, these systems have been undermined by aging populations. Intended to have as many as 10 workers support one retiree, the programs in Argentina, Brazil and Chile have only two workers supporting each beneficiary.
"The Brazilian pension system is collapsing because it was designed in the 1940's when the average Brazilian died at age 45," said Simon Schwartzman, a Brazilian demographer.
With their treasuries empty, most South American state systems pay pensions far below local poverty lines. By law, Argentina is to pay 82 percent of a worker's final wage as a pension. But in a nation where blue-collar pay averages $800 a month, Argentina's Government pays retirees an average of $180 a month and last year owed retirees $11 billion.
"Pension contributions will no longer be a tax, but a savings, and the only owner will be the worker," Domingo Cavallo, Argentina's Economy Minister, said last July in introducing the alternative private system.
Beyond freeing governments of burdens they are unable to shoulder, private pension funds give enormous stimulus to local capital markets and thus to economic growth.
 
Chile Sets the Example
 Planners look to Chile, which established its private pension funds system in 1981. Its pension funds now control $19 billion, half of the gross national product. "The Chilean system has principles that are applicable to the great majority of Latin American countries," said Julio Bustamante, state superintendent of Chile's private system.
With virtually all Chilean workers now contributing 10 percent of their monthly salaries to the system, private pension funds have almost doubled the nation's savings rate in a decade, to more than 20 percent of gross national product.
By heavily investing in mortgage-backed securities, pension funds have helped to finance a construction boom. Accounting for about one-third of holdings in Santiago's stock market, these institutional investors have fueled corporate growth and added stability to a once flighty exchange.
"This system is positive for the formation of capital markets because all retirement contributions that before went to cover fiscal holes now go to savings," said Raul Buonuomo, an economist for Baring Securities in Argentina. He estimated that by the end of the decade Argentina's private funds would be worth $30 billion, about 10 percent of Argentina's gross national product.
At the same time, Chilean account holders have benefited so handsomely that some may retire with pensions larger than their salaries. From 1981 through the end of August, private pension funds have provided an annual rate of return of 13.9 percent. The funds compete and account holders can switch among them at will.
"I think it is a system that is going to spread across all of Latin America," said Jose Pinera Echenique, a Harvard-trained economist who devised the program 15 years ago. He cautions, however, that a private pension system can work only with low inflation, healthy local capital markets, strict regulations and a well-trained, incorruptible monitor.
Venezuela, for example, would be far from meeting such conditions for a private pension fund system. With government oversight weak, its insurance industry is tottering and half of its banking sector has collapsed.
In Brazil, the enduring myth of an all-providing state has kept discussion of private pension funds out of the debate preceding the Oct. 3 presidential election. Private funds, all supplements to a universal state system, control about $6.4 billion.
And in Argentina, deep memories of stock market swindles and financial embezzlment kept workers wary when private pension funds were announced last May. After spending millions of dollars on promotion, the funds ended their first month with about 50,000 enrollments.
Movement has also been slow in Colombia, where the state-run social security administration has a relatively good reputation. Nevertheless, private fund directors predict that by the end of the decade they will be managing a $3 billion portfolio, held by 1.7 million Colombians.
In Peru, where about half of all insured workers are now with private plans, two small funds are merging with larger funds. In moves that have hurt all funds, some state companies have failed to pay workers' contributions to private funds and the Government has been slow to draw up regulations to allow funds to invest fully in stocks and mortgage securities.
Although almost half of Argentina's 5.5 million insured workers are now enrolled in private funds, fund mergers are expected, since the market is probably not large enough to support 24 funds.
In Bolivia, the big hurdle is President Sanchez's ambitious goal: the American-educated businessman wants to make Bolivia, South America's poorest country, its first with truly universal social security.
Over the next year he intends to privatize Bolivia's six largest state-owned companies, selling 50 percent of shares and management control to private investors, foreign or national. The companies include the national electricity company, oil company, telephone company and airline. Remaining shares will be divided among all Bolivians over 21 years of age -- about 3.2 million people.
Despite start-up challenges, no South American country shows any sign of going back to the past.
"The old social security schemes, many of which were instituted by former populist regimes, now appear terribly outdated and unsustainable -- if not outright bankrupt," a business monthly, U.S./Latin Trade, said last month. "Private pension funds, as Chile has discovered, are among the best options for Latin American governments trying to redress their social ills."

HEADLINE: Sister Parish, Grande Dame of American Interior Decorating, Is Dead at 84

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Sister Parish, the acclaimed and enduring American interior decorator who began her career when she was a young Depression-era mother and later came to redesign rooms of the White House during the Kennedy Administration, died on Thursday at her home in Dark Harbor, Maine. She was 84 and also had a home in New York City.
She had suffered a lengthy illness, said Dorothy B. Gilbert, one of her daughters. 
 Mrs. Parish's six decades of decorating epitomized the rise of women in her own and other professions in 20th-century America. The one-room business she founded in 1933 in Far Hills, N.J., evolved into the noted decorating firm of Parish-Hadley Associates, based in Manhattan, whose designs consistently exuded quality.
The anxious 23-year-old of 1933 -- whose nursery nickname had replaced her seldom-used given name, Dorothy -- went on to become a force in forming and articulating tastes in interior design. Vogue magazine once said she was "the most famous of all living women interior designers, whose ideas have influenced life styles all over America."
 
'Patrician Aplomb'
 John Richardson, an art historian, wrote in 1989, "No one else in America does a room with such patrician aplomb, such life-enhancing charm, such a lack of gimmickry or trendiness."
With a profile that seemed carved from the Maine coastline, her longtime home and design influence, Mrs. Parish was a strong traditionalist. "What seems important to me is permanence, comfort and a look of continuity in the design and decoration of a house," she once observed. "The happiest times of my life are associated with beautiful, familiar things and family."
She and her firm became known for the low-keyed handsomeness of their work and for their well-heeled and relatively conservative clientele. It included President and Mrs. John F. Kennedy; the philanthropists Brooke Astor and Enid Annenberg Haupt; William S. Paley, the chairman of CBS, and members of the Bronfman, Getty, Mellon, Rockefeller, Vanderbilt and Whitney clans.
In 1988, one of Queen Elizabeth II's daughters-in-law, the Duchess of York, asked the firm to design the interior of the ducal couple's new house near Windsor Castle. But the assignment was eventually switched to a British designer, and the British press reported that the Queen thought the Americans' plans were too expensive.
 
Still Working in Her 80's
 Mrs. Parish stayed on as a partner in the firm into her 80's, proving to be a notably durable member of a pioneer cohort of American women who came to prominence as interior decorators between the two world wars.
Mrs. Parish is widely considered to have originated, in the 1960's, the decorating idiom that became known as American country style: she was an early and influential champion of the humble striped cloth called mattress ticking, which had traditionally covered mattresses, using it for slipcovers and on throw pillows.
She saw no conflict between innovation and traditionalism. As she wrote in HG magazine in 1990, "Years ago, my partner, Albert Hadley, and I were delighted when patchwork quilts, four-poster beds, painted floors, knitted throws, rag rugs and hand-woven bedsteads were first listed among the 'innovations' of our firm."
"The list sounds old-fashioned, and no decorator wants to be that," she continued, "but Albert and I understood that innovation is often the ability to reach into the past and bring back what is good, what is beautiful, what is lasting."
 
Father Collected Antiques
 Mrs. Parish's own girlhood was, if not regal, at least baronial. She was born Dorothy May Kinnicutt in July 15, 1910, in Morristown, N.J., the daughter of G. Hermann Kinnicutt and the former May Appleton Tuckerman, who had homes in Manhattan, Maine and Paris, as well as New Jersey.
Mrs. Parish's father was a collector of antiques (as was a cousin, Dorothy Draper, who also became a renowned decorator). Much later she would recall the distaste she felt as a child for the furniture her father collected, "that awful English brown," as she put it.
As a teen-ager, she saw painted French furniture in Paris -- and experienced a revelation.
She went to the Chapin School in Manhattan and to the Foxcroft School in Middleburg, Va., made her debut and was married to Mr. Parish in 1930 in Manhattan with, as The New York Times reported at the time, "a representative gathering of old New York families on hand."
 
Decorating a Farmhouse
 After her marriage, she and her husband had a home on East End Avenue in Manhattan -- which had been done by a decorator -- and a farmhouse in Far Hills, N.J., which Mrs. Parish herself decorated, with gusto.
Her handiwork was admired, friends began coming to her for help with decorating, and she later confidently recalled that "it never occurred to me that I wasn't qualified to give it."
It was four years after the Wall Street crash of 1929 that Mrs. Parish, who had never received a high school diploma, opened her first office. Hard times were coming upon her husband and her father, both blue-blooded stockbrokers. She called her business "Mrs. Henry Parish 2d Interiors" and placed it in Far Hills.
The success that followed was fueled by her taste, talent and strength of will. Mr. Hadley, who joined forces with her in 1962, said in 1991 that "Sis always knows when a room is right and a room is not." She was famed for creating a homey "undecorated look."
 
'Money, Big Money'
 In some ways, Mrs. Parish's rise was made easier by her upper-crust roots, and her earliest work was decorating the houses of friends.
Decorating by Mrs. Parish and her firm also acquired a reputation for being expensive. The New York Times columnist Charlotte Curtis wrote in 1985 that Parish-Hadley work "costs money, big money."
But Mrs. Parish also had an economical streak. In the mid-1960's, she acquired a batch of turn-of-the-century golden oak furniture at a bargain basement price, the story goes, then painted it white and used it in decorating a house that she and her husband had bought in Maine.
As the design editor Elaine Greene wrote later in The New York Times, "when shown in the January 1967 issue of House & Garden, the house dazzled decorators the way Christian Dior's 1947 New Look did the fashion world."
The white furniture and other furnishings in the house -- including soft-hued chintz, needlework, hand-crafted cotton rugs and paintings of dogs -- became staples of the style.
 
Decorating for the Kennedys
 Mrs. Parish met Jacqueline Kennedy socially in the late 1950's and helped her decorate the house in the Georgetown section of Washington where she and her husband, John F. Kennedy, lived while he was a Senator. After Mr. Kennedy was elected President, his wife made Mrs. Parish a consultant in her redecorating of the White House.
Mrs. Kennedy also named her to a committee that was formed to help furnish the White House with authentic pieces from a century and a half earlier.
Speaking of Mrs. Kennedy's plans for redoing the family quarters in the building, Mrs. Parish said early in 1961 that the nation's new First Lady was a person of "simple tastes who wants to create a home."
The walls of the family quarters were done in pastel tones -- the private drawing room was eventually done in yellow and white.
In the years since, there have been persistent reports that Mrs. Kennedy and Mrs. Parish -- who could be blunt and acerbic -- had a falling-out over the White House. As Town & Country magazine recounted it in 1988, the First Lady "fired Sister for telling little Caroline to keep her feet off the upholstery. Sister would later describe the experience in explicit, harsh terms."
But Mrs. Parish could go to enormous lengths to please a client. Sally Bedell Smith wrote in her 1990 book "In All His Glory: The Life of William S. Paley" that in a single bedroom Mrs. Parish and Mr. Hadley did in the 1960's in Mr. Paley's Fifth Avenue duplex, "a painter worked for five months applying 18 coats of paint -- six different shadings just for the base, plus glazing."
Mr. Parish died in 1977, having spent 34 years with the Wall Street securities firm of Loeb Rhoades & Company.
Mrs. Parish is survived by her daughters, Mrs. Gilbert of Hot Springs, Ark., and May Appleton Bartlett of Boston; eight grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall As Inflation Fears Rise

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For months now, anxious traders and investors have been flinching at every apparent sign of inflation and selling stocks and bonds, only to discover sheepishly that little inflation could be found.
But yesterday, they found clear and unambiguous evidence of inflation in the Government's Producer Price Index and rushed to sell. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.65 points, to 3,874.81, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 4.96 points, to 468.18. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 5.57 points, to 763.73.
Bond prices also nose-dived, and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond soared to 7.70 percent from 7.56 percent. [Page 45.]
 
Bears Trample the Bourses
 European markets, girding themselves for the American inflation news, dropped even more than the eight-tenths of one percent decline in the Dow. German stocks fell 1 percent, in after-hours trading; British stocks fell 1.3 percent, and French stocks dropped 1.7 percent.
It was the announcement of a higher-than-expected increase in prices at the producer level that sent international markets skidding and sank the Dow so fast that the New York Stock Exchange invoked its "circuit breaker" rules to curb high-speed computer guided trading. The rules came into play at 2:22 P.M. after the Dow fell 50.13 points.
The August Producer Price Index rose six-tenths of 1 percent, the largest gain in almost four years, while the "core rate," which excludes food and energy costs, rose four-tenths of 1 percent. Along with the Consumer Price Index that will be released Tuesday, the Producer Price Index is one of the critical economic gauges that the Federal Reserve Board uses to guide monetary policy.
The Fed has raised short-term interest rates five times this year, and the stock market's rally in late August was based, in part, on a market consensus that the Fed would not raise rates again soon, perhaps not until after the November election.
Now, some traders speculate the Fed may raise rates as early as its meeting this month and could choose an increase of half a percentage point in its target for the short-term Federal funds rate, which is now 4.75 percent.
Yesterday's inflation numbers also mean that traders on Monday are likely to trim values on stocks and bonds further in expectation of an equally jarring Consumer Price Index on Tuesday.
"Tuesday's C.P.I. numbers will be the focal point," said Todd Clark, senior director of equity trading at Mabon Securities. "If producers are able to pass on higher prices to consumers, then you're really going to shake up the market."
Matthew F. Alexy, government trading strategist for CS First Boston, said: "What traders see in the numbers is that we've been dodging the bullet on the Producer Price Index and Consumer Price Index for quite a while. Now the bullet is here."
 
A Worrisome Bond Market
 The bond market will be a special worry, said David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers, who last Wednesday cut his recommended allocation for stocks in investor portfolios to 45 percent from 50 percent. Because bond yields are so high, "stocks are going to get a lot of meaningful competition from bonds," Mr. Shulman said.
The stock market's rally in late August and sideways trading earlier this month have also confirmed some traders' belief that the August rises in the Dow and the S. &P. 500 were temporary -- a short-covering rally in the parlance of traders in which professional short-sellers were forced to buy stocks to stem their losses.
Short-sellers sell borrowed shares in the expectation that the price will fall and that they can repay the loan with shares purchased later for less than they sold the borrowed stock, pocketing the difference. But if the price rises, all bets are off. The investor must scramble to buy back an unexpectedly expensive share to prevent a large loss.
Utility stocks, which are especially vulnerable to inflation fears, were hard hit yesterday. Consolidated Edison, for example, dropped 1 1/2, to 23 3/4. The staff of the New York Public Service Commission also rejected Con Ed's request for a rate increase. Pacific Gas and Electric dropped 1 1/8, to 22 1/2.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above average with 294.3 million shares changing hands. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 2.44 points, to 258.38, with advancing stocks lagging declining stocks by 584 to 1,635. The American Stock Exchange market value index was off 0.97 point, to 454.54.
Of the 30 component stocks of the Dow industrials, 22 fell, led by J. P. Morgan, the financial-services holding company, which fell 1 3/8, to 63 1/2. Financial services are also vulnerable to rising interest rates.
Of the 500 issues in the S. &P. 500, 396 fell, led by Philip Morris, which droppedl 1 3/8, to 59 7/8.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Broad Front After Producer Price Report

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell two pfennigs against the German mark and tumbled against other currencies yesterday after a sharp rise in producer prices sent bond prices plunging.
"The dollar got slaughtered," said Alfonso Alejo, senior proprietary trader at Sakura Bank Ltd. "People got scared because they see inflation eroding the value of U.S. assets." 
 Treasury bonds plummeted, pulling down the dollar and stocks, after the Government reported that the Producer Price Index rose a larger-than-expected six-tenths of 1 percent in August, the biggest increase in almost four years.
"For many players in the market, this is the worst possible development for the dollar," said Marc Chandler, director of research at Ezra Zask Associates, a Norfolk, Conn., hedge fund with $180 million under management.
Currency traders often watch the performance of the $3 trillion Treasury market to gauge foreign investors' appetite for American stocks and bonds and the dollars needed to buy them.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5368 marks, down from 1.5568 on Thursday. It also fell to 99.18 Japanese yen from 99.60.
Concerns about inflation also drove the dollar to a two-year low before it ended the day at 1.2811 Swiss francs, off from 1.3022 on Thursday.
The rise in producer prices increases the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates a sixth time this year in an effort to control any inflationary pressures, analysts said.
The selloff in the financial markets turned into a rout because the producer prices report fueled lingering concerns that the Fed had not raised interest rates fast enough to control inflation, traders said.
"People think the Fed is behind the curve on raising rates," said Marc Cohen, managing director at C-Wave Capital Management, a currency trading firm in Fort Lee, N.J.
Higher interest rates often buoy the dollar by making dollar-denominated deposits more attractive to overseas investors. This year, though, higher rates have depressed bond prices, driving the dollar down.
The dollar's losses against the yen were limited yesterday because traders were waiting to see if negotiators made progress in talks aimed at opening Japanese markets to American goods. Many traders expect the dollar to rally if the two sides find a way to curb Japan's $60 billion trade surplus with the United States.
The dollar also weakened against the British pound, which rose to $1.5530 from $1.5440.

HEADLINE: Manufacturer Of Rail Cars To Construct A New Plant

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
Dangling a $41.5 million contract for 34 new commuter trains for the Metro-North Railroad, New York State has lured a Canadian rail car manufacturer to build a new assembly plant in upstate New York.
The plant, officials said yesterday, will be located at the Plattsburgh Air Force Base, which is scheduled to close next year and has long been the economic heart of the relatively isolated area near the Canadian border. The closest major city is Montreal, which is 65 miles away. 
 The military base, one of four in New York State that are scheduled to be closed or cut back in the next year, at its recent peak employed 3,000 military personnel and 900 civilians. The base pumped almost $180 million last year into the local economy.
The new plant will employ at least 150 people, and could expand with additional orders to provide as many as 500 jobs.
"It's been a tough year," said Clyde Rabideau, the Mayor of Plattsburgh, a small city of 22,000. "But this is a big boost, not just economically but as a confidence builder for the future."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced yesterday that Bombardier Inc. of Montreal, one of Canada's largest manufacturers, would build the new plant.
Bombardier was the target of heavy attacks by Mr. Cuomo in 1982 when it received a big contract to build rail cars for Metro-North during his first campaign for Governor.
"When I became Governor, New York was importing all of its rail cars and buses," Mr. Cuomo said. "Now, almost 12 years later, we are the transit manufacturing center for North America."
New York, the largest user of commuter rail trains, transit cars and buses in the nation, has used contracts to lure several other manufacturers to locate in the state.
Today, three of the largest subway car makers in North America have factories in New York: ABB Traction in Elmira Heights, Morrison Knudsen in Hornell, and Kawasaki in Yonkers. In addition, Bus Industries of America has a plant near Utica and Transportation Manufacturing Corporation has a facility near Schenectady. Together, these firms employ more than 2,000 people.
 
The Promise
 In its campaign to win transit contracts in New York, Bombardier approached Governor Cuomo last fall with a promise to build a plant in the state.
"All their competitors are already here," said Mary Ann Crotty, the Governor's policy director. "They thought this would give them a leg up."
Bombardier will equip a former warehouse at the Air Force base to assemble the transit cars for Metro-North once the contract is approved by the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Bombardier expects to begin work even before the base is closed and is scheduled to deliver the first cars in March 1996.
"Establishing a plant in Plattsburgh enables us to get closer to the vast rail transit equipment markets of New York State and New York City," said Jean-Yves Leblanc, president of Bombardier's North American transportation equipment group.
For Metro-North, the new plant will also help broaden political support in the State Legislature for its spending program to improve transit operations.
Peter Stangl, chairman of the M.T.A., said, "This announcement demonstrates that the M.T.A.'s capital plan not only benefits millions of commuters each day in the metropolitan New York area, it also helps boost the economy in every region of the state."
In addition to Plattsburgh, the three other military bases in New York that are affected by the Pentagon cutbacks are Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome, the Staten Island Naval Base and the Seneca Army Depot in Romulus. The state has established a task force to respond to the cuts.
Despite praise for the new plant, Mayor Rabideau couldn't help expressing nostalgia for the lost base.
"No matter how much money we bring in," he said, "it will never replace the heritage of the Plattsburgh Air Force Base."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Inflation Fears Push Gold To Highest Level in 2 Months

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
A surprisingly strong rise in the Producer Price Index pushed gold prices to their highest point in more than two months yesterday, as investors shifted money out of financial markets and into precious metals.
The rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in the August Producer Price Index, the biggest monthly advance in four years, caused turmoil in the currency, bond and stock markets, and attracted investor interest to the supposed safe haven of gold. 
 Gold for December delivery finished $1.20 higher at $395.80 an ounce, the contract's highest close at the Commodity Exchange in New York since June 24.
 
Lower Energy Prices
 But there was no strong rush to buy other commodities, and a weak gasoline market led energy prices lower. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose a slight 0.24 point, to 232.94.
The signs of inflation in wholesale prices -- which rose a significant five-tenths of 1 percent in July -- focused attention on the August consumer prices report, which is scheduled to be released on Tuesday.
 "It's going to be a very important week," said James Steel, an analyst at Refco Inc.
The resurgence of inflationary pressures in the last two months increases the chances that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates again this fall to control any inflationary pressures.
Trading in the Comex silver pit was sluggish compared with that for gold. December silver rose 5 cents, to $5.565 an ounce. And October platinum gained $1.20, to $421.50 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Also on the New York Merc, gasoline prices declined, as the summer vacation driving season wound down. October unleaded gasoline fell 0.92 cent, to 47.47 cents a gallon.
Traders said several American refineries would be shutting down in coming months for maintenance, and crude oil supplies are expected to be replenished by ocean-going cargoes.
 
October Oil
 "Gasoline is going to help pull crude oil down," said Jim Ritterbusch of the Sweeney Oil Company in Chicago.
October oil declined 14 cents, to $17.53 a barrel. And October heating oil fell 0.26 cent, to 49.37 cents.
Elsewhere, coffee moved higher in a quiet trading session. December coffee gained 1.45 cents, to $2.17 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
"Nobody wants to sell it because of the weather," one trader said, referring to the lack of rain in drought-hit Brazil.
