HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Brazil Stocks Fly High, But the Word Is Caution

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez 

 BODY:
FOR months, the Brazilian stock market has been serving up some of the sweetest returns in the world.
The Bovespa stock index at the Sao Paulo exchange has risen an eye-popping 90 percent in dollar terms this year, compared with the 1,325 percent in local currency caused by the country's hyperinflation. In the Lipper Analytical Services' survey of closed-end investment funds, the best performers through August were the Brazilian Equity Fund and the Brazil Fund, each up nearly 60 percent for the year. Now that the monthly inflation rate has dropped from more than 50 percent in June to about 5 percent, Brazil is even more enticing. 
 But money managers treat the country, the largest in Latin America and home to an economy the size of Russia's, like a beautifully wrapped present that on close inspection ticks ominously. Until the presidential elections are locked up in November and the leading candidate's currency stabilization program advances, caution is the byword, they say.
"Brazil is not for beginners," said Eduardo de Faria, the fund manager for the Brazilian Investment Company, in London.
If the country's program to stabilize the currency continues to work, research coverage of the more than 600 stocks on the Sao Paulo exchange will improve markedly and investor interest will probably soar. Institutions, wealthy investors and eventually individual investors of more modest means could profit as Brazil makes a long-anticipated conversion from an emerging market to a developed one.
A recent political imbroglio underscored just why professional investors remain wary. Brazil's economy minister, Rubens Ricupero, said that he had helped distort inflation figures to bolster the campaign of the pro-business presidential candidate, Fernando Henrique Cardoso. Mr. Ricupero, chagrined to discover that his casual remarks had been broadcast through an open microphone, abruptly resigned.
Maria Elena Carrion, head of the Latin American equity team for the Bankers Trust Company in New York, said, "It just shows how something can come out of left field in Brazil." In June, she cut Brazilian exposure in the $200 million Latin American portfolio she manages to 20 percent from 30 percent.
Although lower inflation -- prompted by the July 1 exchange of the old hyperinflated cruzeiros for a new currency, the real -- is key to Brazil's future, the minister's statement and resignation roiled the Brazilian stock market only briefly and have done little to hurt Mr. Cardoso's presidential campaign. Most commentators have dismissed the minister's remarks, noting that inflation figures are compiled by independent agencies.
The market's volatility is another problem. Mr. de Faria, who manages $100 million, said: "How's this for volatile? January to February, up 63.1 percent; February to May, down 44 percent; and May to August, up 106 percent. "
And for investors with long memories, the promise of Brazil is a case of deja vu all over again. John R. Hickling, portfolio manager of the $2.2 billion Fidelity Overseas Fund, has only 1 percent of his assets, or just $22 million, invested in Brazil. "My father grew up in Argentina," Mr. Hickling said. "People in Argentina say Brazil is the country of the future, and it will always be the country of the future."
For speculators and brave spirits, there are few opportunities to invest directly in Brazil. The only Brazilian stock easily acquired is Aracruz Celulose S.A., a paper processing company based in Rio de Janeiro, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange in the form of American depository receipts. The A.D.R.'s, which represent shares of the foreign company, have risen 57 percent this year to $13.875 yesterday, up 75 cents.
A few diversified Brazilian funds are easily accessible. The Brazilian Equity Fund, based in New York, returned 58.7 percent in the first eight months of the year, making it the leading closed-end fund, according to Lipper. The Brazil Fund, also based in New York, came in a close second, at 58.2 percent. Shares of both are traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
Although handsome, these companies' returns did not beat out the gain in the Bovespa stock index. So why don't money managers set up an 83-stock index fund that mirrors the Bovespa? Because more than 40 percent of the index reflects one stock, Telecomunicacoes Brasileiras S.A., or Telebras, the national telephone company. For better or worse, fund managers are paid to set up diversified stock portfolios for the long term.
The obvious choice for Americans are funds that invest throughout Latin America or even in emerging markets around the world. Most money managers follow a simple strategy in Brazil: buy blue-chips or economically sensitive stocks. Managers are buying Petroleo Brasileiro, a large oil company; Banco Itau, a big bank; and Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, a mining and steel company.
Even skeptics say Brazil's economic picture may be clearer in just six months. Mr. Hickling, of the Fidelity fund, said, "If you could approach Brazil like a developed market, you could stock-pick your way through the country."

HEADLINE: Some Investments Tailored for Tuitions

 BODY:
Some investments are specifically tailored for parents saving for college.
The simplest is a United States series EE bond. Backed by the Government, these savings bonds are readily available from most banks and through many employee payroll savings plans at no charge. The interest on series EE bonds issued after 1989 is tax-free if it is used to pay for education and if the family's income is below a certain level. 
 For couples, the income limit for tax-free treatment is $68,250 a year, and for single parents, $45,500. Partial tax deductions are available until couples reach $98,250 in annual income and single parents hit $60,500. The downside? A low rate of return compared with investments with greater risk. The guaranteed minimum return is 4 percent, though the actual rate may be higher. The market rate through Oct. 31 is 4.7 percent.
Parents who want peace of mind that their investment will provide sufficient returns even if college costs spiral upward may be drawn to the College Sure certificate of deposit from the College Savings Bank of Princeton, N.J. Returns on the deposits, which are insured up to $100,000 by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, are intended to keep pace with college costs.
The yield fluctuates with the college inflation rate index published on July 31 each year by the College Board. A public college generally costs 40 percent of the College Board figure, while Ivy League schools cost 143 percent of that amount. On July 31, the index rose 5.4 percent, and the average yield on the bank's certificate was 4 to 4.5 percent. The minimum initial purchase is $1,000 and additions must be at least $250.
College Sure deposits maturing in up to 25 years are available, with a stiff penalty for early withdrawal. Interest, of course, is fully taxable.
 Parents who intend to send their children to state schools may be interested in prepayment plans. Begun by Michigan in 1988, these plans allow parents to pay for tuition in today's dollars and have been approved by legislatures in Alabama, Alaska, Florida, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Missouri, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, West Virginia and Wyoming. Each plan has a different structure and administration, and some have been suspended because of financial problems.
Florida's prepayment program is the one that other state plans are measured against. It has the most participants, at 250,000, and the most assets under management, at $680 million. More important, it has great flexibility, covering both community colleges and four-year institutions in the state. Payments can be made in a lump sum or installments. Best of all, contracts are backed by the state, and the interest accrued is not taxable.
Finally, parents may be able to use a college savings plan established by an employer. R. J. Reynolds, Citicorp and other big corporations offer such programs. Some even provide matching money.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Performance Is Defying Pat Explanations

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
It is difficult to find a theme that explains the behavior this year of the various stock fund categories. While rising interest rates and a weakening dollar account for some of the movements, they certainly do not explain all of them.
Technology funds, which focus mainly on stocks in small United States companies, have performed well. But aggressive growth funds, which also own small company stocks, have fared poorly. 
 Gold, traditionally considered an inflation hedge, has not been profitable this year. But utility and income funds, which are sensitive to changes in interest rates, have predictably underperformed.
Investing in overseas markets has helped investors' returns, mostly because the decline of the dollar has made investments abroad more valuable.
Despite the market volatility, most investors have neither made nor lost money this year. The United States diversified stock fund average was up four-tenths of a percent through Sept. 3, and including international and sector funds, the average was up 1.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Samuel Ervin Hill, Conservationist, 81

 BODY:
Samuel Ervin Hill, a conservationist and retired labor arbitrator, died on Sunday at his home in Redding, Conn. He was 81.
The cause was cancer, his son William said. 
 Dr. Hill, who had a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard University, was an economic planner in Federal agencies from 1941 to 1953 and a research associate in industrial relations at Princeton University in the later 1950's and early 1960's. Afterward, he was a self-employed labor arbitrator and owned an old, working farm in Redding.
In 1964, he became the first chairman of the Redding Conservation Commission, and conservation took up much of his time in his later years. He served on that panel most of the time until his death.
He did much to persuade Connecticut legislators to adopt regulations on the use of inland wetlands and was one of the regulations' drafters. He was also instrumental in bringing about the purchase by the Town of Redding of more than 1,000 acres, mostly woodlands and other scenic open space, which has kept those lands undeveloped.
Dr. Hill was born in New Rochelle, N.Y., and received a bachelor's degree in 1935 from Ohio Wesleyan University, then his doctorate in 1940. He was a co-author of "Toward Fair Employment" (1964).
His marriage to Edith Foster ended in divorce.
He is survived by his wife of 41 years, the former Betty Anne Bell; a daughter, Susanna Hill of Redding; two sons, William and Robert, both of Redding, four grandchildren and one great-granddaughter.

HEADLINE: Cuba: Keep Talking

 BODY:
The immigration agreement reached yesterday between Washington and Havana is a good beginning. If humanely carried out it should bring immediate benefits, including a cooling down of anti-immigrant politics in Florida, fewer drownings of Cuban rafters at sea and faster reunifications of divided Cuban-American families.
But matters should not rest here. The Administration, having made its point by limiting this round of talks to immigration, should now find the courage to move on to expanded discussions on all the political and economic issues dividing the United States and its largest Caribbean neighbor. 
 Washington has now agreed to admit at least 20,000 Cubans a year "under existing authority," in exchange for Havana's taking "effective measures to prevent unsafe departures of Cuban citizens."
What this means on the American side is that Cubans eligible for admission through family ties to U.S. citizens and residents will be moved ahead of the waiting lists applicable to eligible immigrants from elsewhere. Such discrimination in favor of Cubans is acceptable only if it does not increase waiting times for others. The remaining Cuban slots will be filled by those with special skills, the politically persecuted and others, but not by those now being held at Guantanamo.
On the Cuban side, the agreement means that Havana will discourage unauthorized departures. How this is done is crucial, since the freedom to leave one's own country is an internationally recognized human right. At a minimum, Cuba must not resume jailing those who try to leave.
Cuba has already said that it wants to expand discussions with the U.S. to other issues. Obviously, Havana wants relief from the U.S. economic embargo. But it has also given tantalizing hints, including discussions with opposition activists this week in Madrid, that it is willing to talk about a political transition toward multi-party politics as well.
The Clinton Administration should seize the chance to explore these issues, even though that would infuriate the hard-line Miami emigres with whom the Administration has rashly allied itself. If Mr. Clinton can now break free of this sterile embrace, he will find bipartisan support among enlightened members of Congress. As well, he could find encouragement from a newly published report that during the Ford Administration Henry Kissinger sought, unsuccessfully, to move toward full diplomatic normalization with Cuba.
The U.S. has a clear interest in less tense, more pragmatic relations with Cuba. It also has an interest in promoting a nonviolent transition to democracy and greater respect for human rights. Those interests argue for building on this week's agreement with increased dialogue and new incentives for greater openness by the Castro regime.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Mortgage Study Found Race Discrimination, Not Redlining

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Boston Federal Reserve Bank study on discrimination in mortgage lending is misrepresented in "Redlining Under Attack" (front page, Aug. 30). The study found discrimination in mortgage lending based on race, not on geography (redlining), as you assert. Indeed, in a follow-up effort using the study's data we found no redlining in Boston.
You imply that our findings are questionable because the study did not include all the relevant variables in the decision to grant a mortgage, was overinfluenced by two minority-owned institutions and was invalidated by the published analysis of David Horne of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. In our view, all three observations are incorrect. 
 The Boston Fed collected and tested for all the variables that loan officers, underwriters and economists working for other regulators (including the F.D.I.C.) believed were important to the lending decision. Contrary to your assertion, we included variables measuring the applicant's ability to pay for closing costs: liquid assets and net wealth. We found these variables to have no effect on the findings of discrimination.
We eliminated the six major lenders to minorities, including minority-owned banks, from the analysis and still found racial bias.
The analysis by Mr. Horne did not, and could not, invalidate our results. It consisted solely of an examination of 95 of the 3,000 files in the Boston Fed study. Such analysis does not permit any meaningful conclusions to be drawn about the statistical results of our study.
Our study's results have been replicated by the Office of the Controller of the Currency and the Federal National Mortgage Association, and we are confident they are accurate.
It is important to separate the Boston Fed's findings from public policy prescriptions that appear to emanate from it. We try to help private-sector lending institutions address this issue within their own systems of credit quality control. We believe lending in low- and moderate-income areas can be profitable and safe for private-sector lenders.
 
CATHY E. MINEHAN
President & Chief Exec. Officer
Federal Reserve Bank of Boston
Boston, Sept. 7, 1994

HEADLINE: New Ethics in Mexico;
Move in Bank Scandal Shows Willingness To Attack Corruption, Yet Old Ways Persist

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9

 BODY:
By seizing one of Mexico's most powerful financial groups and issuing an arrest warrant for its fugitive chairman, the Mexican Government this week sent a pair of powerful messages to United States businesses planning to cross the border.
The first concedes that the old system of influence and corruption, which marked Mexican business while the economy was largely closed to outsiders, still exists to some degree despite far-reaching economic modernization under President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. 
 The second signals that the Mexican Government is willing to prosecute such illegal activities, even at the cost of losing business as well as prestige.
The scandal, caused by the collapse of what authorities say was an elaborate insider loan scheme at the Cremi-Union financial group headed by Carlos Cabal Peniche, 37, could end up touching all companies, domestic and foreign, that operate in Mexico. But its greatest impact may be felt by the dozens of United States banks, brokerage houses and other financial institutions that have applied to enter the Mexican market.
In the eyes of some businessmen, Mexico's most serious bank crisis in a decade could turn out to be an unexpected bonus for American financiers. With the years of experience they bring, American banks could be seen as far more secure operations than many Mexican institutions, especially smaller ones like Cremi-Union that are less well run.
Although Mexican Federal insurance guarantees that no depositors will lose money, the recent scandal may make people more willing to trust a big name like Chase Manhattan or J. P. Morgan, both of which are seeking to operate in Mexico, than one of the Mexican banks that have been privately operated since being privatized three or four years ago.
More than 100 foreign banks and financial institutions have applied to enter Mexico this year, the result of the North American Free Trade Agreement and changes in Mexican law. Until now, Citibank has been the only foreign banking institution allowed to operate openly in Mexico.
As with the savings-and-loan crisis in the United States, the exposure of banking irregularities in Mexico seems likely to change the way financial business is done in this country.
"If they don't strengthen their capacity to supervise, these things are going to happen again," said Isaac Cohen of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean.
Mexican Government officials have already acknowledged that regulations will have to get tougher.
 
How a Scheme Worked
 The Cabal case provides an uncensored insight into the way some business is done in Mexico today. The authorities say Mr. Cabal had his banks arrange loans to shell companies, which then illegally funneled the money -- as much as $700 million in all -- back to him. He used the funds to buy a number of companies, including Del Monte Fresh Produce of Florida.
A registration statement for Mr. Cabal's planned purchase of another Del Monte company, the canned food division in San Francisco, says that he was charged in a civil suit with conspiracy to defraud, involving the operations of a New York company called Eastbrook in the late 1980's. The sellers accepted his offer anyway, although Mr. Cabal's disappearance makes it unlikely that the deal will ever be completed.
A representative of a bank in the United States that has applied to operate in Mexico said he had been approached by Mr. Cabal earlier this year to arrange some kind of financing. After checking Mr. Cabal's background, the banker said he decided to have nothing to do with him.
"In Mexico, it's always easy to tell the good guys from the bad guys," the banker added. "What's hard is to prove it."
Mexican banking's problems can be traced in good part to political issues. With the exception of Citibank, the banks were nationalized in 1981, and during a decade of Government management, they fell far behind in the services and modernization offered by banks in other countries.
President Salinas began to sell them in 1991 as part of his administration's huge-scale program to get the Government out of private business and industry, and raise enough money to reduce Mexico's crippling foreign debt.
It now seems that the attempt to raise money through the privatizations led the Government to sell many properties to the highest bidder, regardless of any doubts about the buyer's character. Mr. Cabal was widely suspected of illicit activities when he purchased his first bank from the Government in 1991. Before then, he grew bananas and exported shrimp.
 
Coping With Embarrassment
 The bank takeover follows other financial embarrassments. A Mexico City leasing company was found last month to have fraudulently received loans from the national development bank. And another company, Sidek, reportedly tried to bribe the Government oil company Pemex with the equivalent of $26,000 in marked bills that was said to be part of a $30 million ransom paid for the release of a kidnapped banker in June.
The president of the Association of Mexican Banks, Roberto Hernandez, said recently that these problems could happen in any country. What was important, he said, was that Mexico's regulatory system caught them. "The system worked, and it worked well," he said. Mr. Hernandez dismissed the idea that foreign investors would shun Mexico because of what had happened.
Yet, for some American businessmen, the scandals represent far more than aggressive entrepreneurs who were outsmarted by Government regulators. "In ways, Mexico is like a frontier now," an American doing business here said. "Guys like Cabal are trying to make as much money as they can before they get caught."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 19, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article in Business Day on Sept. 10, about the Mexican Government's response to a bank scandal, misstated the year Mexico's banks were nationalized. It was 1982, not 1981.

HEADLINE: The Discipline of Saving for College

BYLINE: By JOSHUA SHAPIRO 

 BODY:
When Kalman A. Chaney, author of "Paying for College," begins to brief parents, he urges them to take a deep breath and quips that he has a supply of smelling salts. A newborn today, he explains, will pay about $360,000 for a degree from an Ivy League college, $180,000 for a private college and $85,000 for a public university.
Once parents get over the shock, Mr. Chaney tells them to accept the uncertainties of interest rates, inflation, taxes and tuition costs and to establish a regular savings plan, no matter how small. To his mind, something saved is better than nothing, and with the power of compounding, the sooner parents start, the better. 
 Stuart Kessler of the accounting firm of Goldstein, Golub, Kessler & Company in New York raises the issue of college planning with clients as soon as they inform him of a pregnancy. "Most parents talk seriously about saving for college," he said, "but they generally lack the money or the discipline."
 Indeed, a look at two families in sharply different financial situations shows that a reasonable strategy to pay for college can be created at various income levels and ages. As with investing of all stripes, saving for college means weighing investment risk against potential return. Then come the amount parents can contribute, the parents' and childrens' age, tax considerations and financial aid prospects.
Bob Grimes, a service manager for Eastman Kodak in Boston, has tackled the middle-class challenge of saving for college head-on. "Most people plan more for a two-week vacation than they do for their children's college education," he said. "They're just not thinking long term."
Mr. Grimes, 48, makes $50,000 a year and his wife, Patricia, 44, earns $6,000 from part-time work. They aim to cover half of their three childrens' college expenses.
Working with a financial planner, he divides savings into five portions and reviews his assets once a month using a Lotus spreadsheet on a personal computer. He keeps $10,000 in a savings account for living costs and emergencies. Top priority goes to his 401(k) retirement account, which gets 10 percent of his pretax income.
For his 18-year-old daughter, Susan, who is enrolling at Assumption College in Worcester, Mass., he has about $36,000 in certificates of deposit paying 5 percent a year to cover her college bills. Given that all of the money will be needed within four years, he does not want to take any investment risk. He began saving years ago for her education and expects to pay half of her $18,000 yearly bill for tuition, room and board. Susan will cover the other half with financial aid and loans, owing an estimated $36,000 when she graudates.
Mr. Grimes has amassed company stock worth about $30,000 for Robert, who is 15, by putting $10 a week in Kodak's employee stock purchase plan through automtic payroll deductions. Because the risk is great in having so much money in one stock, Mr. Grimes is slowly moving this money into a balanced mutual fund.
For Julie, his 9-year-old daughter, he began investing about $2,000 a year in several aggressive growth mutual funds from Putnam about three years ago. Given that college is several years off, he is taking greater risk in hopes of greater return.
For people who hope to qualify for some financial aid, keeping college funds in the parents' names generally makes the most sense, Mr. Chaney says. Even though taxes may be higher, student aid formulas generally require parents to contribute only 5.6 percent of their assets annually to their child's education, while students are expected to contribute 35 percent of their assets, even if held in trust. If the money is all in the child's name, financial aid may evaporate.
 To gauge whether a child will qualify for college aid, parents can consult high school counselors, aid experts, software and books. Even families with high incomes may qualify for some aid, albeit probably loans.
Parents far outside the boundaries for financial aid may want to shift money into their children's names for tax reasons. A child under 14 will be taxed at his own low rate on unearned income of up to $1,200 a year. Larger amounts are taxed at the parents' rate. Once the child is 14, all his income will be taxed at his own rate.
Giving money to children, of course, raises issues of control. A savings account in the child's name, often called a Uniform Gifts to Minors Account, can be handled by an adult guardian only until the owner turns 18 or 21 (varying by state).
People with a high net worth often prefer to use a trust, which allows them to dictate terms of distribution and shield the funds from any of their own debts. Income in the trust, however, may be taxed at a high rate.
 Formal trusts have been created by Ralph Earle, 37, and his wife, Jane Mendillo, 35, who have combined income of well over $200,000. He is a management consultant for Arthur D. Little and she manages part of Harvard University's endowment.
"Kids complicate our financial picture, and funding college is an incredible expense," Mr. Earle said, "but both of us have benefited from higher education, so we made saving for college the highest priority after paying the bills." They are setting aside $10,000 a year each for Elizabeth, 2, and Thomas, 3 months, with the objective of financing their children's education within about eight years.
 Ms. Mendillo directs their investments into mutual funds and looks closely at fund expenses. She likes Vanguard for its low management costs and Scudder for its low cost and international equity fund choices.
While her children are young, she will concentrate on high-growth equity funds. As they reach junior high school, she plans to shift into high-quality bond funds, aiming for growth of 9 to 10 percent a year.
For new grandparents, who find a layette ho-hum, Mr. Kessler suggests a trust. Any person can give someone $10,000 a year without incurring gift taxes. If grandparents contribute $20,000 a year, Mr. Kessler figures, college could be covered in the child's first three years of life.

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE CIVILIZATION OF EUROPE IN THE RENAISSANCE, by John Hale. (Atheneum, $35.) On the canvas of a whole continent, a distinguished historian portrays the expanding, reforming, self-consciously new Europe that led to where we live now.
 
DAISY BATES IN THE DESERT, by Julia Blackburn. (Pantheon, $22.) A bold biography whose author risks identifying with the consciousness of her subject, an adventurer, a self-taught anthropologist and a liar who invented her past anew at every turning of her life.
 
DR. JOHNSON & MR. SAVAGE, by Richard Holmes. (Pantheon, $23.) Mr. Holmes re-creates Johnson's pre-Boswellian existence as a sort of belated adolescent, an impoverished bohemian wandering the streets of London with his friend, the barely tolerable Savage, whose biography became Johnson's first great work in prose.
 
IN THE TENNESSEE COUNTRY, by Peter Taylor. (Knopf, $21.) In mellow, elegant prose, this fine novel follows the quest of an academic hustler and failed artist to pin down a cousin who escaped from history a generation after the Civil War.
 
THE LAUREL AND THE IVY: The Story of Charles Stewart Parnell and Irish Nationalism, by Robert Kee. (Hamish Hamilton/Viking, $29.95.) An intelligent, shrewd examination of Ireland's pre-eminent nationalist of the 1880's and of the absurd domestic drama that brought him down.
 
MR. VERTIGO, by Paul Auster. (Viking, $21.95.) A badly abused 9-year-old boy is taught to fly by a mysterious Master Yehudi in this fanciful novel of an education for death or for art, controlled by the metaphorical meanings of flight.
 
MY OWN COUNTRY: A Doctor's Story of a Town and Its People in the Age of AIDS, by Abraham Verghese. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) An eloquent personal memoir of a foreign-born doctor's experience in Tennessee, where he arrived just in time to encounter and treat men returning home with the AIDS they caught in the big city.
 
THE REPUBLIC OF WHORES: A Fragment From the Time of the Cults, by Josef Skvorecky. (Ecco, $21.) Published in Czech in 1971, this keen comic novel concerns a Warsaw Pact tank commander and his men, who hate their allies far more than their prospective American enemies.
 
SEX AND SUITS, by Anne Hollander. (Knopf, $25.) An art historian endorses fashion's claim to be an art, concentrating on the development of the tailored suit as an aspect of modernism.
 
THE STORIES OF STEPHEN DIXON, by Stephen Dixon. (Holt, $25.) Selected from 30 years of Mr. Dixon's work, these stories play unsettling variations on several grand themes: relations between the sexes, the plight of the individual in a hostile society, the instability of truth.
 
A STRANGER IN THIS WORLD, by Kevin Canty. (Doubleday, $20.) A debut collection of sharp, smart short stories about people caught at the intersection between what they know they should do and what they can't help doing.
