The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 11, 1994

SECTION: Section 6; Page 66; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 8958 words

HEADLINE: A Hoplophobe Among the Gunnies

BYLINE: By Philip Weiss; Philip Weiss is a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
Gun lovers call the military-style semiautomatic weapons that will be banned by the crime bill "ugly guns." That's because they lack the wood stocks and clean lines of such pretty guns as the Benelli semiautomatic shotgun with walnut stock that President Clinton used to get a duck last December. Ugly guns are usually made from polymers. They bristle with high-tech accessories -- mushroom-shaped pistol grips, ribbed shrouds on the barrel that keep your hand from getting burned. The surfaces are as dull as office furniture. "Plain Jane" is how one gun collector describes the look.
Joe Harriton is a member of the National Rifle Association and has a bunch of ugly guns at his firing range in the Poconos. Several weeks ago, he took me into the back of the range's gun shop to see a few. There was a Russian-designed AK-47 made in Yugoslavia. An Israeli Uzi with a folding stock. An AR-15, Colt's civilian version of the M-16. Another AR-15, this one in green and olive camouflage. And an Austrian Steyr AUG, a lightweight matte-green thing, bluntly streamlined, almost like a cartoon gun. All are among the so-called assault weapons covered by the crime bill, which made it through the Senate on Aug. 25 and is set to become law early this week. Senator Dianne Feinstein had singled out the AUG, for instance, as the "favorite of drive-by shooters because of its light weight and firepower." 
 "The idea of these being used in crimes is so fallacious," Harriton said. "If we ban things because they're ugly, half the people in the country would be thrown out."
While we were looking at the ugly guns, hefting them, trying to conceal them, talking about the ballistics, considering the idea of knocking off a 7-Eleven with one (which Harriton said would be nuts), an employee came in from the range with another ugly gun, a Chinese-made SKS. A cartridge had gotten jammed in it. Harriton swung the gun up on his workbench and used a screwdriver to free the cartridge.
It was time to shoot. Harriton, a chunky and gregarious 53-year-old, grabbed a couple of guns and we walked out through the shop. Political literature lay out on the shelves: N.R.A. membership forms, books about women and guns. One leaflet promoted an Aug. 14 rally in Washington by the Gun Owners of America against the crime bill. "Question. What do the following have in common? Clinton, Hitler, CBS, Metzenbaum, ABC, Goebbels, Schumer. . . ." the leaflet began. "The attack on the Constitution has nothing to do with crime, or health care, or safety, or the children. It is about an all-out attack on our freedom and rights."
The Paradise Shooting Center is set in a hollow amid the mountains, not far from the big resort hotels in Cresco, Pa. The range itself looks like several football fields chewed to bits by gunfire. On one side of us people were learning how to shoot skeet. On the other side was a long wooden firing range, a row of a dozen shooting cabinets with a handgun or rifle chained at each window. Tourists filled the booths, paying roughly 50 cents a pop. A range officer named Brian Coffey showed a woman how to place her thumbs on a .44 Magnum.
We had a bench to ourselves. "Blaming a gun for its misuse is animism," Harriton went on. "This is the modern witchcraft."
He reached for the Uzi. It was black and had the angular formal properties of a home improvement device -- a caulking gun, a roof rack. "This thing is a relatively low-powered weapon," he said. "You can tell people it's not that powerful, but till you get to show them it isn't, they won't believe you."
He began pushing cartridges into the magazine.
"Can I do that?" I asked.
"Push them straight down," he said, sliding me the magazine and a tray filled with cartridges. "That's it."
The 9-millimeter cartridges slid in against a spring with the finger pressure it takes to knead dough. From the nearby cabinets came the steady clatter of gunfire. When someone hit one of the red-metal targets that hang like Chiclets from rusted iron gates, it made a sharp clang like a boxing bell. I lifted the Uzi.
"Keep the gun braced in your shoulder," Harriton said. "That's where the security comes from, is the three-point brace."
THE NATIONAL RIFLE Association is a grass-roots organization. Its strength comes from people like Joe Harriton and gun clubs like the one at Paradise across the country. You don't have to go to Washington to hear the N.R.A. catechism; you can go to any hive of the people who call themselves shooters. They will tell you that gun control has never been effective, that Hitler's first step was gun control, that government has failed to go after the real problem: the criminal. They will explain that the Second Amendment has nothing to do with hunting, that it guarantees the freedom of a people from tyranny from within.
Especially in rural and western areas, the N.R.A. beliefs tap into deep traditions of self-reliance going back to frontier days. When a boy gets his first .22 rifle from his father, it is a highly ritualized crossing. Guns have a respected place. "My state has probably one of the highest gun ownership rates in the country," says Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont. "We have virtually no gun control law, and we have the second-lowest crime rate in the country."
In nonurban communities like Leahy's, the N.R.A. philosophy is widely shared: even moderate gun controls represent a violation of an essential freedom. Before long, the reasoning goes, the gun grabbers will be coming for your .30-caliber Remington. At times that freedom seems almost bodily. "It's a birthright confirmed for us by the Constitution," says Wayne LaPierre, the N.R.A.'s executive vice president and highest-ranking officer. "It was ours the moment we were born beneath these heavens." By mobilizing its largely male and middle-class faithful -- and by donating millions of dollars to Congressional campaigns -- the N.R.A. for years was able to exercise veto power over gun control legislation. Since 1991, a militant contingent has led the N.R.A., bringing its membership to nearly 3.5 million, an all-time high.
"They are the most effective political contact organization I've seen," says Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico. "Their pressure is intense and unrelenting and they're one-issue voters." Political analysts say that crossing the N.R.A. in a gun-friendly district can cost a candidate anywhere from 3 to 8 percentage points.
The crime bill's tortuous passage through Congress demonstrated the N.R.A.'s continuing influence in Washington. Public opinion polls showed close to 80 percent support for the assault weapons ban, which would outlaw the sale or manufacture of 19 weapons, scores of knockoffs and magazines of over 10-round capacity. Still, a knot of legislators stalled the bill's progress for weeks. "On this issue, the Republicans are under the control of the National Rifle Association," said George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader. Senator Joseph Biden of Delaware said that the politics were simple: "Guns, guns, guns, guns."
But the organization's success in very nearly derailing the crime bill masks an underlying truth: the N.R.A. is losing political power. The popular understanding of the assault weapons ban as a blow against drive-by shootings and "grievance killers" caused the defections of several longtime N.R.A. supporters. "The N.R.A. has strongly endorsed my past two elections," Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona said when the Senate first approved the ban. "I only wish I was running again this time, because they would not endorse me and I would take that as an issue that that organization has lost touch with America."
May's close vote in the House, 216-214, especially enraged the N.R.A. "Those are our guns you're trying to ban, big government," Tanya K. Metaksa, executive director of the N.R.A.'s Institute for Legislative Action and the N.R.A.'s second-most-powerful executive, told the organization's annual convention after the vote. "Those are our rights you trashed. We want them back and we will take them back!" Similar alarms were sounded in direct mail campaigns and on the Internet.
But in its broader appeals, the N.R.A. became surprisingly shy. Its ads against the crime bill did not mention gun ownership; they focused on pork in the bill and bore the logo of an N.R.A. division called Crimestrike. The organization's major public initiatives these days also avoid mentioning guns. They advocate prison-building programs and three-strikes-you're-out legislation. One program, Refuse to Be a Victim, aims to inform women of how to protect themselves against crime, with the "choice" of owning a gun merely No. 42 on a list that includes pepper spray and doorstops.
"They spent what we understand to be a half million dollars against us in our last race and there was little talk about guns," says Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat, through a spokesman. "Even though gun ownership is probably around 70 percent in my district, the N.R.A. knows that 70 or 80 percent of the people think that the Brady bill" -- which requires a five-day waiting period on handgun purchases -- "and the assault weapons ban are reasonable." The N.R.A.'s message was that Synar was wrong on "values" issues. "When Mike Synar voted for flag-burning," said one N.R.A. ad, "so did you."
Arguably, the country is now at a turning point on the gun issue, one that recalls the period in the 60's when two other private matters were transformed into public health issues: smoking and auto safety. Indeed, sponsors of the semiautomatics ban argued that gun injuries are costing the health care system $3 billion a year.
The crime bill, the N.R.A. charges, represents the first step down the slippery slope of a near-abolitionist agenda, and I think they may be right. Thirty years from now, who knows how much the landscape will have changed? Handguns might be banned altogether. Ammunition dealers might be required to number every bullet.
BUT SUCH POLITICAL REVERBERATIONS WERE less interesting to me than the gun issue's personal dimension, the fervor of the absolutist. "The citizens who share our passion reside in every state in the Union," Tanya Metaksa had told Congress during hearings in April, and when I met her a month later at the N.R.A.'s convention in Minneapolis, she used an expression I'd never heard to describe an old friend: "He's a gunny."
How did gunnies cling so ferociously to beliefs that even they understood were completely at odds with majority opinion? How deep were the springs of that passion?
I spent a lot of time at May's annual meeting listening to N.R.A. intellectuals rise on the floor to speak about those beliefs. They called for the impeachment of members of Congress who had voted for the gun ban. They argued that, historically, the difference between a citizen and a subject was the right to bear arms. It wasn't hard to stereotype the N.R.A. activist. They were self-sufficient people, many of them loners or backwoods dandies. They wore moleskin vests and carried knobby canes. Western ties. Waxed mustaches. "No More Gun Control. What Part of No Don't You Understand?" one button said. An N.R.A. board member from Alaska wore a thick beard, black cowboy boots and a three-piece pin-striped suit. He took careful notes on a tiny notebook with a pen made from a brass cartridge casing.
The convention's rhetoric was predictable -- if heated -- until one man approached a floor microphone with a "point of privilege." The "enemy" was at the very gates, he announced: "H.C.I. has organized a group of women in a protest outside! We need all women, and women only, to proceed outside to confront this." H.C.I. -- Sarah Brady's organization, Handgun Control Inc. -- is the N.R.A.'s deadly enemy.
About 20 women left the hall. The enemy was a line of five women in their 60's with placards. They looked dear. They wore lipstick and long skirts and rubber-soled shoes. Their placards spelled out "Grandmothers for Peace Support Gun Control" (H.C.I. had nothing to do with it) and compared the number of children's deaths from guns in 1993 in the United States (5,000) to Japan (60) and Great Britain (33). The 20 women from the hall swirled around the protesters. "Are you a socialist?" one cried. A man who had come outside gave the grandmothers the Nazi salute. One N.R.A. member, Karin Ostrand, a sixtyish teacher with short gray hair, held her face inches away from the face of a protester.
"That number is not correct," she said. "It's a lie, put out by the American Medical Association. What are you defining as a child?" (Nineteen and under, according to the demonstrators.)
For weeks after the convention, I could picture Ostrand leaning forward, her white T-shirt stretching tightly over her buxom, burly frame. "I <heart> Shooting," the T-shirt said.
I couldn't imagine a more alien sentiment. I'd shot only once or twice in my life. In the political landscape of gun control, I was part of the N.R.A.'s enemy: urban-suburban, non-gun-owning. Or, as gunnies on the Internet chat group rec.guns put it (according to David Brooks, a pro-gun-control lurker), I was "hoplophobic," afraid of guns. It seemed pointless to try and explore the mind of the N.R.A. without doing some shooting myself.
AT THE N.R.A. CONVENTION, Tanya Metaksa had told me to talk to a man named Bill Doughty about going shooting. Doughty is president of the N.R.A.'s New York affiliate, the New York Rifle and Pistol Association. I reached him by phone and he said he was amenable, but that we should meet first.
He invited me to a hearing that night in Bedford, in Westchester County, where the town board was considering a hoplophobic measure: an ordinance to bar outright the discharge of firearms. A few suburban families had grown alarmed over a neighbor who had a state permit to kill deer but was shooting too close to their homes. The town administration had pushed the measure with little feeling for the community's tradition of hunting and shooting.
Angry sportsmen crowded the middle-school auditorium. Almost all of them were men. The high point came when a skinny 11-year-old boy named Peter Aquilino went up to the microphone. He had to stand on the toes of his sneakers to reach it. "I want to become a future hunter -- I guess you guys just don't give a damn about that," he said throatily, and walked back to his seat. The place exploded with cheers. Ralph Angeline, a firearms instructor sitting in the front row, spoke next. "I hope I have the privilege of instructing you in the safe use of firearms one day," he said, making a pistol of his left hand and firing off a couple of shots in young Aquilino's direction.
Bill Doughty turned out to be a dark-haired and intense man of 55. He wore a gray suit with an N.R.A. pin on the lapel, a white shirt and a tie clip on his tie. He is vice president of a small computer company.
We met to talk a few days later. He picked me up at the Croton train station in a 1979 Mercedes with a faint mildew smell and drove me to a park on the Hudson River. At the park, he suggested we sit at a picnic table under a shelter so the birds wouldn't get us.
"I deal constantly in emotional issues, and we have to strip away the emotions," he said. "The perception of the general public is that crime is our No. 1 problem. Certainly it's a problem, but . . . unfortunately, in the politicians' haste to do something for the vast uninformed public, the easiest thing to say is 'Let's ban the guns.' We're saying, 'Hey, time out, folks.'
"If you look at this logically, you say to yourself first, what has changed? The basic firearm hasn't changed. Semiautomatic firearms, so-called assault weapons, basically haven't changed technologically in a hundred years. But this certain segment of society has changed. There have always been criminals and highwaymen. All of a sudden they've become more vicious, more random. That to me says, logically, we don't have a problem with the instrument, we have a social problem, something that's been many years -- if not a couple of generations -- in the creating."
I asked Doughty how he felt about the need to have metal detectors in schools. He nodded rapidly.
"I think metal detectors in schools and courtrooms make a lot of sense," he said. "First of all, in schools we don't need youth who are volatile by their nature confronting each other with lethal weapons. So I have no problem with metal detectors in schools. However, when people say there are too many guns around, I say there are not enough guns around. And I really mean that. If I were bent on robbing someone, the person I would like to rob is one who I thought had no abilty to protect himself."
He motioned toward the Metro-North commuter train line.
"A group of youths boarded a train in Yonkers earlier this year and robbed it, Jesse James-style. And the reason they were able to do this successfully is because it's a fair bet people on a commuter train are responsible, honest citizens; they don't break the law. And therefore, if they're coming from New York City" -- where handgun owner ship is particularly restricted -- "chances are they're not carrying any weapon. So there you have a trainful of sitting ducks. This is like putting a sign saying, 'Take me, I'm yours.' If everybody in New York City who was a responsible, qualified citizen were permitted to properly protect themselves, they might not be such easy targets for muggers."
"Like they were saying at the convention," I said, "that a well-armed society is a polite society."
"Exactly."
Doughty drove me back to the station and gave me a pile of what he called "propaganda" to look over. He said he'd see about a shooting date later.
ONE OF THE THINGS DOUGHTY LENT ME WAS A videotape, "The Myth of AK-47 Power," which made an argument for ugly guns. It was produced by the Gun Owners of America, another grass-roots wing of the gun lobby, and featured Neal Knox, a former Texas newspaperman and longtime N.R.A. board member. In the video, Knox wore a tweed shooting jacket and fired several guns to demonstrate their relative destructiveness. The AK-47, in the collective mind, at least, is synonymous with "assault weapon" (William Emanuel Tager used a Chinese-made copy of the AK-47 to kill a stagehand outside the "Today" show studio 11 days ago). But "The Myth of AK-47 Power" shows it to be actually less powerful than the .30-caliber hunting rifles and 12-gauge shotguns that the crime bill won't touch.
Knox fired his arsenal at round watermelons he balanced on a wooden stool. The AK-47 blast merely shattered the watermelon. Skull-sized fragments glopped fluid down over the stool. But the shotgun shell pulverized it. Red smithereens of watermelon bloodied the air. You got to see this over and over as the video replayed it, backward and in slow motion. It was eerily reminiscent of the Zapruder film.
I talked to Knox by phone and he said that shooting "is not an extension of the death wish or the power game or the penile implants -- none of that. It's fun." But the pornographic lushness of the video hinted at a primal gratification behind that fun. No wonder the N.R.A.'s campaign against the semiautomatics ban had steered away from discussing ballistics in favor of slamming midnight basketball.
The tape carried a stipulation warning the media not to use it to illustrate the destructive powers of the AK-47 alone: the comparison to hunting or shotgun loads had to be shown. The gun lobby has indeed become highly sensitive about its public image. In planning its August rally in Washington, the Gun Owners of America warned sportsmen to dress appropriately. "Nothing that can be used by the enemy or the media against us should be brought or displayed at the rally," it warned.
N.R.A. officials blame the "political classes" and the "media elite" for demonizing the organization. Much of the annual convention in Minneapolis was devoted to attacks on the press. "Our media has become the master over the very Constitution that created it," said Wayne LaPierre, the N.R.A. leader. "Forget Stalin's Russia. Forget Hitler's Germany. The mightiest propaganda machine the world has ever known is right here in 1994 America." Even though Tanya Metaksa heads the N.R.A.'s political operations, she was slightly cruder. When one member questioned the effectiveness of the preprinted postcards that members were being urged to mail to TV anchors to protest anti-gun coverage, Metaksa shrugged. "Put it on a piece of toilet paper and send it in," she said. "Do it before the cost of postage goes up again."
Metaksa said she would take me shooting. The N.R.A. sent me three books on the basics of shooting, and then in July I went down to Fairfax, Va., to talk to her.
The N.R.A.'s headquarters is 10 miles outside the Beltway, in a six-story chevron-shaped building clad in metallic blue glass. "We stole that building," Knox said. It was all but in foreclosure, he explained, and was bought in March 1993 for $16.9 million, less than half its construction cost. Still, the N.R.A. is quite defensive about the purchase. The organization has been operating in the red for the last three years while seeking to revitalize its mission (Knox said reserves have dipped from about $90 million to half that sum). Besides, the N.R.A. still hasn't figured out what to do with its old headquarters on Scott Circle in downtown Washington.
In Fairfax, I was shown into a windowless conference room that felt gee-whiz, a little Big Brother by way of Virginia. One wall was filled with a couple of dozen television sets, all going, all mute, all on different channels.
Metaksa appeared in the doorway. She is an intimidating presence. Square-shouldered, large-breasted, handsome. She has a withering stare that she says comes from her late father, a Russian immigrant named Komisarjevsky. Metaksa, 57, seems like a character out of Ayn Rand. Later, in her office, I saw a dogeared copy of "Atlas Shrugged" in a bookcase.
Our conversation rapidly became disputatious, which didn't seem to bother Metaksa all that much.
"There is, I believe, a hidden agenda among what I call gun prohibitionists who want to disarm the American people, and they're selling the greater number of unknowing Americans that guns all by themselves are evil," she said. "What you have here is a firearm, which is protected under the Bill of Rights of this country, which is being attacked because people are being taught -- to go back to my favorite bogyman -- by the media."
I asked her about a comment she'd made to me in Minneapolis, that our Government behaved like the Gestapo when it overpowered the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Tex., last year.
She nodded but didn't look at me, staring over my shoulder at the TV screens. "What you have here is what you have in every situation," she said. "When government wants to press its case, and it owns the media, it can do a very good job of propagandizing." Hitler, Metaksa said, "owned the media. And Dr. Goebbels was very good at it, and he told everybody what they wanted to know. Now we have Holocaust memorials, but in the 1930's there were precious few that were standing up."
"But isn't the American public more enlightened? Don't they say, O.K., our government abused people's rights in Waco, but it's still a benign, benevolent government?"
"I don't think any government is terribly benign or benevolent as long as they have the power to do what they want. Benign by its definition means that you leave things alone. We've had the government jumping into houses because they got a tip from some lowlife and killing people and ruining their lives looking for drugs. Now I'm sorry, it's the wrong address. This is a benign government?"
"When you say the government owns the media, what do you mean?"
"I think the major television networks, the major newspapers, the major magazines are very supportive of this government's agenda."
"How would you characterize that agenda?"
"The agenda of this government is to increase the size of government and to put more and more of our lives under the control of government bureaucrats."
"But doesn't Waco show us that even if citizens arm themselves the government will always win?"
"Have you read history?" she said.
"What's your point?"
"Look at the history of the world." Just because a government, Metaksa said, "may have the bigger and the better and the fancier doesn't mean that when their freedom is threatened, that people don't go to absolutely heroic means -- including dying -- to make the point that they are going to be free. We just celebrated D-Day, but what really helped bring the Nazis to their knees were those freedom fighters all over France and in Holland and every place else in Europe, with their antiquated blunderbusses, picking off German occupying soldiers one at a time."
Metaksa excused herself for a few minutes and came back in with a Diet Dr Pepper and a tall, green glass. I tried arguing that her anti-media talk is a case of killing the messenger, that people really do believe that guns are too available.
"Twenty, 30 years of gun control laws haven't made guns less available," she said. "The only people they've made them less available to is all those people who were at the annual meeting."
"But isn't there a groundswell behind H.C.I.'s influence?"
"They became a business," she said.
"Sarah Brady's commitment on this issue seems pretty genuine."
Metaksa set her glass down. "She's making a lot of money."
"I assume you make a lot of money," I said. "At the annual meeting, you had critics on the floor who tried to make an issue of your computer businesses." (Metaksa is skilled in the use of computer bulletin boards. According to N.R.A. reports, her company received $192,000 from the N.R.A. in 1993 for computer services. And her salary is a reported $130,000 a year.)
"Go look at my house and go look at her house."
"But Sarah Brady's motivation is more complex than that."
"I'm not even going to start to talk about her motivation because I don't know it, so it's not something I should even discuss. I know she makes a lot of money, and more than I do."
Metaksa seemed cross. I moved her off the subject.
"I want to go shooting with you," I said.
She said fine, that she'd have to check with her husband.
IT TOOK A LITTLE PRODDING TO GET A shooting date. In the end, I bought a box of Winchester .223 ammo, the kind the Colt AR-15 fires. It's illegal to mail ammunition if you're not a dealer, so I dumped the shells out in a sneaker and sent the box to Metaksa. She called me the next day. "Got your ammo," she said. "Dinner date Thursday. Friday morning we go to the range."
While waiting for our date, I visited the N.R.A.'s former headquarters, an imposing affair with black granite sheathing and a portion of the Second Amendment ("The right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed") chiseled into the facade. I could see broken-down desks through the glass doors of the deserted building. A Christmas wreath over the door withered in the Washington summer. It looked as though an army had retreated.
The N.R.A.'s recent reinvention as a militant and evangelical movement active on cable television and the Internet is the latest in a long series of transformations. The National Rifle Association of America started up in 1871 as a marksmanship training organization. For the next hundred years it found its mission in promoting the shooting sports. The cover of its monthly publication, The American Rifleman, dealt in sportsmen's themes. One Rifleman promotion, now famous among N.R.A. militants as a symbol of how lightweight the organization had become, showed one hunter goosing another.
The Rifleman figures in political history for another reason. In 1963, Lee Harvey Oswald ordered an Italian bolt-action carbine from an ad in the magazine, then used that gun to kill President Kennedy. Five years later, following the assassinations of Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr., the Federal Government enacted the landmark Gun Control Act of 1968, barring mail-order sales of firearms and requiring gun dealers to keep records of all sales.
The N.R.A. supported that measure. But opposition to gun control sprang up across the country in pugnacious "sportsmen's alliances," which had surprising political power. They mobilized to help J. Glenn Beall Jr. defeat Senator Joseph Tydings of Maryland, an anti-gun incumbent, in 1970 and to stymie a handgun ban that Massachusetts was considering in 1976. The alliances then turned on the N.R.A. itself. In 1977, the N.R.A.'s complacent leadership was thinking about leaving Washington for an outdoorsy headquarters in Colorado that would serve as a sportsmen's paradise. At the annual meeting in Cincinnati that year, militant forces, led by Neal Knox, ambushed the old guard. The meeting went on into the next morning. The insurgents installed a new executive vice president and rededicated the organization to defense of the Second Amendment.
The N.R.A. became a formidable political power. It blocked almost all important gun control legislation and in 1986 succeeded in watering down the Gun Control Act by allowing the resumption of interstate sales of firearms. According to Common Cause, the N.R.A. was the ninth-largest contributor among PAC's in the 1992 Federal election cycle. "It's true grass-roots Jeffersonian democracy," says Pat Raffaniello, an aide to Representative Bill Brewster, an Oklahoma Democrat and N.R.A. board member.
Aggressive tactics are the lobby's hallmark. "Letters I get from doctors on the health care issue tend to be courtly," says Representative Andy Jacobs Jr., an Indiana Democrat. "These fellows, you get the impression that they might shoot you. They're absolutely truculent; there's no compromise."
Unwavering militancy began to isolate the N.R.A. from the political mainstream as early as 1982, when the organization, opposing the ban of armor-piercing bullets known as cop killers, parted company with police groups. The current battle over assault weapons echoes that unpopular battle and underlines a core philosophy within the N.R.A.: mistrust of authority. That mistrust is evident in the belief of many N.R.A. members that the Second Amendment exists for the broadest notion of self-defense -- from one's own government. The wildest cheers at this year's N.R.A. convention came when a tape was played of a young chiropractor and gun owner named Suzanne Gratia testifying before a House subcommittee. The Second Amendment, she said, "is about all of our right to be able to protect ourselves from all of you guys up there."
If that indeed is the thinking behind the amendment, as the N.R.A. might assert, why shouldn't the citizenry have the most modern militia-style weapons?
Supporters of the semi automatics ban cited what they called an overarching constitutional mandate: "to insure domestic tranquility," as Senator John Danforth, the Missouri Republican, put it last year. Especially for the suburban voters who represent the swing vote on gun control issues, militia-style weapons symbolize random killings and drug dealers doing business outside of schools. All three Republican members of Congress from Long Island voted for the semiautomatics ban, in some measure because their constituents were so aroused by the memory of Colin Ferguson stalking through a Long Island Rail Road train emptying 15-round clips. (Those clips will be illegal under the crime bill; Ferguson's Ruger 9-millimeter handgun, purchased in California after the required 15-day waiting period, would not.)
"There is a crisis in the cities," Representative Amo Houghton, a Republican from Corning, N.Y., who describes himself as a "proud" member of the N.R.A., said in support of the ban. "It is clear -- whether it is drugs, whether it is killings, whether it is unemployment -- these weapons have no place there."
The gun ban won other celebrated converts, notably Ronald Reagan (whose vocal support for the Brady bill helped it become law in 1993). Senator Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat, said that the ban was an "agonizing issue" for him politically, but he recognized that the healthy respect for guns he'd learned from his father had "faded" from too many American communities. As the crime bill neared passage, Representative John Dingell, a Michigan Democrat, used a speech on the House floor to resign his post as a board member of the N.R.A. "The only way they can lobby is through threats and intimidation," he said.
The political fault lines opening under the N.R.A.'s feet owe as much to long-term demographic changes as they do to the hot-button nature of the crime issue. Women in public office, for instance, tend to favor gun control. "There are fewer people in rural areas and more in urban-suburban ones," says Peter Fenn, a Democratic political consultant. "The average person does not see a threat to the right to keep and bear arms. You can get it if you need it."
In the half hour I spent at N.R.A. headquarters talking with Wayne LaPierre, a telegenic man with a slight twang, he seemed well aware of the need to reach out. "The N.R.A. didn't understand public relations very well," he said. "On cop-killer bullets, instead of responding aggressively, we let a distorted position get relayed to the American public." LaPierre keeps the conversation off guns, focusing instead on the N.R.A.'s efforts to fix the criminal justice system. "I'm so sick of us being portrayed as the bad guys," he said. "We are not the bad guys. N.R.A. cares."
But when LaPierre addresses his constituency, he preaches nonaccommodation on guns. "The Final War Has Begun" was the message he delivered in The Rifleman after the House passage of the weapons ban.
The setbacks in Congress have rallied the faithful with an us-against-them fervor. The N.R.A. claims that over 1,000 new members are signing on each day, at $35 a year per person. Gunnies have been rushing out to get ugly guns before the ban becomes law. One dealer told me the price of a Colt AR-15 had gone from under $700 to over $2,000 in less than a year.
SHOOTING WITH Tanya Metaksa was anticlimactic. We went to a scrubbed-up range near Manassas -- the Izaak Walton League of America -- and there were so many people around from N.R.A. public affairs that the experience became a media event, far removed from the rude pleasures of firing a gun. There was at least one true moment, when Tanya's husband was shooting a Chinese-made SKS, seized as a war trophy, and Tanya picked up the shell casings from the floor, dropping them in my hand to show me how hot they were.
By comparison, the dinner date the night before, at a Sichuan place near N.R.A. headquarters, was far less guarded.
When Metaksa picked me up at the Holiday Inn in her late-model black Ford Bronco, there were two other people in the car, a young couple named the Manowns. They were both shooters. Jim Manown was thin and clean-cut, with very erect posture. He is the system operator for Gun-Talk, the N.R.A.'s computer bulletin board. His wife, Jennifer Manown, had a slightly fey appearance, fine pale skin made paler by the faint pink boat-neck blouse she wore. Jennifer teaches art. At the restaurant, she passed around slides of her work.
A couple of other people from the N.R.A. showed up, along with Metaksa's husband. George Metaksa is an engineer. With his steel-rimmed glasses, white shirt and ungraying brown hair, he had an abstracted air. He sat on his wife's right but with an empty seat between them.
We talked about shooting. Thirty years ago, the Metaksas' new relationship had flourished with guns as a leitmotif. George had taken Tatiana out on her father's land in Connecticut to introduce her to guns. A few years later, he had pushed to get a baby sitter one night a week for their three daughters so that Tanya could get out of the house and participate with him in a Hartford pistol league.
The Manowns' young marriage was also cemented by shooting. Jim sounded the theme of the evening when he linked shooting with the libertarian spirit.
"Is the political power going to lie with the individual or are we going to cede our own political sovereignty to the government and turn what the founders said on its head?" he said. "That's the struggle. For me, shooting is also a struggle. It's to make myself a little better through hard work and effort, concentration and sacrifice. Because, ultimately, the only thing I have control over in my world is myself. I can't stop crime. I can't feed starving people. I can't take care of the problems in Bosnia. But I can make the world a better place by making myself better. And that internal struggle to make myself a better shooter is symbolic of that overall struggle."
The waiter brought out chicken with cashews, moo shu pork. He put dishes on a lazy susan in the middle of the table.
"That's really true for myself, too," Jennifer said. "Art is ambiguous." But, she said, with shooting, "it's, O.K., focus on the front sight, target should be fuzzy. When I do it right and it feels right and it goes where I want it to go, that's when I can say, Yes!" -- she made a little fist in the air and her face whitened -- "I did something right. The rest of my week is all maybes."
We put food on our plates and talked about the House's vote in May on the semiautomatic weapons ban.
"To me, that was the difference between freedom and no freedom," Tanya said. "We're trying to draw a line in the sand by telling the American people that if you trash the Second Amendment you're going to end up with a line in the sand that's way over here." She used her sea breeze cocktail to indicate a line in the air. "You're going to have no way of defending yourself against a government that truly gets out of hand."
I brought up Waco again and the fact that the American people seem to shrug off signs of brutish government force.
"Let me just explain," Jim said. "The primary reason there's been so little backlash against the Federal Government is the same reason that innocent Germans turned their back on the death camps. . . . People in black shirts who were under the orders of Janet Reno kicking that door in, dumping tons and tons of nerve gas and then watching -- I don't know who set the fire -- as 86 people burned to death. We can point fingers at the A.T.F., but we were the ones who did that ultimately. Our government is us."
The N.R.A. libertarian manifesto doesn't extend across the full spectrum of personal liberties. The organization has embraced conservative family-values appeals and attacked Time Warner for selling gangster rap. It has conducted "ethics" proceedings against former board members who publicly criticized N.R.A. business, and is petitioning the Federal Communications Commission not to renew WNBC's license, claiming the TV station has misrepresented the nature of semiautomatic weapons. Senator Larry Craig, an Idaho Republican, an N.R.A. board member and one of Metaksa's closest allies on the Hill, has an approval rating of 5 (on a scale of 100) from the American Civil Liberties Union.
It was after 10. We drained the tea and I remembered the N.R.A. members who had risen on the convention floor to advocate legalization of drugs. The government, they said, had institutionalized the war on drugs as a means of violating individual rights. But the N.R.A. board had shut the discussion down. Bad publicity.
"How do you feel about legalizing drugs?" I now asked Tanya.
"I'm not going to do this on the record."
She drove me back to my hotel. Her members' current outrage over the semiautomatics ban, she said, reminded her of the 1970's, when she was swept into the movement that rose up against the Gun Control Act.
"But Tanya, do you feel any regret that Oswald was able to get that gun through The American Rifleman? That it's good for that kind of thing to be against the law now?"
She pulled the car under the portico of the Holiday Inn.
"I go back to the same argument," she said. "The person who wants to get a gun to commit a heinous crime, whether it's killing the President of the United States or your next-door neighbor, is going to get that gun or that weapon one way or the other and do the deed. Or at least try to do the deed. So if you make things illegal, he'll figure out another way of doing it."
BACK IN NEW YORK, Bill Doughty finally set up our shooting date. Wednesday morning, at 8, the Putnam County Fish and Game Association outside Carmel, N.Y. I got there first. Wooden signs by the trees pointed to the range. A rabbit ran up the drive and I sat on the big concrete stoop outside the clubhouse. There were ashtrays around me, one-gallon metal beer barrels painted red with the word "butts" painted in white.
I'd brought the 20 cartridges from the ammo box I sent Metaksa, heavy gleaming brass cylinders clenching pointy .223-caliber bullets. Touching them, the surreality of the experience began to work at me. We would be shooting enormously expensive ammunition designed to drop an assailant or kill a guerrilla fighter at 400 yards. But what would we be shooting it at? Paper targets, in a place designed to be incredibly safe. The N.R.A. people keep saying that a range is one of the safest places to be in society. Almost no one is ever hurt. At some level, the experience is inauthentic, play acting, just a couple of degrees removed from the kids who run down my street with toy guns, screaming "You're dead!"
Bill Doughty's old Mercedes came through the trees. He looked slightly Soldier of Fortune. He wore black jeans and boots and a black ammo belt with a fanny pack riding over it. We spent the first hour going over the parts of a gun, using the first rifle he ever owned, a .22-caliber Winchester 75. Then his friend showed up -- Scott Sommavilla, the political director of the Westchester County Firearm Owners Association, a 31-year-old Valhalla contractor and town constable with blond hair and wide-set blue eyes. Sommavilla had more "goodies," as Doughty put it, ugly guns in large hard-plastic cases that looked like they were carrying electric guitars.
The range was a hundred yards or so back through the woods, a wide concrete slab sheltered by a roof supported on 4-by-4's and painted red. The grass on the range was scruffy, tufted. Old wooden target frames listed in their mounts, pipes set into the ground. The atmosphere seemed as masculine as the clubhouse, crude.
Doughty struck a heavy brass bell seven times, warning anyone in the area who might be wandering through. "We've done our duty," he said soberly, and after that we shot for an hour and a half, slowly working our way up from the .22 to semiautomatic rifles that would be covered by the weapons ban.
The guns were heavy. They wearied my arms, and when I looked through the circular or notched sights, everything else dropped away. The solid kick goes out through your shoulder and back and it feels good. You don't know when the gun is going to go off. "It should always come as a surprise," Doughty explained to me. At his urging, I tried to establish a rhythm, squeezing the trigger slowly, applying more pressure as the target came closer, letting off as it drifted away. Hopefully, the gun explodes when the target is nearer alignment. It was almost orgasmic.
Our highest goal was to "tack drive," to put one .22 round in the same hole the previous .22 round had made in the paper target. Sommavilla and Doughty spoke a gun lingo I strained to understand: "ghost rings . . . belly bump . . . throat it . . . you're in the crotch . . . cheek it . . . it looks like a log in the cutter. . . ."
"You want to put this up? There's your peep," Sommavilla said to me, handing me a Ruger 10/22 semiautomatic.
I could rarely tell where my rounds ended up. It didn't seem like sport; it was so internalized, so cut off from the world. The ear protectors I wore only isolated me more. The awareness that I'd acquired the power to take human life confused my hoplophobia. I knew that I could turn the gun on everyone around me but that through some tacit, freshly negotiated social contract, we had all agreed not to do that. Issues of trust, individualism and community started to transform themselves. I understood what Jim Manown meant about personal sovereignty. Still, the gun seemed a crude means of arriving at that feeling. And besides, I wasn't ready to give up the social contract I'd already bought into, and so I actually felt freer when I put the gun down.
Ugly guns seemed to be Sommavilla's favorites. Military specifications, he said, made them durable enough to carry around outside when "varminting." He also shot them in competition. One gun dealer had told me that 30 percent of his ugly gun sales are to hunters or competition shooters. The rest are sold to collectors and shooters who prize the guns' similarity to military weapons. They are the state of the art.
Sommavilla opened a case and gently withdrew a black plastic gun: a Heckler & Koch SR-9 rifle, a .308-caliber ugly gun with a polygonal barrel and a pistol grip. The gun looked oddly toneless and austere. Sommavilla was proud of its price tag, upward of $2,800.
"The stock from this item here is a $400 item," he said. "The trigger, just the trigger, the piece that fits inside the rifle, is $200. So you're not seeing this show up on the street."
"How many guns do you own?" I said.
Sommavilla shrugged. "I think that's a no comment."
"These things accumulate over the years," Doughty said.
We were winding down. My arms were tired; my nerves a little frayed. I asked Doughty, optimally, how many people would be armed on, for instance, the Long island Rail Road train that Colin Ferguson shot up last December.
"I would venture to say that on a given trainful of people, it is likely that some measurable number of people, call it 10 percent, call it 20 percent, would so choose to carry," he said. "Even if there are only one or two of them in a situation like that, they could adequately deal with an individual like him."
But Doughty said that he differed from the N.R.A. in that he might require people to show evidence of some modicum of training. "Then if 90 percent of the people on the train are carrying, I say, 'Hey, I'm safe.' "
Sommavilla stood smoking a cigarette with one foot braced against a 4-by-4. Doughty brought me over to see his handguns. He showed me the pancake holster he uses for concealing a firearm in his pants.
"I believe when one is carrying a handgun concealed, that the best thing to avoid trouble is keep a low profile and not provoke anyone," he said. "No one even knows when I'm carrying a firearm. As a matter of fact, I've been carrying my .38 here all the time." He pulled the fanny pack around to the front and withdrew a handgun. "This is great for walking in the woods. Because if anyone disturbs you, they're in for a little bit of a surprise."
He dipped his hand into his jeans pocket for a velvety pouch, from which he slid a tiny five-shot .22-Magnum revolver. He could only hold it with two fingers. Still, it was just the thing if he was walking through the mall parking lot and sensed trouble.
"This is belly to belly," he said. "It's a last-ditch self-defense. If I want to, I can stick this in my watch pocket and slip my belt over it. My kids call this my nasal decongestant. This is absolutely secret stuff. If I find myself in a threatening position or perceive that the environment is such, I will quietly retrieve it from the case and I know that if I have to, I can deal with the situation."
All the high-minded notions about personal sovereignty had melted down into wired fear. Hoplophobics may be too trusting of their government. But gunnies, once you get past all their talk about birthrights and nerve gas, are plain paranoid.
Everyone was sweating. Doughty's red shirt had two circles of sweat right at diaphragm level. We packed up the guns and went out to our cars. A white-haired guy was coming up to the gate. He could have been walking down the boardwalk at Rockaway; he wore a T-shirt and trunks, sneakers without socks. He sat on a rock and chatted with us before heading over to the range. He and Doughty talked about buying their first guns.
I asked him what he was shooting and he slung a busted fake-leather bag around his shoulder and let me look in. There were two handguns inside, .22's, nestled in old cloths. It reminded me of my own secret adolescent rituals, getting Playboy magazines, one boy introducing another to the pleasures of masturbation. The bond with guns shared some of that same seediness.
A FEW DAYS LATER was when I drove out to the Paradise Shooting Center, Joe Harriton's place in the Poconos. The Pennsylvania affiliate of the N.R.A. had recommended it and Harriton had said something bracing on the phone, that he viewed guns as "entertainment."
Harriton turned out to be Barnumesque. He wore a body mike to address the crowd of vacationers at his split-rail fence, opening up with a stunt to show that the bullets they'd be using were real. He filled a gallon can with water and set it on a stump, then perched an empty can on top. When he turned and shot the water-filled can, the top can rocketed a hundred feet into the air, to applause.
On the range, the concrete floor was covered with spent shell casings. A 5-year-old boy bent to finger a hot one. Guns hung by chains to the cabinets; underneath, hand-lettered signs advertised the legend of each piece. "The .44 Magnum. Clint Eastwood made famous in 'Dirty Harry.' " "The .38 Special. For 125 Years an American Classic."
I shot smoking revolvers and a Chinese-made SKS whose wooden barrel-shroud was hot from the shooter before me. Later, Harriton took me out to a private area of the range and held up an Uzi.
"In Israel, if you're going into an area where you feel you may be in some danger, you go to a police department and say, 'May I have an Uzi, please?' And they don't give you this toy, which is no more effective than this pistol." Harriton touched the Glock at his hip. "They give you one with an extra selector switch for full automatic." (The sale of fully automatic machine guns in the United States was so sharply curtailed in 1934 that, by gunnies' lights, they were banned.)
"Joe, that's no toy," I said.
"No, it's no toy. But by comparison to a machine gun, it's so much less effective."
It was fun shooting with Harriton. With other gunnies, their concerns about projecting the right image tend to mask the power trip. Wayne LaPierre's "N.R.A. cares" agenda and Tanya Metaksa's libertarian patter seem like elaborate screens to divert attention from the core obsession that the people at Paradise wanted to share with me.
Harriton encouraged me to shoot the Uzi as much as I wanted. The gun made a good hollow punch in my shoulder, and when I missed the targets I saw bursts of dirt rise from the berm near the forest 300 feet away. I imagined how hard it would be to hit a person at that distance. I imagined myself running across the shot-up ground while customers let loose.
I filled the Uzi's 23-round magazine again and tried to keep the target fuzzy, as Bill Doughty had taught me. The gratification of shooting is private. Other people looked on but they couldn't share in it, couldn't even see what I was doing. It all happened in my head.
Gunnies traded stories of real encounters with enemies -- of people with blunderbusses subduing Nazis, of someone pulling a gun on you while you were taking a walk in the woods -- to give the fantasy greater verisimilitude. But they wanted to avoid the reality at all costs. A real encounter would be both uglier and richer than the fantasy. It was much easier to live in a never-bloodied belief about their powers and put off engagement. The gunny's dream about subduing endless enemies was like a pornographic illusion: your sexual powers caused scores of people to succumb to you at your will. No wonder the gunnies were so attached to ugly guns. Asking a gunny to go back to a less sophisticated firearm was like asking a devotee of pornography to go from videos back to still photographs: the level of actuality, the degree to which the thing simulates a primal experience, was greatly diminished.
Of course, it isn't a fantasy for everybody. The gunnies' obsession was so intense that they blinded themselves to the consequences of easy availability of guns in a crowded society: the single woman who feels the need to arm herself, the inner-city kids who want to bring a gun to junior high school. But here we were firing away in the safest place in the world.
"I believe that hit it," called out Brian Coffey, Joe's assistant, as I shot. "Took some paint off it."
Harriton slid the ammo tray across the table and I refilled the magazine. The .35 cartridges were like jewels, heavy and symmetrical, perfectly milled of expensive metals. The Astroturf on the shooting bench was so worn its black roots glistened in the sun.
I worked at the .44 Magnum and .45 service revolver, too. Harriton threw a one-gallon spaghetti sauce can out on the ground and said, "Quick, Phil!" I banged it up and cried out with each shot. The dirt jumped, Harriton shouted with laughter and the can danced and spun. It was only later, driving away, that I remembered the books I'd read about shooting. All those rifle and handgun chambers I'd blackened would need cleaning. Oh well, someone else would have to clean up after us.

PUB-DATE: September 11, 1994

SECTION: Section 5; Page 30; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2049 words

HEADLINE: A Seaworthy Retreat

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE; BETSY WADE writes the Practical Traveler column.

 BODY:
DOORS have distinctive sounds. Long ago, I lived with a screen door in a beach house that swung shut with a twang, a thwack and a ting of the dangling hook. It imprinted itself on me as the heart of summer, distilling memories of ice cream, hammocks, breakers over the feet and a child padding into the kitchen in a sandy bathing suit.
Now, a year or so after a trip to the Rosario Resort in the San Juan Islands of Washington State, my memories focus on the door sounds at the Moran Mansion there: authoritative, heavy, tight clicks of solid mahogany doors built in the first decade of the century for maritime people who liked things seaworthy, even on bedrock. Cupboard doors in the mansion were so airtight their closing whoosh sent children's crayon works fluttering from the table to the floor. 
 We went to the Rosario resort, on East Sound, the fjord that nearly divides Orcas Island, for a long weekend last August. Getting there from New York was time-consuming, involving a flight to Seattle, a night in a motel, an hour-and-a-half trip in rented cars to the state ferry terminal in Anacortes, Wash., a ferry ride and then a half-hour drive from the landing on Orcas Island to the resort. The resort was right for our extended family group, exotic enough for the grandparent generation and with a wealth of recreation opportunities.
Management had its bad moments, particularly in getting people settled in and dispatching housekeeping help (the resort has since changed hands) and the guest rooms were ordinary. But the site at a junction of mountains, sea and sky was wonderful, as were its grounds and activities. The Moran Mansion was one of a kind, a historic curiosity that was worth the trip. The 54-room mansion houses the resort's health facilities, including two pools, and the dining rooms, bar, porches, sitting rooms and Music Room. Crave it as you might, though, the literature warns: "Guest rooms not available in the Moran Mansion." The 179 guest rooms are in 11 motel-style structures ranging up the hillside on the estate, some facing the water, some the grounds.
The memory of the Moran Mansion doors closing evenly on their special load-bearing hinges condensed into a Rosario essence for me. But I needed a reality test. I asked two granddaughters what they remembered best about the trip. I did not need to prompt. "The swimming pool with the pole!" they exulted.
Well, that's real. When mealtimes came at Rosario, the girls and their cousins had been in that pool so long that they were the texture of refrigerated prunes, bluish-white ones. The pool, one of four at the resort, was a 13-by-40-foot plunge that the founder, Robert Moran, built into the ground floor of his mansion. It occupies most of a tiled room, with an iron pipe running across the breadth of the pool a foot or two above the water surface. This looked like a tie rod to a New Yorker, the sort of thing that holds old buildings together, but the management says it is an old drain pipe.
When we first walked into this pool room, it was filled with the shrieks of bathing-suited children who were walking along the pole like a tightrope, maintaining their balance with hands along the ceiling. Of course, at some point they jumped into the pool with splashes that kept the lavish tiled floor awash. The grandchildren's eyes widened.
"Can we get in?" they shouted over the din. It looked intimidating, but those kids climbed trees and hung by their knees when they were tiny, and now they were 9 and 10, so I said O.K. In roughly 50 seconds, they were in their suits and into the water. In 51 seconds, Grandma the lifeguard was drenched, gave up and got in, too.
The suite we were assigned, No. 2003, was in a building near the top of the hill, nearest the two tennis courts. It had a back bedroom with small windows facing immediately into the hillside, making it dank and gloomy, and an always-bright living room with kitchen facilities and a scattering of implements, and a Murphy bed and sofa bed. This room overlooked the water through sliding doors to a balcony. In the morning, deer moved across the grass among the buildings and children popped out in nightclothes with apples and leftover bread as cameras buzzed like flies.
At the time of our visit, the rooms showed signs of neglect: The sliding screen door could not be operated, and the light bulbs were more suitable for meditation than reading. Nothing was actually dirty, but the motel-style furniture and carpets were worn, and trying to read in bed required moving around heavy lamps and tables. The bathroom was acceptable if not the latest word. Although the housekeeping staff was pleasant and willing, there seemed to be too few employees.
The former resident manager, Gary Vaughn, said in a recent interview that 100 of the rooms had been renovated over the last winter. Mr. Vaughn concurred that the furnishings that were there last year "left something to be desired," adding that renovations had waited until the summer rush ended. A new director of housekeeping arrived in February, he said, and some help was added and the system reorganized.
As of Aug. 23, the resort was under new ownership, having been sold to the same company that operates L'Auberge de Sedona in Sedona, Ariz. Dirk Oldenburg, the new general manager, said that the Orcas Dining Room would be redone by Thanksgiving, and a smaller, fancier dining room would be added by then, with all the guest rooms scheduled for renovation by next June.
Restaurant service was tops when we were there, and children got prompt attention, with special menus and information for dubious vegetarians about what was in various dishes. I was awed but still passed up the oyster frittata for breakfast, electing a homemade granola with fruit and yogurt. Most children went eagerly for the small order of pancakes.
The Friday night seafood buffet would put a cruise line to shame. Fortunately, we were seated in another room and had to walk to the buffet in the bigger Orcas Dining Room or we might all have succumbed on the spot. Rice and pasta dishes and salads made an ample dinner possible for those in our family who avoid red meat and shellfish.
Like many resorts, Rosario tends to overwhelm you with food. We ordered box lunches for our three-mile walk around Mountain Lake in adjacent Moran State Park. One box, with a sandwich, a quarter of a chicken, fruit, bread, cookies and a drink, would have served two easily.
In addition to hiking, sea kayaking and whale-watching were family members' outdoor choices. We tried the other pools: a large, unshaded outdoor one with a wide concrete apron, which reminded me of a economy-model municipal pool; an indoor whirlpool big enough for dog-paddling, and a small adults-only pool near the cocktail terrace, sheltered from the wind by a glass shield. The pool with the pole and its high windows became my favorite; its old-time design was a perfect vehicle for millionaire fantasies.
Eventually we all attended the popular daily slide lectures on the history of the Morans and the resort, complete with a recital on the organ of nearly 2,000 pipes. Like many set pieces, the lecture is designed with laugh lines: the vanity of Moran, who installed the giant player-piano organ in such a way that his guests could not tell he wasn't playing it himself. But the history is a classic: the rise and demise of a private empire on a peerless island.
The mansion was built as the start of a family compound by Moran, a millionaire shipbuilder who in 1875 had fled New York with the customary few dollars in his pocket. He had no connection with Moran Towing in New York; he built his fortune in the Moran Brothers' shipyard in Seattle.
In 1906, at the age of 49, having been told he had a bad heart and not long to live, he sold the company and retired to Orcas Island, the largest of the San Juans. The mansion is dated 1911 but the family evidently took up residence in 1909. Other buildings were added, including two beguiling Craftsman bungalow-style houses for Moran's brothers, built identical to halt rivalries. Moran called his compound Rosario, after the strait that separates the San Juan islands from the mainland.
As a group of more than 20 people, counting children, our family had use of a meeting area in the mansion, a pair of sitting rooms and a bathroom on the second floor next to the Music Room. These quarters gave me a chance to poke around and see how things worked. Like the door hinges with their lignum vitae cores, the windows -- unframed vertical glass panels 7/8-inch thick that pivot to open -- were created for the house. One room had a desk built into an alcove; the children caucused under it.
Other guests often poked their heads in; normally "our" rooms were among the three open for looking on the upper floors, in addition to the Music Room and organ balcony. The two-story Music Room, described as Moran's pride, was lavished with art glass, the organ and a library. As a main focus of the resort's history, it apparently has not been tinkered with at all, except for the addition of dark shades and a screen for the narrated show of Moran's own photos.
Other parts of the building have been modified to accommodate the restaurants and resort. But after I studied old postcards and a pictorial history, "Rosario Yesterdays" by Christopher M. Peacock, I began to discern the original outlines. Visiting with a niece over a drink in a glassed-in lounge, I suddenly understood we were under the arched ceiling of the old veranda and I should have been holding a straw hat and a croquet mallet instead of a glass of wine.
Even after he "retired" for health reasons, Moran kept on buying and building. Of 7,800 acres he acquired on the island, he eventually gave the state 3,000 as a start for Moran State Park, across from the entrance to the resort, which includes 2,405-foot Mount Constitution.
Moran, who despite the doctors' warnings lived until 1943, sold the estate in 1938, having outlived his wife and siblings and realizing that the children had no interest in it. After still another sale, 15 of the remaining acres were turned into a resort in 1960, with the mansion as the operating core.
The Moran Mansion, mercifully durable, is a periscope into another world. Like other vestiges of the age of robber barons -- Newport cottages or Rockefeller estates -- it would make a good house museum. Maintaining it as part of a resort, however, means visitors are able to touch things at will, lean out the windows, eat and drink there, and swim in Robert Moran's own pool, an experience more vivid than a walk through a museum.
 
 
 
HOW TO RELAX LIKE A MILLIONAIRE
 The Rosario Resort on Orcas Island, Washington State, is open year round. Room rates June 24 to Sept. 24 range from $95 a night for a garden-view room, double or single, to $220 a night for a suite with a fireplace and kitchen. These rates also apply for weekends the rest of the year. Sunday to Thursday nights from Sept. 25 to April 6, 1995, excluding holidays, rates are $63 to $145 a night. Reservations are essential in July and August.
The charge for an added guest in a room is $10 a night, but children under 12 stay free.
Weekend packages include a room for Friday and Saturday night, the Friday night seafood buffet, a Saturday picnic lunch, the Sunday champagne brunch and restaurant tips. Until Oct. 2, the package costs $162.50 a person, double occupancy; from Oct. 21 to June 11, 1995, the package, excluding the picnic lunch, costs $132.50 a person.
Oktoberfest packages are offered Oct. 7 to 9 and Oct. 14 to 16, at $152.50 a person, double occupancy, and for Thanksgiving at $130 a person. Meal tips and entertainment are included. Call (800) 562-8820 or (206) 376-2222.
The drive from Seattle to the Washington State ferry terminal in Anacortes takes an hour and a half to two hours. In warm weather, cars may have to wait several hours to get aboard; reservations are not accepted on this run. The ferry trip to Orcas takes an hour or an hour and a half, depending on the route. For information: Washington State Ferries, Colman Dock, 801 Alaska Way, Seattle, Wash. 98104; (206) 464-6400. In Washington only: (800) 843-3779.

HEADLINE: THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR;
ARCHITECTURE

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
Here is a selective guide to cultural events in New York and beyond in the months ahead. As usual, programs change, and some events are sold out. Unless indicated, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan, and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear at the bottom of page 61.
 
EXHIBITIONS 

September
 
 "HOUSE RULES" Everything you always wanted to know about the impact of race, class and other social factors on residential design -- and more -- will be revealed in 10 collaborative projects by architects and writers. "H'ome-lette," a project by Henry Smith Miller, Laurie Hawkinson and Silvia Kolbowski, cooks up a new kind of dwelling from the leftover spaces in and around the single-family house. To Dec. 11, Wexner Center for the Arts, Columbus, Ohio. (614-292-0330)
 
 "GOOD OFFICES AND BEYOND: THE EVOLUTION OF THE WORK PLACE" A show for your virtual lunch hour: how information technology has transformed office design. With more people "telecommuting" from home, should employers start chipping in on the rent? Tues. to Feb. 19, Cooper-Hewitt Museum.
 
 "ART FOR LEARNING" Art projects for new public school buildings in New York City. The question is, How do these new works measure up to the legendary murals of the W.P.A.? Sept. 23-Nov. 10, sponsored by the Municipal Art Society at the Urban Center.
 
 "SUBURBS OF UTOPIA" A retrospective of work by the New York architect and critic Michael Sorkin, featuring theoretical urban projects. Mr. Sorkin is one of the sharpest critics of our diminished public realm. The show will offer an opportunity to see how well he has retained a critical edge in design. Sept. 24-Nov. 5, Storefront for Art and Architecture, 97 Kenmare St. (431-5795)

 "INVISIBLE CITIES" Stanley Greenberg has been photographing New York's hidden infrastructure for the past two years. The result is a haunting film noir of the corroded, undermaintained machinery -- bridge supports, turbines, water valves -- that still does its best to make the city tick. Sept. 26-Oct. 29, Avery Hall, Columbia University. (854-3510)
 
 "THE MACHINE NEXT DOOR" Loud discos aren't the only noisy neighbors. This show looks at the integration of residential and industrial architecture and its effect on urban life. Sept. 30-Dec. 9, sponsorec by the Municipal Art Society at the Urban Center.
 
October
 
 "FROM SOCIETY TO SOLITUDE: PRIVATE AND PUBLIC SPACE IN THE 17TH CENTURY"
It is sometimes thought that modern architects were the first to redefine traditional relationships between public and private space, but this show will demonstrate that the "inside-outside" question arose long before the advent of the open floor plan and the glass-curtain wall. Oct. 12-Jan. 15, Canadian Center for Architecture, Montreal. (514-939-7000)
 
 "KARL FRIEDRICH SCHINKEL, 1781-1841: THE DRAMA OF ARCHITECTURE" A hundred drawings, presented in an installation designed by the exuberant Chicago architect Stanley Tigerman, highlight the theme of theatricality in the work of the influential German classicist. The drama here is, which architect will steal the show? Oct. 29-Jan. 2, Art Institute of Chicago. (312-443-3600)
 
 "ARCHITECTURE IN A WELL-ORDERED UNIVERSE: LORD BURLINGTON'S VILLA AT CHISWICK AND THOMAS JEFFERSON'S GROUNDS FOR THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA" Finely manicured hands-across-the-sea in this tribute to two masterpieces of Palladian Revival architecture, which brings together shows first seen in London and Charlottesville, Va. Oct. 29-Jan. 8, Heinz Architectural Center at the Carnegie Museum of Art, Pittsburgh. (412-622-3131)

November
 
 THRESHOLDS/O.M.A. AT MOMA: "REM KOOLHAAS AND THE PLACE OF PUBLIC ARCHITECTURE" Designs for a new office complex in Lille, France, will be featured in this much anticipated show of recent work by the Dutch architect. Mr. Koolhaas, born in 1944, is one of the most widely admired architects of his generation. This show could persuade people that the rumors of modern architecture's death are vastly exaggerated. Nov. 3-Jan. 15, Museum of Modern Art. (Traveling to Columbus, Ohio, and Montreal)
 
 "WORLD WAR II AND THE AMERICAN DREAM: HOW WARTIME BUILDING CHANGED A NATION" A bomber nose cone and a jukebox modeled after its design are two of the exhibits in a show devoted to the impact of military production on architecture and design. Nov. 11-Dec. 31, 1995, Building Museum, Washington. (202-272-2448)
 
December
 
 "CONTEMPORARY BRITISH ARCHITECTURE: RECENT PROJECTS FROM THE ROYAL ACADEMY OF ARTS SUMMER EXHIBITION" Sleek high-tech designs should dispel fears that the Prince of Wales has killed off modern architecture in England. Featuring projects by Norman Foster and Richard Rogers, the show also includes neo-Classical designs in the preferred Windsor style. Dec. 10-Feb. 26, National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Ave. (369-4880)
 
 "ITALIAN RENAISSANCE ARCHITECTURE: BRUNELLESCHI TO MICHELANGELO" Frank Lloyd Wright once caustically dismissed it as "the Pantheon on top of the Parthenon," but for millions of others St. Peter's Basilica remains the symbol of the Eternal City. Antonio da Sangallo's massive wooden model (nearly 15 feet tall) of St. Peter's is the centerpiece of a show that stunned visitors over the summer at the Palazzi Grassi in Venice. Also on view will be Michelangelo's model for the dome. Dec. 18-April 16, National Gallery of Art, Washington. (202-737-4215)
 
BUILDINGS
 
September
 
 TIMES SQUARE HOTEL COMPETITION The New York State Urban Development Corporation will choose a design for a new hotel on Eighth Avenue and 42d Street; Peter Eisenman, Frank Gehry, and Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates are three of the architects competing. With only a few new shows scheduled to open on Broadway this fall, the designs by these architecture stars should provide one of the liveliest spectacles in town.

October

 CALIFORNIA CENTER FOR THE ARTS, ESCONDIDO, CALIF. A concert hall, museum and conference center are among the features of a 12-acre complex designed by Charles Moore. Quietly classical pavilions, rising from a serene garden setting -- a sublimely simple legacy from the influential post-modern architect and teacher.
 
 "THE CONCILIATOR" John Hejduk, dean of the architecture school at Cooper Union, has not completed a building in New York since his remodeling of Cooper Union in 1975. This full-scale realization of his design for a tower, from his 1982 suite of drawings, "Berlin Masque," will stand for six months at the intersection of Fifth Ave. and 23d St.
 
 EAST ACADEMIC BUILDING, HOSTOS COMMUNITY COLLEGE, CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE BRONX An international Hispanic arts festival will inaugurate Gwathmey Siegel's multipurpose building, which features galleries, theaters and a gymnasium, arranged around a central atrium.
 
 SWISSAIR NORTH AMERICAN HEADQUARTERS, MELVILLE, L.I. Headed for the Alps? Test your Ray-Bans on this white-on-white office complex -- Richard Meier's first American building in five years.
 
 November
 
 DISNEY FEATURE ANIMATION BUILDING, BURBANK, CALIF. With Disney in turmoil, isn't it time for those indestructable icons Mickey, Snow White, Tinkerbell and the Fairy Godmother to come to the entertainment giant's rescue? Robert A. M. Stern's cartoon collage of a building enshrines executive offices inside a peaked sorcerer's hat.
 
January
 
 SAN FRANCISCO MUSEUM OF MODERN ART
Though the trees were trimmed from the top of Mario Botta's classical-modern design, the building's Cyclopean rotunda still has its eye on the skyline. Across the street from the Yerba Buena arts complex, the new museum will reinforce the civilized status of the city's south-of-Market district.
 
 SEPULVEDA RECREATION CENTER, LOS ANGELES Architects seeking to defuse tensions in poor neighborhoods face a conflict between the need for security and the ideal of access. Hank Koning and Julie Eizenberg's design for an inner-city gymnasium seeks a taut, athletic balance between these needs.
 
February
 
 THE NEUROSCIENCES INSTITUTE, LA JOLLA, CALIF. Like Jonas Salk, founder of the nearby institute that bears his name, the Nobel laureate Gerald Edelman hopes to bridge the gap between the sciences and the humanities in a complex designed by the New York architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. It features a recital hall and gardens for contemplation along with research labs.

 March
 
 TOWN CENTER COMPLEX, SEASIDE, FLA.
While Seaside is known as the godmother of "neo-traditional" town planning -- a resort community famed as a testing ground for old ideas for housing and urban design -- the town's commercial center is graced with a distinguished modern building, by Steven Holl. A second will open this spring, with the completion of a new complex of shops, offices and apartments, designed by the Boston architects Rodolfo Machado and Jorge Silvetti.
