HEADLINE: U.S.-CUBA ACCORD SETS OFF A SURGE OF NEW REFUGEES

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LAS BRISAS, Cuba, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The tide of people fleeing Cuba surged again today as hundreds rushed to beat a 72-hour deadline set by the Government after its agreement with the United States to halt the exodus.
Cuban Coast Guard officers in green fatigues patrolled the shore on foot, but seemed to be making little effort to block the motley procession of homemade vessels into the sea. 
 Though the Government announced that it would begin at noon today to urge people not to leave, many of those on the beach said they were told by the Coast Guard that they would have until midday on Tuesday to shove off.
After that, the authorities said, they would stop the rafts by force if necessary. "Nonetheless," the Government said in a statement published today by the Communist Party newspaper Granma, "persuasion will always be the fundamental method employed."
[In Washington, State Department officials reacted cautiously to Cuba's gradual approach to enforcing the accord, which was signed in New York on Friday after eight days of negotiation.
["The agreement started yesterday," said the chief American negotiator in the talks, Michael Skol, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. "We expect that actions will take place right away. We are going to have to judge this based on actual numbers of people who are picked up."]
Throughout much of the afternoon and evening on Friday, rain, wind and choppy seas appeared to limit both the departure of rafts and their rescue by United States Coast Guard ships waiting at the boundary of international waters.
After 610 Cubans were picked up by the Coast Guard on Thursday, only 177 were rescued on Friday.
But by 9 P.M., however, today's total was 447, and was expected to rise as scores of rafts that had left after the agreement was announced on television and radio news programs here floated beyond the 12-mile limit of Cuban waters.
United States officials emphasized on Friday that would-be immigrants detained at American military bases in Panama and Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, would have to return home to apply for entry into the United States.
Still, it seemed to remain an article of faith along the shores east of Havana that being picked up by the United States Coast Guard and taken to Guantanamo would mean some sort of priority on the list of people seeking to immigrate.
"The people who are going to get in are the ones who get to Guantanamo," said Guillermo Vega, 30 years old, an automobile mechanic who was preparing to leave from this beach town aboard a rickety platform floated by some empty oil drums and festooned with a banner calling it "The Miraculous One."
"The people who stay are going to have to apply to God," he said.
Under the terms of the accord, the Government of President Fidel Castro is obliged to "take effective measures in every way it possibly can to prevent unsafe departures, using mainly persuasive methods."
In the past, the Cuban authorities generally punished people trying to leave the island by raft with jail sentences or stiff fines. But as it did briefly in 1965 and 1980, the Government suddenly lifted the ban last month after the hijackings of several state-owned vessels and a riot against the security forces near the port of Havana on Aug. 5.
In what Granma called an "exhortation" to the citizenry today, the Government called on Cubans who have built or are building rafts to disassemble them, gather up the materials and put them to some other use.
"We do not want to arrest anyone or confiscate belongings or materials," it said.
 
Emphasis on Persuasion
 The statement added that Cuban negotiators had proposed the language in the accord that called for an emphasis on persuasion, and that Government agents would not fire on anyone trying to leave the island unless they were attacked and their safety endangered. In another statement, the Interior Ministry said this evening that it would arrest anyone caught transporting rafts to the coast after 6 A.M. Sunday.
Some diplomats and other observers have been skeptical that Cuban officials will be able to easily reimpose their control over the coastline after the flight of some 30,000 people since last month. As he watched half a dozen large rafts preparing to put to sea this morning, a uniformed Interior Ministry major at Las Brisas seemed somewhat uncertain about that himself.
"Let's see how people behave," the officer, who did not give his name, said of those seeking to leave.
In remarks on Friday, Cuban officials suggested that the agreement was as important as a step toward normalizing Cuba's relations with the United States as it was as a framework for limiting undocumented migration. Mr. Castro and other officials have argued that unless the United States lifts its 32-year-old embargo on the island, desperate Cubans will continue trying to escape the economic crisis that began with the collapse of the Soviet bloc and its preferential trade with Cuba.
 
Cuba Vows Compliance
 Reflecting Cuba's hopes to build on the accord, the Government's statement today described Cuban compliance with the deal as "essential" in order to show the American public "that we are a serious, disciplined and dignified country that knows how to and will comply with its commitments."
The immediate focus of Cuban diplomatic attention appeared to be on the new restrictions that President Clinton imposed on Aug. 20 on Americans wishing to travel to the island and Cuban-Americans who want to send dollars to their relatives here.
In an interview on Friday night on Cuban state television, the Government's chief negotiator in New York, former Foreign Minister Ricardo Alarcon, described the measures as incompatible with the spirit of the immigration agreement. "We hope for and are confident that these measures will be overcome in a more or less short period," he said.
At least some Cubans seem to share their Government's optimism.
"I have to hope that the agreement will make things better," said Roberto Lopez, 66, a resident of the coastal town of Cojimar who supports Mr. Castro but had just watched his stepson and son-in-law push off to sea aboard a raft. "Cuba is practically not Communist anymore, because the Communist bloc disappeared. What fear can the United States have of Cuba?"
 
Pessimism at the Beach
 But along the coast such views appeared to be in short supply.
"I would rather be locked up in Guantanamo than here with Fidel," said Juan Carlos Ordonez, 22, from the interior of Havana Province who was preparing to board a small, homemade raft at Cojimar. "I love this country -- I am Cuban -- but you cannot live here anymore."
Mr. Ordonez said he hoped to join his brother, Reynaldo, who was a shortstop on the Cuban national baseball team until he defected last year during the World University Games in Buffalo. Rey Ordonez was signed by the Mets and now plays for the team's Class AA minor-league team in Binghamton, N.Y.
Even if he were able to get a United States visa, Mr. Ordonez told a reporter, the Cuban Government would prevent him from leaving because he had not completed his obligatory military service. He was also discouraged by the inability of his sister-in-law, Lisa Maria de Ordonez, to get a visa to join her husband.
Waist-deep in the waves, a woman shouted at Mr. Ordonez to get a move on. "Juan Carlos! Let's go! Let's go! They can interview you when you get to Miami."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI PROPOSES TOUGHENING LAWS ON X-RATED SHOPS

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Saying New York City had to do more to protect its quality of life, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed sweeping new zoning regulations yesterday that would restrict sex-oriented video stores, X-rated theaters and topless bars to a few relatively isolated nonresidential neighborhoods.
The Mayor's proposal, which must now go through a lengthy review process, would prohibit such establishments from opening within 500 feet of residences, schools, houses of worship or one another. In effect, the restrictions would push them to the city's fringes, even forcing out almost all of those in Times Square. 
 Existing shops, theaters or bars in the newly restricted areas would, under the proposal, be allowed to remain open for an as-yet-unspecified time to allow owners to recoup their investment. The Mayor also proposed an immediate moratorium on the opening of new sex-oriented businesses anywhere in the city while his proposals are considered.
The plan is subject to approval by the City Council, where similar, though less far-reaching legislation has found wide support. But civil libertarians and owners of adult businesses expressed opposition yesterday, and the plan will likely face challenges.
With his proposal, Mr. Giuliani has tapped a welling anger over the proliferation of adult video stores and topless bars in neighborhoods where they had rarely been before -- from the Upper East Side of Manhattan to Rego Park in Queens. In the last decade, the number of such businesses has risen 35 percent, from 131 in 1984 to 177 as of last December.
Appearing before an adult video store in Queens, where new shops have met vociferous protests for more than a year, Mr. Giuliani said the city needed "reasonable regulations" to halt the spread of "sex shops" in places where New Yorkers and their children live.
The stores "have deteriorated the quality of life in the city," said Mr. Giuliani, who made "quality of life" a mantra of his two campaigns. "They hurt the economy of the city. They cost us jobs. They cost us money."
The United States Supreme Court, as well as lower state courts, have long held that sexually explicit videos, books and dancing are forms of free speech protected under the First Amendment -- provided they do not fall under the strict legal definition of obscenity. The courts, however, have allowed municipalities to restrict adult businesses through zoning regulations as long as officials demonstrate harmful "secondary impacts" from their presence and do not onerously reduce their accessibility.
A number of cities, including Detroit, Boston, St. Louis, Los Angeles and the town of Islip, L.I., have adopted various restrictions in recent years -- either by confining them to "red light" districts or dispersing them to prevent such concentrations.
Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said yesterday that the Mayor's zoning changes could prove too restrictive to pass muster in court. He said Mr. Giuliani's proposal was "a radical departure" from the city's tradition of fostering freedom of expression, even when sexually explicit.
"The Giuliani administration is trying to impose its morality, or the morality of one part of the city, over all of the city," he said.
In the 1970's, when the number of adult businesses had grown from 9 in 1965 to 151 in 1976 before tapering off slightly in the 1980's, similar legislation withered under intense opposition from liberals as well as residents in neighborhoods where the shops would still be allowed.
But while some elected officials have expressed misgivings about restrictions, the new proposal appears likely to pass through the Council. Already, two pieces of legislation to restrict adult businesses have been embraced by officials across the political spectrum, with 48 of the Council's 51 members signing on as sponsors of one of the bills, including the Speaker, Peter F. Vallone.
The city's zoning laws now treat adult businesses like any other business, permitting them to open in any area zoned for commercial or manufacturing uses. Under the Mayor's proposal, the laws would be amended to impose for the first time restrictions on adult stores -- defined by the Department of City Planning as book or video shops, theaters or topless bars that advertise themselves as sexually explicit.
 
Effects of the Plan
 In effect, the changes would put wide swaths of the city's residential neighborhoods off limits. In Manhattan, for example, the businesses would be allowed only in areas along the West Side Highway below 59th Street and in small commercial pockets in midtown and Washington Heights. In Queens, they would be banished to remote, largely industrial areas such as those in Long Island City and along Newtown Creek.
 
Expecting Challenges
 Richard N. Kunis, the owner of Manhattan Video on West 39th Street, which has sold adult videos since 1985, said the proposal amounted to the repression of free speech.
"Limiting access is the beginning of censorship," he said. "Until now New York has always been a censorship-free city."
Mr. Giuliani predicted that his proposed restrictions would withstand political and legal challenges. He said each aspect of his proposal had been enacted in other cities and upheld in court. "There are legal challenges to everything," he said. "That's O.K."
Joseph B. Rose, the director of the Department of City Planning, said the administration would try to impose the moratorium by the end of the year, speeding it through the review process, which begins with the borough presidents and Community Boards, then moves through the Planning Commission and ends in the Council. Final approval of the zoning changes could take a year or more.
In announcing his proposal, Mr. Giuliani also released a 65-page report by the Department of City Planning on the impact adult businesses have on neighborhoods. The Mayor and his aides said the study showed enough negative "secondary impacts" -- as required by the courts -- to warrant the restrictions.
The department's study, which began last year under Mayor David N. Dinkins, focused on sexually oriented stores and bars in six areas -- Chelsea and the Upper West Side in Manhattan, Fordham in the Bronx, Sunset Park in Brooklyn, Sunnyside in Queens and South Beach on Staten Island. Generally, the report deals less with actual effects and more with the perceptions of residents and merchants, who, the report concludes, overwhelmingly felt that the businesses were harmful.
Specifically, the report notes that blocks with adult shops sometimes recorded more criminal complaints than blocks without them. But the report says crime on such blocks could have as much to do with the proximity of, say, a subway station. "It was not possible to isolate the impact of adult uses relative to criminal complaints," the report says.
Andrew S. Lynn, the department's executive director, said court rulings allowed the city to rely on experiences of other cities and findings of other studies, including ones by Ruth W. Messinger, the Borough President of Manhattan, and the Times Square Business Improvement District.
But after reading the report yesterday, Mr. Siegel of the Civil Liberties Union said the city had failed to show the impacts. "It's not persuasive," he said.
 
Plan Is Welcomed
 Others welcomed the Mayor's proposal. Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, said the provision to bar adult businesses from opening within 500 feet of one another would prevent them from clustering into the sort of "red light" district that has made Times Square notorious.
The Mayor chose to announce his proposal in Queens, where the shops have proliferated more rapidly than anywhere else in recent years, reaching into middle-class neighborhoods and provoking fears that their garish "XXX" signs would attract seedy characters, drugs and prostitution.
"These places are opening up in my district faster than McDonald's and Burger King," said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens, the primary sponsor of legislation that would restrict topless bars from residential neighborhoods but not go as far as Mr. Giuliani's proposal.
In a show of support, Mr. Giuliani stood beside Mr. McCaffrey and several other elected officials in front of the Ultimate Choice, a video store on Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst only a stone's throw from the Elks Lodge and shaded rows of neat homes.
Mr. Giuliani said he would work with the Council, which is scheduled to hold a hearing on its legislation tomorrow. Councilman Charles Millard of Manhattan, the Republican who is the sponsor of legislation to restrict video stores, said the restrictions balanced protections of free speech with protections for residents.
"Nobody," Mr. Millard said, "wants their neighborhood to be the next red light district."

HEADLINE: Freewheeling Ways Pay Off for the White House

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration was able to claim a triumph Friday in its talks with Cuba, although its policy-making process on the immigration crisis was undisciplined and untidy even by the Administration's freewheeling bureaucratic standards.
Many Administration officials acknowledge that the last five weeks of policy-making on Cuba have been marked to an unusual degree by ad-libbing, domestic politics and a constantly changing cast of characters. Adding to the confusion, several new voices on foreign policy were involved because the Cuba crisis so heavily involved immigration matters and because so many officials were on vacation. 
 Despite the bureaucratic messiness, the Administration was still able to get exactly what it wanted in its talks in New York with the Cubans: Havana's promise to end the flow of boats and rafts. Administration officials said the reason for their success was that all the potentially contradictory veins of American policies agreed on one point: trying to make the crisis Fidel Castro's.
 
Turning the Tables
 Mr. Castro unleashed the flow of boat people with the aim of throwing President Clinton on the defensive and pressuring him to ease the three-decade-old embargo. But Administration officials boast that they turned the tables on the Cuban leader by their decision to stop admitting boat people and to tighten the embargo.
This dual strategy was driven largely by domestic politics: specifically, to appease Floridians worried about a surge of refugees and to please Cuban-Americans who constantly favor turning up the heat on Mr. Castro. But Administration officials recognized early on that this strategy dovetailed neatly with their goal of pressuring Mr. Castro to clamp down on the flow of refugees.
"We decided we weren't going to play Castro's game," a senior State Department official said. "We took him by surprise when we decided to stop allowing in Cuban refugees."
But that decision also took some members of the Administration by surprise. This is because, in a little-understood chapter of the Cuba crisis, the Administration shunted aside its main Cuba contingency plan and started ad-libbing.
In its first few months in office, the Clinton Administration put together an emergency plan to deal with a flood of Cuban refugees in case a flotilla of rafts began drifting toward Florida. The classified plan, known as Operation Distant Shore, called for distributing thousands of Cuban refugees to forts and other Federal sites around the nation so Florida would not be overwhelmed.
 
Abandoning the Plan
 But at a pivotal White House meeting on Aug. 18, with the wave of Cubans growing, that emergency plan was pushed aside. Instead, Defense Secretary William J. Perry, Attorney General Janet Reno and State Department and White House officials recommended to the President that he end the three-decade-old practice of admitting all Cubans and instead send Cuban boat people to the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station.
That recommendation came just hours after Florida's Governor, Lawton Chiles, declared a state of emergency and warned President Clinton that he would order Florida officials to detain all Cuban boat people. Back at the White House, policy makers were mindful of Mr. Chiles's plight, recognizing that a tidal wave of boat people not only could cripple the Democratic Governor in a tough re-election campaign this fall, but could spoil Mr. Clinton's chances in Florida, the fourth-most populous state, in the 1996 Presidential campaign.
Even though the United States was in a diplomatic showdown with Mr. Castro, an unusually large role fell to Attorney General Reno, who used to be Dade County prosecutor.
"Early on, she wore two hats: her Florida hat -- she was the most knowledgeable person about Florida politics -- and her Department of Justice-overseer of immigration hat," a senior Administration official said.
 
Vacations and Policy
 Because both Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, were on vacation during most of the second half of August, large policy roles fell to two other officials.
Sandy Berger, the deputy national security adviser, was the behind-the-scenes crisis manager. Then, Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff, a long-time student of Cuba, became his department's point man in the crisis. As a special assistant to Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance during the Carter Administration, he held secret talks in Havana aimed at normalizing relations with Cuba.
Several officials said Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, had a strong hand in Cuba policy as he made sure political considerations were not forgotten.
Administration officials say their decision to stop admitting Cuban refugees was key to their ability to resist pressures from Mr. Castro. If they had followed their original contingency plan and distributed refugees around the nation, that might have encouraged Mr. Castro to turn up the faucet even more.
 
'No More Mariels'
 According to Mr. Clinton's advisers, two mottos animated the President's thinking. One was "No More Mariels." With anti-immigrant sentiment growing nationwide, he did not want a replay of the 1980 Mariel boatlift in which 125,000 Cubans swarmed into the United States, contributing to President Carter's loss in the 1980 elections.
The second motto was "Remember Fort Chaffee." Bill Clinton lost his race for re-election as Arkansas Governor in 1980 partly because Cuban refugees rioted at that Arkansas fort. Several military police were injured and hundreds of Cuban escaped, before being captured.
The decision to turn away Cubans pleased Florida officials, but it angered many Cuban-American groups. To placate them, President Clinton told Cuban-American leaders on Aug. 19 of his plans to step up sanctions against Cuba, including tighter restrictions on travel and a ban on almost all remittances to Cuba.
To some officials, that was a sharp lurch away from the longstanding recommendations of several low- and mid-level officials. In their view, the best way to promote a peaceful transition to democracy in Cuba is to increase, not decrease, the flow of Western ideas to Cuba, and that means increasing travel, telecommunications and student exchanges.
"This was a self-coup against our own policy," one Administration official said. Indeed, several officials said the ban on remittances went too far and might be adjusted soon. One change under consideration would be aimed at helping Cuban dissidents who have been kept alive by remittances from American relatives.
When the wave of refugees surged in mid-August, the Administration feared that it would be overwhelmed and might be forced to make concessions to Mr. Castro. But by the time talks began on Sept. 1, Administration officials were confident they held the stronger hand.
 
Embarrassment for Castro
 President Clinton won some room to maneuver by doubling Guantanamo's capacity to hold refugees and by persuading Panama and Honduras to take up to 15,000 Cubans. And while the refugee flow created big inconveniences for Washington, Administration officials said it had backfired for Mr. Castro, becoming such an embarrassment that he needed a deal to defuse the crisis more than President Clinton did.
So the Cubans signed an agreement that did not mention the embargo. The Administration promised to grant entry to at least 20,000 Cubans a year, and Mr. Castro pledged in return to stop the boat people.
According to several officials, Mr. Castro approved the agreement in an effort to earn some good will in the hope that the Administration would pursue the route recommended by mid-level officials: increased openness toward Cuba.
On Friday, Mr. Tarnoff signaled that Cuban-American relations could indeed follow a new path. He said, "If there are significant steps towards democracy, free-market economy and human rights in Cuba, the United States will respond with carefully calibrated measures of its own."

HEADLINE: Town Finds Rare Way To Protect Farms: Tax

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: OLD MISSION, Mich., Sept. 10

 BODY:
The loss of scenic farm land to real estate development is a familiar story across much of the nation's rural landscape. But here on Old Mission Peninsula, where Center Road winds through cherry orchards and vineyards above the striking blue expanse of Grand Traverse Bay, a community has taken an extraordinary step in an effort to halt the trend.
For more than 100 years, the peninsula's long frost-free growing season and its sandy loam soils have supported a thriving farm economy. Roughly half the $14 million fruit harvest of far larger Grand Traverse County comes from this 16-mile-long spit of land, no more than 3 miles wide at any point, near the top of Lake Michigan. 
 But the same union of climate and terrain that made this one of the nation's premier fruit-growing areas has also brought a lively real estate market. The population of the peninsula, just north of Traverse City, has swelled to more than 6,000, 20 percent more than in 1990, bringing increased demand for housing and services.
Last month the voters of Peninsula Township, which stretches the entire length of the peninsula, opted for a novel approach to protect not only farm land but also a way of life. Acting counter to national anti-tax sentiment, they narrowly approved a property tax increase that will raise at least $2.6 million, and perhaps much more, over the next 15 years.
The tax increase, an extra $81 a year on a $130,000 home, will be used to preserve thousands of acres of orchards and farm fields by paying growers not to sell to developers -- indeed, not to use their land for anything but farming.
This is the first time a Midwest community has embraced new taxes specifically to protect its farm economy and rural landscape, said Ralph Grossi, executive director of American Farmland Trust, a preservation group in Washington.
Mr. Grossi and other land preservation advocates said the vote reflected changing priorities.
"We have found in our work around the country that the public is developing a more mature attitude about what's important in the environment," said Mr. Grossi, whose 14-year-old group helped design the Old Mission Peninsula program. "The public is becoming more leery about the latest environmental toxic scare of the week. They are looking at more fundamental issues, such as the long-term protection of open space. Those are the things that are part of their quality of life."
The program on Old Mission Peninsula will offer farmers cash payments, to be distributed to them over 15 years, for the development rights to their land. The price of the development rights will be the difference between the land's value for agriculture and its value for housing.
The program will enable the farmer to continue to own the land while giving the township permanent authority to prevent its development.
Gordon Hayward, a former dairy farmer who is the township's planner, said that in most cases the development rights to a cherry orchard with views of the bay would cost the township roughly $1,800 an acre.
Mr. Hayward said he expected the township to buy the development rights to at least 2,000 of the peninsula's 9,000 acres of farm land. The township is also working with state and private groups to buy development rights to thousands more acres.
The campaign to enact the measure was led by Rob Manigold, a 43-year-old cherry farmer who is the township supervisor. Mr. Manigold was elected in 1988 on his promise of effective management of the peninsula's surging growth. At the time, interest rates were beginning to fall, and builders had begun planning immense housing subdivisions, golf courses and other developments.
Mr. Manigold hired Mr. Hayward, a professional planner, and the two men went to work with the town planning commission to develop a master plan for the peninsula. The plan specified the most valuable farm land, places where views of the bay should be protected and locations where housing would most readily fit in.
Perhaps the most crucial argument for the preservation plan was Mr. Hayward's assertion that the township's expenses would soar as population increased. He said his analysis of state tax and population data showed that the per-capita expense to run a township of 10,000 would be nearly $200 a year, twice the township's current cost.
Those extra costs would be in higher expenses for road maintenance, police protection and other services that are now provided largely by the state and the county, neither of which would be eager to pick up the higher tab for a booming township.
So higher costs, of course, would mean higher taxes. As a result, Mr. Hayward and Mr. Manigold made the case to voters that spending a little extra in taxes now might save a lot in taxes later.
"We don't want to be flagged as anti-growth, because we're not," Mr. Manigold said in an interview in the tiny white town hall. "We want to keep our scenic views. We want to keep the natural farm resource, which has national significance. And we want to move the development into locations where we can have the best for everybody."
 
Hardly Unanimous
 Not everybody here is satisfied with the program. The close vote in early August -- 1,208 to 1,081 -- was a clear indication that the preservation effort had not been an easy sell.
A total of 137 families now farm on the peninsula, and some are suspicious of the plan, predicting that it will fail to control growth because land has simply become too valuable.
Up and down Center Road, "for sale" signs are staked out in orchards, one of which belongs to 57-year-old Russell J. Holmes, who is asking $434,000 for his 79 acres and their magnificent view of the bay.
Mr. Holmes, who would get $140,000 if he accepted a development-rights payment from the township, said: "This preservation program is a day late and a dollar short. You've already got too many people out here. What gets me now is that my taxes are going up to pay for it."
But other farmers say they support the program because it will add to the income from their land without requiring them to give up ownership or farming.
The debate over land use is by no means unique to Old Mission Peninsula. In many rural communities, the most pressing environmental issues of the 1980's -- hazardous wastes, and toxic chemicals in air and water -- are being nudged aside by more immediate problems. Two years ago a state study identified the deterioriating rural landscape as the top environmental issue in Michigan.
The principal reason for the change in attitude, public officials say, has been the success of the air and water pollution laws enacted since the early 1970's. The Great Lakes region is much cleaner than it was a generation ago, according to findings announced at several scientific conferences this year.
But the cleaner environment also attracts more residents. The Traverse City metropolitan region, for instance, now has more than 64,000 people, an increase of almost 20 percent since 1980. Glen Chown, the executive director of the Grand Traverse Regional Land Conservancy, said in an interview that the growth was fueling new housing subdivisions, shopping centers and roads on land that only a few years ago was forests and fields.
"The irony," he said, "is that the natural beauty that attracted all the growth is itself now threatened."

HEADLINE: For Black-Owned Businesses, a Directory of Their Own

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Let your fingers do the walking in the Black Pages, and those fingers will find themselves on the pulse of an often unacknowledged world.
"It's the world of black businesses owned by black people," said Celeste Morris. "Word of mouth was how black people in New York used to find those businesses. Now part of that world is in these pages." 
 Ms. Morris, 44, is the founder and publisher of New York City's Black Pages, formally known as "The Big Black Book." The 1994 edition, the eighth, circulation 75,000, has 137 pages with more than 500 display ads in categories from psychotherapists to locksmiths. It sells for $1 at 60 distributors citywide, including stores and nonprofit agencies.
According to a report last month by the University of Georgia, blacks' spending power is expected to reach $399 billion by 1995, up 33.9 percent from 1990, compared with a 29.6 increase projected for the country as a whole. A large chunk of those billions is spent in New York City, which has about 25,000 black-owned businesses.
"But you have to find each other to spend money on each other," said Ms. Morris, also the president of the Black Pages Publishers Association. More than two dozen other cities have equivalents of the Big Black Book. The Black Pages of Atlanta has been publishing for nearly two decades.
Ms. Morris, a native of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was working for the Transit Authority in 1986 when she decided the city could use a Yellow Pages for black businesses. She pushed her idea 24 hours a day, working craft fairs on weekends and dance floors by night.
She sold 200 ads and stored all the copy in a cardboard box under her desk. Then the box was taken out with the trash. After a frantic dawn search at the Greenpoint dump, the targeted truck was yanked off the disposal line, and its contents were spread out in front of Ms. Morris. Sanitation workers helped tear open bags. The box was uncovered.
Eventually, the 200 ads became 400, then peaked at 700 in 1992 before settling to the current 500. Ms. Morris's offices, once located in her son's bedroom, now take up a floor of a Brooklyn brownstone. She employs a staff of three, with 10 independent ad salespeople. Space in the book, whose cover is always the work of a black artist, runs from $275 to $3,000.
"I always had faith in the book," said Elenora Willis, the president of Gem Travel in Queens, who has advertised since the book's debut. "Black businesses were suffering, and its time had come."
Jeffrey Watts, who runs Pro Tech Locksmith in Flatbush, Brooklyn, said: "I wasn't looking at the political side of it when I took out the first ad. I was looking for business. It's worked out well.
"If you need a locksmith and it's 3 A.M. and you live in East New York, there aren't a lot of shops that are going to send someone to you," he added. "But we'll go.."
Ms. Morris's next ambition is a black business institute, a center for the research and advocacy of African-American enterprise.
"Years ago, one of the downsides of integration was that it helped the demise of many black business," she said. "But the Big Black Book is a testament to the creativity of black people, to the tenaciousness of black people. People can say what they want about blacks and business and initiative, but they can't argue with this book."

HEADLINE: Cairo Parley Hits a New Snag on Migrants

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 10

 BODY:
After six days of snail's-pace maneuvering over abortion, the United Nations population conference ran into fresh problems tonight when developing nations revolted over the refusal of the United States to agree that migrants have a right to be united with their families.
People taking part in the gathering said about 60 delegates from Latin America and other parts of the developing world rose in a closed committee meeting to protest the American move, which assumed added significance in light of the recent flood of Cuban and Haitian refugees seeking to reach the United States. Many of the Cubans in particular are seeking to join relatives. 
 A senior conference official reported that agreement was close on a number of other issues discussed in the conference's final document, including abortion. But in an unanticipated hitch, several Muslim groups and governments were objecting to language in the 113-page declaration that they felt would sanction homosexuality and sexual permissiveness. Vatican diplomats also indicated that the debate over abortion was far from over.
"I feel rather saddened after a lot of work was done," said Fred Sei, the chairman of the conference's main drafting committee. "I hate to end this meeting on such a despondent note."
 
Immigration Flood Feared
 The new deadlock arose because of longstanding American opposition to a sentence in the conference's draft declaration recognizing "the right to family reunification," a clause that the United States fears would lead to a flood of immigration.
"The whole thing still needs a lot of examination," said an Argentine diplomat, arguing that by excising the contested clause, the principle of family reunification for migrants would be jeopardized.
The contentious language comes in Chapter 10 of a 113-page draft declaration that the conference hopes will serve as a blueprint for nations confronting a looming population crisis. The strategies for limiting population growth include a range of new initiatives in health, education, family planning and the empowerment of women.
While the final declaration to be formally adopted when the conference closes next Tuesday is nonbinding on governments, many delegations are seeking the widest possible consensus so its recommendations will be as authoritative as possible.
The disputed paragraph says, among other things, "Governments of receiving countries must insure the protection of migrants and their families, and recognize the right to family reunification." Under the United Nations policy for registering objections to a text, the United States sought to have parentheses around the words, "and recognize the right to family reunification."
 
Surprised by Vehemence
 An American official said the language was completely unacceptable but acknowledged that the newest objections to Washington's position had been surprisingly vehement. While American diplomats did not address the closed committee meeting, the official said, the United States position was that American legislation already provides for the reunification of migrant families.
European and other participants also said the revolt had come as a surprise. "At 7:30 we thought we had agreement," said an official of the 12-nation European Union. "An hour later, we did not."
The fierceness of the protest persuaded Mr. Sei to postpone the committee sessions until Monday, participants said.
Sunday was initially scheduled as a day of rest for the delegates from more than 150 countries. But European officials said the day would now be spent in more of the closed-door maneuvering that generally dominates such gatherings.
The development shifted the focus of the debate here, which has centered on the Vatican's opposition to language in the final document that it said implies a universal right to abortion.
After forcing many changes, the Vatican agreed on Friday to suspend its objections to one section on abortion. Delegates devoted much time today to changing proposals in another chapter relating to abortion and sexual rights to address the Vatican's concerns.
 
Vatican Resistance Expected
 Nicolaas Biegman of the Netherlands, the deputy chairman of the drafting committee, acknowledged that the revised language was still expected to meet with Vatican resistance but would nonetheless be put before his committee on Monday.
"Then I will bang my gavel," he said, meaning that he would declare a consensus on the disputed abortion language. "That is not so certain," said a senior Vatican negotiator.
If a consensus is declared, that would leave the Vatican and its few allies to register their reservations at the formal conclusion of the conference on Tuesday.
Mr. Biegman reported an agreement on all of Chapter 7, a section on reproductive rights and reproductive health that the United States views as a cornerstone of a new approach to development and population issues.
United States officials said the compromise involved inserting language to remove any impression that abortion could be construed as a universal right or that it could be perceived as a means of family planning.
The officials also reported that a smaller drafting committee had offered changes in a paragraph alluding to the sexual rights of "marriages and other unions," to meet the objections raised primarily by Egypt and other Islamic countries that the language endorsed homosexuality and promiscuity.
European diplomats said there had been no final agreement on that issue.
 
Formal Objections Expected
 Even though language on abortion has apparently been drafted to the approval of many delegations, it is widely expected that the Vatican and other delegations will register formal objections to any suggestion that abortion should be legal.
Under United Nations rules, delegations can do so in committees or at the conference's final session. To insure that their position makes the most impact and secures the widest publicity, delegates say it is politically astute to raise objections at the last minute in the full session, when the reservations are formally inserted into the document published as the conference's conclusions.


GRAPHIC: Burgeoning growth in East Asia's emerging economies has been one of the most pressing issues facing the United Nations population conference in Cairo. Considerable attention has also been devoted to China and India, already population juggernauts, which have high growth in terms of absolute numbers of people. Western Europe and North America, on the other hand, have relatively low rates of population growth.

HEADLINE: As Primary Nears, Barry Runs Hard

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
In the final weekend before a Democratic primary virtually certain to produce the District of Columbia's next mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., the man driven from that office by a drug conviction, is close to achieving what many residents once thought unimaginable.
With the city reeling from a serious budget deficit, an eroding quality of life and strained relations with Congress, he finds himself a leading contender to be returned to office, despite having ended his last term four years ago with a six-month jail sentence. 
 Mr. Barry, who was Mayor for 12 years, is practically tied for the lead in recent polls with John Ray, a city councilman for 15 years who has run for mayor unsuccessfully three times. Each is favored by nearly one-third of the voters. Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly, who succeeded Mr. Barry in 1990, promising change and reform, is a distant third with less than 20 percent of voters' support.
In the last days of the campaign, Mr. Barry and Mr. Ray have focused much of their efforts on undecided voters and those who might be swayed by a late-inning argument.
 
Last-Minute Campaigning
 Today, in ideal weather conditions for handshakes and kibbitzing, the 58-year-old Mr. Barry meandered about the city on a schedule that included nine campaign stops in five of Washington's eight wards. Mr. Ray planned to appear in 10 places in six wards. Mrs. Kelly's official schedule included only one stop.
Mr. Ray, a 51-year-old lawyer, has been endorsed by several big unions, leading business organizations and The Washington Post. But the most electrifying theme throughout the campaign has been Mr. Barry's robust return to citywide politics, attempting to convince voters that he can be trusted enough to serve as mayor again.
To many, it has been an easy sell. The willingness to forgive and acknowledge repentance runs strong and deep, especially in poorer sections of the city, where crime, drug use and shabby public housing are fixed parts of the urban landscape. These residents have seen countless people fall prey to guns and drugs, and they rarely have the chance to share in the kind of triumph over misfortune that Mr. Barry says he has experienced.
 
'Some Charisma'
 "I'm just blessed with some charisma," he said in an interview, explaining why voters would still find him attractive as a candidate. "I have substance. But I add style to it. That means you're really dynamite."
But to voters less convinced of Mr. Barry's sincerity or worthiness to serve, particularly whites and many affluent blacks, his campaign represents little more than a power grab, an audacious one at that, with campaign themes that implore voters to look forward, not back.
That is asking a lot, critics say, given the city's deterioration during Mr. Barry's last four-year term and the graphic nature of his fall. The former Mayor was caught smoking crack cocaine in a downtown hotel room, with the entire scene captured by the authorities on videotape.
With so little time before the primary, Mr. Barry's biggest problem could be expanding his support base beyond its solid core. Over the summer, he has held fairly steady in the polls, with Mr. Ray surging lately and Mrs. Kelly flagging.
But Mr. Barry has managed to energize other constituencies, including voters in the contiguous Wards 4, 5 and 7 along the northeast boundary of the city, with their heavy black middle-class population.
"I think the vote here is going to be split," said James Chappelle, a real estate developer and one of 10 candidates in Ward 5 running for the City Council. "Ray has a lot of support here. Barry has a whole lot of support. The sentiment right now is that Barry was considered a good mayor. His personal problems, that's his business. Hey, Oliver North is running for the Senate in Virginia. Come on."
 
Endorsement by the Post
 The Post's endorsement, which came on Friday, had been anxiously awaited by all the candidates, but especially by Mr. Ray and Mrs. Kelly, the only two who had a reasonable expectation of getting it.
Mr. Barry had no hope that The Post would endorse him. Yet this week he turned its endorsement of Mr. Ray into his own campaign tool, proclaiming that it was little more than a "stop Marion Barry movement" to help any other candidate to prevail.
Mr. Ray, who supported Mr. Barry in 1978, scoffed at such a notion. "The Post endorsed him in 1978, 1982 and 1986," he said. "You didn't hear him complaining then. You get the message."
Mr. Ray is also telling voters that Mr. Barry and Mrs. Kelly have become a "tag team," with some sort of tacit agreement to attack only Mr. Ray, not each other.
At the same time, Mrs. Kelly is portraying Mr. Ray and Mr. Barry as two of a kind politically. In one of her latest radio commercials, music from the television series The Odd Couple plays in the background as a voice blames Mr. Barry and Mr. Ray for the mess she inherited.
"I'm still the only candidate of change," Mrs. Kelly told reporters on Friday.
For the most part, the events of Mr. Barry's downfall -- his arrest, conviction and incarceration -- have played a commanding role in the campaign only in the broadest context. For example, Mr. Ray and Mrs. Kelly occasionally refer to that night in the hotel room. "This election is not about the Vista Hotel and Mr. Barry's redemption," Mr. Ray said this week.
 
Barry's Record at Issue
 But in general, they emphasize the state of government when Mr. Barry departed, and challenge him on the more pertinent, and possibly more damaging, issue of his record as Mayor.
In response, Mr. Barry has built his campaign around themes of rehabilitation and redemption. While he has not ducked specific questions about the past, he does his best to deflect them. He has apologized for the "pain" he caused the city but argues that "1990 was a snapshot, not the whole picture, and I bring to the table a lot more than videotape."
"Most people are recovering from something," he said, when asked about winning the voter's trust. "Like a storm. You're either in a storm or have just come out of a storm or on the way to a storm."
He cited examples of people who go bankrupt, people who drink too much, people who use drugs. He said: "So here's this man who can come back to be better than he was before he went down, and so they say, 'God, maybe I'll decide to stop feeling sorry for myself right here. Maybe I'll grab onto something he grabbed onto.' That's the lesson."
And the parable for his campaign: He fell; he rose.
"The city's on its knees now," he said. "It was probably down when I was there, but it was never knocked to its knees like this. I know the government better than anybody else. I know it up and down. I have more ideas about how you solve problems than anybody else, so add that to the dimension of my personal recovery, and somebody might say, 'Well, maybe he can bring this city back to greatness and glory.' "

To Mr. Barry's left were other candidates in the primary, Don Folde and Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Rosenbaum and Pataki Close on Issues

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 9

 BODY:
At first blush the Republican primary for governor on Tuesday seems a contest between two candidates whose visions are canyons apart.
One hopeful, Richard M. Rosenbaum, has deep roots in the liberal Rockefeller wing of the party and says he is crusading to "return the party to the moderates." 
 The other contender, State Senator George E. Pataki, has courted the ascendant right wing of the Republicans and has won the Conservative Party endorsement.
But beneath the ideological trappings the differences blur. Mr. Rosenbaum, aware that Republican primary voters tend to lean right, calls himself "conservative enough" in a commercial. Mr. Pataki, firmly focused on winning Democratic votes in November, has billed himself as a "social moderate."
A result is that in a virtual nonrace that Mr. Pataki has all but ignored, the two have staked out similar just-right-of-center positions on a variety of issues like cutting taxes, spending, the death penalty, tougher penalties for violent felons and restricting welfare programs.
"The born-again Pataki is being refashioned as a centrist, and that's where Rosenbaum has been," a poll taker from New Hartford, John Zogby, said. "They are certainly not playing up many differences."
On just one issue, abortion, do they clearly disagree. Both make appeals to female voters by labeling themselves as "pro-choice" on abortion. But while Mr. Rosenbaum opposes any restrictions on abortion, Mr. Pataki, keeping a foot in the conservative camp, backs mandatory waiting periods, parental notification for minors and counseling for women seeking abortions financed by Medicaid.
But there are few such sharp differences. Although Mr. Pataki has offered few specifics about his platform -- he differs from Mr. Rosenbaum in that he has released no position papers and rejected requests for an interview for this article -- his speeches, previous interviews and legislative record clearly suggest that he supports many of the same ideas as Mr. Rosenbaum.
Nowhere is that clearer than on taxes. Both politicians accuse Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of promoting high-tax policies that, they say, have driven jobs out of state. Both offer tax-reduction plans that are more extensive than Mr. Cuomo's.
Mr. Rosenbaum has called for reducing taxes $4 billion a year from the $34 billion collected in taxes and fees, largely by cutting the top personal income-tax rate of 7.785 percent to 6.7 percent. He would eliminate state income taxes on capital gains; raise the taxable income at which the top rate takes effect, from $26,000 a year for married couples to $100,000, and increase the number of poor people who pay no taxes.
Mr. Pataki has said he will also cut the personal income tax, though he has not specified by how much. And he has called for cutting a variety of business taxes, including immediately ending the surcharge on corporate income taxes and reducing the minimum and petroleum taxes.
Both candidates advance a trickle-down theory that tax cuts will pay for themselves by stimulating the economy and creating jobs. But they also say the state needs to slash spending.
Mr. Rosenbaum has released a plan for cutting $1 billion in his first year as governor that will include reducing welfare payments, eliminating some services for prisoners, raising tuition for wealthier students at state colleges and reducing wages at state construction projects.
Mr. Pataki pinpoints three areas to trim waste. He says by leaving empty one-third of the vacancies in its work force each year, the state could save $300 million annually. Second, he has called for consolidating the State Energy Office with another agency, an idea that Mr. Cuomo suggested in 1991 but that the Legislature rejected. And he has called for cutting back the Education Department, which had a $278 million budget last year.
Several of Mr. Rosenbaum's budget proposals would require legislative approval and would most likely face fights. Most of Mr. Pataki's proposals could probably be carried out by the governor alone, but it is not clear that they would createprojected savings.
Statistics from the Governor's Budget Office indicate that Mr. Pataki's plan to reduce employees would save half of what he estimates, or $150 million a year. Abolishing the Energy Office would eliminate 214 jobs, according to the budget office.
The state supplies $56 million of the Education Department budget. The rest is mostly Federal money. Under Mr. Cuomo the department has reduced its state-financed positions 62 percent, from 2,551 to 969.
Neither Republican candidate has offered plans for reigning in the two largest components of the $34.2 billion annual state budget, Medicaid, which has grown at double-digit rates in recent years, and school aid, which has more than doubled, to $9.6 billion, since 1983.
 
Recipients to Managed Care
 Both Republicans say they would try to cut Medicaid costs by sending additional recipients to managed-care programs, a procedure that the Cuomo administration is carrying out. The Republican candidates say education aid can be controlled by reducing administrative costs, although neither has pinpointed how.
Both candidates have suggested that they might want to increase school aid, because that can help control local property taxes. And both say they support a state takeover of Medicaid costs that counties now pay. That would add more than $3 billion a year to the state budget.
"Somebody might say, 'Isn't that more big government,' " Mr. Rosenbaum said about the Medicaid takeover. "But no way. It's a good argument for bringing down the costs."
On what is possibly the most important issue this year, crime, the two candidates have offered the death penalty as the centerpiece of their platforms. "There is no question in my mind that the death penalty will save lives," Mr. Pataki often says.
Both men have also called for restricting, even ending, parole for violent criminals. Both support life sentences without parole for criminals convicted of their third felonies. And both Republicans have endorsed banning military-style assault weapons, although Mr. Rosenbaum has accused Mr. Pataki of waffling on the issue because he voted against a proposal by Democrats in the State Senate that would have sharply restricted ownership of such weapons.
The two candidates have both called for drastically curtailing welfare costs. Mr. Rosenbaum said he would limit welfare payments for childless able-bodied adults in the home-relief program to one year. There is no time limit now. Mr. Pataki has said he would consider ending payments after 90 days. Both politicians said they would also require welfare recipients to work or attend school in exchange for payments.
Mr. Rosenbaum has also proposed requiring teen-age welfare mothers to live with their parents, cutting welfare grants for families to the national average, by about 40 percent, and not giving welfare mothers additional money for new children.
On the environment the candidates say they want to protect open space in the Adirondacks and elsewhere, but neither has endorsed significant state land purchases to achieve that. Both also say they oppose building garbage incinerators.
"Incineration has proven to be environmentally and economically costly," Mr. Pataki has said.
In a race with so few clear policy differences, Mr. Rosenbaum has sought to distinguish himself by running as an outsider, even though he is a former state party chairman. He has proposed a host of changes with populist appeal, including recall, initiative and referendum, term limits and easier ballot access.
 
ISSUES
Governor's Race: Where the Republicans Stand
 
Economy
 
Richard M. Rosenbaum: Says he would reduce taxes by $4 billion a year mainly by cutting the personal income tax rate, eliminating capital gains taxes and increasing the number of low-income wage earners who pay no income taxes.
 
George E. Pataki: Says he would reduce a broad range of taxes by an unspecified amount, notably the personal income tax and a variety of business taxes.

Spending
 
Mr. Rosenbaum: Has proposed raising the tuition at state-run colleges for upper income families and reducing wages paid on state construction projects.
 
Mr. Pataki: Has said he would let one-third of all vacancies in the state work force go unfilled each year, would turn prison health services over to private companies and would reduce the state education administration.

Crime
 
Mr. Rosenbaum: Would sign a death penalty bill, impose adult sentences on violent felons over the age of 14, require all parolees to undergo drug testing and bar parole for anyone convicted of a violent crime.
 
Mr. Pataki: Has made signing the death penalty a centerpiece of his campaign, and says he would end early release for violent felons.

Welfare
 
Mr. Rosenbaum: Has proposed ending welfare payments for able-bodied adults after one year, requiring those without young children to work or attend school before receiving welfare checks, cutting welfare payments to families by about 40 percent and aggressively pursuing absentee fathers who don't pay child support.
 
Mr. Pataki: Has said he would limit welfare payments to able-bodied adults without children to 90 days, supports requiring children in welfare families to attend school and would require able-bodied adults to work in exchange for their checks.

Social issues
 
Mr. Rosenbaum: Supports a woman's right to an abortion, without restriction. Opposes expanding state civil rights legislation to include homosexuals.
 
Mr. Pataki: Supports a woman's right to an abortion, but supports a range of restrictions. Opposes expanding state civil rights legislation to include homosexuals.

HEADLINE: At Immigration, Disarray and Defeat

SERIES: Chaos at the Gates -- First of five articles.

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The Immigration and Naturalization Service does not bother to collect as much as $23 million a year in fees, easy money that could be gathered with just a letter here or a phone call there. That is because, officials say, the agency cannot afford to hire the accounting clerks to write those letters and make those calls.
Yet each month the immigration service finds a way to allow dozens of its inspectors to take round-trip, all-expenses-paid cruises to places like Nassau in the Bahamas and Cozumel, Mexico, often accompanied by friends or family members whose expenses are also paid by the cruise lines. The inspectors' job is to check the passengers' travel documents on the return trip. 
 It is a curious division of resources -- no staff to collect millions but just enough to perform a courtesy service for the cruise industry. Yet it is a classic example of the mismanagement that plagues the immigration service, perhaps the most troubled major agency in the Federal Government.
An investigation by The New York Times has found that the Immigration and Naturalization Service, an arm of the Justice Department, is broadly dysfunctional. Hobbled by understaffing, underfinancing, conflicting mandates from Congress and widespread mismanagement failures, it is an agency in disarray. It lurches from one immigration emergency to the next, its employees demoralized, its mission unrealized.
On the most mundane level, the agency cannot even find a way to open its mail and answer its phones. On a more serious one, it does not make a concerted effort to find and deport most aliens with criminal records.
Even its own officials, inured to failure, consider the agency ill-equipped to handle its ever-rising demands.
"Lots of people are burned out, fed up, not willing to go on," said Walter D. Cadman, district director in Miami.
Among the findings by The Times, emerging from interviews with scores of I.N.S. employees nationwide, were these:
*No agency of the Government is more vulnerable to corruption than the I.N.S., where front-line workers, paid little more than the minimum wage, give out green cards and other coveted documents that are worth thousands of dollars on the black market. Year after year, dozens of employees are arrested for taking bribes or related crimes. Yet even when corruption cases repeatedly expose glaring weaknesses in the system, the agency usually neglects to correct them.
*Deportation officers seldom deport anyone. Most deportations that do occur are carried out on an honor system. Deportees are asked to turn themselves in on a certain day. In New York, for example, only about 4 percent actually show up.
*More than four million aliens come to the immigration service each year with simple and perfectly legal requests for green cards, work authorizations or other permits, but, as one senior manager put it, "we make people suffer." At I.N.S. offices throughout the country, telephones go unanswered, mail goes unopened, and immigrants stand in daylong lines that often lead them to surly, untrained workers who cannot answer their questions. Even Attorney General Janet Reno complains that sometimes when she calls the immigration service she cannot get through.
For its inquiry The Times interviewed more than 100 agency employees and visited immigration service offices in Chicago, El Paso, Los Angeles, Miami, New York, Phoenix and San Francisco, among other cities. The employees ranged from entry-level workers to senior officers at headquarters in Washington. Most were selected by their supervisors, presumably because the supervisors thought these employees would present the agency's best face. What the employees offered, however -- with a candor that is rare in government -- was a grim one.
"We have no mission, no tools, no leadership, so where are we?" complained Juan Bustos, a deportation officer in San Francisco.
Patrick E. Kane, acting director of the Phoenix office, said, "We're dabbling in everything, and we aren't really doing anything."
Robert E. Crebbs, a special agent in San Francisco, lamented, "There's overwhelming apathy from top to bottom."
And A. D. Moyer, district director in Chicago, said: "A lot of people have gone out of their way to make this a cold, rude, insensitive and inefficient agency. The mentality of this organization leaves a lot to be desired."
Ruth Anne Myers worked for the immigration service for 33 years, and in June, just four days after she retired as director of the Phoenix office, she reflected on the agency's latest budget crisis.
"It's a mess," she said, shaking her head, "and I don't know if we've ever been in a bigger mess."
All of this fosters a numbing fatalism. As a senior examinations officer in Miami put it, "No matter what we do, good or bad, it makes no difference."
 
The Task
Impossible Job, Few Advocates
 The service's mission, broadly stated, is to keep illegal aliens out of the country and admit legal immigrants in an efficient, orderly manner. To accomplish those goals it has about 19,000 employees and will spend $1.6 billion this year. About one-third of that is from fees the agency collects from immigrants.
Its budget has nearly tripled and its work force has grown by 50 percent since 1986, but in that time the agency's workload has markedly increased, too.
Last year the agency admitted almost one million new residents and naturalized several hundred thousand others. It also handled more than three million requests for work permits, border passes or other documents.
In addition, the agency apprehends more than one million aliens each year as they try to enter the country illegally. Theoretically, the I.N.S. is also responsible for finding and deporting almost four million others who are here. And it must be ready to scramble whenever unexpected immigration emergencies flare, like those in Haiti and Cuba.
With all that and more, agency officials say, the I.N.S. is overwhelmed. In fact, the service's performance has usually been so lacking that others in Government have generally preferred to look the other way and dispose of the problem with a simple explanation: the task is impossible; there is no way the United States can control its vast, open borders.
As a result, the I.N.S. has remained, in the words of a former Commissioner, Gene McNary, "the agency nobody cared about -- dumped on, dirty-faced kids."
The occasional official who does take an interest finds that a large part of the problem is the I.N.S. itself. "I tell you, 90 days over there, and you don't know whether to laugh or to cry," said Don Wortman, a former senior official at several Federal agencies who served on a Federal panel that studied the I.N.S. three years ago.
Most members of Congress see no political benefit in trying to improve the agency. After all, "in the immigration business, you're never right," said Chris Sale, the Deputy Commissioner. "Half the people always think you're wrong, depending on which half of the people you're dealing with."
 
An Unpopular Cause
 As a consequence, the immigration oversight committees remain among the least popular in Congress. The Senate subcommittee has only three members, the minimum number, because "we could only find three senators who were willing to be on it," said Jerry Tinker, its longtime staff director. Only two other Senate subcommittees are as unpopular -- the one that oversees the Federal deficit and the one that looks after the Internal Revenue Service. The House immigration subcommittee is among the smallest in that chamber, too.
But now, for the first time, the rest of Government may have to take an interest. Politicians from the border states are in open rebellion over Federal immigration policy, denouncing it as a failure. Several of those states are suing the Federal Government, saying millions of illegal aliens are draining their resources. And from Florida to California this year, immigration has become a fiery issue in election campaigns.
"Our immigration crisis demands action, and it demands it this year!" Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Republican, declared in June.
Representative Anthony C. Beilenson, Democrat of California, said as the lawsuits were being filed this spring, "All of a sudden, immigration sort of arrived, or ripened and blossomed as a national issue."
Doris M. Meissner, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, is well aware that she runs a deeply troubled agency. "In the current climate," she said, "I don't think we can continue to get by with some of these chronic and traditional behaviors."
Ms. Meissner was a senior manager at the immigration service in the early 1980's and after that worked as an immigration expert at a research institute in Washington. When she took office last October, the Clinton Administration and Congress made it clear that they expected her to rescue the agency. Very quickly she outlined an aggressive strategy for change, and she is now reorganizing the management structure. It was "dysfunctional" when she took office, Ms. Meissner said.
Even with that change and many others planned, Ms. Meissner has come to a disquieting realization. The agency's problems remain so numerous, so deep and so daunting that many of her own employees openly question whether she or anyone else can turn things around.
"These are huge challenges," she said in an interview. "I know the jury's still out."
Attorney General Reno echoed that. "It is very difficult to create a functional agency," she said, "while at the same time addressing all the emergencies that constantly beset it," like the Cuban refugee crisis. "I don't think Doris and I are satisfied yet, but I am proud of what they have done."
 
The Leadership
Little Guidance, Less Control
 The Commissioner of immigration presides over an empire -- more than 19,000 employees in 62 offices throughout the country and 3 overseas. To manage such a collection is difficult at best. But the service's own district leaders say they are not being managed at all. Most say they never speak to their supervisors in Washington, and this communication failure contributes to almost every one of the agency's other problems.
"You feel like the Lone Ranger out here, you're so out of touch," said Mr. Kane, the acting director in Phoenix.
Mr. Cadman, head of the Miami office, said: "We get no guidance. We have a feeling we're adrift, in limbo."
And Mr. Moyer, head of the Chicago office, said, "I didn't speak to my boss for two and one-half years."
James A. Puleo, an executive associate commissioner in Washington, was responsible for supervising all of the districts from January 1993 until last July. "I agree with them that the system doesn't work very well," he said of his district leaders. "But I only have an illustrious staff of two. I don't call them up to chat about nothing."
Ms. Meissner, the Commissioner, said the new management structure would alleviate the problem, and Mr. Moyer said he had already seen some improvement from his Chicago vantage point. But that will not necessarily clear up another complaint, this one by Richard K. Rogers, head of the Los Angeles office: that "absolutely no one is held accountable" for his work.
 
Expense-Paid Cruises
 The leadership vacuum can breed embarrassments, like the messy problem of en route inspections.
The I.N.S. is responsible for checking passengers arriving on cruise ships, usually as they step off the ship. But some cruise lines prefer to have the inspector carry out the work during the cruise, as a convenience to passengers. So dozens of times each week, immigration inspectors from ports around the country sail to Mexico, the Caribbean or more distant points, with little work to do on the outbound trip, and then carry out the inspections on the way back.
The Justice Department's Inspector General's Office looked into the practice and found that on some of the inspectors' trips, "family members and friends accompanied them for free or on discounted fares." The inspectors traveled free, too. In addition, the report said, if an inspector had other costs, "such as taxi fares, hotels, meals, etc., the ship's purser would reimburse the inspector directly." Most were one-day cruises, but some lasted five days. While on board, some inspectors charged the cruise lines for overtime.
All of this, the Inspector General's Office concluded in its report last spring, "creates a conflict of interest." And "since an inspector can fine a cruise line $3,000 for each undocumented alien discovered," the Inspector General wondered whether all these gratuities "could result in more lenient inspections." But perhaps the most startling finding in the report was that while I.N.S. management officials knew in a general sense that some inspectors were doing inspections en route, they were unaware of the fringe benefits.
"This wasn't something I knew about," said Mr. Cadman, head of the Miami office. "But it's wrong, flat wrong."
The agency's leaders were informed of the Inspector General's preliminary findings on May 21, 1993. But nothing was done about them for more than a year. A few weeks ago Mr. Cadman said he had given his staff no new instructions about accepting gratuities, and during a round-table discussion with eight Miami office employees, all of them said they had not heard about the report.
"There has been no notice of it," one said. She had carried out an en route inspection the day before.
Mr. Cadman said, "I'm waiting for headquarters to set a policy."
At headquarters, Mr. Puleo deplored the practice of taking family members along and declared: "The directive on that went out a year ago. We stopped it." But asked for documentary evidence, Mr. Puleo said through a spokesman that he had misspoken. Actually, nothing had been done.
Guidelines forbidding the acceptance of gratuities were finally issued only after a reporter asked about them this summer.
The Money
Millions Owing, No One to Collect
 Year after year, budget crises ripple through the I.N.S. The agency repeatedly overestimates the fees it will collect from immigrants and visitors, fails to plan for the inevitable immigration emergencies, then loses track of much of the money it does have. Finally the agency finds itself with another shortfall, and that hobbles every effort to start new programs or fix old problems.
"Budgeting over there," said Mr. Tinker of the Senate immigration subcommittee, "is an Alice in Wonderland kind of thing."
After Congress passed major immigration laws in 1986 and 1990, the agency grew so quickly that "the infrastructure collapsed," said Ms. Sale, the Deputy Commissioner.
But financial management at the agency has long been sloppy. In 1980, the Senate Judiciary Committee demanded a management study before it would appropriate any money. In 1990, the General Accounting Office said the agency's budget process was "deplorable." Today, the Office of Management and Budget labels the financial controls at the I.N.S. "high risk," meaning they "warrant top-level attention at the agency and by the Congress."
Kenneth W. Rath has been a senior I.N.S. financial officer since 1991, and he now heads that office. Critical audit after critical audit has landed on his desk. "I was the guy who was hired to sit on that stack of audit reports," he said, "and I've solved those problems."
But around the country, other I.N.S. officials laughed at that. They noted that about the time Mr. Rath made that remark this summer, his office announced that the agency was once again $60 million short.
That led to the annual rite of midyear budget cuts in every office. "We just had to cancel our contract with the convention center, where we were holding naturalization ceremonies," said Mr. Cadman, the Miami director. "We couldn't pay the rent."
 
Mail Doesn't Go Through
 Part of the problem is downstairs in Mr. Cadman's own mail room. Because of budget shortages, the office does not have enough people to open the mail -- 1,500 letters a day. Many of the envelopes contain checks and cash -- application fees that could be fed into the I.N.S. budget. "Right now," the records and information supervisor for the office said, "we're opening mail from a month ago."
Even when the office does get around to opening the letters, Mr. Cadman said, the volume of mail is so great that if a letter does not have the immigrant's file number on it, "we can't deal with it."
"It goes in a box," he said. "We have a million letters like that in boxes. We don't know what to do with them."
The paradox is that the agency may hold the solution to many of these problems in its own hands. It lies in another critical audit from the Justice Department, one that landed on Mr. Rath's desk a few months ago.
Airlines and cruise ships collect $6 from each passenger arriving in the United States, and they are supposed to turn that money over to the I.N.S. But the Justice Department found that the agency was failing to collect the fees from 22 airlines and six cruise lines -- a loss of as much as $23 million a year.
Mr. Rath explained: "I can't say that's wrong because I don't know. But there are only two people down there monitoring this" in accounting.
The agency has the authority to subpoena records from the carriers and call witnesses. But to collect the money, usually just a bit of research along with a letter or phone call is enough.
 
A Simple Solution?
 Mr. Rath conceded that the sensible solution might simply be to put more clerks in that office, considering the money they could easily collect. But he said that was easier said than done. "When you ask Congress for funding for support personnel, it's not very glamorous," he said, adding with a wave of the hand, "it's the first thing they cut."
On Capitol Hill, Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, a Kentucky Democrat who heads the House immigration subcommittee, was visibly stunned by that notion. He almost bellowed as he said: "We'd leap across the committee table to give them those people and 10 more! We're not stupid. But they've never asked."
The carrier fees are only one example of the millions of dollars the agency is owed that it fails to collect. The I.N.S. also loses track of the bonds that many immigrants post to guarantee that they will appear for hearings. When an immigrant does not show up, the bond money is forfeited to the immigration service. But in many offices no one looks at the bonds again -- and finally they expire.
"We don't have anybody assigned to that," Phil Waters, acting director of the San Francisco office, acknowledged with a shrug. "The only time we go back and look at some of the bonds is if somebody asks."
Nationwide, the Justice Department found, the immigration service failed to collect about $38 million in bond money in the last six years.
All of that, Mr. Rath said matter-of-factly, "is an inevitable result of the management situation we have." But in Phoenix, Ms. Myers thinks explanations like that are too facile.
"This kind of thing goes on year after year, but nobody's ever held accountable," she said, her voice rising with anger. "Nobody loses his job. Nobody gets demoted. Everyone gets their bonuses. Now here we are again in 1994 and we're $60 million short. It's so depressing."

HEADLINE: Leaders in Their Fields, From Science to Business, Who Died in USAir Crash;
Edwin K. Wiles, Energy Consultant, 50

 BODY:
Edwin K. Wiles, an energy consultant who once headed the West Virginia Coal Association, died on Thursday in the USAir plane crash. He was 50 and lived in Mount Lebanon, Pa.
As a reporter for United Press International in the late 1960's, Mr. Wiles covered the rescue of coal miners trapped underground in Hominy Falls, W.Va., prompting a lifelong interest in the coal industry. 
 That interest lead to jobs as vice president of corporate relations for the West Virginia Coal Association, a group representing coal mine owners, from 1970 to 1974 and president of the association from 1974 to 1985. Later, he worked as an energy consultant specializing in coal interests. Most recently, he was a vice president of the Center for Energy and Economic Development, a Virginia-based organization that promotes coal use.
He was born in Tunnelton, W.Va., and graduated from West Virginia University.
He is survived by his wife, Sheri; two sons, Edwin Jr. and Kevin; his mother, Mrs. Harrison Fuller of Keyser, W.Va., and a sister, Carolyn Sue Wiles of Kansas City, Mo.
