HEADLINE: U.S. Urged to Lift Its Embargo in Cuba

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 10

 BODY:
A group of Latin American and Caribbean presidents urged the United States today to lift its economic embargo of Cuba and called for a peaceful transition to democracy there.
The leaders of the Rio Group of presidents also issued a statement urging the military government of Haiti to step down in order to avoid an American-led invasion. 
 The presidents said in a statement at the end of the 14-country Rio Group Summit that they were anxious to increase their contacts with Cuba and to incorporate it fully into the hemispheric community.
The Rio Group countries "consider indispensable a peaceful transition towards a democratic and pluralist system in Cuba that will respect human rights and freedom of opinion, that is consonant with the popular will," the statement said.

HEADLINE: China Warns U.S. on Relations With Taiwan

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 10

 BODY:
China registered another "strong protest" today over the Clinton Administration's decision to upgrade unofficial ties with Taiwan, warning that Taiwan was a potentially "explosive issue."
A senior Foreign Ministry official summoned Ambassador J. Stapleton Roy and accused Washington of "taking steps" to create "two Chinas, or one China, one Taiwan," and said this would not only stall the development of relations but would also lead to their deterioration. 
 "We demand that the U.S. Government approach the question of Taiwan with every seriousness and caution," the official, Deputy Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu, said in remarks carried on the official New China News Agency.
Mr. Liu accused Washington of "gross interference in China's internal affairs" and of infringing upon China's sovereignty, saying, "This represents a major retrogression of the United States policy on the question of Taiwan, which will entail grave consequences."
Western diplomats here have nevertheless argued that China's warning does not portend a serious rift in relations. Indeed, for the last several weeks, the Chinese leadership has been questioning American officials to determine what it will take for President Clinton to make a state visit to Beijing as a sign that relations are improving.
Beijing's Taiwan strategy appears to be one of stepping up diplomatic pressure to counter the recent successes of Taipei in winning greater recognition for its economic power.
China immediately protested on Wednesday when the Administration announced a series of modest upgrades in the unofficial relationship that has existed between Washington and Taipei since formal diplomatic ties were severed in 1979 with the recognition of the People's Republic of China. Mr. Clinton, who traveled to Taiwan five times before he became President, has reaffirmed the "one China" policy that American Presidents have adhered to since 1949.
At the core of the dispute over Taiwan are American military sales, most prominently the sale of F-16's that President Bush approved in the middle of his re-election campaign.
This year Beijing told Washington that it would not discuss the issue of missile technology assistance for Pakistan until Washington agreed to high-level discussions on military sales to Taiwan. The State Department's third ranking diplomat, Peter Tarnoff, the Under Secretary for Political Affairs, is expected to arrive in Beijing next week for talks.

HEADLINE: Primary Tests Strength of Troubled Party

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Two months after winning the Democratic Party's endorsement for his bid to become Connecticut's next governor, John B. Larson is waiting to see what that support is worth.
Mr. Larson, the president pro tem of the State Senate, is facing a tough primary election on Tuesday against an insurgent candidate, State Comptroller William E. Curry Jr. The two men have approached the contest with different strategies, and the election has turned into something of a bellwether of the future of the state's Democratic Party. 
 Mr. Curry, whose base is the liberal wing of the party, has spent months building an independent field operation, identifying voters who support him, repeatedly calling them through phone banks and preparing to get them to polls. A longtime critic of the party, he has used his campaign to call for its overhaul.
In contrast, Mr. Larson has concentrated on raising money and saturating the airwaves with television commercials describing his effectiveness as the leader of the Democratic-controlled State Legislature. An elected official who proudly wraps himself in the party's tradition, he is counting on Democratic town committees and the campaign organizations of elected officials to get out the vote for him on Tuesday.
"If Curry wins, the lesson will be that the organized Democratic Party has no life in it any more -- that it can't produce any votes," David McQuade, a top adviser to Mr. Larson, said recently.
 
Four Years After Setback
 The campaign comes four years after the Democrats suffered one of their worst setbacks in state history. After holding the governor's office for 16 years and dominating state politics for decades, the party ran a candidate in 1990 -- Bruce Morrison, a former United States Representative -- who received a little more than 20 percent of the vote.
The dismal showing was largely attributable to the presence of Lowell P. Weicker Jr., an almost legendary figure in Connecticut politics, who won the election as the candidate of a new third party, A Connecticut Party. Democrats have acknowledged that the defeat was aggravated by dissension in the party and the failure of the party organization to mobilize effectively behind Mr. Morrison.
 
A Different Race
 This year's race is very different from 1990's. Mr. Weicker is not seeking re-election, and A Connecticut Party's candidate is Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, who lacks Mr. Weicker's political stature and has not yet demonstrated an ability to raise money. The Republican candidate will be the winner of Tuesday's primary between Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer and John Rowland, a former Representative who was the candidate in 1990 and is considered the front-runner in both the primary and general election.
While Mr. Curry and Mr. Larson have said they would avoid the pitfalls Mr. Morrison encountered, the two have different ideas of what those pitfalls were, and their campaigns reflect those perceptions.
Mr. Larson said in an interview a few weeks ago that Mr. Morrison ran into trouble because he was viewed as a "programmatic liberal" challenging the three-term Democratic Governor, William A. O'Neill, who ultimately decided not to run. In Mr. Larson's view, this cost Mr. Morrison the support of some party stalwarts and of conservative Democrats, who felt comfortable voting for Mr. Weicker, a former Republican Senator known for moderate views.
Mr. Morrison's problems were worsened by his difficulty in raising money and getting his message out, Mr. Larson added.
Since declaring his candidacy in April 1993, Mr. Larson has put much of his energy into raising $1.4 million and has spent more than $500,000 on commercials to portray him as a likable moderate Democrat. The ads highlight his support for anti-crime measures like a more broadly applied death penalty, his opposition to the income tax and his success in achieving social service legislation, like the Family Medical Leave Act and a bill expanding immunization for children.
 
Seeking Name Recognition
 Polls found that this approach increased Mr. Larson's favorable name recognition, which could be helpful in November's general election against the expected Republican opponent, Mr. Rowland, already is well known from 1990. The ads are also credited with giving Mr. Larson a 2-to-1 edge over Mr. Curry in polls of registered Democrats.
But the problem for Mr. Larson is that the commercials have less impact on the primary, in which only a small percentage -- as little as 20 percent -- is expected to vote. As a result, the primary may be decided by the candidates' ability to get supporters to the polls.
Mr. Larson is depending on the party organization and the campaign operations of other Democratic elected officials, particularly the mayors of the largest cities, to bring out the vote on his behalf on Tuesday.
Anthony V. Avallone, a member of the Democratic National Committee and a former State Senator who supports Mr. Larson, said: "The trend in campaigns in recent years has been to be candidate oriented, to run things out of the headquarters of candidates. There's been a diminution of reliance on the party. John is trying to change that. He got the party endorsement and feels it's important. He's going to rely on his organization to supplement the existing party organization."
But Mr. Curry's supporters say that the existing party machine no longer can pull votes, and they say that other elected officials such as the mayors are not going to be able to convert the personal allegiance of their own constituencies into votes for Mr. Larson.
"They have no grass-roots campaign," Mr. Curry recently told a group of supporters to resounding applause.
Instead, it is necessary to build a new organization to replace the old party apparatus, Mr. Curry said, and for months his campaign has concentrated on assembling a coalition of unions, citizens' groups and environmental groups to identify his supporters and line them up to vote.
The strategy reflects Mr. Curry's belief that the previous Democratic candidate, Mr. Morrison, faltered not because of his criticisms of the policies of his party's control of the state government, but because he did not distance himself enough from an administration that ran up a $1 billion deficit.
 
'A Whole Bunch of Negatives'
 "Morrison transferred a whole bunch of negatives onto himself," Mr. Curry said. "It's unfortunate, because he was not really of that crowd, but he got all the negatives of Bill O'Neill and never had a chance to shake them off."
Throughout the campaign, Mr. Curry, who as Comptroller and as a State Senator from 1979 to 1983 often clashed with party leaders, has cast himself as an outsider who would shake up the established order.
Mr. Curry has raised $845,000 and put most of the money into developing his field operation.
Despite these different approaches, the two candidates agree on many issues, from hiring more police officers to expanding day-care services to revamping the state's economic development department to place greater emphasis on providing assistance to small businesses.
The two disagree in their approaches to cutting taxes, with Mr. Larson giving priority to reducing the income tax and Mr. Curry favoring a lightening of the property tax burden. They also part ways over state approval for a casino in Bridgeport, with Mr. Larson in favor and Mr. Curry opposed.
But in five debates, the two have discussed these and other issues amicably, and the race has been devoid of the personal attacks that many had expected. Even the state Republican chairman, John Mastropietro, commended them on running such a "gentlemanly" campaign, though adding that their congeniality made the race somewhat boring.
It appears that both candidates recognize that whoever wins on Tuesday will need the other's support. While they may have clashing views on the party's future, they remain loyal Democrats committed to a party victory in November, and have already discussed how to proceed on Wednesday.
Martha Carlson, Mr. Larson's campaign manager, said, "Regardless of who wins Tuesday, we will be united in either headquarters the next day."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
More Talks, Same Result: No Progress

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The flame of optimism that flickered among some union people 24 hours earlier quickly dissipated on the 30th day of the baseball players strike yesterday as the union chief charged that the owners don't want an agreement unless the players bow to their will.
Representatives of the two sides held three bargaining sessions on two different matters but made no progress on the salary cap issue that divides them and threatens to force cancellation of the last three weeks of the season and the World Series. 
 No further talks were scheduled, though at the conclusion of the second meeting on the core economic issue, John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox indicated that perhaps the parties should meet again tomorrow or Tuesday. By then or Wednesday at the latest, however, Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, is expected to announce he is calling off major league baseball for 1994.
Neither Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, nor Richard Ravitch, the clubs' chief labor executive, attended any of the sessions. Ravitch was a spectator at the United States Open tennis tournament while Fehr engaged in first a physical, then a verbal workout.
"They're engaging in a show for public relations sake," Fehr said in a telephone interview after he worked out at a Manhattan hotel exercise room. "They have no interest in making a deal. Bud has no interest in making a deal. He got the idea in his head that players have to do what the owners want. They're going to teach us a lesson. That's what Bud's doing."
Later, at a news briefing, Fehr was asked what he would tell the players executive board when it convenes tomorrow in New York.
"I'll tell them," Fehr said, "they have to take the position that spring training is in jeopardy, and if it goes past the end, the owners are counting on breaking them in the spring or May or June."
Selig was back in Milwaukee. He flew to New York Friday and joined the talks long enough to reject the players' tax plan for revenue sharing. He then flew home Friday evening.
"Bud is teaching children a lesson," Fehr said. "This is plain old-fashioned garden variety union-busting. They want to see if they can starve the players out. There's nothing else there."
 
Refusing to Discuss Plan
 Fehr was clearly disgusted at the refusal of the owners even to discuss the players' tax concept. After imploring union officials for months to make a counterproposal to their salary cap plan, the owners dismissed it out of hand, saying the tax on payrolls and revenues did nothing to contain the growth of player salaries.
Speaking by telephone from his office, Selig said Fehr's comments disappointed him.
"If anybody thinks this is anything preordained and we had a plan, that is just sheer and utter nonsense. Were there firm convictions that the system needed to be changed? Yes. Were we willing to discuss that? Yes. There's no sense in getting into a debate about who's being intransigent."
The outbreak of angry words in place of negotiated progress came as no surprise in a dispute that has created rigid positions on both sides and threatens to do irreparable damage to major league baseball and relations between labor and management.
The owners have said they don't have to have a salary cap but cited the lack of a cap in the players' tax concept as they rejected it. The players, who want to retain the existing free-market system of determining salaries, budged slightly in devising their plan but clearly were not willing to place too great a restriction on the salaries they might earn.
 
Fehr Hints at Betrayal
 Because their plan emerged from conversations with Jerry McMorris, owner of the Colorado Rockies, union officials, who had to persuade players on the negotiating subcommittee to approve the plan, thought the owners at least would be willing to consider it and negotiate from it.
Some union people also thought they saw signs from some members of management Friday that indicated there was some hope for a settlement. But, in his comments yesterday, Fehr almost sounded betrayed.
"On the few occasions when someone said we have to try to work something out," he said, "it was clearly a joke, their authority was stripped or they never had any."
Curiously, McMorris was not one of the owners who attended the economic session yesterday.
"I wasn't asked," he said before returning to Denver. "I'm sure I probably could have asked myself in, but I made it clear that I'll be available by phone and can be back as quick as I'm needed."
Harrington, Stan Kasten of Atlanta and Wendy Selig-Prieb of Milwaukee met in the morning with three union lawyers and four players. Their discussion centered on revenue-sharing ideas. The tax concept was not discussed in great detail.
That meeting lasted for about two hours. Reduced teams met later in the afternoon for an hour.
In another morning session, Chuck O'Connor, general counsel of the clubs' labor relations committee, and Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, led bargaining on other elements of the expired collective bargaining agreement. They reached agreement on nothing.
At the morning session on revenue sharing, the two sides discussed the amount of money the owners' revenue-sharing plan would send from high-revenue clubs to low-revenue clubs. The owners have said that amount was $70 million and made a big issue out of the fact that the players' tax plan would produce only $50 million for the same purpose.
But, one of the participants on the players' side said, the owners acknowledged that if their salary cap proposal were plugged into their revenue-sharing plan using the clubs' pre-strike financial projections for 1994, the amount to be distributed would be more like $60 million.
Selig said yesterday he was "startled" that the players "would come in with considerably less," citing the $70 million to $50 million difference. Asked if he thought the owners might have been able to get the union to raise its total by raising the rate of tax on club payrolls, he said, "I don't know."
The owners obviously had no desire to find out.

HEADLINE: Retired Executives Aid Nonprofit Sector

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Out of Retirement Life, and Back Into the Fire" (The Executive Life, Aug. 14) makes no mention of the National Executive Service Corps, a sister organization of the International Executive Corps. 
 The N.E.S.C.'s volunteer retired senior executives provide pro bono management consulting services to not-for-profits in the arts, health care, education and social services -- unlike the for-profit clients of the retired executives being recruited by search firms and the Agency for International Development.
The Agency for International Development, an arm of the State Department and financed by taxpayers, directs its efforts toward political ends only, and at times seems to be working against the very taxpayers who support it.
I have had experience as an independent consultant working in Central America and witnessed the efforts of the Agency for International Development to entice United States companies to shift work from United States plants to Central American companies (for-profit organizations), to the detriment of the American workers whose jobs were eliminated. This effort was purely political to create jobs as a bulwark against communism. Should public money be used to support private enterprise here or abroad?
The N.E.S.C. offers critically needed management experience to the not-for-profit sector and is financed by foundations, corporations and individuals. It needs and deserves support and recognition.
 
ROBERT J. DAVIS
Manhattan, Aug. 15
 
The writer is a retired senior executive and is now a volunteer consultant with several not-for-profit organizations.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Some Movement in Midst of Strike: Talk of a Rival League

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
If major league baseball is prepared to fade from 1994 without a World Series, maybe it's ready for another new and unusual development: a new rival league. The baseball establishment hasn't had one since the Federal League lived briefly 80 years ago.
Given the monthlong strike that is on the verge of wiping out the rest of the baseball year and the prospect of a continued shutdown into next season, talk has stirred about the resuscitation of a plan that was looked at but didn't remain viable five years ago. A replacement league could be on the horizon. 
 "I've had many inquiries, and I'm convinced there are many well-established, capable people out there who would love to be involved in the baseball industry," said Richard Moss, who as general counsel of the players union for its first 10 years successfully took on the owner establishment in landmark cases.
"It's not a unique idea," he added. "Other people have talked about it. I don't know if anyone else is working on it. I think the players could be ready to play next April. That's all it takes."
When Donald Fehr, head of the players union, was asked about a new league, he said: "We'll have to look at any and all options. I haven't looked at anything yet."
 
From Delay to Cancellation
 Moss was a founder of the Baseball League, a venture that became a victim of circumstances in 1989 after a promising planning phase. Moss and his partner, David LeFevre, a New York lawyer, who also had connections to major league baseball, had lined up owners for eight teams and initially planned to begin play in 1990 but delayed the debut until 1991, then canceled their plans altogether.
"Collusion was over and players were being signed to long-term contracts," Moss said, explaining the problems the Baseball League encountered. "The economy went into serious decline, and real estate people were losing. A lot of the people in our venture were real estate people."
There also was the Donald factor.
Donald Trump was going to be one of the eight owners. "I have agreed to become a part of it," Trump said in August 1989, "to work with them and make this league a great success."
Meshulam Riklis, a friend of Trump and husband of Pia Zadora, was also set to own a team. But when the owners met in New York to plan the announcement of the creation of the league, Trump and Riklis did not show up. Shortly after the meeting began, their aides arrived and announced to the other owners and the founders that Trump and Riklis didn't think the league was ready to proceed to the next step.
 
Momentum Is Lost
 Their vacillation turned a stick of dynamite into a water-soaked firecracker. The league lost its momentum and never recovered.
But now Moss sees "another window of opportunity approaching, like a locomotive at full speed." To pick up speed, though, the train needs passengers in the form of players. Where would they come from? To a large extent from the existing major leagues, Moss suggested.
He classified major league players by their contract status:
*Those eligible for free agency or are released, not tendered contracts or not offered salary arbitration as one-time free agents with repeater restrictions. "They're clearly free," Moss said, estimating that 250 players would fit into that category.
*Those signed to multiyear contracts. Moss said their availability would have to be determined through litigation. "It will come down to how the owners' action is perceived," Moss said. "If they deliberately tried to create this situation and have not negotiated in good faith, there's a possibility you could get players out of those contracts."
*Those with less than six years of major league service and not eligible for free agency. "They would have to be litigated," Moss said, "but the only thing holding them is the reserve system. My view is the reserve system is an internal system, holding them to a club so they can't go to another in the system. It has nothing to do with another system."
If those players were added to a prospective player list, Moss said, about 550 would be free to move.
 
50 Percent Equity
 Besides maybe having the only game in town, Moss's new league may offer players another inducement: 50 percent equity, a 50 percent share of the profits and a 50 percent share in the decision-making process.
"If you ask players how they feel about a new system, a new league," said Moss, who also serves as an agent for players, "if my sampling is representative, you'll find 98 percent enthusiasm."
But a new league wouldn't be interested only in major league players, Moss added.
"We're not above considering some of the people presently involved in major league baseball," he said, meaning owners. "I can see a significant and profitable role Ted Turner could play, for example."
He didn't mention Donald Trump.
 
Don't Defend Cap, Miller Says
 Marvin Miller, the first leader of the baseball players union, has long been a critic of the players union in the National Football League. He never was impressed with the leadership of Ed Garvey in the 1970's, and he doesn't think much of the job Gene Upshaw did in taking his members under a salary cap. He also doesn't go for Upshaw's spirited defense of the cap.
"I realize they had a difficult situation," Miller said, referring to the football union's effort to gain meaningful free agency, "but be honest about it. Don't try to make a virtue out of a sin."
 
Warning-Track Power
 In an abbreviated season in which an average of 2.07 home runs were hit per game, Otis Nixon of Boston didn't hit one home run in 398 times at bat. No other hitter comes close for over-the-wall futility. Nixon is not new to this sort of thing. In 1991, playing for Atlanta, he went 401 at-bats without a home run. Last year he hit one home run in 461 at-bats.
Rey Sanchez of the Chicago Cubs has the second most at-bats, 291, without a home run this year. Last season he finished with none in 344 at-bats.
 
Tigers the Latest to Drop Hints
 It seems like every other team has used the Tampa Bay area as a threat so the Detroit Tigers might as well do it, too.
The Tigers, who are trying to induce the Michigan Legislature to help build a new stadium, apparently have made inquiries about the domed stadium in St. Petersburg and the Tampa Bay area. The club says it wants to stay in Detroit, but well, you never know.
By actual count, the Tigers would be the eighth team to try to move to the west coast of Florida or at least hint it might go there. The Giants came closest to actually making the move, leaving their hearts and bats in San Francisco in 1992 only after local owners stepped in and bought the team from Bob Lurie.
Earlier that year, Tampa Bay thought it might get the Seattle Mariners, but a Japanese-led group wound up buying the team from Jeff Smulyan.
In 1988, the Chicago White Sox appeared to be on their way to becoming the St. Petersburg White Sox until the Illinois Legislature, in a last-minute vote, agreed to build a new stadium in Chicago.
Later that year, a Tampa Bay group thought it had a deal to buy the Texas Rangers from Eddie Chiles, but a group of Texas investors came through with a deal that kept the Rangers at home.
In 1984, Tampa Bay investors bought 42 percent of the Minnesota Twins in anticipation of getting the team and moving it, but baseball officials persuaded them to sell the minority interest to Carl Pohlad with the promise they would be seriously considered for an expansion team.
The Oakland Athletics were the next target, in 1985, but the Athletics gained concessions from the Oakland mayor and stayed home.
In 1991, the area was a finalist for a National League expansion team, but the leading investors pulled out at a late hour, undermining any chance Tampa Bay had of getting a franchise.
The area has become so jaded that talk of the Tigers' interest, no matter how preliminary, has not generated much excitement.
 
Statistical Achievements
 Stats Inc. is one of those outfits concocting fantasy games for Rotisserie league types who need their daily fix of box score lines. But the statistical service is far more informative when it researches real live numbers and determines the significance of league offensive achievements this year.
The 10.45 runs per game scored by American League teams, for example, rank seventh in league history. The league's .273 batting average is its highest since 1939. The National League's .267 average is also its best since the same season.
 
At the Tone, Leave a Rhyme
 Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, uses a rhyming message to entertain callers to his home who get his answering machine. Changing the rhymes monthly, he offers this message for September:
This September's a month to dislike
What with players still forced out on strike
Yeah, and if you don't think
That the clubs caused this stink
At the tone you can go take a hike.

HEADLINE: Airport Fiasco Hastens New York's Decline

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The proposed multibillion-dollar monorail system between Kennedy International Airport and Manhattan's Upper East Side, which promises years of gridlock to go with its extravagant price tag while construction goes on and over the country's most crowded highways, is just the latest ploy by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to avoid providing a connection between our airports and the central city.
The Port Authority has been under a mandate to connect Kennedy and Newark Airports with this city by rail since 1962. This mandate is not a suggestion; it is the law. 
 Existing rights of way and existing high-speed rail lines could provide service directly to Pennsylvania Station, in both cases requiring a minimum of capital or disruption of the surrounding residential, industrial or highway environment, as well as direct connection to much of the region's transit system. Indeed, even La Guardia Airport is close to and easily connected with such a rail line.
Such practical action has never been and never will be pursued by the Port Authority. The agency's bondholders have an aversion to its undertaking any rail or transit project. New York and New Jersey codified this impediment to the Port Authority's usefulness by limiting its responsibility for rail projects beyond the PATH system to the two airport links.
This is the second absurdly expensive, environmentally disruptive and impractical airport connection project submitted by the Port Authority. The first was to serve Newark Airport by extending the PATH system to Plainfield, N.J. That extension beyond the airport, which would have inexplicably paralleled an existing commuter line, was not built.
From its success in avoiding build
ing any Newark Airport connection, the Port Authority knows an extravagant, impractical and disruptive airport connection will be soundly vetoed. It also knows the debate will exhaust proponents of a rational transit link, who will spend energy defeating such an absurd proposal. Voters and state officials will have little fight left to get the Port Authority to perform the task in any practical way.
The Port Authority will shrug its bureaucratic shoulders and blame New York for the continued isolation of its airports. Such air traffic as remains the Port Authority will move to Newark to join the port, removed to Newark Bay in the 1950's. As with the port, most of the country's international traffic will go elsewhere.
By avoiding its mandates, the Port Authority has thus presided over the dissolution of the port and industrial collapse of the city and of the region. Its inaction has produced the worst congestion in the country, the second highest levels of air pollution, the highest rates of unemployment and the least desirable site for industrial investment in the Western world.
Indeed it has made the greatest natural port in the Americas a maritime relic soon to be a commercial desert. Our airports are now following this pattern. This latest proposal should be taken as the final insult to this region's residents and a signal that the Port Authority should be dissolved.
 
JOHN F. MCHUGH
New York, Sept. 6, 1994
 
The writer is a lawyer with a particular interest in transportation.

HEADLINE: Every U.S. Interest Is at Stake in Haiti

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I believe the United States does indeed have compelling interests in restoring the democratically elected government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power in Haiti.
There is a strategic interest. The situation in Haiti cannot last. It is ripe for bloody revolt, and who knows what forces could come to power in such a crisis? It is clearly in the interests of the United States to prevent overtly anti-American factions from replacing the junta. 
 There is an economic interest. Haiti is an economic cipher, unable to buy or sell anything of real value. A stable, democratic Haiti, developing economically, could be a lively trade partner of the United States, bringing profit to both countries.
There is a political interest. If we expect democratic forces around the world to risk their lives transforming their countries into liberal democracies, we must demonstrate that we will stay with them when the going gets tough. The eyes of democrats worldwide are focused on Haiti.
Strategically, economically and politically, restoring democracy to Haiti is important to the United States. That should be enough to warrant effective action, military if need be.
However, there is also a moral imperative. Haitians are suffering unbelievably for the sin of choosing democracy. Rape, imprisonment, torture and murder are being visited daily on our democratic friends there because they are our friends. We can no longer turn a deaf ear to their cries for help.
 
EDWARD C. SULLIVAN
Member of Assembly, 69th Dist.
Albany, Sept. 7, 1994

HEADLINE: Rosa Parks Leads Again on Civil Rights

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I take exception to your Sept. 1 editorial and Bob Herbert's Sept. 4 column, commenting on the mugging of the civil rights heroine Rosa Parks.
Mr. Herbert says "we are in the dark night of the post-civil rights era" and "have disgraced the legacy of Rosa Parks." He lays responsibility for ending the violence in urban slums upon the new leadership of the African-American community, who should "recapture the high ground" taken by Mrs. Parks and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. when they originated the nonviolent civil rights movement in 1955. 
 Is it not asking too much of a people abused for centuries, and still deprived of the economic means to realize the equality promised by the civil rights movement, to continue to take the "high ground"? What about the role of the white community?
What position has the majority of white Americans taken on ending crime? For the crime bill to pass, crime prevention funds had to be cut. When Congress passed the "Move to Opportunity" law, suburban white communities (in Baltimore County, for example), objected to sharing their socially healthy environment with as few as 285 black families.
It is the poverty in America's slums that creates the breeding ground for crime. It is the greed that motivates the drug kingpins that makes junkies out of black youth.
Dr. King saw the handwriting on the wall when he began the March on Poverty in 1968. Some, like Myles Horton, Mrs. Parks's Highlander Folk School teacher, and mine, have wondered aloud whether Dr. King's assassination wasn't linked to his move to fight for economic rights for African-Americans. His step was the logical sequel to the civil rights movement -- the earthy ground that needs to be taken by the new black leaders.
Had Dr. King lived and the movement for economic rights continued, it is quite possible that the vicious violence of our times would not have developed. This is the significance of Rosa Parks's victimization by a violent black man. There is a connection between the positive zeitgeist of the civil rights movement she initiated and the present "mean and violent zeitgeist that is at work in our country." Rosa Parks once again awakens our national consciousness to the need for wide-reaching social change.
Frail yet strong she is the symbol of the unfinished civil rights movement.
 
ALEINE AUSTIN
Baltimore, Sept. 7, 1994
 
The writer retired as professor of American history at Western Maryland College.

HEADLINE: The French Keep Africa Under Wing

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Nine months after France, as a spur to economic reform, devalued a West African currency it had long supported, foreign businessmen and diplomats say that Paris is sending ambivalent signals to its former colonies over their efforts to open up to more international investment and trade.
Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France has said the devaluation was an attempt to reinsert Africa "in the grand commercial currents of the world." The International Monetary Fund and others had called for a devaluation of the currency, the African franc, which is used by 11 countries in the region. 
 But while France has urged the countries to open their economies, many people here say that it has shown little willingness to make room for other influences in an area where its hold remains powerful after more than three decades of independence.
 
French Presence Remains
 France's reach in its former colonial empire can be seen in everything from the symbolic to the concrete. In countries like Ivory Coast, Senegal and Gabon, boulevards are named for every French president since de Gaulle and French troops train their African counterparts and serve as the ultimate republican guard.
Throughout this region, experts sent from Paris supervise services from the police to the postal service. And until Mr. Balladur recently put a stop to the practice, timely French financial assistance helped assure stability by paying civil servants when governments were hard pressed to meet payrolls.
And decades of carefully cultivated ties and oversight of African affairs have meant that French companies were almost certain to enjoy a decisive leg up whenever major international contracts were being awarded.
 
Private Reserve
 In international business circles, France's advantages in its former African colonies earned this region the reputation of being Paris's chasse gardee, or private game reserve.
The exchange rate for the African franc, fixed at a value of 50 to 1 against the French currency from 1948 until its value was cut in half early this year, gave Paris another strong commercial advantage over other exporters to this region.
Since the devaluation, however, Paris has grown anxious as West Africans have begun scrambling in search of the best deal, rather than automatically looking to France. "The days when all roads ran through the former metropolis are over," wrote the French daily Liberation.
 
Protecting Markets
 Hoping to protect long-cozy markets, the French have been scrambling. In an effort to head off African pharmacists seeking medicines from lower-cost suppliers in Europe and Asia, for example, the French Government recently began encouraging the export of generic medicines to the continent for the first time.
Businessmen and diplomats in Ivory Coast and elsewhere tell of mysterious port delays holding up the arrival of new Canadian telecommunications gear and discreet political intervention from Paris urging that a major cocoa trading concern here not be sold into American hands.
No recent case has drawn more attention than that of an independent American oil company, United Meridian, which in March discovered enough oil and natural gas offshore here to meet this country's fuel needs, and perhaps eventually allow it to become a small exporter.
 
French Challenge
 A French group led by the civil engineering company Bouygues had rights to an adjacent field, and nurtured hopes of building a pipeline to the coast, where it would install turbines to generate electricity from the natural gas offshore. Bouygues, which already controls the national electricity and water companies, and is believed to be interested in Ivory Coast's telephone business as well, has long enjoyed close ties to the Ivorian political elite and diplomatic support from Paris.
"We felt we could negotiate with them and sell them gas from our well, which was ready to produce," said Steve Thornton, director of United Meridian's Ivory Coast operations. "Their response was, 'Thank you, but you have no right to exploit gas in the Ivory Coast.' "
Several people with knowledge of the dispute said that what ensued was a fullcourt press by the French company, supported by France's diplomatic machine, aimed at shoving the American company out of the picture. Ivory Coast's new President, Henri Konan Bedie , was invited to Paris as one of a select few foreign guests to review French troops on Bastille Day. "Had this deal gone sour, I think it would have been the kiss of death for American interest in this country," a Western diplomat said.
In the end, United Meridian won out over its French rival, but not before what many said was rare support from the State Department and Energy Department in Washington. Also not before Bouygues was itself awarded a contract to go ahead with its gas turbines, which will be fueled from the American-developed field.
"Its kind of like an empty-nest syndrome," one diplomat here said of France's protective actions. "Your child is finally going away to college. You know that's what's best for him, but you just can't deal with it."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 13, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about West Africa misstated the number of countries in the region that use the CFA franc as their currency. It is 13, not 11.

HEADLINE: MANHATTAN MINUTE . . .

 BODY:
FAIR'S FAIR: The city decides to turn the huge shell on Piers 35 and 36 near the Manhattan Bridge -- the site abandoned for a fueling station after a "fair share" fight -- into a youth center and a garage for the neighborhood's sanitation trucks . . . HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Restored Tibetan Palace Opens Amid Controversy

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
AFTER a five-year restoration that has drawn protests from human-rights groups and Tibetan dissidents, the Potala Palace in Lhasa, among the holiest structures in Tibet and the former home of the Dalai Lama, reopened to tourists last month.
The $7 million restoration of the 17th-century hilltop palace is the centerpiece of the Chinese Government's campaign to expand tourism in Tibet, the "Rooftop of the World," which China invaded in 1950 and later annexed. 
 Government leaders have talked of increasing tourism threefold in Tibet, which remains one of the most impoverished regions of China. About 23,000 foreign tourists, many of them Western mountaineers seeking to explore the Himalayas, visited Tibet last year.
Tibet has been periodically shaken by violent anti-Chinese protests since the 1950's, and the spiritual leader of the nation, the Dalai Lama, has lived in exile since 1959,
when he fled after a failed uprising against Beijing.
Human-rights groups have documented widespread abuses in Tibet, and they have suggested that attempts to revive the Tibetan economy through tourism are really an effort by the Chinese to entice non-Tibetans to settle there, in hopes of diluting the political and cultural influence of native Tibetans.
Dissidents have also suggested that the restoration is a Chinese ploy to insure that the 13-story, 1,000-room palace is never again used as a staging area for protests by Tibetan nationalists and dissident monks.
The Chinese Government has acknowledged that the restoration team installed an elaborate security system in the palace, including closed-circuit surveillance cameras and alarms, to protect it from "hooligans."
"We get a lot of reports from Tibetans who are very uncomfortable about this project," said Robert Barnett, director of the Tibet Information Network, a London-based human-rights group. "We hear reports that valuable objects have disappeared from the palace during the restoration, that murals have been damaged."
The Chinese insist that nothing of value has been removed or damaged.
Whatever their concern that tourism tends to bolster Chinese control, major human-rights groups do not discourage foreign travelers from visiting Tibet.
Because reporters are generally barred from visiting the region, foreign tourists and business people provide the best -- and often the only -- means of getting information in and out. "I think the Tibetans would be quite worried if there weren't any tourism," said Mr. Barnett.
That has produced its own set of problems for foreign visitors, who occasionally find themselves the victims of intense police surveillance during visits to Tibet.
In June, two American tourists on a group tour were detained by the Chinese police in Shigatse, Tibet's second-largest city, and interrogated for four days after they gave a monk a tape-recording of a speech by the Dalai Lama.
According to the two Americans, their passports were confiscated, their room was searched and two other copies of the tape and seven photographs of the exiled Tibetan leader were impounded by the Chinese police before the Americans were deported to Nepal.
As part of its campaign to increase tourism to Tibet, the Chinese Government announced last month that it would ease visa restrictions for visitors wishing to enter Tibet directly from Nepal.
In preparation for a tourist influx, the Chinese Government has also completed a $30 million restoration of the Gongkar Airport in Lhasa, the capital, by expanding the runway to allow jumbo jets to land, and is trying to encourage major hotel chains to consider building international-standard hotels in Lhasa and elsewhere. Tourists to Tibet will find international standards of comfort in only one hotel, a Holiday Inn in Lhasa.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST RIVER PARK: The Ups and Downs (and Ups) of a 57-Acre Dream Park;
Decrepit Stage Becomes Tragedy Itself

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
On a mild summer night in 1956, Joseph Papp presented "Julius Caesar" against the backdrop of the East River and the Williamsburg Bridge.
The following year, the New York Shakespeare Festival found a home in Central Park, but the East River Park Amphitheater went on to even greater glory, as the site of free Evenings-by-the-River, a summer concert series that drew several personal appearances by its honorary chairwoman, Eleanor Roosevelt. 
 But for much of its 50-year history, the 2,500-seat amphitheater has stood empty. Today it is a hulking wreck, piled with rubble, cast-off clothing, plastic containers and rusty car parts, waiting for demolition or a miracle.
The open concrete theater was built in 1941 as part of an urban renewal project for the Lower East Side, said Jonathan Kuhn, the curator of monuments and historian for the Parks Department. In addition to the bandshell and stage, there was a limestone recreation building with space for theatrical productions, sometimes used when open-air events were rained out.
But the amphitheater was rarely used until the 1950's, said Mr. Kuhn. Then, not only did Papp and Mrs. Roosevelt use it, but local schools found it perfect for their graduation exercises, and the Group of Ancient Drama gave free performances of the Greek classics.
In 1973, faced with worsening budget problems, the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay closed the amphitheater, turning it from a town hall into a vandals' target. There was no budget for maintenance to stop the site's deterioration.
There was a glimmer of hope in the early 80's. First, the East River Park Amphitheater Restoration Corporation, a coalition of neighborhood groups, obtained $15,000 in grants for a feasibility study, said the corporation's director, Rafael Jaquez, who now teaches at Columbia University's School of Public Health. The group landscaped the area and made pilot presentations of theater, dance and music in the amphitheater.
In 1981, Mr. Papp contributed $5,000 for cosmetic repairs, Mr. Jaquez said. At that time, the Board of Estimate allocated $1.5 million for capital improvement of the amphitheater, he said, but the Parks Department stipulated that local organizations be responsible for the yearly maintenance, about $300,000.
But the restoration group was unable to come up with the money, Mr. Jaquez said, and the capital financing was reallocated to other parks projects. In a last-ditch effort, when the theater itself was condemned, a few die-hard supporters staged performances on the lawn outside.
"Now we'd like them to level the recreation building and just keep the bandshell in a green space, with maybe some food concessions," Mr. Jaquez said. "But I'm afraid demolition costs almost as much as restoration today." M.H.

HEADLINE: Affairs Both Foreign and Domestic

BYLINE: By David M. Kennedy; David M. Kennedy teaches American history at Stanford University. His books include "Over Here: The First World War and American Society."

 BODY:

NO ORDINARY TIME
Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt:
The Home Front in World War II.
By Doris Kearns Goodwin.
Illustrated. 759 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $30. 
TWO great events convulsed American society in the middle decades of the 20th century: the New Deal and World War II. Taken together, they produced what Doris Kearns Goodwin rightly calls "the most profound social revolution in the country since the Civil War -- nothing less than the creation of modern America." Historians continue to argue about the relative importance of those two distinct developments in shaping the character of American life in the post-1945 era.
And behind that historical debate lurks a philosophical question about the relationship of will and fate: does conscious human striving, as represented in the deliberate policies of the New Deal, count for more in determining the human condition than unwilled events, like the war, that simply befall us? Are we the masters of our own souls or the creatures of historical forces beyond our control?
In "No Ordinary Time" Ms. Goodwin, who has explored some titanic individual wills in her previous books, "Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream" and "The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys," seems to agree with those scholars who see World War II as working even more far-reaching transformations in midcentury American life than the New Deal. Yet by employing the biographical approach she so artfully used in her previous books, she seeks to defend the importance of individual effort as well -- especially Eleanor Roosevelt's struggle to wring gains for social justice out of the turbulent changes on the war's home front. "No Ordinary Time" is an ambitiously conceived and imaginatively executed participants'-eye view of the United States in the war years, though at times the private lives of Ms. Goodwin's famous participants loom larger than the war itself.
"This book," Ms. Goodwin writes, "is the story of that home front, told through the lives of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt and the circle of friends and associates who lived with them in the family quarters of the White House during World War II." What a circle it was! At one or another time during the war the Roosevelt household sheltered Crown Princess Martha of Norway; Franklin's secretary, Marguerite (Missy) LeHand; the lend-lease administrator and all-purpose Roosevelt high factotum Harry Hopkins; Eleanor's sometime companion Lorena Hickok; and Joseph Lash, Eleanor's youthful wartime protege and later her worshipful biographer.
The complex geometry of their relationships gave to the wartime White House the air of a Borgia court, or perhaps an Ottoman seraglio. Ms. Goodwin opens one chapter with successive accounts of Franklin's intimacy with Missy LeHand; Eleanor's obsession with Joseph Lash; Eleanor's passionate friendship with the journalist Lorena Hickok; Franklin's trysts with Princess Martha; Hickok's infatuation with her new lesbian lover, and Hopkins's amorous pursuit of Louise Macy, a socialite. Scarcely missing a beat, the author effortlessly segues to a discussion of B-17 production and the Battle of Midway.
This kind of shuttling between public events and the innermost lives of her principals is at once a weakness and a strength of Ms. Goodwin's book. At times it threatens to submerge the sublime in the ridiculous, as the narrative snaps suddenly back and forth from historical documentary to salacious soap opera. But for the most part, the biographical technique serves her well. It yields exceptionally readable accounts of such potentially numbing subjects as wartime tax reform and labor disputes, and enlivens her analysis of topics ranging from military strategy, race relations and women's changing employment patterns to controversies over refugee policy and civilian versus military claims on economic production.
"No Ordinary Time" is no ordinary book. It rests on prodigious research in archival and oral history sources. "I treasure the details that emerged from these primary sources," Ms. Goodwin reports. She shares those details profligately with the reader, from descriptions of Franklin's dental bridge and Winston Churchill's bare backside to the contents of the wardroom lockers on the destroyers that the United States handed over to the British in 1940 in exchange for leases on North American base sites: "tinned asparagus, corn, chipped beef, clams, instant coffee, tomato juice and pumpkins." Indeed, the expression "lavish detail" is inadequate to describe this book's technique. It might better be described as relying on sumptuous detail, extravagant detail, rococo detail. So huge is the Niagara of facts that the reader braces when informed that some 6,000 registrants drew number 158 in the 1940 lottery for the country's first peacetime draft; mercifully, Ms. Goodwin names only 11 of them.
But despite its occasional excesses, "No Ordinary Time" provides an engrossing picture of the World War II era. The sheer abundance of colorful biographical anecdotes and the cumulative weight of telling detail sustain an atmosphere of immediacy and leave a lastingly vivid impression of what the war looked like from the perspective of some centrally involved participants.
No participants, of course, were more central to the drama than Eleanor and Franklin Roosevelt. Their story lies at the heart of Ms. Goodwin's account. Eleanor, "whose primary concern was the home front, not the war," appears in these pages as the voice of conscience, trying to preserve New Deal liberalism amid the urgent crises of the war. Franklin, preoccupied with diplomacy and strategy, is cast as the wily politico, bedding down for the duration with his erstwhile big-business adversaries and replacing "Dr. New Deal" with "Dr. Win-the-War," in his characteristically homey phrase.
Eleanor pressured Franklin to pursue more liberal policies toward European refugees, especially Jews fleeing the Holocaust. She championed the cause of labor. She spoke out on behalf of women in the war industries. She constantly pleaded with her husband to seek better treatment for black Americans, prompting Secretary of War Henry Stimson to condemn her "intrusive and impulsive folly." "I sometimes acted as a spur," Eleanor wrote in her autobiography, "This I Remember," "even though the spurring was not always wanted or welcome."
Nor was it always effective. Sometimes she successfully bent the President's ear, as in her pleas on behalf of black Americans; sometimes not, as in her failure to change refugee policy. Yet when she took stock of the massive transformations the war had occasioned -- opening new opportunities for women in the workplace, liberating millions of blacks from virtual peonage in the sleepy backwater of the Cotton Belt and fueling the explosive growth of the South and West -- Eleanor eventually acknowledged "that the nation had taken even greater strides toward social justice during the war than it had during the New Deal." It remains debatable, however, whether it was her conscientious spurring or simply the random disruptions of the war -- or Franklin's own initiative -- that made those strides possible.
"While Eleanor thought in terms of what should be done, Franklin thought in terms of what could be done," Ms. Goodwin writes. "She was more earnest, less devious, less patient, less fun, more uncompromisingly moral; he possessed the more trustworthy political talent, the more finely tuned sense of timing, the better feel for the citizenry, the smarter understanding of how to get things done."
This dichotomous image of Eleanor and Franklin can be overdone. Franklin needed little wifely encouragement, for example, to attend to the well-being of labor, the constituency on which his political fortunes largely rested. And Eleanor could at times lend herself to the most nakedly political of ploys, as when she agreed to Franklin's request that she intercede with the black labor leader A. Philip Randolph in the spring of 1941 to stop a march on Washington on behalf of equal employment opportunity in defense plants. "I was one of those," Eleanor concluded late in life about her relation with Franklin, "who served his purposes."
The bloody clashes on countless battlefields, the delicate dance of allied diplomacy, the struggles for military supremacy abroad and for economic production and social justice at home -- all these episodes are fetchingly and even brilliantly recounted in the pages of "No Ordinary Time." But as the book progresses, history yields to biography. In the end, the most intriguing thread in Ms. Goodwin's complex narrative fabric is the story of the Roosevelts' marriage; high public dramas recede into the background as the intimately personal story of Eleanor and Franklin grinds to its desolate conclusion. It is a tale that has been told before, but rarely with as much effect and poignancy as here.
FRANKLIN'S affair with Lucy Mercer during World War I had permanently altered the terms of the Roosevelts' marriage. Thereafter they were partners in politics but not companions of the heart. Much of the biographical material Ms. Goodwin has excavated documents the ceaseless strivings of both Roosevelts to fill their respective emotional voids. The wartime White House, she writes, was "the site of the irrepressible renewal of love and desire." Her portrait of Franklin is especially affecting. When his attachment to Missy LeHand (to whom he bequeathed half of his estate) was terminated by her illness, his dalliance with Princess Martha was ended and his friendship with Harry Hopkins was attenuated by Hopkins's marriage, he turned again to Eleanor. Ms. Goodwin touchingly describes two moments during the war, in 1942 and again in 1944, when Franklin "approached Eleanor with the idea that they should try once more to live as man and wife." But her "inability to forget" doomed Franklin's overtures to failure.
He resumed his liaison with Lucy Mercer, and it was she, not Eleanor, who was with him when he died at Warm Springs, Ga., on April 12, 1945. Jolted into a new self-awareness by Franklin's earlier infidelity, Eleanor had long since created a different, independent life for herself, and she would not abandon it. "Indeed," Ms. Goodwin writes, in a sobering conclusion about Eleanor's psychological priorities, "had she been given the choice between supplying the relaxation for her husband that Lucy was providing or summoning her powers to effect a change in the lives of Negro Americans, she would undoubtedly have chosen the latter."
In the final pages of this book, Franklin Roosevelt, broken in health, isolated as much by the history of his marriage as by the burdens of office, appears unspeakably lonely. So too does Eleanor. She still loved Franklin, Ms. Goodwin insists, but could no longer touch his soul, nor be touched by his. Even at the moment of his death, Eleanor confessed that she had "an almost impersonal feeling," which she attributed to the fact that "much further back I had had to face certain difficulties" -- a scarcely veiled reference to the old Lucy Mercer affair. "I was lost somewhere deep down inside myself," she wrote in her autobiography. The same might be said of Franklin. The constricting hand of history reached even here, to the inner cloisters of the heart.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Franklin D. Roosevelt with Harry and Louise Hopkins and his daughter Diana, houseguests at the White House in 1942. (ASSOCIATED PRESS)

HEADLINE: OUT THERE;
Vail's New Darwinians: Even Leisure Turns Pro

BYLINE: By ALEX MARKELS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: VAIL, Colo., Sept. 10

 BODY:
It was the quintessential Vail date. In a town where the skiing is the predominant social institution and dinner-and-a-movie evenings are rare, Mike Harvey invited his new flame, Lanell Avery, to compete on July 3 in the Vail Hill Climb, the annual 10-kilometer run that rises 3,000 grueling feet up the side of Vail Mountain. As usual, more than 600 residents, about a quarter of the town's permanent population, showed up to compete.
Mr. Harvey, 31, and his svelte companion jockeyed for a starting position at the front of the pack and began to jog. 
 "I haven't run in this big of a crowd in years," Mr. Harvey, who was competing in the race for the first time, said.
"The last time I did anything like this was the New York Marathon," Ms. Avery, a local entrepreneur, replied.
Mr. Harvey gulped. The New York Marathon? Though he works as a sales manager at Vail's chic Cascade Athletic Club and considers himself something of a hardbody, he suddenly envisioned his worst nightmare: getting dusted by his date. Pumping up his pride, he finished the race at her side, though thoroughly winded.
Romance is like everything else in this high-powered ski town. "If you can't keep up, don't bother showing up," said Kristen Coil, a resident whose choices in boyfriends lean heavily toward the toned and the fleet. "We work hard, we play hard and we party hard. A lot of people can't deal with that."
Unlike rival ski towns like nearby Aspen, whose past as an old silver mining town is integral to its hip image, Vail remained a sleepy backwater until the ski resort's founding by Vail Associates in 1960. That group has turned a valley inhabited by sheepherders and lettuce growers into the largest ski resort in Colorado. Originally dubbed "Shake 'n Bake Bavaria" for the fake Alpine architecture the founders used to fabricate an ambiance, Vail now defines itself by the competitive zeal its residents bring to nearly everything they do.
When the resort managers chose mountain biking as a way to attract more summer visitors, they immediately set about securing the sport's premier event, the World Mountain Bike Championships, which will begin on Tuesday and will continue through next Sunday on Vail Mountain. "Why go for the No. 2 event when we can go for No. 1?" said John Garnsey, who headed the campaign to secure the event for the Vail Valley Foundation, a private nonprofit group that promotes cultural and sports events. "Vailites want the best."
Nowhere is Vail's competitive bent more evident than in the successful campaign to bring in the 1999 World Alpine Skiing Championships, which is second only to the Winter Olympics as the most important ski-racing event. Going head-to-head with its more formal European rivals at the site-selection conference last spring in Rio de Janeiro, the Vail contingent -- including everyone from the town's Mayor to Vail Associates' chairman -- filled a promotional booth with cowboy gear and went about wooing votes by offering tastes of medallions of elk and lessons in country-and-western line dancing. Organizers had already scored a public-relations coup last winter, when Hillary Rodham Clinton donned a Vail '99 jacket while attending the Winter Olympics in Lillehammer, Norway.
"We've always been very goal-oriented here," said Peter Seibert, 70, Vail Associates' founder. "And when you exude that, you draw more and more people who fit that personality type."
To be sure, Vail has a history of attracting the powerful. The list of the resort's original partners reads like a Who's Who of American industry, including the chairmen of I.B.M., Kellogg's and Motorola. Their $10,000-apiece investment in 1960, which bought 2 acres of land, 100 shares of stock and 4 lifetime season ski passes, paid off: each stake is now worth more than $1 million.
Of course, wealth begets wealth, and heavy hitters like Henry R. Kravis, the financier, and Peter A. Cohen, the former chairman and chief executive of Shearson Lehman Hutton, built lavish second homes here. And politicians like former President Gerald R. Ford, Ross Perot and Jack F. Kemp, who also have homes here, have found gushing support among Vail's conservative elite.
"What Aspen is to Hollywood, Vail is to Wall Street," said Jerry Jones, who helped Vail's founders market the resort to a select group of newcomers.
Even the ski bums who move here are Type A's. "The young guy who goes to Telluride or Crested Butte has probably heard so much from his old man about getting a job and succeeding that he just wants to go somewhere and hang out," Mr. Seibert said. "The guy who comes to Vail is a bit more career-oriented, at least in the back of his mind."
And those who arrive here as ski bums often become infected with the entrepreneurial spirit. New businesses, many of which cater to Vail's rich and time-strapped second-home owners, seem to sprout like wildflowers, bolstering a local economy that's become one of the fastest-growing in the state.
In Vail, ambition takes many forms. This, after all, is a town where more than 500 residents race in a highly competitive weekly mountain-bike series and dozens of superfit men and women juggle professional bike-racing careers in the summer and professional mogul skiing in winter.
"The level of athleticism is unparalleled," said Davis Phinney, a bicylist who won a bronze medal in the 1984 Olympics. He now runs an annual summer cycling camp in Vail with his wife, Connie Carpenter, a bicyclist who won a gold medal in 1984. "I avoid the bike club's training rides because I know I'll get shellacked."
Vail residents have even elevated relaxation to a competitive level. Members of the renowned Lawn Chair Drill Team handle lounge chairs with the same precision as soldiers handling rifles. "We'll challenge anyone to a competition," said Josh Hall, 40, who marched with the team in President Clinton's inaugural parade. "We've got muscles in places these all-American runners and skiers just can't imagine."
Craig Campbell, the leader of the drill team, added: "In a regular town, the competition is over who has the biggest house or the best job. But here, it's all based around who's the best at recreating: who skis the most days or bikes the most miles. The drill team kind of fits right into that. We call it the 'Pro Leisure Tour,' and we get a lot of points for being on the team."
Attendance at ski-conditioning classes each fall is worth big points, too, if you can survive. Led through a strenuous series of workout stations by a team of trainers and professional mogul skiers, enthusiasts at the Cascade Athletic Club drop like flies as the sessions stretch on. "It's like boot camp here," said Annegret Howe, a nutritionist at the Vail Valley Medical Center who quit the ski classes after a few weeks. "Between the power lunges, the plyometrics and the suicide sprints, you've got to be a superwoman just to keep up."
And where does that leave the rest of the pack? Melodee Crawford, who manages the T. Lame clothing store, has found that Vail's hardbodies have little patience with laggards.
"I was going out with this guy, but he dumped me after we went skiing," she said. "He told me: 'You've got the basics down, but you're just not good enough. So our relationship isn't going to last.' I was appalled."
