LENGTH: 608 words

HEADLINE: Soon, a Serious Governor's Race

 BODY:
So far, this has not been an edifying gubernatorial race. New York is a proud but uneasy state with big problems like crime, education, a crushing Medicaid burden, a swollen public payroll and a stubborn recession.
But the issues that have so far dominated public attention include Republican front-runner George Pataki's real estate ventures, Gov. Mario Cuomo's speaking fees and the question of who is paying for the nursing home-care of Mr. Cuomo's mother and Mr. Pataki's father. Each side has also filed a lawsuit accusing the other of breaking the legal limits on campaign contributions. 
 These matters are legitimate grist for campaign debate, since they may help voters judge the candidates' integrity and character. But they are no substitute for a sustained debate about crime, mediocre schools, campaign finance reform, how to create a more hospitable business climate and how, precisely, the candidates intend to pay for the tax cuts they have promised.
In fairness, Mr. Cuomo and Richard Rosenbaum, the Republican underdog, have tried to sharpen the policy debate. Mr. Rosenbaum may not be around after tomorrow's primary, but he has at least said how he would try to revive the economy.
That puts him one up on Mr. Pataki, whose mudslinging reached a comical apotheosis when he released a Letterman-like Top 10 list of how he thinks Mr. Cuomo has used taxpayer money to enhance his life style, including the purchase of flea collars for his dogs. The Democrats then organized truth squads to bombard the press with Mr. Pataki's "10 top fibs."
For Mr. Pataki, this dithering around represents a blown opportunity to give himself personal and doctrinal definition. It is true that he had to spend much of the summer raising money. It is also true, as Mr. Cuomo points out, that apart from vague promises about cutting taxes and welfare Mr. Pataki has said very little about what he believes in and what he would do as governor.
Mr. Pataki, who has now offered to debate Mr. Cuomo, promises to set forth a more detailed agenda if he wins the primary. That would surely please his party. Most Republicans know that despite Mr. Pataki's lead in some polls their party cannot beat Mr. Cuomo without credible alternative policies. The underfinanced Mr. Rosenbaum, by contrast, has offered a detailed proposal to cut taxes by 24 percent and spending by $4 billion. Whether one likes his ideas or not, Mr. Rosenbaum has at least put them on the table.
As for Mr. Cuomo, he is now running for the history books. His candidacy carries the presumption that a fourth term would be a crowning achievement in which he would bring to closure many of his earlier promises.
The Governor has certainly been visible, zooming around the state to tout the local benefits of projects financed by Albany. And he is not short of ideas. His aides promise proposals on school financing, prisons and tax relief for businesses and individuals. But the voters really need a clear, thematic explanation of how a fourth term would build, extend and solidify what would become New York's longest executive tenure.
Though the last two gubernatorial races in 1990 and 1986 were walkovers for Mr. Cuomo against hapless opponents, a competitive race this year fought on issues of genuine concern to New Yorkers would be healthy all around. There is a precedent. Mr. Cuomo's race in 1982 against a sharp and ideologically committed opponent, Lewis Lehrman, was at times a riveting and stimulating competition, an educational exercise of high order that engaged New Yorkers in a way they have not been engaged since. There is still time for a sequel.

HEADLINE: When A.C. Was a Glint in Engineer's Eye;
The Forgotten Worker

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It seemed maddeningly appropriate, on the Labor Day closing a summer that saw the insurance industry buy a national consensus against universal health care, that the lead editorial of The Times -- America's newspaper of record -- celebrated the joys of air-conditioning. 
 One might have hoped to see a brief salute to all the men and women throughout American history who had their skulls dented or smashed to win a living wage. One might have hoped for some recognition of the small, debt-plagued farmers who fed and clothed our young nation, and lined the pockets of its bankers.
One might have hoped for some mention of the millions who still must endure unsafe working conditions for subsistence wages: the Asian and Latino immigrants sewing away in locked sweatshops down the street from your air-conditioned offices, the migrant farm worker breathing in lungfuls of pesticides, the millions who work part-time, no-benefit jobs in the service sector.
These are the people who make our economy run. If they had been born in any other Western industrialized country, they would be entitled to lifelong health care, as well as the representation of a political party at least nominally committed to their interests. Instead they are here in America, where Labor Day is an occasion to appreciate air-conditioning.
 
ANDY VAZAC
East Chatham, N.Y., Sept. 6, 1994

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Press Notes

BYLINE: By William Glaberson 

 BODY:
THE American newspaper industry, humbled by slipping advertising revenue in recent years, is showing strong signs of returning health.
Revenue from advertising in newspapers across the country for the first half of this year showed the strongest gains since 1987, according to industry data, and the advertising is projected to remain stable. As a result, the earnings of most big newspaper companies are improving. 
 "We believe it is very, very good news," said Cathleen Black, the president of the Newspaper Association of America, the publishers' trade group. "The very slow recovery has begun to come home."
A recent report by the association said ad revenue increased 6.25 percent during the first half of the year, compared with the corresponding period last year. And the group is projecting a 6.7 percent gain for the entire year, compared with 1993.
That level of growth would be the biggest increase since 1987, when newspapers' advertising revenue grew 9 percent, to $29.4 billion. The trade group is projecting ad revenue of $34 billion for the industry this year, up from $31.9 billion last year.
Sluggish advertising the last several years and drastic declines in the early 1990's highlighted long-term problems for newspapers, including declining readership, increasing competition for advertising dollars and the disappearance of longtime advertisers like department stores.
Those problems, industry analysts say, continue to haunt the future of the nation's newspapers.
Some analysts say the dose of business reality has sobered newspaper publishers in a lasting way. And some say the new bottom-line orientation at newspapers across the country is likely to remain. Cost-containment programs and more aggressive business competitiveness, they say, are now permanent parts of the industry.
"The industry is not on its deathbed by a long shot," said Kenneth T. Berents, a media securities analyst at Wheat First Butcher Singer in Richmond. "But it has changed. The question remains: How strong will it be in the long term?"
But for now, at least, publishers can be forgiven for pinching themselves as they notice they are still alive after all.
 
The Journal's Latin Voice
 Last week, more than 1.1 million newspaper readers in Latin America could read The Wall Street Journal's account of a banking scandal in Mexico and learn about the travails of Berlin's only legally sanctioned shoeshine man.
They could read those and other articles on economic and business news in their own big-city newspapers. In Spanish. And they could read them on the same day they were published in The Journal in the United States, Asia and Europe.
The Wall Street Journal Americas, a daily two- to three-page section inserted into eight newspapers in Latin America, is the latest expansion by the flagship newspaper of Dow Jones & Company. The section began publication last month in newspapers in Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Puerto Rico and Venezuela.
"The idea behind expansion is that we think the global business person in Buenos Aires or Santiago needs the same business information as the business person in New York or Dallas," said Bill Casey, director of development for the international business development group at Dow Jones.
The unusual section is translated, edited and laid out by editors at The Journal's headquarters in New York and sent digitally to a computer in Miami. Each Latin American newspaper then retrieves the prepared pages electronically and inserts them in time for the next day's press run.
The newspapers can sell local advertising for some space and keep the revenue. The Journal's advertising staff sells pan-Latin advertising to run in all the papers and then splits that revenue with its partners.
The Digital Equipment Corporation is the first pan-Latin advertiser in the new section. Diane Spencer, director of print services for Young & Rubicam in New York, said the advertising agency had advised Digital to make the purchase partly because the identification with The Journal provided the right image for a big corporate advertiser.
"We're trying to reach key business influencers in these countries," Ms. Spencer said. The Journal, she added, has invented a novel way to do that.
 
Sobering News on Salaries
 Generations of aspiring journalists have been advised that journalism won't make you rich. A new study shows that guidance, for beginning journalists at least, to be as true as ever.
In an annual survey of salaries conducted by Ohio State University's School of Journalism, 2,556 graduates of undergraduate and graduate schools of journalism or mass communications were interviewed. Those who went to work for newspapers, the study found, earned a median starting salary of $18,200.
According to Lee P. Becker, one of the professors who conducted the study, salaries paid to new journalists have not kept pace with inflation since he began directing the study nine years ago. In 1985 dollars, he said, salaries paid to new journalists have slipped from the equivalent of $14,800 in 1990 to the equivalent of $13,600 last year.
Mr. Becker said most of the entry-level jobs obtained by the recent graduates he interviewed were at smaller newspapers.
He said that having spent years studying salaries for new journalists he had come to a conclusion that raised questions about the future of the nation's news organizations. "I think you can't expect to get workers of high quality if you aren't willing to pay them very much," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 14, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A brief report in the Press Notes column of the Media Business page on Monday, about a new Spanish-language newspaper supplement published by The Wall Street Journal, misidentified one area in which the supplement appears. It is Peru, not Puerto Rico.

HEADLINE: Bargain Zoning in the Big City;
New York Seeks an Economic Lift, Suburban Style, by Wooing Discount Stores

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
Stretched across the open doorway at the store entrance on a recent morning was a red-and-gold ribbon with a fancy bow tied in the middle. Outside, almost 300 people waited impatiently in line, clutching fliers promising gifts. Inside, dozens of employees clapped and cheered as the opening of the largest free-standing home appliance and electronics store in New York City drew near.
"The name of the game is jobs," said Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, just before she cut the ribbon at the new 75,000-square-foot Tops Appliance City superstore on Northern Boulevard in Long Island City that will employ 350 people. "Thank you for this expression of faith in the future of Queens." 
 If the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has its way, such ceremonies, trumpeting the opening of big, suburban-style discounters, supermarkets and megastores, will be increasingly common in New York.
City officials, looking to fill the void left by the long decline of manufacturing and the loss of many of New York's department stores, say they can create more jobs and generate higher tax revenues by attracting large retailers. They hope to lure residents to shop in the city rather than drive to the suburbs to stock up on groceries and buy large items.
To do this, officials are suggesting that areas of the city long restricted largely to industrial activities be opened to much wider uses, including big retail stores.
Given the absence of demand for new office buildings, a decision to encourage an influx of superstores is likely to do far more during the next decade to shape economic development in the city -- particularly outside Manhattan -- than any other City Hall policy.
 
Conflict With Urban Life
 But to opponents, such plans threaten to unleash forces they fear would undermine the special urban character of New York City, one of the few cities in the United States that still have a host of dense neighborhoods where residents can walk to local shops.
Small merchants worry that the big stores could drain the lifeblood of many neighborhood shopping districts. Some urban thinkers, arguing that the auto-oriented life style of the suburbs is incompatible with the city, contend that zoning should be used to limit rather than encourage isolated warehouse stores surrounded by large parking lots.
"If you build a single big box and surround it with blacktop, those shoppers walk by nothing but other cars," said Roberta Brandes Gratz, author of "The Living City," which is being reissued and updated this year by Preservation Press. "We shouldn't assume that the suburban model of the past 50 years is the only one. Big retailers can be O.K., but only if they are told they must fit into the framework of the urban New York model. Otherwise, we should just say no."
To most city officials, however, this attitude represents little more than nostalgia for the long-lost days before shopping malls as well as an ignorance of economic trends that favor suburban areas.
"It's long past time to bring our zoning laws up to date with the real world," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission. "New York can't afford to turn large retailers away at the border just because they don't fit someone's image. We're losing sales taxes and jobs to the suburbs that should be ours."
 
Shaping Development
 This month, the City Planning Department plans to release detailed recommendations for ways to make it far easier for large retailers to operate in the city. The department, with the blessing of Mayor Giuliani, is expected to propose, among other things, raising the size limit on most stores in areas zoned for manufacturing to 100,000 square feet (roughly the size of two football fields) or more, from the current 10,000 square feet.
The Giuliani proposal follows suggestions made in early 1993 by city planners under Mayor David N. Dinkins aimed at redeveloping abandoned and underused industrial areas through zoning changes.
Stephen DiBrienza, a City Council member from Park Slope, Brooklyn, predicts that the proposal faces a tough political battle. "The superstore issue raises a number of sensitive questions," he said. "We're going to look at it very closely."
Already, many large retailers are seeking special permits that would exempt them from current land-use restrictions. Kmart, for instance, has applied to build a 123,000-square-foot discount store across the street from Tops, on land where Ronzoni pasta was once made. It is also negotiating to acquire a 9.5-acre site on the edge of Park Slope.
Many more developers are likely to follow suit if the Planning Commission and the City Council agree to Mayor Giuliani's plan to untangle the labyrinthine requirements to obtain a zoning variance and open thousands of acres of underused industrial land to wholesale redevelopment.
 
New York Losing Retailers
 From 1984 to 1991, 92 percent of the new retail stores built in the New York metropolitan area, totaling almost 50 million square feet, were constructed outside the city, according to the F. W. Dodge Group, a construction research unit of McGraw-Hill Inc.
While New York City's share of personal income earned in the region has dropped to 43 percent in the early 1990's, from 50 percent in the early 1960's, it has lost a far bigger share of retail sales. They fell to 34 percent from 48 percent, city planners found. As a consequence of that and other factors, retail employment in the city has declined to less than 350,000, from 440,000 in 1968.
But now, many large retailers -- Home Depot, Sports Authority, Caldor and others -- increasingly see New York and other large cities as the last untapped territory in a national landscape saturated with suburban shopping centers. The year-old Home Depot store in Ozone Park, Queens, for instance, is already one of the most popular in the nation. Executives at Tops, which now has eight home appliance stores in the New York area, say they expect the new Northern Avenue outlet -- their first in the city -- to exceed $100 million in annual sales and quickly become the chain's biggest revenue generator.
To build high-volume, low-profit-margin stores that draw customers from a wide area, retailers need large parcels of land, sometimes 10 acres or more, for sales, storage and parking. Only a few such sites that are already zoned for commercial and retail use are available in the city.
The general absence of large supermarkets, which have a wider food selection and lower prices than most local grocers, particularly grates on many city residents.
 
Complaint of Subsidies
 "Just because we live within the boundaries of New York City, why should we be stuck with just one type of store?" asked Pat Oettinger of the Queens Citizens Organization, a church-based community group that supports Pathmark's efforts to open a warehouse-sized supermarket in Springfield Gardens in southeast Queens. "Not only would that bring more jobs for our young people into the community, it would also force the existing grocers to upgrade their merchandise. Competition should be healthy for everybody."
Studies by the Community Food Resource Center, a nonprofit group, and the Planning Department have found little harm, if any, to neighborhood grocery stores after supermarkets moved in nearby.
But many small merchants remain fearful. "The megastores do nothing to build up the neighborhoods, which are the lifeblood of the city," said Sung Soo Kim, president of the Korean American Small Business Service Center of New York. "The big supermarkets abandoned the city in the 1970's, leaving a vacuum that immigrant businesses filled. Now they want to come back, but only on their terms and with a host of unfair subsidies. This is not free competition."
Mr. Kim and leaders of several other merchant associations complain that the big chains are unfairly aided by special packages including tax abatements and energy rebates. The associations help support the efforts of a lobbyist, Richard Lipsky, who is the most outspoken opponent of the zoning changes. He is also active in campaigns to stop several big retailing projects. "I like being David to their Goliath," Mr. Lipsky said.
But behind Mr. Lipsky, his critics say, are not just small storekeepers but a network of big locally based wholesalers, like Krasdale and White Rose, that help finance and supply many local grocers in the city. Mr. Lipsky does not receive any financing from the wholesalers, he says, but acknowledges that they generally favor his stance.
 
'Downhill Ever Since'
 It is certainly not easy to survive as a traditional independent retailer against the big chains. For instance, not far from Tops, on Steinway Street -- the popular shopping street for Astoria and Long Island City -- Fairway Lumber, a small lumberyard and hardware store, is going out of business after 49 years at the same location.
"We expanded six years ago to serve the neighborhood better and it has been downhill ever since," said Vincent Napolitano, president of Fairway. "A bad economy, along with the entry of Home Depot and Pergament nearby, did us in. For every job they create, they destroy two or three others."
Still, not all smaller merchants are convinced that the big megastores will wipe out everything around them. "We welcome Tops," said David John, store manager of the Big Daddy home appliance store on Steinway Street. "It will give everyone a chance to see that their prices are actually higher than ours. Competition is a two-way street."

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
Operas on Willful Women and Pliable Men

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Like many another American arts institution, the San Francisco Opera fell on hard financial times recently and had to adopt stringent austerities. But with one exception, these showed little onstage during the glittery first weekend of the company's 72d season, which was filled with big-name singers in new productions.
Perhaps taking a cue from a 1993 book by George Martin, "Verdi at the Golden Gate," the company opened on Friday evening with Verdi's "Macbeth." On Saturday evening it repeated the theme of the strong-willed, malicious woman who wreaks havoc through a weaker male proxy with the premiere of Conrad Susa's "Dangerous Liaisons." 
 Lotfi Mansouri, the opera's general director, oversaw the production of "MacBeth," and here, especially in the set design by Gerard Howland, some of the budget-cutting became apparent. Artistically, Mr. Mansouri seems determined to show, this season, that the best economic defense is a good offense. He is presenting no fewer than seven new productions (with Verdi's "Trovatore," Rossini's "Otello," Wagner's "Tannhauser," Massenet's "Herodiade" and Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" to follow), all designed by Mr. Howland with an eye toward mass-production efficiencies.
The main element was a facing wall, which opened in sections and flaps and sprouted staircases and platforms. For all its spareness, which no number of bobbingly suspended witches or other garish effects could conceal, it was nonetheless distracting in its constant adjustments and reconfigurations.
But any fears that San Francisco audiences might have to face the same unyielding structure through seven operas were dispelled on Saturday by Colin Graham's elegant production of "The Dangerous Liaisons." Commissioned by the company, Mr. Susa's opera, with libretto by Philip Littell, is based on the 18th-century novel by Pierre Choderlos de Laclos, which has inspired several films, including one from 1988 based on a popular play by Christopher Hampton.
Since the novel consists entirely of letters among the principals, any dramatic structure based on it is likely to vary in emphasis from any other. In contrast, for example, to the 1988 film, Mr. Littell's distillation lends the characters a certain depth and concreteness. The history and thus the motivations of the manipulative Marquise de Merteuil are deftly limned. And the Vicomte de Valmont, while philandering with a vengeance (or without, no matter to him), maintains a modicum of humanity, which makes his ultimate breakdown not only believable but, on some minimal level, touching.
The humanity of the characters was seconded here by Mr. Graham's canny stage direction. If in the end these creatures, mindlessly bound up in their religious or societal pieties or their sexual adventures and retributions, still seemed insubstantial and unsympathetic, they were nevertheless faithful inhabitants of the world Laclos imagined.
Mr. Susa's music, in its perfumed decadence, was also an honest mirror, grateful for the singing voice but unflattering in its import. Partly because of its very effectiveness in its sinuous, manipulative melodicism and its avoidance of straightforward cadence or gesture, it was difficult to warm to.
A composer could hardly hope for a better premiere than the San Francisco Opera gave "The Dangerous Liaisons," in both casting and production. Thomas Hampson was an ideal rogue as Valmont, dashing in voice and mien. ("One does not applaud the tenor for clearing his throat," Glenn Close's Merteuil said to John Malkovich's Valmont in the film after an easy seduction, but of course this hormone-driven villain had to be a baritone.) And the women impressed even more, in both quality and variety.
The ease with which Frederica von Stade can transcend her familiar boyish persona and nice-guy image should no longer come as a surprise, but the depth of her portrayal here, with world-weariness and cynicism festering under a beauteous surface, was remarkable. Renee Fleming was superb as the married Madame de Tourvel, Valmont's target of choice, and Mary Mills, a young soprano with a lovely, pure tone, showed considerable promise as the betrothed Cecile de Volanges, Valmont's target of Merteuil's choice.
Johanna Meier sang Madame de Rosemonde strongly. Some roughness of tone in Judith Forst's portrayal of Madame de Volanges could be ascribed to the character's age, and the callowness of David Hobson's tenor seemed similarly appropriate for the Chevalier de Danceny, Merteuil's prey.
The orchestra performed well for its music director, Donald C. Runnicles, once past some rocky wind playing in the introduction. The chorus made little effect in its offstage contributions. The lead characters articulated the English text with such admirable clarity that the supertitles proved distracting for the most part, though undeniably useful in the jumble of a few ensembles.
Still, the most striking aspect of the evening, after the lowering of expectations on Friday, was Mr. Howland's scenic design, in combination with Mr. Graham's stage direction. Using projections and reflections, Mr. Howland created a richly textured, subtly shifting visual fabric that enhanced the flow of Mr. Graham's conception. In all, this was as convincing an evening of theater as one is likely to see on an opera stage nowadays.
"Macbeth" had to settle for more modest virtues. Verdi, as George Martin colorfully demonstrates in his book, has been a favorite here since the 1850's, when the sprawling, brawling, mostly male populace attracted by the gold rush took opera to its inscrutable heart. But "Macbeth" has always had to struggle for a place in the Verdi canon in English-speaking countries, and although the San Francisco premiere, at Maguire's Opera House in 1862, "passed off with greater satisfaction and gratification than any opera yet given in the Pacific," by one newspaper account, the work evidently disappeared here until the 20th century.
While tending assiduously to the city's rich Verdi tradition over the decades, the San Francisco Opera has performed "Macbeth" relatively infrequently, in 1955, 1957, 1967 and 1986. And to judge from the tepid response of the festive opening-night crowd, it may not be back anytime soon.
Not that enthusiasm was necessarily warranted by everything that happened onstage. James Morris was splendid as Macbeth, robust of voice yet appropriately hesitant and confused in manner, and Robert Lloyd's matching splendor as Banquo made a listener regret all the more the character's early assassination.
But Gwyneth Jones, as Lady Macbeth, gave new evidence of her vocal troubles of the last decade or so, with a woolly sonority and a wobbly vibrato. True, prettiness is not the point; "I would like the Lady to have a harsh, stifled and hollow voice," Verdi wrote. Yet Ms. Jones was often harrowing above and beyond the call.
Hong-Shen Li was suitably noble as Macduff, in contrast to Stephen Guggenheim, a most unkingly Malcolm. The chorus was fine, the orchestra even better, and all responded well to Mr. Runnicles's baton.
"Macbeth" runs through Oct. 2, "The Dangerous Liaisons" through Sept. 27.

HEADLINE: Deciphering Rules In a Competition For Arts Grants

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
With $10 million in city and state money up for grabs, arts organizations throughout the city's five boroughs have been racing to turn in grant applications due today. Under the challenge-grant initiative, a plan announced with great fanfare in July, the city's Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York State Council on the Arts are each to award $5 million in grants to organizations able to match the grant money dollar for dollar with grants from other sources.
As details of the plan have become clearer in the last month, however, some arts administrators and officials at philanthropic foundations say it is unlikely that it will generate $10 million in new money from the private sector. Further, they say because the grants must be used to expand an institution's programs to draw an increased audience, they could actually harm many smaller arts institutions that need to stabilize their operations before undertaking an expansion. 
 Like many other arts administrators, Norma Munn, the chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, an advocacy group, praised the initiative not only as a gesture of support for the arts, but also for its treatment of culture as an industry that offers economic benefit. Nevertheless, Ms. Munn said the program would probably result in the redistribution of funds rather than the creation of money.
 
On Levels of Increase
 "It will encourage shifting within arts organizations from one program to another, and to a certain extent among funders from one organization to another," Ms. Munn said. "No one will be able to verify what the level of increase is."
Bob Crane, the vice president for programs at the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, said he agreed. "If we give $10,000 in general support, as we generally do, and an arts organization came back and asked for money under the challenge grant, we'd probably not increase it over the $10,000," he said. "But we'd be happy to target it in such a way that it loosened the money from the challenge grant. The new money is the state and city money. The foundation money is more an accounting procedure."
The program will work very well for certain kinds of organizations, arts administrators said, primarily for larger institutions with well-organized development offices and the kinds of donors who can write large checks quickly. It will also be a boon, they said, to smaller organizations that are on a firm footing and are already preparing to expand.
The Museum of Modern Art, for example, prepared a grant proposal to allow it to expand programs on Thursday and Friday nights and on Saturday mornings during an exhibition of Jacob Lawrence's "Migration Series," to run Jan. 12 through April 11, 1995, which is a series of paintings depicting the movement of blacks from the South to the industrial cities of the North in the postwar period.
 
'We Want to Do More'
 "For us this is a stroke of luck," said Dan Vecchitto, the museum's director of development, who said the Modern would apply for a $250,000 matching grant. "We want to do more programs that reach out to the African-American community and schools. We hope we can build an audience and that they'll come back."
Davis Hall at City College is also well positioned to take advantage of the grant money. "This comes at a timely period for us, as we've just gone through a major campaign to firm up our infrastructure, and we're also increasing our programming," said David Rodriguez, the executive director of Davis Hall. He said Davis Hall would apply for $50,000, the greatest amount allowable under the rules for an institution with a budget of its size. Mr. Rodriguez said that Davis Hall already had pledges in hand, but that the money could not have been raised without the challenge grant.
Holly Block, the executive director of Art in General, an alternative art gallery in Manhattan, said she planned to apply for the smallest possible grant in her category, $5,000 from the city and the state. "I have no interest in trying to dream up a program to fit the guidelines," she said. "I think people are really hesitant to take on a challenge to find new money."
 
On Distributing Money
 Patricia McNeill, executive vice president of J. C. Geever, a company that raises money for nonprofit arts institutions, said: "What they should be doing is giving money for operational expenses. For special projects, let the arts groups turn to the foundations, which is what the foundations increasingly are geared for."
Officials at the city's Department of Cultural Affairs and the state arts agency say that whatever its shortcomings, the mere existence of the plan, in a year when the city is preparing to cut its arts budget by $4.6 million, is no small achievement. "It's a miracle," said Kitty Carlisle Hart, the chairwoman of the state arts commission. "It was very, very difficult."
Money was not the only obstacle. The City Department of Cultural Affairs and the State Council on the Arts have different systems for awarding grants. Like the National Endowment for the Arts and most other arts organizations, the state sets up peer panels to review and approve grants. The city adheres to a set of formulas that have evolved over time and that many arts administrators regard as highly politicized.
About 85 percent of city money goes to 31 institutions known as the cultural-institutions groups, most of them on city land or in city buildings. The remainder goes to several hundred organizations known as program groups. The percentage split between the two categories has been a contentious issue in recent years, and this year the city amended the formula, giving about 23 percent of its grant money to the program groups. Only the program groups make use of peer panels in approving grants.
 
Resulting in a Hybrid
 The different methods used by the city and state led to a clash in deciding how the challenge grants should be administered, with each side insisting on its own system. "We had what diplomats call a 'free and frank exchange of views,' " said Schuyler G. Chapin, New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.
In the end, the State Council on the Arts held its ground, resulting in a hybrid that leaves many arts administrators wondering what will happen when the state and the city sit down to parcel out the money. The city is committed to disbursing the money to the cultural-institution groups and the program groups in a ratio of 5 to 3, and arts administrators have expressed fears that the panel it appoints to review grant applications will dole it out with the primary goal of pleasing political constituencies. Mr. Chapin said he expected the panel to be named this week.
The state is not bound by the 5-to-3 formula. Moreover, the state does not give grants to some of the cultural-institutions groups, like the Staten Island Zoo and the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, which it does not define as cultural institutions.
One undisputed triumph did emerge from the discussions between the city and states arts officials: a simple, straightforward and short application form.
"Last month, when I addressed a meeting of the Mayor's cabinet and held up the application form, there was a stunned silence, and then everyone burst into applause," said Mr. Chapin.
 
'The Jury Is Out'
 The short timetable for the challenge grants has put pressure on arts organizations and financing sources alike. Grant applications are to be approved in November, and the winning organizations will have until three months before the end of their fiscal year to find the matching funds. For most organizations, that date is April 1.
"I think the jury is out until we see how the awards are made,"
said Jenny Dixon, the executive director of the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. "The outcome I hope for is that some groups that have not had access to city dollars, that have been well regarded on the state level, will start to get some city money." Mr. Chapin said: "We will slip on banana peels, we will fall, and we will get up. That's inevitable in a program that's totally unprecedented. But in the end we will put new money into the arts community."

HEADLINE: Steep Hurdles for Rescue

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
TAKING an ecosystem-wide approach to the management of Yellowstone, as many conservation biologists argue is the only effective approach, might require some over-arching political authority, given the near-impossibility of forging an alliance among the ecosystem's welter of political and administrative jurisdictions. But opponents appear to have killed off, at least for now, any attempt to impose such an arrangement.
As recently as four years ago, greater Yellowstone was being touted as a first-class laboratory for ecosystem management. But in the Bush Administration, highly organized defenders of extractive industries and private property succeeding in killing a "vision document" for the ecosystem's future that had been drafted by Federal agencies. Opponents attacked the document as part of an environmentalist plot to "lock up" land against development and exploitation, and their conservative allies in Washington prevailed. 
 Although the concept of an ecosystem-wide approach to conservation has been generally promoted by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, the Clinton Administration is not about to try to foster the approach in Yellowstone by trying to impose an ecosystem-wide management plan devised in Washington. "That kills it," said George Frampton, the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for fish, wildlife and parks.
Rather, he said, the Administration's approach will be to emphasize the state, local and private role as being critical and decisive in land-use issues, while offering Federal help where possible and appropriate. Since local people have to live with the results, he said, "you have to push decision-making down to the local level."
Local communities have indeed begun to rein in development, historically a heretical idea in these conservative parts. Three of the region's fastest-growing counties -- those containing Bozeman, Jackson and Cody, the economies of which depend on the new wealth of recreation and population growth -- are taking steps to control the spread of subdivisions. The Cody area has declared a moratorium on development until it decides what to do. Jackson, with perhaps the most advanced effort, has adopted a county-wide land use plan that offers incentives for building outside ecologically sensitive areas and encourages "cluster developments," high-density subdivisions that would leave sufficient open space to accommodate wildlife.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

COMPANY: BUSH ADMINISTRATION (68%);

HEADLINE: Latest Threat to Yellowstone: Admirers Are Loving It to Death

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.

 BODY:
A HIKER to the top of Mount Washburn in the heart of Yellowstone National Park may find it hard to believe that the wild land stretching out before him could ever be in serious jeopardy, so eternal does the spectacle seem.
From 10,243 feet, where marmots scurry about above the timberline, distant slopes garbed in evergreen forests alternate with the gold-beige velvet of grassy inclines and alpine meadows. Deep gorges, cascading cataracts and broad rivers cut through a sweeping vista punctuated by blue lakes and bright green mountain marshes. Close up, Yellowstone's incomparable geysers spout and its hot pools bubble, and the land abounds with the elk, bear, moose, deer, antelope, bison and bighorn sheep that have earned it the nickname "America's Serengeti." 
 The magnificent, world-famous landscape still ranks as the most nearly intact of big American ecosystems outside Alaska. But scientists and conservationists say that even Yellowstone's ecosystem is under increasingly serious threat from human pressure -- much of it, they say, exerted by the region's more committed admirers.
The park itself is merely the protected core of a vast, seamless ecosystem seven times as large. As big as West Virginia, it includes not only the jagged ranges of the Gallatin, Beartooth, Absaroka and Teton Mountains, along with the national forests that carpet their slopes, but also public and private lands that lie beyond them. "Everything in view is part of the greater Yellowstone ecosystem," Jim McKown, the park ranger who lives in his observation post at the top of Mount Washburn, says as he gazes into the distance. It is on private lands far from here, out on the ecosystem's ramparts, that the latest threat to its integrity has appeared. There, scientists and environmentalists say, a private real estate boom fueled by the desire of people to live close to Yellowstone's natural charms is eroding those charms and punching deep salients into the wild.
People "are literally loving the place to death," says Dr. Patrick Jobes, a sociologist at Montana State University in Bozeman, on the northern fringe of the ecosystem, who has joined with ecologists to study interrelationships among the region's people, economy and environment.
Some ecologists fear that unless it is controlled, a proliferation of subdivisions on private land will disrupt rhythms on which the ecosystem's biological health depends. Among the features believed to be at particular risk are these:
*River-valley habitats, which contain some of the ecosystem's richest assortments of plant and animal species.
*The purity of some of the region's cold, clear rivers and streams.
*Migration routes traveled by elk and other big ungulates as they move from the high country to lower elevations when winter approaches -- not to mention the winter habitat itself, much of which is on private land.
*Habitat of the threatened grizzly bear, the creeping loss of which is already forcing the scarce bears into no-win conflict with people.
This new hazard joins that of mining, logging, grazing and petroleum drilling in national forests and other federally owned lands outside Yellowstone and the adjacent Grand Teton National Park, which are themselves off limits. The latest alarm along these lines involves a plan to open a gold mine near Cooke City, Mont., in the Gallatin National Forest just outside the Yellowstone park borders. Environmentalists and some politicians vehemently object, for fear that poisonous waste, which must be contained forever, will ultimately escape from the mine and ruin some of the ecosystem's most beautiful streams.
But such exploitation of Federal lands may no longer be the most serious threat. Extractive industry has been far eclipsed, economists say, by a new economy founded on outdoor recreation and on the earnings of footloose businesses and residents, especially retirees, attracted by the natural wonders here. The resulting growth in population, development and general human traffic may now be responsible for the most intense ecological pressure.
These new realities are also changing the political equation that has governed the long-running struggle over Yellowstone's future. The dispute has commonly been cast as one between adherents to the status quo, who hold that the land is there for people to exploit, and conservationists, who say the ecological health of this international treasure should come first. Now the conservationists have an economic argument of their own: destroying the natural attractions on which the region's economy is now based would kill the goose that lays the golden egg.
The struggle's center of gravity is shifting perceptibly away from the Federal level, where it has become highly polarized, toward the state and local levels where private land-use decisions are made. There are signs that some early progress is being made toward reconciling the competing claims of ecology and economy.
 
Getting It Right in Yellowstone
 Conservationists believe the ecosystem is still robust enough that it can be sufficiently protected, and the new regional economy with it. "Not only can we get it right in Yellowstone, not to get it right would be an enormous black eye," said Louisa Willcox, the program director of the Greater Yellowstone Coalition, a decade-old alliance of 110 environmental organizations based in Bozeman.
The boundaries of the ecosystem are necessarily fuzzy, varying according to who defines the system and on what criteria. But clearly the moist, hilly Yellowstone plateau and attendant mountain ranges stand out from the adjacent, drier plains in many ways. They display a rich and characteristic assortment of flora and fauna. The biggest elk population in North America, more than 90,000 strong, lives in greater Yellowstone, as does the largest herd of free-ranging buffalo and one of two main populations of grizzly bears remaining in the contiguous 48 states. The bears, listed by the Federal Government as a threatened species, number about 250 here.
The extensive ranges of elk and bears, whose travels help knit the ecosystem together, are one of its major defining features. So is its rich and characteristic assemblage of plant communities, dominated by forests. Douglas fir blankets lower elevations, lodgepole pine (by far the most common vegetative cover) rules the middle elevations, and Englemann spruce, alpine fir and whitebark pine drape the harsh regions just below the timberline in green festoons misshapen by the wind.
The region contains many smaller-scale ecosystems, and both they and the larger landscape undergo constant change at the hands of naturally recurring forces like insect infestations, lightning-set fires and climatic fluctuations. These rearrange vegetation, destroy old habitats while creating new ones and redirect the wanderings of wildlife. They are the agents of regeneration and biological variety.
Seemingly devastated ridges in Yellowstone testify to the power of the great fires that ecologists say occur unavoidably every two or three centuries. Countless acres of naked lodgepole pines, killed by the unstoppable blazes of 1988, still look gray and lifeless from a distance. But up close, new trees up to two feet tall can be seen poking their heads up.
In ways both subtle and obvious, humans are altering the terms on which these fluxes of nature take place. Much of Yellowstone's plant life, for instance, now consists of exotic Eurasian species that have spread across the continent, often displacing native species; hikers nearing the summit of Mount Washburn are greeted by dandelions, invaders from Europe. In another example, clear-cutting of timber in the national forests has eliminated the soil nutrients ordinarily replenished by fires, eliminated habitat for bird species that nest in dead trees and deprived streams of the logs that help create fish habitat. Logging roads have also cut the habitats of deep-woods animals into fragments. Regiments of hikers and snowmobilers are disturbing the back country in growing numbers.
And the wolf, Yellowstone's top predator and former keystone of its food pyramid, has long since been exterminated from the ecosystem. An experimental attempt to re-introduce it is to be made later this year or early in 1995.
 
'For Sale' Signs in Rich Ecosystems
 Humans' impact on the region's rivers and streams and the species-rich land along them is creating special concern. They appear to be the biologically richest parts of the ecosystem, and they happen to be where people like to congregate and build. Ecologists say stream-side real estate development could foul and heat waters now clean and cold enough for the region's prized trout -- magnets for droves of well-heeled fly-fishers -- as well as innumerable other aquatic species.
And the development is there. Subdivisions and "for sale" signs dot private property, for instance, along the Yellowstone River south of Livingston, Mont., along the North and South forks of the Shoshone River west of Cody, Wyo., and along the edges of forests outside Bozeman. The Snake River watershed outside Jackson, Wyo., in the ecosystem's southwestern quadrant, has long felt development pressures.
While private lands like these account for less than 20 percent of the ecosystem, their ecological importance is outsized, scientists say. In addition to their potential impact on stream quality, they contain a disproportionate share of riverside and low-elevation habitats for a wide range of wildlife -- from elk, moose and bears to eagles, ospreys, trumpeter swans and countless other birds. One especially big worry: since winter weather is a chief factor in regulating the size of ungulate populations, biologists fear that a return of severe winters would cause high mortality if migration routes from high country in the national forests and parks to lower elevations outside them are blocked by subdivisions and fences.
Already, conflicts between grizzly bears and people are taking place along the developing river corridors west of Cody. Bears forced by this year's hot, dry summer to forage in the valleys (sometimes at residents' garbage cans) are being trapped and released elsewhere. But wildlife officials expect that some will inevitably be killed, as often happens in bear-human confrontations. Even a single death is no minor threat to such a small population.
It seems certain to many scientists that the human impact is substantial, but just how substantial is not known. "Certainly, the impression among those who have lived here 20 or 30 years is that it's just black-and-white clear that the trends are very harmful to the integrity of the system, but there are no good quantitative measures of all that," says Dr. Tim W. Clark, a Yale University conservation biologist who has long lived and worked in Jackson.
Many ecologists and conservationists, including the Greater Yellowstone Coalition, believe the best way to attack the problem is to manage the ecosystem as a whole. The overriding goal would be to maintain its biological diversity and the natural processes that make it function, while allowing ecologically friendly human use of its resources. Rather than emphasizing the management of big animal populations in limited areas of the ecosystem, as has generally been done, the welfare of all species from bugs to bears -- and humans -- would be promoted simultaneously throughout the system.
Many agree that for now, at least, this can be done only at the state and local levels, with Federal help where it seems appropriate. And while a number of local communities have begun to rein in development in general, others have enacted regulations requiring development along rivers to be set back far enough from the bank so that riparian habitat and water quality can be preserved. This effort recently suffered a major setback, however, when county officials rejected such a plan for the Yellowstone River south of Livingston, where it flows through many miles of private property north of the park. Meanwhile, environmentalists are also negotiating conservation agreements with landowners along some of the ecosystem's rivers.
 
Enlisting Help From Ranchers
 On another front, Mike Clark, the executive director of the Greater Yellowstone Coalition, is conducting exploratory discussions with ranchers on ways to protect valuable wildlife habitats. Although grazing has some harmful ecological effects, ranchers have preserved habitats and migration routes for many animal species simply by keeping the lands they own open and undeveloped. The object now is to find ways to enable ranchers to keep their land intact in the face of intense pressure to sell to developers.
"In the Yellowstone area, the breakup of ranches may be the biggest threat to biodiversity there is," said George Frampton, the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for fish, wildlife and parks. "So there, the Federal Government might want to continue to subsidize grazing and keep large tracts of land together because the alternative for wildlife is worse." Typically, ranchlands are an amalgam of public and private property.
Under a law signed last year by President Clinton, the Yellowstone coalition is also instrumental in exchanging tracts of private land lying athwart a major elk migration route within the Gallatin National Forest for other lands outside the ecosystem.
That is how the effort to preserve greater Yellowstone is now proceeding: not according to some grand, all-encompassing blueprint, though blueprints do exist, but step by step, in a hard-slogging campaign at many governmental levels to save the ecosystem one piece at a time.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Seiko Plans Wristwatch With Worldwide Paging

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 12

 BODY:
In what sounds like something out of the Dick Tracy comic strip, the Seiko Corporation said today that it planned to develop a worldwide paging service that would deliver messages and other information to wristwatch receivers.
But unlike the two-way wristwatch radios used by the cartoon detective, the Seiko watches cannot receive voice messages, only text messages limited to 16 digits or letters. 
 The Japanese watchmaker envisions that subscribers will use its watches to receive sports scores, traffic alerts, stock quotes, bank balances, winning lottery numbers and messages to call the office.
 
Expanding in U.S.
 The company has offered the wristwatch paging service in Seattle and Portland, Ore., for about a year and a half and has about 14,000 subscribers.
Now, Seiko plans to expand service to 20 cities in the United States by the end of 1995 and to more than 50 American cities by the end of 1996, Yoshiyuki Narahashi, a company official, said at a news conference here today.
The service is also being introduced in Europe and parts of Asia, said Mr. Narahashi, who is the president of Seiko Communications B.V., a new subsidiary with headquarters in the Netherlands that will develop the system.
Seiko said its worldwide service would be the first one that was affordable, but it might take many years before the service was truly global. MTEL International, based in Washington, already offers international paging. There are also several nationwide paging services in the United States.
Michael Krier of Economic and Management Consultants International, a consulting firm in Washington that specializes in wireless communications, said Seiko was moving into a crowded field. Paging technology is also changing rapidly.
Mr. Narahashi said that Seiko would be able to offer less expensive service than existing paging services. While conventional systems require their own towers and antennas, Seiko will transmit messages over existing FM radio stations, using the FM subcarrier, a part of a radio station's signal that does not carry music. Seiko said its system could also transmit faster than conventional paging systems.
 
$6.95 a Month in Some Places
 In Seattle and Portland, the service costs as little as $6.95 a month for unlimited messages plus a $20 sign-up fee. Customers also have to buy a receiver watch selling for $100, which is now being reduced to $80. Mr. Narahashi said the fee for nationwide service would also be about $6.95 a month.
The technology used by Seiko was first developed by AT&E, a start-up company in San Francisco that attracted attention in the late 1980's. A company official predicted that AT&E would have 10 million subscribers by 1994 for wristwatch worldwide paging. But AT&E never could fulfill its ambitions and failed financially in 1991. Seiko, which had been providing the wristwatch receivers for AT&E, took over the company and the service.
The original wristwatch receivers were rather clunky and cost nearly $300. But with inevitable improvements in chips, Seiko's receiver is now the size of a normal wristwatch with a liquid crystal display.
The service will not be limited to wristwatches. The same information can be sent to notebook computers, radios and new information appliances that are sometimes called personal digital assistants.

HEADLINE: Gibson Files Lawsuit Over Derivatives

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Gibson Greetings Inc. sued the Bankers Trust Company yesterday, accusing it of "deception, cheating and fraud" in connection with a series of financial transactions known as derivatives.
In April, Gibson said it was taking a charge of $19.7 million because of several derivative transactions. 
 Bankers Trust, based in New York, said in a statement that its actions were "legal, proper and appropriate." It declined to discuss the details of Gibson's charges.
This is the first legal action by any of the half-dozen prominent companies that disclosed losses related to derivatives earlier this year. The Procter & Gamble Company, which said that it had lost $157 million in transactions also with Bankers Trust, said yesterday that it was still considering legal options.
 
An Obligation Claimed
 The suit by Gibson, a greeting card company based in Cincinnati, argues that Bankers Trust had an obligation to disclose more fully the risks of the derivative transactions and perhaps to protect the company from them. It seeks $73 million in damages.
Bankers Trust is expected to respond that as in most financial transactions among large corporations its derivatives dealings with Gibson were at arm's length. In other words, "buyer beware."
Many derivatives experts sympathetize with Bankers Trust's position. "It's just human nature when a trade goes against you, you find someone to blame," said Leslie Rawl, a partner in Capital Market Risk Advisers, a derivatives consulting firm in New York.
She said a number of other companies posted losses related to derivatives but had not made them public.
Like most large companies, Gibson had begun using a very common form of derivative known as an interest-rate swap in order to reduce the cost of its interest payments on the money it borrowed. Derivatives are financial contracts whose value is based on, or derived from, an underlying financial asset like interest rates, in the case of swaps, or stocks or commodities.
The lawsuit, filed in Federal court in Cincinnati, says the company was encouraged by Bankers Trust to enter into increasingly complex swap structures that were more speculative and volatile than Gibson realized. These contracts lost value rapidly this spring as interest rates began to rise sharply.
In addition to large corporations, a number of mutual funds and other investors have found that this year's rising interest rates have caused more damage than expected to some derivatives and other complex financial concoctions like certain mortgage-backed securities that had been designed to profit from declining interest rates.
The derivatives debacle at Procter & Gamble, for example, has shaken its upper management. Edwin Artzt, Procter & Gamble's chairman, said earlier this month that he had turned down $100,000 of his $420,000 annual bonus because of the derivatives losses. In addition, P.& G. disclosed yesterday that Raymond D. Mains, who had been the company's treasurer when the derivative transactions occurred, had retired as of Sept. 1. He had been on "special assignment" since the derivative problems emerged April, the company said.
"We're not surprised Gibson has filed suit," Mr. Artzt said in a statement yesterday.
 
'Cheating' Charged
 In its complaint, Gibson describes itself as financially unsophisticated and dependent on Bankers Trust, which the company says is its "lead bank" for advice and guidance regarding a series of swaps meant to reduce the interest cost of $30 million of bonds that Gibson had issued. Gibson contended that Bankers knew that it had policies to maintain a conservative financial posture.
The company accused Bankers Trust of "cheating Gibson out of nearly $500,000" in relation to several swap transactions that actually earned a profit in 1992. Gibson charges that Bankers paid it $260,000 to close out transactions that it subsequently learned to be worth $750,000.
After that, the suit says, Bankers Trust "recognized its opportunity for gain at the expense of an unknowing customer and, ignoring its obligation as Gibson's adviser and banker," solicited Gibson to enter at least 16 additional transactions.
The suit also asserts that Bankers Trust "knowingly and deliberately did not reveal the material risks and misrepresented the nature of the transactions and thereby deceived and defrauded Gibson."
At least one of those transactions committed Gibson to make a series of payments that would be determined by a formula involving taking the square of a common short-term interest rate known as Libor, for London interbank offered rate. By squaring the formula, Gibson's costs would increase rapidly as rates went up. Gibson says the disclosure of risks by Bankers Trust were inadequate.
In particular, the company says that the bank's disclosure assumed that the transaction would be held to maturity and did not how the market value of the swaps could fall during their life. Gibson had planned to use an accounting treatment for the swaps that did not recognize changes their changes in value.
But like executives at many other companies, Gibson's accountants changed their view when the market dropped and forced it to recognize its losses early. Gibson charges that Bankers Trust should have warned that its planned accounting treatment would be inadequate.
Among other charges of impropriety, Gibson says that at 11 P.M. on March 3, Bankers Trust gave the company an "ultimatum" that it had to pay the bank $17.5 million by the next morning to cover losses on derivative transactions or enter into another transaction that would limit the company's losses to no more than $27.5 million. The company chose the loss-limiting transaction, which it later said publicly cost $3 million.
Gibson is claiming actual damages of $23 million and punitive damages of $50 million.

HEADLINE: In a Shift, The British Lift Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Hoping to choke off inflation before it imperils the nation's steady if unspectacular economic recovery, Britain raised its benchmark interest rate today by half a point, to 5.75 percent, its first rate increase since 1989.
Following similar rate increases in Italy and Sweden last month, the move in Britain's base rate for short-term lending offered further evidence that Europe was now joining the United States in one of the trickiest dances in economic policy-making, tamping down incipient inflationary pressures without stamping out the underlying growth. 
 The task will be all the more complicated because Europe will be moving to restrain economic growth even while unemployment rates remain near record levels.
"The U.K. move reinforces expectations that the interest rate cycle has turned in Europe," said a report today from Salomon Brothers, the investment firm.
Britain emerged from the worldwide recession a year or so later than the United States, where the Federal Reserve began attacking inflation in February through a series of rate increases. But Britain is further on in its recovery than Germany and most of the rest of Western Europe.
 
Shift in Outlook on Germany
 Until recently, most analysts were convinced that the Bundesbank in Germany would cut rates one more time in the next few months to give that nation a final push out of its deep recession. But the combination of stronger-than-expected growth figures and the rate rises in Britain, Italy and Sweden has now led some economists to conclude that the Bundesbank will not cut again and that Europe's rate-cutting cycle has come to an end.
"Stronger European growth prospects, which encouraged the U.K.'s pre-emptive action, also make it unnecessary for the Bundesbank to cut rates further," the Salomon Brothers report said.
After suffering its worst downturn of the postwar era, the British economy is now growing at an annual rate of 3.5 percent. Unemployment has been falling gradually from double digits to its current 9.4 percent rate. While high by American standards, it is relatively low for Europe. The American unemployment rate now is 6.1 percent.
Inflation, as measured by the retail price index, is expected to be 2.4 percent for this year, rising to around 3 percent next year. At those rates, inflation is well within the Government's target range.
But there are clear signs that long-term inflationary pressures are building as industry bids up the cost of labor and raw materials and seeks to restore its profit margins. Just moments before announcing the rate increase, the Government said prices of goods as they left factories had risen three-tenths of a percent last month, which is higher than expected.
For the last several weeks, economists had been predicting a pre-emptive strike against inflation, although few analysts expected the Government and the Bank of England to act so soon. In raising interest rates, British policy makers hope to temper economic growth by making borrowing more expensive for businesses and consumers.
Only once since 1989 has Britain sought to raise rates. That was two years ago, when the Government announced two rate increases on the same day -- from 10 percent to 12 percent and then to 15 percent -- in the midst of a frantic effort to defend the value of the pound during a run on European currencies. But the Government decided within hours to allow the pound to float in value and rescinded the rate increases before they came into effect.
The Conservative Government has publicly committed itself in recent months to breaking the boom-and-bust cycle that has plagued the economy here since World War II. Governments have repeatedly stimulated the economy out of recession through aggressive rate cuts, but then failed to keep inflation under control until they had no choice but to raise rates to extremely high levels. Official interest rates last peaked here at 15 percent in 1989.
"So often in the past, accelerating inflation has prevented us from enjoying sustained growth," said Kenneth Clarke, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, in announcing the rate increase today. "I am determined this will not happen again."
Mr. Clarke also told reporters at a news conference that the Government would not cut taxes this year, and would focus instead on efforts to continue bringing down Britain's budget deficit.
Today's rate increase was criticized by some business leaders, who said they feared that the increase came too soon and could, as the British Chambers of Commerce put it, "sabotage much of the gentle recovery we have seen."
 
Peril for Prime Minister
 The move also held political peril for Prime Minister John Major, whose popularity in opinion polls is at a low. Mr. Major has received little or no credit from voters for Britain's economic recovery, according to polls. The prospect of rising mortgage rates and other interest charges was seized on by the opposition Labor Party today as evidence of Mr. Major's economic mismanagement.
The interest rate increase came earlier than most economists had expected, and seemed intended in part to build credibility in the financial markets for the Government's anti-inflation efforts.
In that sense, the rate increase appeared to be working today. With investors more confident that inflation can be kept under control, bond prices rose, sending the yield on the benchmark 15-year Government bond, or "gilt," down by 9 basis points, to 8.69 percent, from 8.78 percent on Friday. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Reaction on the London Stock Exchange was mixed, with the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares dropping by as much as 25 points during the morning then recovering somewhat to close at 3,128.8, down 10.5 points.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries End the Day Little Changed in Price

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday as investors shied from placing bets before today's report on consumer prices.
Bonds tumbled on Friday, after a Government report showed a surprising surge in producer prices. The six-tenths of 1 percent gain in the Producer Price Index fed concerns that the Federal Reserve, despite five increases in short-term interest rates, had not subdued inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income securities like bonds. 
 Yesterday, the bond market was anxiously waiting to see if inflation had filtered down to consumers.
"Every precondition for inflation to rise has been in place," said Charles Lieberman, chief financial markets economist at Chemical Securities Inc. "Now it looks like the chickens have finally come home to roost."
The price of the 30-year bond fell 3/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.71 percent, from 7.70 percent on Friday, the highest since July 11. The yield on the two-year note was 6.34 percent, 2 basis points higher than its yield on Friday. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
At yesterday's weekly auction of Treasury bills, rates rose on concerns that inflation is picking up. The Treasury sold $11.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 4.61 percent, up from 4.58 percent last week. Another $11.7 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 4.99 percent, up from 4.89 percent.
The Consumer Price Index for August is expected to show an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent, and a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent when food and energy costs are excluded, according to a survey of economists. Inflation as measured by the C.P.I. was running at an annual rate of 2.7 percent through July, the same as for all of last year.
"If the C.P.I. confirms the P.P.I., then we'll head down again," said Andrew Brenner, senior government bond trader with the Nomura Securities Company International.
The August Producer Price Index showed wholesale price inflation running at an annual rate of 2.9 percent, compared with two-tenths of 1 percent for the first eight months of 1993, as well as for all of last year.
"There's no way you can make this look good," said Dennis Bushe, managing director at Prudential Investment Advisers in Newark, which has $12 billion in assets.
Even if the consumer prices report shows a less-than-expected increase, investors may not buy government securities because they are wary of economic reports later this week that could also suggest rising prices and faster growth.
The Government will report tomorrow on last month's retail sales and Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, will deliver his periodic economic report to Congress. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia will release a regional price survey on Thursday, and the Fed will report Friday on industrial production and capacity utilization in August.
If the consumer price figures are better than expected, "people will still be looking forward to some relatively strong numbers," said Timothy Jay, head United States government cbond trader at Lehman Brothers. "If we get a bad one, then the market will continue to deteriorate."
The following are the results of yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: President Leads Swearing-In Of New Corps of Volunteers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Raising his right hand and beaming like a proud scoutmaster, President Clinton swore in a group of the first 15,000 members of Americorps, the domestic Peace Corps that he promised in his campaign and that was authorized by Congress a year ago.
The members, most of whom will receive educational grants in exchange for their service, will begin work around the country in programs ranging from immunization efforts for children and the elderly to recycling, tutoring, crime prevention and urban revitalization. 
 Some 850 were inducted as more than 2,000 dignitaries and supporters took part in the ceremony on the North Lawn of the White House. They were kept sweltering there for more than two hours, and an elaborately synchronized satellite television transmission was thrown awry because of the crash of a light plane early this morning on the South Lawn, where the event was supposed to have taken place.
Mr. Clinton swore in five members in the Oval Office, and this ceremony was broadcast to more than 50 places around the country where members of the Cabinet, governors and mayors swore in groups of volunteers.
 
Not a Question of Money
 "Any of us could get a job that pays much more," said Russell C. Teter 3d, a 22-year-old from Middletown, N.Y., who will work in a psychiatric hospital for veterans. "I'm young, not married -- no children. This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to give something to my country."
For his part, Mr. Clinton seemed to exult in an opportunity to seize the moral high ground. In recent weeks, a rebellious Congress has apparently shelved his ambitious plan for expanding health insurance coverage, and he has had a difficult time in several areas of foreign affairs.
"I will get things done for America to make our people safer, smarter and healthier," the President said, leading volunteers in an oath written for the occasion. "Faced with apathy, I will take action. Faced with conflict, I will seek common ground. Faced with adversity, I will persevere. I will carry this commitment with me this year and beyond. I am an Americorps member, and I am going to get things done."
 
Favorite Clinton Idea
 The idea of a national service agency has been a favorite of Mr. Clinton's ever since he proposed it at a meeting of the Democratic Leadership Council in May 1988.
Both Mr. Clinton and his aides were eager to link the National Service Corps with such warmly remembered predecessors as Franklin D. Roosevelt's Civilian Conservation Corps of 1933 and John F. Kennedy's Peace Corps, which was created in 1961 and is still going.
"We hope our program will delight Americans in the same way that the Peace Corps has," said Eli J. Segal, chief executive of the Corporation for National Service.
Mr. Segal emphasized that the program had bipartisan support and took pleasure in ticking off a list of Republican governors and mayors, like Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles, who officiated at swearing-in ceremonies around the country.
Kimberly Barnes O'Connor, an aide to Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum, the ranking Republican on the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources who led the fight against authorizing the program last year, said: "There has always been bipartisan support for the general concept. We would have preferred a slower growth rate, less Federal control and a few other things, but now it's the law and we hope it succeeds."
Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, is less reconciled. "This program gives a lot of help to people who don't need it," he said.
 
'An Opportunity to Serve'
 Mr. Segal disputed the view. "This is not a jobs program or primarily a financial aid program, but an opportunity to serve," he said. "We never thought it wise to ask any one income group to perform national service.
"You might say we're doing two things at once. We're asking people to serve their country and in the process helping them with the cost of higher education at a time when those costs continue to skyrocket."
Under the present program, members will receive $7,500 a year for their living expenses and an education award of $4,725 a year for a maximum of two years to help finance their college education or vocational training, or to pay back their college loans. There are no restrictions on age.
Educators around the country said they were generally pleased with the program. Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, said: "It's the right program for the right time. Young people feel disengaged, but there are many signs that they're ready to be inspired by a larger commitment.
"The numbers are small, but the message is significant. Of course, it doesn't begin to solve the problem of college costs. That requires another solution."
The Corporation for National Service is sponsoring 350 programs in more than 700 communities around the country.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton talking with the audience at the swearing-in for the corps of volunteers that was established last year. Groups totaling 15,000 were sworn in yesterday at the White House and in 50 cities. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines vs. Pound After British Rate Increase

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell to a two-month low against the British pound yesterday after the Bank of England raised short-term lending rates to control inflation.
But the dollar rose against the German mark after Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition Government was dealt a setback in state elections, creating some doubts about its ability to retain power in next month's federal elections. 
 The pound rallied against major currencies after the Bank of England raised Britain's minimum lending rate to 5.75 percent from 5.25 percent, the first increase since October 1989. Higher rates make deposits in pounds more attractive.
"Everyone's attention was on the pound," said Sudir Patel, foreign exchange manager at Nationsbank of Texas, in Houston. "The rate increase was kind of a surprise."
Britain's increase stirred speculation that rates would rise across Europe, bringing a definite end to a two-year period of declines. The speculation started last month when Sweden and Italy raised their interest rates.
In late New York trading, the pound was quoted at $1.5695, up from $1.5530 on Friday, after trading at $1.5733, its strongest level since July.
By contrast, the dollar posted gains against the mark, rising to 1.5436 marks from 1.5376.
The dollar was steady at 99.18 yen, as traders awaited developments in trade negotiations between the United States and Japan. Many traders expect the dollar to rally if the two sides find a way to curb Japan's $60 billion annual trade surplus with the United States.
Many traders and analysts had expected the dollar to rally this year as interest rates fell in Europe and rose in the United States, making dollar-denominated deposits more attractive. But the dollar slumped as concern about inflation sent stocks and bonds into a tailspin. That chased many foreign buyers out of the American markets, dampening their demand for dollars. With rates rising in Europe, the dollar's prospects are now even dimmer, traders said.
"The days of rate decreases in Europe have ended," said Joe Francomano, a trader at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. "The dollar's slump is going to continue."
The dollar tumbled against the mark and other currencies on Friday after the Government reported that producer prices in the United States rose six-tenths of 1 percent in August, an increase that was bigger than had been expected. The report caused concern that inflation would erode the value of dollar-denominated investments.
But the dollar steadied yesterday as traders awaited today's report on consumer prices.
