HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Nears a 4-Year High As Demand Remains Strong

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper prices rose to their highest level in almost four years yesterday as traders continued to see growing demand.
On other commodity markets, coffee and wheat prices rose, helping to lift the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities up 0.19 point, to 233.13. 
 As economies worldwide begin to recover, copper demand is rising for everything from plumbing fixtures used in new housing to wiring for cars and electric motors, analysts said. Copper consumption in the United States grew 9.8 percent in the first half from a year earlier, the United States Bureau of Mines said.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, copper for September delivery rose 2.25 cents, to $1.211 a pound, the highest price for a contract about to expire since Oct. 26, 1990. Copper has risen 8.3 percent over the last two weeks.
Demand is so strong that warehouse operators cannot ship copper to customers as fast as they would like, forcing copper consumers to wait weeks for deliveries, said Richard Hirsch, vice president with the Sharps Pixley brokerage house in New York.
 
Coffee Prices Rise
 Coffee prices also jumped yesterday after another dry weekend in Brazil increased the prospect of further damage to trees already harmed by two frosts in June and July. The coffee contract for December delivery rose 7 cents, to $2.24 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
Wheat prices rose to their highest level in almost nine months after the United States Department of Agriculture lowered production forecasts for several leading exporters, increasing expectations that world demand for American wheat will rise.
The agency projected world wheat reserves at 119.42 million tons, down 4.3 percent from its 124.86-million-ton estimate released last month, as a drought in Australia worsened. Australia, normally the world's fourth- largest wheat exporter, will ship only 9 million tons of wheat this year, down from 13.5 million tons last year.
The September wheat contract rose 4 cents, to $3.80 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, the highest level since Jan. 18.
"With the lower crops in other countries, they'll have to come to the U.S. for wheat," said John Kleist, director of agricultural research with Quantum Financial Services in Chicago.
Crude oil slipped for a third day amid concern that seasonal maintenance work at refineries is reducing demand for crude. Crude oil for October delivery fell 14 cents, to $17.39 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Congress Must Vote on Haiti

 BODY:
To invade Haiti without prior Congressional approval would short-circuit the United States Constitution. It would also leave the President with sole political responsibility if the operation turns sour. Yet that is just what the Clinton Administration now suggests it might do.
Neither of the situations usually cited as justifying independent action by the Commander in Chief -- military crisis or unexpected threat to national security -- exists in this case. To the contrary, Congressional deliberation is both practical and desirable, and there is plenty of time for it. 
 The Constitution vests the power to declare war in Congress while giving the President command of the armed forces. Those overlapping responsibilities have fueled generations of controversy.
Beyond indulging a natural tendency to press against a vaguely defined constitutional boundary, recent Presidents have invoked practical arguments for bypassing Congress, like the need for speedy response or tactical surprise. Under the threat of a missile-launched nuclear Armageddon on 20 minutes' warning, the idea of protracted Congressional deliberation could be made to look like an absurd 18th-century anachronism.
Cold-war Presidents also argued that military actions taken under the authority of treaty commitments or U.N. resolutions were not really wars, but "police actions" or "troop redeployments," and thereby exempt from constitutional requirements.
For years Congress was happy to avoid responsibility. But Presidential excesses in Vietnam drove Congress to reclaim some of its authority in the War Powers Resolution of 1973. This required Presidents to get timely Congressional approval whenever they placed U.S. troops at risk. Since then, Presidents have disputed the resolution's authority but sometimes fulfilled its provisions.
In 1991, Democrats in both houses insisted that President Bush get prior Congressional approval for Operation Desert Storm. Now, misplaced fealty drives many of those same Democrats to relieve President Clinton of the same responsibility.
That is poor governance and poor partisanship too. Democrats would do better to protect Mr. Clinton from enmeshing himself in a military action where most Americans see no compelling national interests at stake and in which the first casualties are likely to bring bitter recrimination.
President Jean-Bertrand Aristide still represents Haiti's legitimate government. But sending the Marines to restore him to power makes no sense even if, as some military experts predict, that turns out to be an afternoon's work.
A century of Latin interventions should have taught Washington that it cannot enforce democracy at gunpoint. Haitians elected Father Aristide and still support him, but even his legitimacy may not survive being installed by foreign troops.
It is frustrating to watch Haiti's generals sneer at sanctions, play games with the U.N. and systematically shoot down democratic leaders in cold blood. Their conduct warrants international ostracism and economic sanctions until they yield power, then generous and muscular support for the elected government that replaces them.
But the conditions that warrant an American invasion -- conditions that include broad public support and Congressional agreement -- are not in place at this time. Mr. Clinton should not abuse his powers and risk damage to his Presidency by plunging ahead.

HEADLINE: Deficit Reduction, Chapter and Verse

BYLINE: By Herbert Stein; Herbert Stein, senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, was chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers under Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The other day I was surfing through the channels when I heard a spokesman for the Christian Coalition explaining his organization's platform. I was surprised to hear that one of the planks was balancing the budget.
I am not an expert on Christian doctrine -- or on Jewish doctrine either, for that matter -- but I have paid a lot of attention to arguments about balancing the budget. With one exception, I don't think I have ever heard it suggested that balancing the budget was a particularly Christian precept. 
 The one exception was a remark by Walter Heller, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers when John F. Kennedy was President. He said, dismissively, that balancing the budget was part of "the Puritan ethic." But Mr. Heller, although a smart fellow, was not an authority on Christianity.
I have consulted a concordance on the Bible. Apparently the word "budget" does not appear in either the Old or the New Testament. The word "balance" does appear about eight times, but never in connection with fiscal policy.
Perhaps I am being too literal in expecting to find a specific reference to balancing the budget in a sacred text. There may be a more general principle from which an injunction to balance the budget can be derived.
Probably the main moral or ethical question has to do with equity between the present generation and future ones. A common, although not universal, view among economists is that running a budget deficit enables the present generation to consume more than it would if it balanced the budget. This reduces the income of future generations by reducing investment. Thus, running a deficit can be regarded as a way in which the present generation puts a burden on the future, or the future generation makes a sacrifice for the present one.
What is the proper moral judgment of that? The Fifth Commandment says, "Honor thy father and thy mother." It does not say, "Thou shalt honor thy children and grandchildren." Thus one might say that the commandment not only sanctions but may even require running a budget deficit as a way for younger generations to sacrifice for older ones.
Of course, one can look at the question in another way. The Old and New Testaments both call on us to love our neighbors as ourselves. If "neighbor" can be interpreted temporally as well as spatially, we can say that the generations to come are our neighbors and we are instructed to show as much concern for future generations as for our own.
One implication might be that we should so behave that future generations will have as high per capita incomes as we do. This may tell us something about budget policy, but it does not tell us to balance the budget.
From 1973 to 1993, when the budget was never in balance and deficits averaged 3.6 percent of gross domestic product, real per capita G.D.P. rose at an annual rate of 1.3 percent. That is enough to double per capita income in 50 years. In the high deficit years that began with the Reagan Administration, from 1981 to 1993, when deficits averaged 4.3 percent of G.D.P., real per capita incomes rose 1.5 percent a year. If loving future generations as ourselves is to be evidenced by leaving them per capita incomes as high as ours, that does not call for balancing the budget.
But our concern for the future will not be, or should not be, measured by real per capita G.D.P. alone. Our legacy will be something more serious than that. If we can leave our children a country free of the danger of war, with safe streets, reduced racial hostility, fewer miserable urban ghettos and an elevated culture, we will not have to apologize for leaving a larger Federal deficit, almost all of which our children will own.
Recently I heard some scientists discussing the research they were doing in the field of genetics. They were talking of the probability that as a result of their work the risk of breast cancer would be greatly reduced within 15 or 20 years. It seems to me that the willingness of our generation to invest in that research shows much love for the next generation. The scientists were at the National Institutes of Health. Their work was financed by the Government -- that is, financed in part by the deficit.

I am not arguing here against a policy of balancing the budget, for which there is something to be said. Nor am I arguing against the right of the Christian Coalition to support a balanced budget. They have the same right to do that as the National Association of Manufacturers or the Concord Coalition or anyone else.
But I do think there is an obligation not to mislead the public about the basis for one's support for balancing the budget or for any other policy. The Christian Coalition would be truer to its name, in my opinion, if it did not give the impression that its support for balancing the budget was derived from Christian doctrine.
"Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's," it is said. I believe that Federal budget policy falls in Caesar's domain. It is also said that "Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain." I believe that means that one should not invoke the authority of God for propositions, however worthy on other grounds, for which God has given no sanction.
 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Why Small Business Disliked Health Care Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Hooray for the collapse of health care social engineering! While the observation of a sickness in our delivery system was accurate, the diagnosis was faulty and the prescription truly horrific.
The problem with our system today is not too little insurance and government, but rather too much. Eighty percent of the $1 trillion spent on health care is affected by government subsidies. There is simply no rational reason for large-scale government involvement in this sector of our economy, nor for insurance to be involved in day-to-day patient care. 
 Medicare, Medicaid and tax deductions for employer-paid health insurance should be abolished. With the $300 billion thus saved, the Federal Government could reduce the deficit and at the same time afford targeted subsidies for medical expenses for the poor, as it does for housing (vouchers) and food (food stamps).
Private insurance can create portable, catastrophic coverage with a variety of deductibles that will socialize some of the costs of expensive illnesses. Below the catastrophic level, mandatory insurance creates more problems than it solves. If costs are ever to be controlled, consumers must want to say, "How much is this costing me, can I get it cheaper and better elsewhere, and will you guarantee your results?"
Today the consumer is told, "Don't worry, it's covered by insurance." With third-party payers, it is no wonder costs are out of control. If our food was mostly paid by someone else, wouldn't we be eating steak every night?
The practice of medicine is not an arcane priesthood that should be exempted from the discipline of private competitive markets. On the contrary, of all the professions it is the one where the consumer can, through education, best help to lower costs and improve outcomes.
With normal economic incentives to shop for the best service and with better pricing information, the same market forces will be brought to bear that have made our food and shelter not only the best, but the best value in the world. Government regulation and more insurance ("universal coverage") go in exactly the wrong direction.
 
CHRISTOPHER W. WALKER
Reston, Va., Sept. 7, 1994
 
The writer is a principal in a commercial real estate development company active in northern Virginia.

HEADLINE: Mexican Government Panel Instills The Unfamiliar Idea of Competition

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 12

 BODY:
In a slender 20-story tower at the center of this city, a team of young bureaucrats is attempting to create what until recently was as unlikely to be found in Mexico as chili peppers that don't burn -- a competitive economy.
 The 140 economists, investigators and staff form the backbone of the Federal Competition Commission, which in its first year of operation has managed to anger, obstruct and scold some of Mexico's biggest companies. The commission has fined brokerage houses for bid-rigging in connection with the sale of Treasury notes. It has made the oil monopoly Pemex loosen its grip on the number of gas stations it supplies. It has even put an end to price-fixing by corner laundries. 
American companies doing business in Mexico, or planning to enter the Mexican market, stand to benefit from the commission's actions. By policing competition, the regulators can make the market freer and more open, essentially more like markets in the United States.
 However, some analysts here doubt the seriousness of trying to legislate competition in a country that still tolerates monopolies in oil, electricity and railroads.
 "The commission represents both a serious attempt to encourage competition, and basic window-dressing for this administration," said Roberto Salinas-Leon, executive director of the Center for Free Enterprise Research, a nonprofit institute in Mexico City.
 Neil Perry, former chief of research for the Mexico City office of Baring Securities, said the new commission was more than just symbolic. "It's been given some bite," he said, "but so far it's just been snipping at people's ankles."
 Legislating freer competition is considered a natural complement to existing trade agreements, which have toughened up an economy that traditionally sheltered businesses from competition and let some become huge, inefficient monopolies.
 The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which covers world trade, and more recently, the North American Free Trade Agreement by Mexico, Canada and the United States, have opened an estimated 55 percent of the Mexican economy to a flood of international competition over the last decade. The law creating the commission in June 1993 envisioned covering areas of the economy not directly affected by the trade pacts, like telecommunications and transportation.
 Using wide-ranging powers granted by the new law, Santiago Levy, the president of the commission, is expected to see that Mexico operates as an essentially free and open market.
 "Mexico," said Mr. Levy, a bookish 38-year-old economist educated at Boston University, "is a country where, for 50 years, competition, monopoly and antitrust were just not household words. When the commission started, people only had rough notions of what competition really meant. Some came in and complained because a competitor was lowering prices. That says a lot about the competitive culture here."
 As Mr. Levy described it in a recent interview, the commission functions like the Federal Trade Commission in the United States, with judicial powers and investigative responsibilities. For the first year, Mr. Levy kept the commission deliberately low key, and he was not available for interviews until recently.
 "People here are not used to what antitrust is," he said. "It can easily be confused with an anti-business attitude."
 
Hoarding Bottles
 Mexican businesses were sometimes flustered by the very concept of competition. Consider the case of a Coca-Cola bottler in the northern city of Hermosillo who filed a complaint with the commission, asserting that the Pepsi-Cola bottler across town was engaging in illegal activity by collecting Coke bottles along with its own. The suit charged the bottler with hoarding his competitor's bottles in a storage yard and later destroying them.
 Mr. Levy said he thought he was on to something until he found out that the Coca-Cola bottler collected empty Pepsi bottles and held onto them, committing the same infraction as his competitor.
 The commission dismissed the suit.
 One of its earliest targets was the laundry industry. The laundry owners admitted that their board fixed prices for cleaning slacks or a shirt, but said they were following Government orders to control prices that dated back to a 1960 anti-inflation campaign.
 In another case, the commission fined five financial firms $800,000 for manipulating the auction of Mexican Treasury notes. According to the commission, the brokerage houses conspired not to bid above a certain level at the auction held by the Bank of Mexico, thus depressing prices.
 Felipe Presbitero, who heads the brokerage division of the National Association of Business Lawyers, would not comment on the merits of the case, but Francisco Velazquez Osuna, in charge of international businesses for the association, complained that the fines were too high.
 "We're not prepared for fines that strong," he said.
 The commission also went after Mexico's biggest company, the state-owned Pemex, whose oil monopoly is based on a clause in the nation's Constitution that leaves the Government in charge of strategic sectors of the economy. Pemex had interpreted this to cover the sale of gasoline. Mexico has fewer than 4,000 gas stations, each of which Pemex protects from local competition.
 
More Pumps Expected
Mr. Levy argued that the Constitution did not cover the sale of gasoline. Under a consent decree, Pemex has agreed to sell gasoline to anyone with municipal and environmental approval to build a station, regardless of how close the existing station is. Mr. Levy expects the number of gas stations to double in the next three or four years.
 The commission also has the power to intervene in the regulatory affairs of other Government agencies. In June, Mr. Levy got involved in one of Mexico's most important regulatory decisions in years, the opening of long-distance telephone service to competition in January 1997.
 In a nonbinding opinion, he took the freest market approach possible, advising that Telefonos de Mexico, the giant phone company and provider of most service in this country, face as much competition as possible.
 The commission's prestige was increased when the Communications and Transportation Ministry adopted most of its positions, although Telmex is known to have resented Mr. Levy's involvement.
The commission is expected to flourish under Mexico's President-elect, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, an economist and dedicated free marketeer. Mr. Levy says he does not expect the commission to expand its powers after Mr. Zedillo takes office on Dec. 1 but rather to consolidate the progress already made.
 Mr. Levy and the commission have been criticized for not going after giant companies like Televisa, the media conglomerate that dominates Mexican television. Some analysts also think he lacks independence because he works too closely with the Ministry of Commerce. Mr. Levy acknowledges that there have been shortcomings but, he said, Mexico has lived for more than half a century without real competition, and "you can't do everything in a year."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In advocating unsettling changes, Mexico's Federal Competition Commission has found itself arrayed against some powerful interests, not least the Government oil monopoly Pemex. Though the panel has succeeded in loosening Pemex's grip as a supplier, its retail stations remain omnipresent. At a Pemex station in the Coyoacan area of Mexico City, German Martinez de Jesus, an attendant, pumped fuel. (Keith Dannemiller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
. . . And in Connecticut

 BODY:
GOVERNOR
 
THE DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES
 
WILLIAM E. CURRY JR., 42. State Comptroller since 1990, lawyer, served as a state senator from 1979 to 1983, ran unsuccessfully for the U.S. House of Representatives in 1982, former political director of Freeze Voter, the political arm of the Nuclear freeze movement. JOHN B. LARSON, 46. President pro tem of the State Senate since 1987, spent four years as a high school teacher, became president of an insurance agency in 1987, served on East Hartford school board and town council before being elected to the state Senate in 1983.,
 
THE ISSUES: The campaign has revolved largely around who would be a better manager. Mr. Larson, the party-endorsed candidate, cites his 11 years in the state Senate as proof of his leadership. Mr. Curry has blamed the Democratic establishment for the state's fiscal problems and says he would shake things up. Both share strong anti-crime positions and similar economic development strategies. The biggest difference is on tax cuts: Mr. Larson promises a $287 million reduction in the income tax; Mr. Curry has proposed a $1 billion cut in property taxes.
 
 ANALYSIS: Mr. Larson has run a high-profile television campaign. Mr. Curry has concentrated on building a field operation. While Mr. Larson's approach has given him greater name recognition, it remains to be seen what impact it will have in a primary, in which voter turnout is usually low and get-out-the-vote efforts are often critical.
 
THE REPUBLICAN CANDIDATES
 
JOHN G. ROWLAND, 37. Congressman from Waterbury 1985-91, barely lost the 1990 race for Governor, member of House Armed Services Committee. Since 1990 has been consultant for several military contractors based in Connecticut. PAULINE R. KEZER, 52. Former teacher, four-term state representative from Plainville. Lost race for Secretary of the State in 1986 but won in 1990, becoming the first Republican elected to a state office since 1970.
 
THE ISSUES: Mr. Rowland and Mrs. Kezer both want to stimulate the economy by cutting spending and taxes. Mr. Rowland promises to eliminate the income tax, Mrs. Kezer to cut the tax rate by 35 percent. Mr. Rowland wants to reduce the role of government in people's lives; Mrs. Kezer proposes to give voters a greater voice through referendums and initiatives.
 
ANALYSIS: Mrs. Kezer, a moderate, contends that Mr. Rowland is too conservative to win a general election. Criticizing his consulting business, she says he cannot speak for the state's workers after taking large fees from companies laying off thousands of workers. Mr. Rowland, endorsed by the convention, leads all candidates in polls and has raised eight times as much money as Mrs. Kezer. He says he is most in tune with the mood of voters, who he says are worried about the state's economy and about crime.
 
SENATE
 
THE REPUBLICAN CANDIDATES
 
GERALD LABRIOLA, 62. Retired pediatrician. Served one term in the State Senate, ran unsuccessfully for lieutenant governor in 1982, lost a party primary for governor in 1986. JOSEPH BENTIVEGNA, 38. Ophthalmologist, volunteer physician in Haiti for Sisters of Mother Teresa, former Republican Town Committee member in Rocky Hill. Has never run for public office.
 
THE ISSUES: Both candidates attack the Democratic incumbent, Joseph I. Lieberman, as a professional politician who is loyal to special interest. Both call for changing campaign-finance laws to limit the advantage of incumbents like Mr. Lieberman, who has raised more than 30 times as much money as the two men combined.
 
ANALYSIS: Neither man is well known or able to afford extensive advertising, so Mr. Labriola, the convention-endorsed candidate, should have an advantage in being on the same ballot line as Mr. Rowland. Mr. Labriola is respected within the party, but Mr. Bentivegna has attracted attention with brash, if sometimes unusual proposals that contradict conventional political wisdom. In early polls, Mr. Lieberman holds large leads over both men.
 
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
 
FIFTH DISTRICT CANDIDATES
 
JAMES H. MALONEY, 45. Lawyer, State Senator from Danbury since 1986. As co-chairman of the General Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, wields great clout in the Legislature. Was a driving force behind a plan to overhaul the state property tax system. THOMAS S. LUBY, 42. Lawyer, Democratic majority leader in the State House of Representatives. A former Federal Prosecutor, he led a bipartisan coalition trying to reduce state spending. Wrote a state law making stalking a crime. Has represented Meriden in the House since 1986.
 
THE DISTRICT: The district is economically diverse, encompassing wealthy enclaves like Wilton and Ridgefield and blue-collar cities like Waterbury and Meriden. Once a Democratic stronghold, it was seized by the Republicans in the 1984 Reagan landslide.
 
THE ISSUE: The campaign has been bitter, with both candidates exchanging charges about tax deliquencies, lying and general unfitness for office. Both have pledged to work for tax cuts and economic development. Mr. Luby puts emphasis on crime and law enforcement. Mr. Maloney trumpets his record on environmental issues.
 
ANALYSIS: Mr. Maloney, endorsed by the party, has blamed Mr. Luby for this spring's lackluster legislative session, while taking credit himself for the bills that did pass. Mr. Luby appears to be relying on attacks -- about Mr. Maloney's character and failure to pay tax bills -- to overtake Mr. Maloney.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
The Primary: Highlights of Major Races in New York State. . .

 BODY:
GOVERNOR
 
THE DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES
 
MARIO M. CUOMO, 64. Governor since 1983. A lawyer, he was appointed Secretary of State by Gov. Hugh Carey in 1975. He lost to Edward I. Koch in the 1977 New York City mayoral race but was elected lieutenant governor with Mr. Carey in 1978. He has raised over $6 million for the campaign. LENORA B. FULANI, 44. A developmental psychologist in New York City and chairwoman of the New Alliance Party. Over the past 12 years she has run for New York City mayor, lieutenant governor, governor and President, never garnering more than 1 percent of the vote. She has raised more than $93,000.
 
THE ISSUES: At the heart of Ms. Fulani's campaign is the premise that she is an alternative to Mr. Cuomo. Beyond that, she has called for easier ballot access for statewide candidates, term limits for state officials, and initiative and referendum. Mr. Cuomo, who has largely ignored the primary challenge, supports improving ballot access, but opposes term limits and initiative and referendum, saying all those issues should be debated at a constitutional convention.
 
 ANALYSIS: Mr. Cuomo is expected to win big, but the question is how big. A less than overwhelming victory in the primary could signal trouble for November. Analysts also say the race will provide a measure of how well Mr. Cuomo is faring with black voters. Ms. Fulani, who is black, has campaigned heavily in black neighborhoods, while Mr. Cuomo is thought to have lost support among New York City blacks who blame him for Mayor David N. Dinkins's loss last year.
 
THE REPUBLICAN CANDIDATES
 
GEORGE E. PATAKI, 49. A State Senator from Putnam County. A lawyer, major of Peekskill from 1981, member of the state Assembly from 1985-91, when he was elected to the Senate. Chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee. He has raised more than $5.2 million. RICHARD M. ROSEBAUM, 63. A lawyer from Penfield, near Rochester, a member of the Monroe County Legislature from 1966-68, justice of the State Supreme Court from 1970-72. Appointed chairman of the state Republican Party of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1973, holding the position until 1977. Republican national committeeman from 1977-92. He has raised more than $2.2 million.
 
THE ISSUES: Mr. Rosenbaum, who won a place on the ballot by circulating petitions, has accused Mr. Pataki, the party's endorsed candidate, of being controlled by United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Though both men call themselves "pro-choice," Mr. Rosenbaum opposes any restrictions on abortion, while Mr. Pataki favors mandatory waiting periods, parental notification for minors and counseling for women seeking Medicaid-financed abortions.
 
ANALYSIS: Mr. Pataki, who has also been endorsed by the Conservative Party, is heavily favored because of his strong organizational support and because Republican primary voters are thought to favor more conservative candidates. Mr. Rosenbaum has a small organization, is widely identified with the party's more liberal Rockefeller wing and is depending on a final-week advertising blitz.
 
SENATE
 
THE DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES
 
DANIEL PATRICK MOYNIHAN, 67. Senator since 1977; cabinet or subcabinet member for four Presidents from Kennedy to Ford; Ambassador to India; Harvard Professor; author or editor of 16 books. Now chairman of Senate Finance Committee and one of the most powerful men in Washington. Has raised more than $3 million. AL SHARPTON, 39, preacher and street protester, ordained at age 10 by a Pentecostal minister in Brooklyn, active in civil rights causes for 20 years, former Federal informant. Made surprisingly strong run for Senate nomination two years ago. He has raised $88,079.
 
THE ISSUES: Mr. Moynihan, one of the most prolific writers and thinkers in American public life for more than a quarter century on issues from traffic safety to family stability, has also long been a lightning rod for controversy. Sometimes scorned by fellow Democrats as too conservative, never fully embraced by Republican administrations he served, his ideas defy easy classification. Since he warned of the collapose of the black family in the 1960's, he has had especially wary relations with black officials, who accused him of blaming the victim. Mr. Sharpton has sought to exploit such strains, and accused Mr. Moynihan of losing touch with the average voters.
 
ANALYSIS: Mr. Moynihan has held overwhelming leads in all polls to date, and Mr. Sharpton concedes he has virtually no chance of winning. But he hopes to use his candidacy in his continuing quest for political legitimacy. If he draws significant support from black voters, he will be a broker in statewide politics.
 
THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
 
EIGHTH DISTRICT CANDIDATES
 
JERROLD L. NADLER, 47. Incumbent, elected 1992; state assemblyman, 1976-92; graduate of Columbia College, Fordham Law School; advocate for rail freight. Raised on a poultry farm in New Jersey, cut political teeth protesting Vietnam war; lives on Upper West Side. Has raised more than $650,000. THOMAS K. DUANE, 39. City Councilman, elected 1991; former stockbroker, community board member, Democratic district leader and Manhattan coordinator for former City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman; graduate of Lehigh University, lives in Chelsea. Has raised more than $227,000.
 
THE DISTRICT: This district stretches from Grant's Tomb to Coney Island, encompassing neighborhoods on the Upper West Side that are among the most liberal in the nation and the conservative Satmar Hasidic enclave of Borough Park, Brooklyn. It is about 80 percent white, 9 percent black, 6 percent Asian, 12 percent are of Hispanic origin.
 
THE ISSUES: The candidates have tried to best each other for the title of most pure and liberal on a host of issues on which they would both be badly out of sync with much of the country, from gay rights (which both support) to the death penalty (which both oppose). Mr. Nadler has a strong record of support for gay rights, for example, but Mr. Duane who is openly gay and has the virus that causes AIDS, contends he could be a more effective advocate for those causes and others in a district with a substantial gay population.
 
ANALYSIS: Mr. Nadler is an accidental incumbent, having won the Democratic nomination that is tantamount to election here in a vote by the county Democratic Committee two years ago, after Representative Ted Weiss died on the eve of the primary. Mr. Duane has won early prominence in the Council and sought to challenge Mr. Nadler as too much of an insider, but the charge fell somewhat flat in light of Mr. Duane's own past as a district leader, and Mr. Nadler has significantly outpaced him in fundraising.
 
15TH DISTRICT CANDIDATES
 
CHARLES B. RANGEL, 64. Congressman, elected 1970, former state assemblyman, graduate of New York University and St. John's Law School. Lives in Harlem. Has raised nearly $1 million. ADAM CLAYTON POWELL 4TH, 32. City Councilman, elected 1991; graduate of Howard University and Fordham Law School. Lives in East Harlem. Has failed to file contribution reports in violation of Federal law.
 
THE DISTRICT: The heart of Harlem, one of the spiritual and intellectual centers of black urban America, but suffering from decades of poverty and crime. It is 47 percent black, 14 percent white, and 45 percent of Hispanic origin.
 
THE ISSUES: Mr. Powell, the son of the legendary Congressman and minister whom Mr. Rangel defeated in 1970, argues that Mr. Rangel is old and out of touch with the needs of his district and has not managed to turn seniority in Congress into tangible rewards for Harlem. Mr. Rangel, one of the highest-ranking members of the House Ways and Means Committee, argues that he was a staunch advocate for the urban poor through two Republican Administrations and is now poised to deliver new benefits like Federal funds for economic development.
 
ANALYSIS: Mr. Powell, whose mother is Puerto Rican, has traded on his family name and a face eerily like his father's to appeal both to older voters' nostalgia and to anti-incumbent sentiment among younger black and Hispanic residents. But he has won virtually no support from established politicians or community leaders, and Mr. Rangel argues that it would be foolhardy to turn him out of office now that he has gained legislative power.
 
17TH DISTRICT CANDIDATES
 
ELIOT L. ENGEL, 47. Congressman, elected in 1988. Former state assemblyman, teacher, guidance counselor; graduate of Lehman College and New York Law School, member of Education and Labor Committee. Apartment in Co-Op City. WILLIE COLON, 44. International salsa music star, bandleader, and community advocate, making initial foray into elective politics.
 
THE DISTRICT: One of the most diverse districts in the nation. Blacks make up more than two-fifths of the district and are the largest single plurality, but non-Hispanic whites and people of Hispanic origin are just behind, with about one-third each.
 
THE ISSUES: Rather than disagreeing over substantive issues -- on which their liberal positions are quite similar -- the candidates have sparred over geography (Mr. Colon notes that Mr. Engel moved his family to suburban Maryland: Mr. Engel that Mr. Colon lives acorss the Westchester County Line) and ethnic succession (Mr. Colon contends it is time to have a representative of Hispanic origin).
 
ANALYSIS: Mr. Engel won this seat after the longtime incumbent, Representative Mario Biaggi, was convicted on corruption charges, and he comfortably staved off a comeback attempt by Mr. Biaggi two years ago. But the district's polyglot makeup is attractive to a minority candidate.
 
ATTORNEY GENERAL
 
THE CANDIDATES
 
KAREN S. BURNSTEIN, 52. Lawyer, resigned in April as judge in Brooklyn Family Court, a position she held since 1990. Elected state Senator in 1972 representing Long Island and southeastern Queens. Served as executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board, president of the state Civil Service Commission and Auditor General of the City of New York. Will appear on general election ballot in November on Liberal Party line. CHARLES J. HYNES, 59. Lawyer, elected Brooklyn District Attorney in 1989. Began career as a Legal Aid lawyer in 1963, then became a prosecutor in Brooklyn, heading the rackets bureau in 1970. Served as special state prosecutor, starting in 1975, to prosecute Medicaid fraud cases. Served for two years as New York City Fire Commissioner. Named in 1987 as special state prosecutor investigating the slaying of Michael Griffith in Howard Beach. G. OLIVER KOPPEL, 53. Lawyer, appointed Attorney General by his colleagues in the New York State Legislature after Robert Abrams resigned in December. Elected in 1970 to the Assembly, representing the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Former partner in law firm, Koppell, Drachler & Lipofsky. ELIOT L. SPITZER, 35. Lawyer, former prosecutor in Manhattan District Attorney's Office, which he joined in 1985. Headed the office's labor racketeering unit. Served as counsel to the Governor's Commission on Youth Crime and Violence. Resigned this spring from the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, where he had worked since 1992.
 
THE ISSUES: The four candidates are moderate to liberal Democrats from New York City who differ little on the major issues. The biggest exception is Mr. Spitzer's support of the death penalty, which the other three oppose. Thus, much of the debate has focused on the candidates qualifications and their view of the office's role in fighting crime. Mr. Hynes and Mr. Spitzer say the office should be redefined as the state's overseer of criminal justice issues. Mr. Koppell and Ms. Burstein do not discount such a role, but say the other two are pandering because the office traditionally focuses on other duties: defending state agencies, consumer affairs, the environment and civil rights.
 
ANALYSIS: Polls show the race is far too close to call. Mr. Koppell, who received the blessing of the Democratic convention, is considered to have an edge on traditional organizational support. Ms. Burstein is the only woman and is considered the most progressive in a primary with a heavy female turnout and where the party's more liberal wing turns out. Mr. Hynes is considered to have a lock on Brooklyn, a plus because the New York City vote is so important. Mr. Spitzer is a long shot, but his support of the death penalty might play well upstate and among more conservative Democrats. Moreover, he has had the most consistent presence on television and could capitalize on any anti-politician sentiment.

HEADLINE: U.N. Population Meeting Adopts Program of Action

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 13

 BODY:
After nine days of arguing about sexuality and morals, the United Nations population conference ended today with a broad endorsement of a new strategy for stabilizing the world's population, mainly by giving women more control over their lives.
The 20-year "program of action" drew unexpected if limited support from the Vatican, which fought a rear-guard campaign throughout the conference against any language suggesting that an abortion could be safe or legal. 
 At the conference's closing session, many Muslim and Latin American nations joined the Vatican in registering formal objections to the program's acknowledgment of legal abortion as part of health care or to language suggesting approval of sexual relations outside of marriage, particularly among adolescents.
But the 113-page declaration approved today enshrined for the first time a new concept of population policy that goes beyond traditional family planning to areas like reproductive health care, enabling women to make their own choices and promoting equality between the sexes.
 
Choices on Family Planning
 Apart from supplying contraceptives, governments and donors will be urged to insure education for girls and provide women with a range of choices on family planning and health care. In countries where abortion is not against the law, the declaration implies that health care embraces safe conditions for abortion.
The last United Nations population gathering, in 1984 in Mexico City, alluded to abortion only once -- to exclude it from its catalogue of family planning methods. At the previous conference in 1974 in Bucharest, abortion was not mentioned at all.
The Vatican withheld its assent to the conclusions of both previous population conferences. This time, said the Vatican's delegate, Archbishop Renato Martino, the Holy See wanted "to associate itself with the consensus, even if in an incomplete, or partial manner" because the plan "opens up some new paths."
 
Vatican Backs Parts of Text
 To loud applause from delegates from some 150 nations, the Archbishop said the Vatican endorsed the declaration's principles, as well as chapters on the family as "the basic unit of society," on stimulating economic growth, on "gender equality, equity and the empowerment of women" and on migration.
But the Vatican made clear that its shift today did not mean that its most fundamental views had changed. "Nothing is to be understood to imply that the Holy See endorses abortion or has in any way changed its moral position concerning abortion," Archbishop Martino said. Nor has it changed its opposition to contraceptives or sterilization, he said, or to the use of condoms in AIDS prevention programs.
Looking back on their torturous negotiations, many diplomats hailed the outcome as a triumph of patience over preconceptions.
"This is an historic document, unlike anything that's ever been drafted before," said the head of the United States delegation, Timothy E. Wirth, the Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs. "We took on a very difficult issue and accomplished a remarkable consensus on that issue."
The aim of the declaration is to stabilize the world's population at about 7.27 billion by the year 2015 -- compared to 5.67 billion today -- and avoid an explosion that could put the world's population at 12.5 billion in the year 2050.
The document foresees a three-fold rise in the amount the world spends annually on population stabilization, from around $5 billion today to about $17 billion by 2000.
At several points in the nine-day conference, delegates labored over minute compromise language only to find their efforts undone or sidetracked by moral arguments from the Vatican or from Muslim countries, mainly Egypt, Iran and Pakistan. Saudi Arabia and the Sudan boycotted the conference.
 
Reservations on Language
 Of more than 150 delegations attending, about 20 registered reservations to language on sex and abortion as the conference closed. The final declaration is not binding on governments, and clauses specify that it does not take precedence over national laws or religious beliefs.
The answer to the question of who won and who lost was ambiguous.
The Vatican claimed a victory in shaping the language of the text so that it did not enshrine any universal right to abortion and excluded abortion as a means of family planning. "The overall effect has been to swing the consensus in a direction it was not going to take," a senior Vatican delegate said.
Yet the fact that abortion was so widely discussed, and acknowledged as a crucial issue in women's health care, represented a defeat for anti-abortion forces and undermined the Vatican's crusade against the practice.
 
A Shift by Vatican
 The Vatican's decision to approve parts of the population document after formally withholding its assent at the previous two conferences seemed to reflect a growing concern about being isolated in the looming population debate.
"They know they have lost more than they have gained and that they need to start building bridges if they are to maintain any sort of voice in the U.N. in the future," said Frances Kissling, president of Catholics for a Free Choice, referring to the Vatican.
Susan Davies, executive director of the Women's Environment and Development Organization in New York, said the most important achievement was that the declaration "gives primacy to women to control their own body and this is huge breakthrough."
Underlying the maneuvering was the question of financing the plan of action. Some delegates left the gathering saying that the plan would be viable only if spending were realigned among the donor and recipient countries, an issue that is to be discussed at a United Nations gathering in Copenhagen next year.
Delegates to that conference are to discuss a proposal that developing countries spend 20 percent of their national budgets on social programs and donors spend 20 percent of their foreign aid on similar projects.
"It's the only proposal on the table which would generate the resources needed for the Cairo agenda," said Richard Jolly, the deputy executive director of Unicef, which supports the so-called 20-20 proposal.
"Without resources the Program of Action will remain a paper promise," said Nafis Sadik, the conference's secretary general.

HEADLINE: Haiti's Forces: Poorly Armed And Seasoned Only in Terror

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Supreme Commander of the Haitian military often comes to work at noon and leaves at 2 P.M.
The Haitian Navy has immaculate uniforms, but only one ship with working engines, although several others float. 
 The air force has two propeller planes; one can fly. It has several old helicopters, in pieces, but one newer helicopter is rumored to be working.
The army has six or seven artillery pieces, almost all of them rusted hulks that are fired only at ceremonies. It has six armored personnel carriers rigged with light machine guns, but not all are running. It has 7,000 soldiers in uniform, a bottomless supply of 150-proof rum, and a force of voodoo priests poised to turn their powers on any American invaders.
As Haiti readies itself for a possible American invasion, it does so without any recent experience in war or the modern-day means to conduct one. In recent history, Haiti's military has waged war only on the country's own defenseless people, controlling them with terror and violence.
It is inevitable that blood will be shed in any invasion. But few people here, not even Foreign Minister Charles David, one of the most hard-line leaders in the military Government, expect Haitian soldiers to hold out long if the United States sends in its better-armed, better-trained troops.
Mr. David and other Government officials portrayed Washington as victimizing a weak nation and preparing to shoot down valiant young men defending their homeland.
Leaders of the Haitian pro-democracy movement and people on the street say with contempt and conviction that the Haitian soldiers will not fight at all, but rather will leave their uniforms behind and hide.
"They will toss their rifles in the street," said a longtime supporter of Haiti's deposed and exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
"They are not afraid of women and children, they will shoot a man who is bound up like a pig, but they will not stand and fight," he said. "They dance and sing now and talk big, but when they hear, 'boom, boom . . .' " He wiggled two fingers to pantomime a man running away.
There is a precedent. In September 1993 a large ship was spotted north of Jeremie, on the northern coast of Haiti's southern peninsula. Word spread through the city that it was a warship, coming to kill the soldiers and reinstate Father Aristide, said a human rights worker who was in Jeremie at the time. Instead of going to the docks to confront the invaders, soldiers shed their uniforms and fled.
It turned out to be a merchant vessel. The soldiers collected their uniforms and resumed their posts to protect Haiti's coastline.
But in the event of an invasion United States officials do not count on a quick retreat and mass surrender, said Stanley Schrager, the United States Embassy spokesman.
He believes some of Haiti's soldiers will fight, as will the civilian gunmen loyal to the military Government, who are said to be the people responsible for the most deaths since the coup that toppled Father Aristide in September 1991.
Mr. Schrager and other United States officials say they hope the Haitian Army will turn on its generals. Mr. Schrager said that any invasion plans would provide for keeping the army intact after the invasion, but without its leaders and in a much less ominous role.
"Now the army is a police force," to control the people, he said. After the invasion, soldiers would be used to rebuild the country, which has suffered under the military Government and the economic embargo.
While Haitian leaders talked about preparations for war, there seemed to be no real preparation at all. Sources close to the Haitian military say there has been no repair work on guns or equipment in Port-au-Prince, where the commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, and the other military leaders have their headquarters.
Early this month the Haitian military blocked off some streets with sandbags, but the barricades were only two bags high, short enough for children to step over, and were later partly washed away by hard rains.
Last week some downtown streets were partly blocked with cement barricades, but not with anything a soldier could not run around or a tank drive over.
 
Training Is Rough
 The much talked about and photographed Haitian civilian militias, despite the efforts of their trainers to slap, kick and curse them into fighting shape, are not taken seriously by the United States officials because the army takes up their unloaded guns every day at the end of training.
Unless the invasion comes between 7 A.M. and 3 P.M., the militia will have to fight without weapons.
Instead, the Haitian military seems to be pouring its efforts into public relations. On Thursday, 3,000 to 4,000 people, most of them trucked in on huge flatbed trucks, were handed signs and sent to demonstrate in front of the United States Embassy.
The signs, bearing different slogans all in the same handwriting, warned that American blood would spill and called President Bill Clinton a warmonger and Father Aristide a pig thief.
Here and there in the crowd were young men known here as attaches who waved pistols in the air and swilled rum.
 
To Be Sorry, or Dead?
 They represent the greatest threat to the poor people in an invasion because they might turn their weapons on them. They are despised by the poor and have no future in a country governed by Father Aristide. "The most we can hope," said one Aristide supporter, is that they are running "too fast to shoot us."
The threat of invasion has brought the appearance of a strong nationalist movement to Haiti, but how deep the sentiment runs remains to be seen.
One recent night, in a bar in Petionville, a suburb of the capital, Mr. Schrager discussed the invasion with Carl Denis, a senior adviser to Emil Jonassaint, President of the de facto Government.
"If you invade," Mr. Denis said, "you will be sorry."
"And what will you be?" Mr. Schrager asked.
"We will be dead," Mr. Denis said.
"Well," said Mr. Schrager, "I'd rather be sorry than dead."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
 Walt Disney is said to have rejoined discussions to acquire NBC. Several executives close to the talks said Disney might be willing to spend as much as $5 billion, though other industry experts doubt the company's enthusiasm. [Page D1.] 
 The head of Goldman, Sachs & Company said he would resign, surprising the firm and Wall Street. Jon S. Corzine will succeed Stephen Friedman, who will retire in November. [D1.] Goldman, Sachs signaled it would return to its trading roots, in choosing Mr. Corzine for its top position. [D4.]
Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts stands to receive as much as $65 million in cash if its acquisition of Borden falls through. [D1.]
BJ Services offered to buy a chief rival in oilfield services, Western Company of North America, for about $450 million. [D3.]
Monsanto's chief executive announced that he would retire next March, much sooner than had been expected. [D3.]
A former chief of 20th Century Fox has returned to the media business. Strauss Zelnick will run the North American operations of Bertelsmann's television and music arm. [D8.]
 
The Economy
 Consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the same increase as seen in June and July. The report calmed fears that the pace of inflation would rapidly pick up speed. [D1.]
Banks will be allowed to operate branches across the nation in a measure that awaits the President's signature. The bill, which would eliminate the remaining barriers to interstate banking in a dozen states and a requirement that banks operate separate subsidiaries in each state, was approved by the Senate. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Taming of Inflation Buoys Centrist in Brazil Polls

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 11

 BODY:
With Brazil's presidential election less than a month away, a pro-American centrist has surged ahead of a leftist candidate in all opinion polls tracking the race to determine who will lead Latin America's largest country to the end of the century.
Not even the surprise resignation of the Finance Minister last week has shaken the commanding lead that Fernando Henrique Cardoso has taken in recent weeks over his Socialist rival, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva. 
 "Fernando Henrique's chances have fallen a bit," Carlos Augusto Montenegro, president of Ibope, a polling organization, said recently. "It's now only 98 percent certain that he will win the election."
 
Free-Market Policies Popular
 The election of Mr. Cardoso, 63, an urbane sociologist, would extend free-market policies that are bringing high growth, lower inflation and a surge of imports.
Argentina's Economy Minister, Domingo Cavallo, predicted that under Mr. Cardoso, Brazil's economic growth rate would jump from 4 percent this year to 7 and 8 percent a year through the end of the decade. He cited the success of the Real Plan, an inflation-fighting blueprint designed last spring by Mr. Cardoso and based on a new currency, the real.
"The election of Fernando Henrique Cardoso and the success of the Real Plan would be the best news of the decade for Latin America," Mr. Cavallo said last week.
The real, which replaced the cruzeiro real, is pegged to the dollar and backed by $42 billion in reserves and a precariously balanced budget.
Confident that Latin America's sleeping giant is awakening, foreigners, largely Americans, have pumped about $5 billion into Brazil's stock markets since January. Since July 1, the day the new currency was adopted, Sao Paulo's stock market index jumped 68 percent.
That includes a seven-point dip in trading last week as investors reacted to the uproar that cost Rubens Ricupero his job as Finance Minister. In a private conversation in a television studio, broadcast around the nation by accident, Mr. Ricupero implied that the Government manipulated economic statistics to favor the Cardoso candidacy.
 
Inflation Rate Slows
 But confidence was bolstered with the swearing in of Ciro Gomes, one of Brazil's most popular state governors, as Finance Minister. And new economic data indicate that Brazil's monthly inflation rate will be below 2 percent in September, far below June's rate of 45 percent.
Confronted with these economic shifts, an estimated 25 million of Brazil's 95 million voters have migrated to the candidacy of Mr. Cardoso, a Social Democrat, in six weeks, opinion polls show.
"I think Lula is going to lose," Francisco Weffort, a campaign coordinator for the Socialist candidate.
Mr. da Silva's collapse in the polls is attributed not only to the new currency and the anti-inflation plan, but also to near-universal opposition to him by Brazil's press and wide support for Mr. Cardoso from the political establishment.
"There is an obvious explanation," Mr. Weffort said of Mr. Cardoso's surge. "It's the success of the Real Plan. Since Governments in Brazil generally don't govern, the population gives them a great deal of credit when they take a few measures."
Recent polls by Ibope and two other organizations, Gallup and DataFolha, gave Mr. Cardoso a lead of 22 points.
"It's quite possible that Fernando Henrique will win on the first round," Walder de Goes, an independent political scientist, said. "Inflation in September will be less than 2 percent, so he will get a boost."
 
Majority of Votes Required
 If none of the 10 presidential candidates wins a majority of valid votes on Oct. 3, a runoff will be held on Nov. 15.
With the return of retail credit, sales of cars, televisions and stereos jumped almost 15 percent in August, compared with July. One supermarket chain said food sales had jumped by 25 percent in the same time.
"Prices are going down," Sueli Regina Coutinho da Silva, 25, a nanny, said with a touch of amazement in her voice. "Last week, my sister went shopping, and she bought more food for less money than before. My other sister bought a videocassette recorder on credit. She wanted to buy one for years."
Today, the political benefits of the Real Plan are being reaped by its author, Mr. Cardoso.
Active in national politics for 12 years, Mr. Cardoso served for most of the last decade as a senator from Sao Paulo State, Brazil's economic heartland. After President Fernando Collor de Mello was impeached in a corruption scandal, Mr. Cardoso joined the Government of President Itamar Franco in late 1992, serving first as Foreign Minister and then as Finance Minister.
"There is not really any other option out there," Mr. Montenegro, the polltaker, said of a crowded field in which no other candidate receives more than 5 percent of voter preferences. "And Lula has a high rejection rate -- about 40 percent."
Defenders of Mr. Cardoso say that Mr. da Silva had erred by using his free television time to attack the Real Plan, a program that wins public approval ratings of 80 percent.
 
'Always Against Something'
 "The Workers Party is always against something," said Bolivar Lamounier, a Cardoso adviser. Fernando Henrique offers hope. This country is crazy to see a light at the end of the tunnel."
Plumbing the public mood, pollsters say that Brazil's electorate is looking for a candidate with a capacity to change things.
"While Lula is on television shouting against the plan, Brazilians are looking for stability and tranquillity," Mr. Montenegro said. "Before, people said Fernando Henrique needs the real. Now they say the real needs Fernando Henrique as President."
In the 1989 presidential election, Mr. da Silva narrowly lost a runoff vote to Mr. Collor. Over the last year, Mr. da Silva campaigned largely unopposed, crisscrossing this vast country, methodically building support that registered as high as 42 percent in public opinion polls in May.
Marcos Antonio Coimbra, president of the Vox Populi polling group, said voters had initially been attracted to Mr. da Silva because of his humble origins as an assembly line worker whose family had fled a drought in Brazil's impoverished northeast.
But Mr. Coimbra also recalled: "One member of a focus group in the northeast said on Monday: 'I don't want someone who loves me. I want someone who can solve my problems.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fernando Henrique Cardoso, on the stump recently in Rio de Janeiro, has parlayed the early success of the economic plan that he shaped into a big lead in the Brazilian presidential election scheduled for Oct. 3. (John R. Maier for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dole Explains Trade Treaty Stand

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, said today that contrary to some earlier signals he had given, he was not unalterably opposed to passing the new global trade treaty this year.
But Congress has a limited amount of time before it recesses for the November elections, Mr. Dole said, and the Clinton Administration may have to choose between the trade accord worked out by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and its other priorities like health care and campaign finance reform. 
 "What the White House has to determine is that we are going to be here only a few more weeks before recess," Mr. Dole said in an interview. "We can't do everything. We would like to have a list of priorities. What is it? Health care, Superfund, campaign finance reform, gifts, lobbying or GATT?"
 
Article in Wichita Paper
 On Aug. 28, The Wichita Eagle, a newspaper in his Kansas constituency, published an article by Senator Dole suggesting that the Administration and Congress take their time in approving the 117-nation global trade accord, which lowers tariffs on manufactured goods by 30 percent and is expected to stimulate billions of dollars in new commerce. Mr. Dole said his constituents had a lot of worries about how GATT, as the treaty is called, would affect them.
Senator Dole's article stunned the Administration and many in the business community. The global trade agreement is popular with businessmen who form a big bloc of the Republican Party. Senator Dole was inundated with calls from the Business Roundtable, a group of prominent corporate chiefs, and with questions from reporters asking why he would join forces with the unlikely coalition of treaty opponents, including Ralph Nader, Patrick Buchanan and Rush Limbaugh.
This afternoon the Kansas Republican made clear that he was not leading a crusade to hold up the global trade accord. But Mr. Dole said he still wanted his concerns addressed, including the content of the agreement, how it would be paid and how it relates to other pending legislation from President Clinton.
Mr. Dole met this afternoon with the Senate Finance Committee chairman, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who said Mr. Dole was being quite cooperative in the efforts now under way to move the trade accord through the various conference committees.
 
Thinks It's 'Doable'
 "I have not been around trying to hustle opposition to the GATT treaty," Senator Dole said in the interview. "I think a trade agreement is doable this year. But the Administration will really have to hustle and clear the decks."
He continued: "The bottom line is that we think there are some serious concerns, but I hope we can resolve them. We are not playing games. This is important and we hope we can get it resolved. But as part of that you have to tell us, Mr. President, what do you want to do this year?"
Senator Moynihan said he too would like to see GATT become the priority now for the Administration, but not necessarily at the expense of health care. "I would assume that GATT would be the Administration's first priority," Mr. Moynihan said, "but if we can do some health care legislation simultaneously, that would be fine."
In an effort to clear away some of the political obstacles to GATT, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, who is spearheading the Administration's effort to win approval for the global trade accord, met with Senator Moynihan and Senator Dole to inform them that the White House was setting aside its proposal to include in the GATT bill an extension of its "fast track" authority to negotiate future trade agreements.
Fast-track authority, which expired Dec. 15, 1993, enables the President to submit any trade accord to the House and Senate for a single vote in each chamber with no amendments allowed. That authority is considered essential to ward off special interest amendments that could doom a trade agreement.
 
Passage Not Assured
 But many lawmakers did not want to vote on it before the midterm elections because labor unions and big business were sharply divided on the fast-track issue and the politicians did not want to choose between them. The White House calculated that it was better to get GATT passed now and worry about fast track later.
Even with fast track now set aside until next year, passage of GATT is not assured. Because GATT entails tax adjustments, it will require 60 votes in the Senate to pass. That means it will need the help of the Republicans, and Senator Dole, as minority leader, needs to be on board.
"We have always had a bipartisan trade policy," Mr. Dole said today. "We have always been able to work out differences, but we are not there yet."
Mr. Dole's critics contend that he is engaged in some dangerously cynical politics by trying to deny President Clinton a major victory in the foreign policy area where he has been most successful: foreign trade.
"I do worry that if Bob Dole's threat proves real, and the Congress fails to enact the GATT agreement this time, you open up the possibility of its unraveling in other parts of the world as well," said Thomas Mann, a Congressional expert at the Democratic-leaning Brookings Institution. "That could put a chill on the global economic recovery. If that happens it would be an act of total recklessness on Dole's part."
But Mr. Dole's supporters say that he is engaged in some rather sophisticated politics by threatening to hold up the trade accord in order to win concessions from the Senate Democratic leader, George Mitchell of Maine, on health care and other pending legislation, while letting everyone know that at the end of the day he will support GATT.
"Somehow you have to get the message across that we have to be talked to," Mr. Dole said today. "Two can play that game."
Some of his Republican colleagues say that Senator Dole, who is a Presidential hopeful for 1996, is also reacting to the fact that his main Senate rival for the party leadership, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, has come out for a go-slow approach on GATT.

HEADLINE: Amid Ivy, Dinkins In New Role

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Like any other university professor facing his first class of the semester, former Mayor David N. Dinkins chose to open his lecture at Columbia University with a bit of levity.
"To those of you who voted for me this fall, I thank you," he told the 150 students sitting in Room A of Jerome L. Greene Hall. "And if you didn't vote for me, thanks anyway. That's how I got to be here." 
 Mr. Dinkins -- or Professor Dinkins, as some of those at Columbia might now call him -- has traded his Mayor's gavel for a lectern at Columbia's School of International and Public Affairs.
He was appointed a professor in January, after he lost a re-election bid against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani by more than 50,000 votes. Mr. Dinkins said he is neither bitter about his loss, nor plans to drop out of the political or public policy arena altogether.
 
'A Worthwhile Pursuit'
 With his new job, Mr. Dinkins said he wants to show that those who no longer govern can still teach.
"I want to share with my students some of my experiences in public life and my quarter-century in politics," he said before the class began. "Among the things I want to do is to persuade young people that involvement in public service is a worthwhile pursuit."
His course, called Critical Issues in Urban Public Policy, will examine the relationship between politics and public policy. In the course, Mr. Dinkins plans to talk about race relations, and about how special interest groups and the media influence public policy.
So for now, besides trading notes with political cronies -- it is, after all, the political season in New York -- Mr. Dinkins has been talking pedagogy with Raymond W. Kelly, the former city police commissioner, who has also entered academia with a class in criminal science at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service of New York University.
The two are in a small club of former politicians and top government officials who are now part of the city's ivy league.
Another former mayor, Edward I. Koch, is a lecturer, also at the Wagner School.
City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, who before his election last fall was a tenured professor at Queens College, is now teaching a course in government at Columbia's School of International Affairs.
During his first lecture, Mr. Dinkins, dressed in a navy blue double breasted blazer, stood confidently and talked easily with his students as he referred to written notes.
To begin the discussion, he read them this description of New York City:
"Two or three murders take place each day, before breakfast. You risk your life by walking the streets late at night. Homeless people lie in the gutters. Prostitution runs rampant and policemen are corrupt. There are useless expenditures of public money, overtaxation and improper contracting. The streets are filthy and in disrepair and filled with drivers reckless of human life.
"There is inadequate health care and TB has reached epidemic proportions and illegal immigrants are entering from ships onto our shores."
Mr. Dinkins then told them he was reading a description of the city from 1856. The students chuckled.
 
The Problems Stay the Same
 "So what I'm saying is that mayors and elected officials come and go and the underlying perceptions of our city's major problems seem to remain the same," he said. "These are the challenges that face politicians and policy makers throughout the years and in cities other than New York."
During the semester, he said, he would bring speakers from inside and outside government to address the topic of how policy makers respond to these problems or prevent them in the first place.
After the class, one student, Cenk Uygur, said he thought Mr. Dinkins would provide valuable lessons to students like himself who plan to go into politics.
"It's good to get it from the horse's mouth, I guess," said Mr. Uygur, a third-year law student. "When I heard that he was going to come here, I knew right off the bat that I wanted to take his class."
"In law school, we're always talking in niceties about what's best for a situation -- economically, politically and socially," Mr. Uygur said. "He's going to give us a sense of what can really be done and what's practical and realistic."
 
Boards of Directors
 In addition to teaching, Mr. Dinkins is serving on four corporate boards, including the American Stock Exchange and New World Communications. He also hosts a call-in show on radio station WLIB-FM (107.5) twice a week with features political guests. This week it was Representative Charles B. Rangel.
But he said his favorite activities now that he is not in public office are those dealing with young people, and especially those that allow him the chance to encourage them to join public service.
