HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Computing's Bold Alliance Falters

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13

 BODY:
It was to be the alliance of former enemies, teaming up to conquer common foes.
At least that was the strategy three summers ago when I.B.M. and Apple Computer stunned their industry by announcing a joint plan to attack the domination of the personal computer industry by machines based on Intel chips and Microsoft software. Apple and I.B.M. called their planned weapon the Power PC, and to make sure they had sufficient firepower, they recruited the big chip maker Motorola Inc. to their team. 
 But recently, the I.B.M.-Apple alliance shows signs of running off track.
 
Mission Not Accomplished
 Although Apple has been selling a line of Power PC computers since March, and I.B.M. is expected to introduce its own version of a Power PC machine next month, the companies have wandered from their common mission: making Power PC a unified technology "platform" that would run both Apple and I.B.M. software interchangeably.
Executives at both companies declined to speak on the record about the troubled alliance. But they have confirmed privately in recent weeks that it may be years -- if ever -- before I.B.M. and Apple fulfill their promise of giving computer users, and the computer industry itself, a true alternative to the Intel-Microsoft standard that accounts for 85 percent of personal computers now in use.
Analysts see an opportunity squandered.
"This was the last hope to stop the Intel-Microsoft cartel, and it's not going to happen," said George Colony, president of Forrester Research, a computer industry consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass.
To be sure, the Power PC chips made by Motorola and I.B.M. are finding a market not only in Apple and I.B.M. machines, but also in other types of consumer electronics. The video-game system maker 3DO, for example, recently announced that it would base its next generation of systems on the Power PC.
Apple, meanwhile, says that it is still on pace to reach its goal of selling one million Power PC Macintosh computers by the end of the year. And I.B.M. has high hopes for the Power PC-based computers that may roll out as soon as October.
But at least initially these Apple and I.B.M. machines will use different software. And Taligent, the I.B.M.-Apple joint venture created to develop a common software operating system, has yet to finish the software tools that third-party software developers will need to create the applications -- word processors, spreadsheets and the like -- without which an operating system is useless.
In fact the two companies are so far apart that Apple has not yet disclosed whether it will include I.B.M. among the computer makers it allows to license Apple's new System 7.5 software operating system for the Power PC.
 
Updating an Old Product
 For its part, I.B.M. appears to be placing new emphasis on its OS/2 operating system. OS/2, around for years, has never had a big following. But I.B.M. has spent considerable time and money improving it lately, and next month the company plans to introduce an entirely new version that has drawn praise from the industry experts who have tested it.
At a computer conference here last week, Lee Reiswig, president of the I.B.M. personal software products division, said the company would spend as much as $500 million to market and advertise the new OS/2.
The initial versions of the new OS/2 will work only with personal computers using Intel chips. But within a year, I.B.M. expects to have a Power PC version of OS/2 ready. Until then, unless I.B.M. obtains a license for Apple's System 7.5 software, I.B.M.'s Power PC machines will run on the Microsoft Windows NT operating system or on I.B.M.'s version of the industry-standard Unix software used primarily by engineers, academicians and computer scientists.
It would seem, as a result, that not only have I.B.M. and Apple stopped cooperating on a common Power PC platform, but they may also eventually find themselves in direct competition, with incompatible versions of Power PC hardware and software.
 
Pessimist's View of Alliance
 The Apple-I.B.M. alliance is "brain dead," in the view of Stewart Alsop, editor of Infoworld, a personal computer industry news weekly. "There are billions of dollars sitting out there, as well as control of a huge industry, and they're giving it away" to Intel and Microsoft, he said.
Mr. Alsop wrote an Infoworld editorial last week, urging I.B.M. to delay introduction of its Power PC computers, contending that there would be so little distinctive software available that no one would buy them.
The ramifications go beyond market-share questions for I.B.M. and Apple alone. Unless it appears that a single Power PC chip "architecture" will be used on millions of computers, then the companies that produce applications software have little incentive to develop versions of their programs for the Power PC.
And only if software companies write applications for the Power PC, will other computer makers be likely to adopt the technology -- just as makers of I.B.M. PC "clones" a decade ago embraced the Intel chip.
 
Improbable Partners
 What went wrong between Apple and I.B.M.?
When the two companies announced their partnership in the summer of 1991, it struck many as an unlikely alliance. I.B.M., the leader in personal computers at the time but also dominant in mainframes, was a $64.7 billion behemoth so powerful that an Apple television commercial in 1984 compared the company to George Orwell's Big Brother.
Apple, which reveled in its free-wheeling Silicon Valley corporate culture, was only about one-tenth I.B.M.'s size but had ascended to No. 2 in the personal computer industry by making machines with easy-to-use software that was intentionally incompatible with the I.B.M. PC.
Despite the companies' differences, however, many industry experts saw the combination of Apple's software wizardry and I.B.M.'s hardware manufacturing prowess as an unbeatable combination.
The idea had emerged from the success I.B.M. was having in early 1991 with its new RS-6000 work station, a sophisticated computer for engineers and other "power users" that was based on a type of chip architecture known as RISC -- for reduced instruction set computing. One of I.B.M.'s designers of the RS-6000, Phil Hester, convinced Jack Kuehler, who was then I.B.M.'s president and vice chairman, that RISC chips could find success in other types of computers.
 
First Approaches
 Intel, then and now, has paid only minimal attention to RISC technology, choosing instead to concentrate on a more conventional approach to chip design. Sensing an opportunity to exploit this difference, Mr. Kuehler did something remarkable. He placed a telephone call to Michael Spindler, president of Apple Computer, the company that had based its business -- and very culture -- on producing personal computers that were nothing like the Intel-based I.B.M. PC.
Mr. Spindler was intrigued by the idea of creating a new generation of technology with I.B.M. But even more smitten was Apple's chairman at the time, John Sculley, a vaunted "visionary" who was quick to embrace new ideas and seized this one as a plan on which Apple could base its future.
Mr. Kuehler also brought into the fold George Fisher, who was chairman of Motorola, the company that produced the 68000 series of chips that powered the Apple Macintosh. On July 30, 1991, the three announced the alliance whose technology would come to be known as Power PC.
But between that date and the time the first Power PC machines reached the market last spring, there were big management changes at all three companies. The biggest shake-up was at I.B.M., whose chairman, John Akers, was forced out in favor of Louis V. Gerstner Jr. in April 1993. Mr. Kuehler retired soon after that.
Meanwhile, at Apple, where the board was concerned with the company's flattening revenues and slipping market share, Mr. Sculley was falling out of favor. He relinquished day-to-day operating responsibilities to Mr. Spindler in June 1993 and in October left the company altogether.
 
New Cast of Characters
 As a result, the main proponents of the Power PC have left the scene, replaced by executives with mandates from their boards to devise their own bold new strategies.
Even at Motorola, Mr. Fisher is no longer in place, having left the company last October to take on the challenge of rebuilding the Eastman Kodak Company. (As the chip-making member of the alliance, however, Motorola would seem to have every incentive to make the technology succeed and sell as many Power PC microprocessors as possible.)
Despite moving in divergent directions, I.B.M. and Apple are still holding talks aimed at putting the partnership back on course, executives at both companies say. But they decline to predict whether they can truly revive the grand alliance described to the world three summers ago.
In the view of some analysts, too much has changed since then.
"What customers want is a unified platform," said Daniel Farber, editor in chief of PC Week, a newspaper. "But it comes down to geopolitics. Apple is afraid of becoming a serf in I.B.M.'s feudal kingdom."

HEADLINE: Chairman of Goldman Will Retire

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stephen Friedman, the head of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the richest partnership on Wall Street, with more than $2 billion in profits last year, surprised the firm and much of the securities industry yesterday by saying that he would retire in November.
Mr. Friedman will be succeeded as senior partner and chairman of the management committee -- a post he has held for two years -- by Jon S. Corzine, 47, now co-head of Goldman, Sach's bond business. Henry M. Paulson Jr., who is 48 and co-head of the investment banking division, will assume the No. 2 job as vice chairman and chief operating officer. Both men were handpicked by Mr. Friedman. 
 Mr. Friedman is leaving at a time when Goldman, Sachs, like many other firms on Wall Street, is suffering a sharp drop in profits after several boom years. That fact, combined with the suddenness of the resignation, sparked speculation about his reasons for retiring, including illness and some dissent among the firm's partners.
But Mr. Friedman, who is 56, said his job was tiring. He said he had been hinting about retirement for months because he holds one of the more physically demanding jobs on Wall Street, with heavy foreign travel and round-the-clock management responsibilities.
He has been among the top three officers of Goldman, Sachs for more than a decade and presided over two record years of profits, 1992 and 1993. In a statement to employees yesterday, he said that "when the job is done with maximum intensity, it can be more than a little tiring."
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Friedman said: "How come I'm doing this? Take a look at this view." He then fished out of his desk an eight-inch-wide snapshot of the snowcapped mountains taken from his "big cabin" in Jackson, Wyo. "Now take a look at that view," he said as he pointed out from his 22d-floor Wall Street office at the East River, blocked by other skyscrapers. "Which is better?"
He denied rumors of serious illness, and noted that he ran up to six miles a day. "But my health is great and that's how I want to keep it," he said. "Only on Wall Street do people think it bizarre that I don't want to spend half of my day on the telephone and the other half on an airplane."
Mr. Friedman is an intensely intellectual lawyer who joined Goldman, Sachs in 1966. He is leaving after helping expand an already rich and prestigious firm into a global investment powerhouse, with profits from investment banking, bond trading, and foreign exchange of more than $2.3 billion in the year that ended on Nov. 26.
But an unexpected rise in interest rates has hurt Wall Street and Goldman, Sachs, slicing the firm's profits this year and making inevitable huge cuts in the partners' bonuses, which are often the envy of Wall Street.
 
An Aloof Style
 Mr. Friedman's decision to leave comes amid reports of disaffection among some of the firm's 150 partners. Some say Mr. Friedman's aloof style does little to smooth the relations between the sometimes contentious factions within Goldman, Sachs.
"The word is that there was some unrest among his partners," said an executive recruiter who has regular contact with Wall Street brokerage firms. "I think you can take at face value that Friedman did a good job and that he is making a life decision. But he's probably getting out before it gets messy."
In response to the reports of disaffection at the firm, Mr. Friedman said, "I'm not going to tell you that all 150 partners are happy. And I've been described as aloof before. But we have had the most collegial management committee in my experience here. And it bothers me when someone outside of the firm says there's a mess here because there isn't."
Mr. Corzine, a member of the management committee, also denied the charges of disaffection, saying, "I wouldn't be jumping into a mess, willingly or unwillingly."
 
Legendary Profits
 While it is a private partnership that does not have to disclose its revenues and profits, the profits of Goldman, Sachs from selling bonds, arranging mergers and acquisitions, and buying and selling foreign currencies are often Wall Street legends.
Last year was an especially good year. Goldman reportedly had pretax profit of $2.3 billion in the year that ended on Nov. 26, a figure that Mr. Friedman and Mr. Corzine acknowledged. They would not comment on this year's figures, but pretax profit reportedly plunged 59 percent, to $450 million, in the first six months. Others say the profit is even lower.
"But all the firms on Wall Street are going through the same thing," said Guy Moszkowski, an analyst who covers the brokerage business for Sanford C. Bernstein. "A top person leaving a firm is not going to leave because of the current environment."
Mr. Friedman has held both chairman and vice chairman positions since 1992, when Robert E. Rubin, the other co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, left to join the Clinton Administration as a senior economic adviser.
 
A Plan for Succession
 Mr. Friedman told the management committee last Wednesday of his decision to retire; the succession plan was made final on Sunday. He told a regularly scheduled partners' meeting on Monday of the move.
Before that, Robert J. Katz, the firm's chief counsel and a close friend, was apparently the only person in the firm who knew 1994 would be Mr. Friedman's last year.
A partner at the 4:30 P.M. partners' meeting on Monday recalled someone asking Mr. Friedman why he did not leave in 1993, when profits were at a record high, and Mr. Friedman replying, "I didn't see this year coming this way."
In the interview yesterday, Mr. Friedman said: "What I actually said was, 'I thought we were well on our way to our second record year.' And then I made a joke that I didn't see this year coming.' "
Mr. Corzine is seen as more open and personable than Mr. Friedman, whose hobbies include chess and long-distance running. Popular with clients, Mr. Corzine may be better able to rally the sometimes contentious egos in an organization at which hundreds in the firm are millionaires.
In Mr. Paulson, who is from the investment banking side, where mergers and acquisitions and other high-profile deals are struck, Mr. Corzine may find a simpatico partner. In interviews yesterday, they spoke warmly of working as a team.
Like Mr. Corzine and Mr. Friedman, Mr. Paulson jogs three or more miles a day. All three wear Timex Ironman digital watches (Mr. Paulson's was given to him by Mr. Friedman).

He was joined at the brokerage firm's office in Manhattan by his successor, Jon S. Corzine, right, and Henry M. Paulson Jr., who will assume the No. 2 post. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Giuliani Cites Drop in Crime In Assessment

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
In an annual assesment of the government's performance, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday painted a statistical portrait of a city that has seen crime drop to its lowest rate in 15 years but still faces staggering social problems and service burdens, including a welfare roll that has climbed to its highest point in at least two decades.
The Mayor's Management Report also found dirtier streets, less inviting parks, skyrocketing overtime costs and increased waiting times for citizens pursuing taxi and consumer complaints, compared with the year before. 
 The report, a survey that has been issued yearly since the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, covered the fiscal year that ended on June 30, straddling the end of the Dinkins administration and the beginning of the Giuliani administration.
It did not fully reflect the new round of service and staffing cuts contained in the $31.6 billion budget that took effect in July.
"We're trying in every single circumstance to alleviate -- as much as we can -- the effects of the cuts," Mr. Giuliani said at a briefing on the report. "And if there are cuts in certain areas, those are the areas in which we seek private participation and are working very hard to do that or where we seek more state or Federal aid."
 
Success Stories
 Some city agencies had success stories: the Transportation Department reported that street conditions improved slightly, with 82.2 percent in good condition, up rom 80.2 percent a year ago. And Fire Department response time held steady or improved in every borough except the Bronx.
But in agency after agency, there were signs that city workers were staggering under new burdens resulting from the loss of workers to attrition and the city's severance program.
The Parks Department reported that the overall condition of small parks and playgrounds declined appreciably because of a shortage of supplies and reductions in staff available to perform repairs. In spring 1993, 51 were deemed acceptable; by last spring, 39 percent were considered acceptable.
 
Staff Vacancies
 Child-welfare caseworkers saw the number of new cases they received per month rise from 6.6 to 7.6 because attrition and severance cut the caseworker staff at field offices by 13 percent. And despite an increase in AIDS cases in the city, workers at the Health Department's AIDS hot line responded to 8,623 fewer calls because of staff vacancies.
The scofflaw tow program of the city sheriff's office brought in only $34 million in fines -- 46 percent less revenue than planned. The report cited a parking-violation amnesty program, the severe winter, staff vacancies and a law setting new standards for towing as factors in the drop.
Mr. Giuliani pointed to statistics on crime and jobs as evidence that his administration was affecting the climate of the city. "I think the two major areas that we wanted to make changes in, we've made them -- crime and the economy," Mr. Giuliani said.
Employment in the city grew by 21,100 jobs. And crime, continuing the trend of recent years, fell by 6 percent from the 1993 fiscal year to its lowest level in 15 years. Total arrests by the city's Police Department rose 4.4 percent to 198,067, but felony arrests were down 1 percent for the same period.
In an effort to highlight the police initiatives of his own administration, Mr. Giuliani included a separate comparison of the crime rates for the first six months of his term to the corresponding period in 1993, showing that total reported crimes fell by 9.7 percent, with 34 of the city's 75 police precincts reporting decreases of 10 percent or more.
City officials said that while the growth rate in welfare caseloads was slower than in the preceding year, the number of people on public assistance rose to 1.14 million -- the highest number in at least two decades.
 
Unemployment Rate
 Officials attributed the increase to a continuing high unemployment rate and to a rise in clients with AIDS-related illnesses. From January 1993 through last June, 8,114 new adult cases of AIDS were reported in the city. Officials linked more than half of the increase to a new definition of the disease by the Federal Government.
Reports of child abuse and neglect declined to under 50,000 for the first time since 1987, after years in which the crack epidemic helped make the caseloads escalate. The number of children in foster care also dropped for the third consecutive year, to 46,814 children.
Homeless families given shelter by the city increased slightly to an average of 5,599 families -- or 17,300 people -- a day. The city brought down the number of families living in hotels to 944. By June 1995, the city is required by law to eliminate the use of commercial hotels lacking private bathrooms and cooking facilities.
But to comply with state and court mandates to prevent families with children from sleeping overnight in emergency-assistance offices, the city recently resumed use of four commercial hotels, a move the report said was temporary.
 
New Approaches
 Peter J. Powers, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, said the city would put a number of new management approaches in place over the coming year to make the government more efficient. But one of the city's chronic management problems, high overtime costs, remained, with overtime rising by $75.3 million, to $521.2 million, in 11 major city agencies. The largest increase came in the Fire Department.
The management report by the Mayor is required to be issued each year under the City Charter. The Giuliani administration, in what it described as an effort to make the report more of a mangement tool assessing agency performance and less of a compendium of statistics, eliminated some of the data measured in the past.
The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, expressed concern about some of the missing data, including indicators measuring the Housing Preservation and Development Department's lead-abatement activities. And he said the Council would hold hearings on both the report's findings and its new format.

HEADLINE: Interstate-Banking Bill Gets Final Approval in Congress

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Senate overwhelmingly approved and sent to the President for signing today a bill that would allow banks to operate branches across the nation.
The interstate banking bill has been the Clinton Administration's top legislative priority in banking this year, and Congressional approval of it represents a victory for the President and for big banks that want to set up branch networks nationwide. The bill would eliminate the remaining barriers to interstate banking in a dozen states and a requirement that banks operate separate subsidiaries in each state. 
 Passage, on a 94-to-4 vote, came after the Treasury Department agreed this morning to a procedure for pursuing negligent insiders at failed savings and loan institutions.
Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, had threatened a filibuster over a controversial provision in the bill that would have effectively limited Federal action against the officers, directors, lawyers and accountants of failed savings and loans. But he dropped his threat after the Office of Thrift Supervision, which is part of the Treasury Department, vowed to undertake what amounted to an end run around the provision.
The House had already approved the interstate banking bill. The four Democratic Senators who opposed the bill today were David L. Boren of Oklahoma, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, Byron Dorgan of North Dakota and Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin.
President Clinton welcomed the Senate action. "Today this country took an historic step -- one that has been delayed for much too long -- to help American banks better meet the needs of our people, our communities and our economy," he said.
The bill will make banking more convenient for Americans who live in one state and work in another. Under current law, for example, a customer of a bank branch in Connecticut typically cannot make a deposit at the same bank's New York branches. The interstate banking bill would eliminate this restriction, along with some of the large and duplicative bureaucracies that banks have established to operate separate subsidiaries in each state.
Smaller banks initially opposed the interstate banking bill. But their hostility weakened when the bill was drafted so that big banks are virtually required, at least for the next few years, to buy a bank in another state before opening branches there.
A conference of House and Senate lawmakers inserted the controversial savings and loan provision in late July. It effectively prevents two Federal agencies, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation, from pursuing most civil cases against the insiders. The House and now the Senate have approved the bill with this provision.
 
 
Third Agency
 But under the procedure agreed upon today, a third agency not covered by the legislation, the Office of Thrift Supervision, told Congress that it would pursue the cases. The strategy does not require Congressional approval, Federal regulators said, because the agencies' budgets come from fees collected from the institutions they regulate, not money appropriated by Congress.
The new strategy came under immediate criticism from lawmakers who contend that the F.D.I.C. and R.T.C. have waged a costly vendetta against anybody with any link to the savings and loan collapse, which has cost taxpayers $200 billion.
"I personally think it's wrong for them to try this end run," said Representative Bill McCollum, a Florida Republican who is a senior member of the House Banking Committee.
Lawyers for the directors and officers of failed savings and loans also reacted angrily today to the plan. They said Congress never intended for the Office of Thrift Supervision to play such a large role. "I think they lack the authority, and it will be litigated," said Ronald R. Glantz, a lawyer here who represents many people facing possible large fines.
Most of the Federal cases against savings and loan insiders are filed by the F.D.I.C., which regulates state-chartered savings and loan associations, and the R.T.C., which disposes of failed savings and loans.
 
 
Payment Plan
 Under today's plan, they would pay the thrift office to file some of these cases for them. The thrift office would then transfer back to the F.D.I.C. or the R.T.C. any money that it won in the lawsuits.
Federal courts have ruled in the last year that state statutes of limitation run out quickly for cases filed by the F.D.I.C. and the R.T.C. But the Office of Thrift Supervision is covered only by Federal statutes of limitation, which run longer.
A provision added to the interstate banking bill in the House-Senate conference in late July would extend the state statutes of limitation for cases of fraud and willful misconduct at savings and loan institutions, but not for cases involving negligence and gross negligence, the charges in more than four-fifths of all cases. Federal regulators criticized the statute of limitations provision in the interstate banking bill as worse than nothing.
Jonathan L. Fiechter, the acting director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, sent a letter today to several senators describing the agency's new plans. While the thrift office has already begun fighting two other cases on behalf of the F.D.I.C., Mr. Fiechter said that it would try to negotiate a memorandum of understanding with the R.T.C. and the F.D.I.C. to pursue such a course more broadly.
 
 
'Reversal of Their Fortunes'
 The letter, a remarkable shift that the thrift office had long resisted, came after Mr. Metzenbaum threatened on Friday to filibuster the entire bill because of the savings and loan provision.
A senior F.D.I.C. official expressed delight at the outcome. "I think the directors and officers out there will definitely see this as a reversal of their fortunes," said the official, who requested anonymity.
But the thrift office's enthusiasm for pursuing savings and loan wrongdoers remains unclear. The office announced in April that it would begin focusing on regulating the nation's remaining savings and loan institutions and, "will rely increasingly on the R.T.C. and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to seek restitution from wrongdoers associated with failed thrifts turned over to those agencies by O.T.S."
Carolyn Lieberman, the acting chief counsel of the thrift office, said in an interview today that the agency had not actually reversed its policy and that any shift today involved "shades of emphasis." She also said that while the thrift office could probably pursue R.T.C. and F.D.I.C. cases involving gross negligence, the thrift office's legal standard for pursuing litigation typically called for more wrongdoing than the basic negligence cases filed by the other two agencies.
The interstate banking bill is formally known as the Riegle-Neal Interstate Banking and Branching Efficiency Act of 1994, after two lawmakers who are retiring from Congress this year: Senator Donald Riegle, the Michigan Democrat who heads the Senate Banking Committee, and Representative Stephen L. Neal, the North Carolina Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee's panel on financial institutions. Banking lobbyists, led by officials of Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C., have made interstate banking their top priority since the mid-1980's.
Hugh L. McColl Jr., the chief executive of Nationsbank, sat with President Clinton in Charlotte last spring when the Arkansas Razorbacks won the national collegiate basketball championship.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rise in Treasury Prices Is First in Two Weeks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday for the first time in nearly two weeks following a Government report indicating that inflation remained subdued.
The Treasury's 30 1/4-year bond rose 12/32 , or $3.75 per $1,000 bond. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 7.68 percent from Monday's two-month high of 7.71 percent. 
 After jumping in early trading, bonds fell as much as a quarter-point before rising again in late trading.
The midday weakness reflected traders' concerns that rising producer prices have not yet worked their way through to the consumer level. But as prices began to recover, the bond market gained support from short-sellers covering their positions.
Even so, "the market's not going to get too excited until it sees some more economic numbers," said Joseph Bench, a money manager at New Castle Advisors in White Plains. "We've got a lot of indicators coming out this week, all of which are going to keep the market under pressure."
Bonds rose early in the day after the Labor Department said its Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, below Wall Street's expectations for four-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Growth Is Seen Slowing
 The bond market found another sign that growth was slowing in a report from the Johnson Redbook service, showing that sales at department and chain stores rose 4.2 percent, less than expected.
Bond traders are looking to today's Government report on August retail sales for further hints of inflation. In a survey, analysts predicted sales would show an increase of 1.1 percent.
The rise in the August Consumer Price Index was less than the six-tenths of 1 percent increase in August producer prices. When the Producer Price Index was released Friday, bonds plunged on inflation fears.
Inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index is running at a 2.9 percent annual rate through August, compared with 2.8 percent during the first eight months of 1993 and 2.7 percent for all of last year.
Yesteray's report "isn't going to remove inflation fears," said Stephen Gallagher, an economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company. "It's still around."
Yields on intermediate- and short-term Treasury issues also declined yesterday. The yield on the two-year Treasury note yield was 6.32 percent, down from 6.35 percent on Monday.
Some analysts said the Federal Reserve would not necessarily hold off on its sixth rate increase this year just because the increase in the Consumer Price Index was less than expected.
"With the economy growing, the Fed has to continue to be nervous," said Steven Wood, director of financial markets research at BA Securities Inc. in San Francisco. "The best they can say is that they dodged a bullet."
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, insisted yesterday that inflation was not "getting out of control." Asked whether the Fed would raise rates again this year, he replied, "I don't know."
Glenn Switzer, a senior investment officer at J & W Seligman & Company in New York, said the Consumer Price Index. might not yet reflect rising prices at the wholesale leve. "It was really more backward looking, and more a reflection that it's difficult to pass on price increases," he said.
"I want to see more early evidence of inflation abating before I'd be more relaxed," Mr. Switzer added, citing commodity prices or prices paid by purchasing managers.
Until those prices drop, "the C.P.I. is not going to have much weight in changing people's minds" about faster inflation, he said.
Still, some investors said they were not deterred by the prospect of higher interest rates.
"Real yields are high by historical standards," said Matthew Gelfand, a senior investment officer at Strategic Investment Partners in Arlington, Va., which has $1.2 billion in United States Government debt. "The higher they go, the more attractive they look. In the long run, we're rewarded."
Bonds also got a lift yesteray from speculation the Federal Reserve was buying five-year notes for another nation's central bank, said Chris Madell, head trader at First Chicago Capital Markets. The Fed declined to comment.

HEADLINE: Eased Fear of Inflation Sends Stocks Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks climbed yesterday as concern about inflation eased when the Government said consumer prices in August rose less than economists had expected.
Technology stocks were among those making the largest gains amid stronger than expected orders for semiconductors last month. 
 "A good rally in the techs does tend to carry the market with it," said Bill Allyn, managing director at Jefferies & Company in Short Hills, N.J. "The market is in good shape. Business is strong," and third-quarter earnings are likely to show large gains compared with last year, he said.
The Dow Jones industrial average increased 19.52 points, to 3,879.86, on gains by International Paper, the Aluminum Company of America and I.B.M.
The ratio of advancing stocks to those declining on the New York Stock Exchange was nearly 11 to 10. Volume grew to 295.7 million shares, from 244.7 million on Monday.
In measures of the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500 climbed 1.31, to 467.52, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 5.82, to 765.83. Many technology issues are traded on Nasdaq.
Among the more visible tech stocks, Intel rose 3/4 to 65 1/4; LSI Logic jumped 1 1/8, to 32 3/4; Texas Instruments surged 1, to 75 1/8; Motorola jumped 3/4, to 53 1/8 and Advanced Micro Devices rose 7/8, to 28 3/8.
Stock prices increased after the Labor Department reported that consumer prices had risen by three-tenths of 1 percent in August, a little below the four-tenths of 1 percent expected. The underlying rate, excluding food and energy, also rose three-tenths of 1 percent, matching forecasts.
 
Optimism on Interest Rates
 The Consumer Price Index report supported the idea that the Federal Reserve, "in all likelihood, won't do anything until after the election in November" to raise interest rates, said Joseph DeMarco, head of equity trading at HSBC Asset Management.
"People can at least be comfortable with that notion," Mr. DeMarco said.
Looking ahead, "the line of least resistance for the market is higher," he continued. "If we can get the leadership out of the technologies, which typically lead the market, it'll be a decent move."
In reaction to yesterday's inflation report, and to remarks by Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, that inflation was not rising out of control, yields on the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell to 7.68 percent, from 7.71 percent at Monday's close.
The consumer price report "stabilizes the market and takes out the fear factor" about a buildup in inflation, said Jack Baker, managing director for stock trading at Furman Selz.
Among other issues, General Datacomm Industries soared 4 1/8, to 28. The telecommunications-equipment company will supply Ameritech with switches for a new high-speed network service. Ameritech rose 1/8, to 41 1/4.
Monsanto jumped 4 1/4, to 84 1/2. The chemical company said its chief executive, Richard J. Mahoney, would retire in March and that its president, Robert B. Shapiro, would succeed him.
Timberland plunged 7 1/4, to 38 3/4. Merrill Lynch cut its 1994 earnings estimate for the maker of shoes and hiking boots to a range of $2.30 to $2.40 a share, from $2.40 to $2.60.
United American Healthcare rose 1 7/8, to 23 1/8. The health maintenance organization earned 38 cents a share in the quarter ending on June 30, up from 23 cents a year ago.
Vermont Teddy Bear surged 1 1/4, to 6 1/4. The retailer of teddy bears said it had reached an agreement with Viacom Consumer Products to market New York City Marathon bears for the New York Road Runners Club.
Western Company of North America spurted 4 1/2, to 16 3/4. The provider of services to the oil and gas industries said BJ Services had offered to buy the company for $450 million, or $18.50 a share. BJ Services rose 1 1/4, to 20 1/8.
Adobe Systems rose 1 7/8, to 32 7/8. The software company and Apple Computer signed an agreement to include's Adobe's Acrobat Reader 2.0 software with selected Macintosh systems by the end of the year. Apple added 1/16 , to 3513/16 .

HEADLINE: Japan Hardens Stand on Trade Talks

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 13

 BODY:
With a deadline looming in less than three weeks, Japanese Government officials toughened their position today on trade talks with the United States, saying that the prospect of a full resolution of the issues was impossible and that at best they might arrange a partial deal.
"At present, there are no prospects" for a deal on all the markets being discussed, said Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Minister for International Trade and Industry. Instead, he said, the two sides would have to settle for a partial deal, something the United States has only reluctantly said it would consider. 
 In a further tightening, another senior Japanese Government official changed gears on a concession that had been offered earlier, saying that a big Japanese Government loan being negotiated with the Ford Motor Company was contingent on eased demands by the Clinton Administration over opening the Japanese auto market.
 
Broader Deal Demanded
 Japan's Export-Import Bank has said it is negotiating a loan of $200 million to $300 million to help Ford produce right-hand-drive automobiles for export to Japan. The loan's concessionary interest rate would have saved Ford millions of dollars in interest costs. The bank has said it is willing to offer similar loans to Chrysler and General Motors.
Today, the senior Government official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified further, said that the loans would not be made if Washington did not strike a broader deal on autos by relaxing its demands.
The comments underscored the fact that the loan was motivated for political rather than economic reasons, and demonstrated how the Japanese Government has been increasingly eager to use financial incentives to put pressure on the United States.
The official also hinted that if the United States sought to weaken the dollar further against the yen, Japanese financial institutions might sell some of their holdings of United States Treasury bonds, thus driving American interest rates higher.
The comments today were part of a vigorous campaign by the Japanese to press the United States to ease its demands on the trade issues being discussed. They face a Sept. 30 deadline for several of the key markets.
For nearly a year and a half, the two sides have been unable to agree on measures to open the Japanese markets for insurance, autos and auto parts, government procurement of telecommunications and medical equipment.
The main hurdle has been an American demand that Japan provide guarantees of increased purchases of American goods or improved access to the Japanese market.
Even though the Japanese agreed in the original framework for the current talks to include such "objective criteria" for measuring progress, they now say they have no intention of making such a concession because it would require Government intervention in the markets.
 
U.S. Backing Away?
 Mr. Hashimoto contended that the United States was already backing away from its demands and had softened its earlier insistence that it would reject a partial agreement. He said today that he had suggested the two sides agree only on "what could be wrapped up."
Although American officials have reluctantly admitted for several months that they would be forced to accept such a deal, Mr. Hashimoto said that during talks with top American officials last week in the United States they had given ground.
"But my impression was that the U.S. has finally shown understanding," he remarked.
Other officials have said that a deal on autos and auto parts appears remote, but that an agreement on opening Japan's insurance market and government procurement was within reach.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Little Change On Consumer Price Report

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday, after a Government report showing a tepid rise in consumer prices eased some investors' concern about inflation.
The Canadian dollar, meanwhile, soared to its highest point against the United States currency in more than six months, after the Parti Quebecois won provincial elections in Quebec by a narrow margin. The results prompted speculation that the separatists did not have enough support for Quebec to secede from Canada. 
 In New York, the dollar was last quoted at 1.5435 German marks, little changed from 1.5436 marks on Monday. It slipped to 98.85 Japanese yen, from 99.18 yen.
The Canadian dollar rose to 74.18 cents (United States), its highest level since Feb. 28, and up from 73.13 cents.
The dollar was initially pulled higher by the rise in Treasury bonds, after the Labor Department said consumer prices rose a smaller-than-expected three-tenths of 1 percent in August.
Bonds and the dollar seesawed for the rest of the day. There was speculation that other economic reports due out shortly would show that the economy was growing fast enough to set off an acceleration of inflation.
"The number was a relief," said Paul Farrell, manager of strategic currency trading at Chase Manhattan Bank. "But reports due out later this week are expected to show strength. There's going to be more anxiety about inflation."
Traders warned that bonds and the dollar could fall today if the Government report on retail sales for August came in stronger than expected. In a survey, analysts estimated that retail sales rose 1.1 percent in August as auto sales rebounded.
Bonds and the dollar plunged on Friday after the Labor Department reported that producer prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent in August, the biggest increase in almost four years.
Canada's currency rallied along with Canadian stocks and bonds because the Parti Quebecois's narrow margin of victory raised doubt about the willingness of Quebec's voters to secede from Canada.
"Secession looks more remote now," said Tom Benfer, director of foreign exchange trading at the Bank of Montreal in New York. "Investors are comfortable with Canadian assets today."
Canada's central bank sold the country's currency yesterday to slow its rise, traders said.
Elsewhere, the British pound slipped yesterday to $1.5637 from $1.5693, after surging on Monday after the Bank of England raised interest rates.

HEADLINE: Angell Said To See Slump

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
A former governor of the Federal Reserve, Wayne D. Angell, expects the economy to fall into recession in 1996 as the Fed fights inflation with higher interest rates, those who heard him on a conference call said yesterday.
The former Fed official, now chief economist at the Bear Stearns Companies, made the remarks in a conference call with the brokerage firm's clients. 
 Mr. Angell said the best thing the Fed could do -- but was unlikely to -- was to shock financial markets by engineering an increase of one percentage point in short-term interest rates this month, the sources said.
The Fed has already raised interest rates five times this year, but the financial markets have been uneasy that inflation may still become a problem.
Officials at Bear Stearns were not immediately available to confirm Mr. Angell's remarks.

HEADLINE: The New Population Control Weapon

 BODY:
The acrimonious debate over abortion at the world population conference in Cairo has obscured the truly radical element in the document approved by delegates at the final session yesterday: the notion that enhancing the educational, political and economic opportunities for women is perhaps the surest way to curb further population growth.
Previous conferences in this once-a-decade event have favored other solutions, such as economic growth ("development is the best contraceptive") or the provision of family planning services. Each approach can claim successes, and the world has made great progress in reducing the rate of growth in recent decades. But the absolute number of births continues to rise and major problems remain in many impoverished countries. 
 The great contribution of the Cairo declaration is to add another weapon to the arsenal: the empowerment of women. This emphasis was largely at the behest of women's groups, giving the document an odd flavor of feminist rhetoric. But surely it is intuitively right to assume that women, as bearers of the world's children, are in the best position to slow birth rates and that, if given greater opportunities, they will forgo continuous childbearing.
Beyond intuition, there is empirical evidence. The state of Kerala in populous India, though very poor, has reduced its fertility rate to replacement levels, thanks in large part to high levels of female literacy and education and growing economic opportunities for women.
The conference did nothing to elucidate the long-running debate between pessimists who fear population growth will outrun food and natural resources and optimists who believe the world can support much larger numbers. But one does not have to be a Malthusian catastrophist to believe that, in many poor nations, economic and social problems could be more readily mastered if population growth were curbed.
In most minds, the Cairo conference will be remembered for the battle over abortion and sexual issues, pitting the Vatican and many Islamic countries against the U.S. and other secular governments. But its true importance will lie in whether it persuades governments and private groups to adopt programs to control growth rates. The Clinton Administration did a masterful job in defusing the Vatican's diplomatic attack and committing U.S. money and influence to the international effort. In contrast to the sorry performance of the Reagan Administration, which virtually withdrew from the global effort a decade ago, the Americans this time took a forceful and farsighted leadership role.

HEADLINE: In America;
Workers, Unite!

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
There seems to be no limit to the docility of American workers. This is the one group that seems never to assert its rights, or even to acknowledge that it has any.
This is a group that will watch in humble silence as once-proud white collar employees are downsized out of their comfortable offices and into hamburger uniforms, as manufacturing jobs are rounded up and shipped overseas to semi-slaves working in squalid conditions, as massive amounts of research and development money flow into monumentally wasteful military projects at the expense of product development and technical innovation in private industry. 
 This is a group that emitted not so much as a peep as the post-cold war peace dividend evaporated, as wages and benefits for ordinary Americans were deliberately and systematically curtailed, as labor unions were trampled by the government and corporations alike, as the spoils seized by corporate plunderers reached breath-taking levels, and as smug and well-fed economists pompously asserted that the nation could not afford an official unemployment rate that slipped below 6 percent or so. (These same economists don't even mention the real jobless rate).
Where is the anger? Where is the outrage? The politicians, who get elected by the masses but answer to the money, have been telling us that the economy is in swell shape. And the august Federal Reserve Board -- well, it's in a constant state of worry that things are too good.
Reality check: The latest report by Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm, puts the number of job cuts announced in August at 46,380. So far this year, employer-announced work-force reductions have totaled 365,519, which is not that far below the 400,578 cuts made over the same period last year.
If this is too good, you don't want to be around when things get really bad.
"Employers have eliminated fewer jobs so far this year, but this in no way means that the downsizing trend of the last 20 months is over," James E. Challenger, the president of the outplacement company, reported.
According to Mr. Challenger, the increased merger activity of recent weeks heralds more job cuts in upcoming months. "Since mergers mold two work forces into one new organization," he said, "the issue of job redundancy means certain positions will eventually be eliminated."
Even Labor Secretary Robert Reich, in a speech that tried to put the best face on the nation's employment picture, acknowledged that the middle class has become "an anxious class, most of whom hold jobs but who are justifiably uneasy about their own standing and fearful for their children's futures."
If employed members of the middle class are anxious and fearful, what is to be said about the many millions of unemployed, partially employed and temporarily employed men and women who arise each day with little or no awareness of where their family's rent or meal money is to be found?
What is to be done? Do the employees and potential employees of America continue to take whatever abuses are thrown at them by the ruling elite? Is the idea of a reasonably steady improvement in the quality of life from one generation to another just a quaint notion from the distant past? Is the American Dream dead?
Herbert J. Gans, a professor at Columbia University who has worried about the problem of unemployment since the early 1960's, has what seems to be a sensible proposal. It is time, said Professor Gans, for the formation of an employees lobby, a national organization that would fight against the exploitation of men and women who have to work for a living.
In an article he wrote for Social Policy magazine, Professor Gans said the lobby "would represent employed workers, whatever the shapes and colors of their collars, as well as supervisory and managerial employees of all kinds. It would speak for the jobless as well, and for 'contingent,' 'flexible' and other involuntary part-time workers."
Such a lobby would suddenly place the issue of jobs high on the nation's agenda, the professor said, and would "educate the public both about the drastic changes our economy is facing and the need to address them politically."
The American Association of Retired Persons has shown the kind of clout a well-organized lobby of ordinary citizens can wield. Working men and women would do well to take a cue from their elders.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: At Harvard Club, Work Rules Stall Settlement

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Michael T. Kaufman's distorted picture of the strike against the Harvard Club (About New York, Sept. 3) sheds little light on the facts of the dispute between the club and leaders of Local 6 of the Hotel, Restaurant and Club Employees Union. By indulging in stereotypes, Mr. Kaufman does a disservice to all who want the strike settled sooner rather than later, with an agreement that's fair to employees and to the club. 
 We are proud that rather than squeezing out a living as grit and grime, as Mr. Kaufman put it, Harvard Club employees are paid better and receive better benefits, including first-dollar medical coverage, than workers in similar jobs at restaurants and clubs in New York City.
We are ready to increase wages and to continue providing full benefits, but we can only do this if we can also bring into the 20th century the club operations governed by Local 6 work rules -- rules that, for instance, don't allow pot washers to wash dishes or dishwashers to wash pots. Work rules that say bus persons in the dining room can't make coffee, even when they don't have anything else to do, because it's a pantryman's job.
So far, leaders of Local 6 have chosen to stall rather than negotiate. When we tried to keep negotiations going and employees working, Local 6's leaders answered by calling a strike. Every time we've suggested using mediators to help reach an agreement, union leaders have participated grudgingly and walked away at the first opportunity.
Employees are indeed valued members of the Harvard Club family who deserve the job security that comes from a club whose operations are economically sound. We want them back, under a contract that works for all.
 
PRESTON TOWNLEY
Vice President
Harvard Club of New York City
New York, Sept. 8, 1994

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Increased 0.3% in August

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Calming fears that inflation might be rising sharply, the Government reported today that consumer prices climbed in August by the same three-tenths of 1 percent that they rose in June and July.
The latest figures caused none of the consternation of Friday, when producer prices showed a surprising surge of six-tenths of 1 percent, roiling the financial markets. Still, many economists maintain that the pace of inflation is increasing, forecasting that consumer prices will rise around 3.5 percent this year after two years of increases of less than 3 percent. 
 Analysts said the August increase in the Consumer Price Index remained moderate because the increases in producer prices -- the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers -- have not yet worked their way to the consumer level. But analysts say that the pressure on consumer prices will continue in the months ahead, as commodity and other prices drift higher.
"We are looking at a slow upcreep," said Eugene J. Sherman, research director at M. A. Schapiro & Company in New York, noting that core inflation has moved up to 3.1 percent in the last six months from 2.6 percent for the six months through February.
Today, the financial markets seemed to react to the news in this light. Bond and stock prices rose after the release of the consumer prices report, but gave up some of their gains later in the day. The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 19.52 points. The bond market was at least encouraged that the report renewed its conviction that the Federal Reserve would forgo any further tightening of monetary policy this month and wait at least until the November meeting of its policy-making panel.
In a related report, the Labor Department calculated that average weekly earnings adjusted for inflation fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in August from July. August was the first month this year to post a drop in earnings compared with a year earlier; inflation-adjusted earnings last month were four-tenths of 1 percent below the level of August 1993.
But it was the Consumer Price Index, which rose a tad less than many analysts had expected, that was the main focus of attention. Analysts found themselves reassured that Friday's sharp rise in producer prices represented a convergence of factors that was unlikely to be repeated. They noted that the goods component of the index, accounting for about 43 percent of the total, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the same as in May and June and less than in July.
The narrower producer price indexes include few services or imported goods and their link with what consumers ultimately pay is often loose, economists say.
Analysts also took comfort in the fact that the so-called core consumer index, with the volatile food and energy components removed, also moved up three-tenths of 1 percent last month -- the same rate as in February, March, May and June -- and, thus, was showing no clearly worrisome acceleration. For April and July, the core rose two-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Annual Pace Below 3%
 "We haven't really seen any kind of a sustained pickup" in inflation, said Michael P. Niemira, chief economist with Mitsubishi Bank in New York.
Inflation is now running at a pace of 2.9 percent for the latest 12 months, compared with 2.8 percent for the 12-month period that ended in August 1993.
Patrick C. Jackman, a Labor Department price specialist, pointed to various factors that seemed likely to keep the September rise in consumer prices to a minimum. The price of gasoline, up 3.7 percent in August and 7.8 percent over the latest three months, has turned down, and there will almost certainly be no repeat of coffee's record leaps of about 22 percent in both July and August.
Moreover, seasonal factors may again restrain the apparel component, which fell for the second consecutive month in August on end-of-season sales of spring and summer wear coupled with smaller-than-usual price increases on new fall and winter lines.
"If you look at the very short run, the situation looks better," Mr. Jackman said.
He and others, however, see a gradual rising of inflation into next year, driven in part by an environmental-protection mandate that is expected to raise the price of gasoline by as much as 8 cents a gallon in some metropolitan areas.
 
Consequences of Growth
 Howard Keen Jr., chief economist at Conrail, said it was "hard to believe" that the economy could expand as rapidly as it has -- an average annual pace of 4.5 percent in the latest three full quarters -- without some price acceleration.
He said that his railroad's shipments of truck trailers, mainly filled with consumer goods, are particularly strong, possibly reflecting inventory building by optimistic merchants. Many economists have been assuming that the apparently unwanted inventories that accumulated during the second quarter would be worked off during the summer.
The services component, accounting for just over 56 percent of the index, moved up four-tenths of 1 percent in August, today's report also showed, the third consecutive small acceleration.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 15, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Government's report on consumer prices in August misstated the period for which the annual pace of inflation is expected by many economists to increase to 3.5 percent. It is next year, not this year.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE GOVERNOR'S RACE;
The Final Heat Is Between Cuomo and Not-Cuomo

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
Yesterday's primary in New York cleared the way for a gubernatorial election between an incumbent whom many New Yorkers do not like and a Republican challenger whom most do not yet know.
Until now, New York's gubernatorial campaign has revolved around a simple question: is Gov. Mario M. Cuomo so unpopular that the Republicans can end his 12-year reign without ever making a compelling case for his opponent, State Senator George E. Pataki? 
 Mr. Pataki, a 10-year legislator from the Hudson Valley hamlet of Garrison, campaigned for 10 months before winning a convincing victory over Richard M. Rosenbaum yesterday. Yet, polls and random interviews suggest that he has made little connection with New York voters.
He stayed out of public view during much of the primary campaign, preferring to hoard money for the fall. He has pointedly declined to provide details about the most central elements of his platform -- cutting taxes and fighting crime. The lone biographical advertisement broadcast by Mr. Pataki's campaign does not even include the candidate's voice.
 
Aggressive Advertisements
 Campaign strategists have promised that Mr. Pataki's visibility will now begin to grow, starting with a news conference in Manhattan today at which he plans to unveil proposals for improving the state's fiscal and legislative processes. But in the same breath, they vow that they will make the 1994 campaign a referendum on Mr. Cuomo and that they will fuel public antipathy toward his tenure.
Mr. Cuomo's aides believe the Governor may reap some marginal benefit in November from Karen S. Burstein's narrow victory in yesterday's Democratic primary for Attorney General. Her presence on the ticket saves the Democrats from the awkwardness of running an all-male slate against a Republican team that includes two women.
The Cuomo campaign believes that the tandem of Ms. Burstein, a lesbian, and State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who was chosen by the Legislature in May 1993 and hopes to become the first black candidate to win a statewide election, will generate enthusiasm among women, homosexuals and minorities and produce a large turnout of the Governor's Democratic base.
Mr. Pataki's fuzzy definition and his eagerness to keep the focus on Mr. Cuomo has made for a general election campaign that turned ugly long before it officially started. Mr. Pataki has assailed Mr. Cuomo's fiscal policies and opposition to the death penalty while also accusing him of misusing his office for private gain.
Mr. Cuomo's campaign has responded by trying to depict Mr. Pataki, in the words of Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, as "a small-time politician who cuts corners." It has raised questions about Mr. Pataki's personal finances, his consistency on issues and the political patronage of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
But with Mr. Cuomo's approval ratings hovering about 35 percent, a dangerously low level for any incumbent, he also carries a heavy burden.
 
Differences in Advice
 Some Democratic leaders worry that the Governor still has not articulated a rationale for a fourth term. Without such a vision, they said, voters may spend the fall trying to decide not only who Mr. Pataki is, but who Mr. Cuomo wants to be, and how his 13th year might differ from the previous 12.
Up to now, Mr. Cuomo has tended to look back as well as forward, seeking to deepen the uncertainty about Mr. Pataki by speaking of the stature required to run a state like New York.
"It really is a contest," Mr. Cuomo said last week, "of the current Governor against another person who will have to run the 10th-largest economy in the world, deal with 16 hostages at Ossining, deal with the explosion at the World Trade Center, take on the President of the United States when he says, 'I'm going to disallow the deductibility of state and local taxes,' stand in the middle of Crown Heights, etc., etc."
Political strategists differ, meanwhile, over whether Mr. Pataki must give voters a reason to support him beyond the inarguable fact that he is not Mr. Cuomo.
"Pataki is more an agent than an actor," said Eddie Mahe, a Republican consultant who has worked in New York. "People will vote either for Cuomo or against Cuomo and all Pataki has to do is meet a minimal standard of acceptance. He doesn't have to establish a Pataki agenda."
Robert M. Shrum, a Democratic consultant who worked on both of David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaigns, disagreed. "For Pataki to think he can take disapproval numbers and turn them into votes for himself without giving people an affirmative reason to vote for an alternative is a big mistake," he said.
For instance, Senator Arlen Specter alienated Pennsylvania voters by defending Clarence Thomas against Anita Hill, yet beat Lynn Yeakel in 1992 by depicting her as a single-issue candidate and by highlighting her lateness in paying income taxes.
In other campaigns, however, challengers have managed to defeat unpopular chief executives by focusing on the frailties of the incumbent.
Despite deep public concerns about his character, Bill Clinton became President in 1992 by exploiting the public's dissatisfaction with George Bush. And Christine Todd Whitman defeated Jim Florio in New Jersey's gubernatorial race last year by relentlessly reminding voters that he had raised taxes.
Mr. Pataki considers Mrs. Whitman something of a role model. But she had one major advantage that he lacks -- a prior statewide race (in 1990 against Senator Bill Bradley) that gave the voters a chance get comfortable with her.
"She had been around the track and it was on the second occasion that she was successful," said Lee M. Miringoff, a New York pollster. "Pataki has to use the campaign to send a message to voters about the competence with which he would govern."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 17, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in some copies on Wednesday about the New York primary for governor misstated the number of terms the Republican nominee, George E. Pataki, has served in the State Senate. He is in his first term, not his second.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Simmons Market Research Bureau changes its methodology to try to reverse some setbacks.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE Simmons Market Research Bureau is overhauling its longtime survey methodology and naming a new president and chief executive. The important changes come as the company seeks to resolve a fractious dispute over magazine audience measurement.
Data from Simmons and its principal rival, Mediamark Research Inc., help agencies decide where to spend billions of dollars a year in magazine and newspaper advertisements. With the 1995 survey to be released in May, Simmons will change how its interviews ask questions for the first time since its founding in 1963. 
 The new Simmons methodology, while perhaps less painstaking, is less time-consuming and less expensive. And it is far more like the manner by which Mediamark has gathered data for the last 15 years.
"A research product, like any other product, has to evolve to meet the needs of its market," said Rebecca McPheters, who will succeed Ellen Cohen as president and chief executive.
Though the Simmons switch is not as momentous as the Coca-Cola Company concocting a "New" Coke that tastes like Pepsi, it represents a sea change for the company, which hopes its new "Survey of American Readership" will reverse setbacks ranging from the increasing reluctance of consumers to participate in lengthy surveys to the increasing defections of important clients like Conde Nast Publications and Hearst Magazines.
"The writing is on the wall," Tim Bowles, chief executive at the MRB Group in London, parent of Simmons, said.
"After a very long period of soul-searching," he added, "we decided we'd try to develop an improved application of the 'recent reading' method." His reference was to the Mediamark methodology, so named because consumers answer questions about articles in publications they say they have recently read.
Simmons, by contrast, has used a methodology called "through the book," named after the interviewing process by which respondents page through mockups of actual issues to determine whether they have read those publications. Since that takes more time than "recent reading," Simmons surveyed 140 titles to Mediamark's 230.
"In terms of competition for client business, that was a disadvantage," Mr. Bowles acknowledged. Though Simmons's approach was better, he asserted, because "we were using the power of recognition rather than recall, you can't have everything."
Stuart Gray, senior vice president for media research at BBDO Worldwide in New York, said: "We would have preferred for Simmons to have found some solution to continuing the 'through-the-book' technique. It's the superior method for developing estimates of average issue readership. But we're accepting of the fact it was just not viable, and we will be supportive of that decision in terms of looking at the new data."
While "we'll have to look at the data with fresh eyes, so to speak," Mr. Gray said, "because this is such a dramatic departure in their methodology," one major benefit is that with both companies using the "recent reading" methodology, "it will be easy to compare both sets of data."
Steven T. Florio, president at Conde Nast, said he "will certainly take a look at" Simmons's new readership survey, and "listen to what they have to say.
"But we're already committed to not committing," he added, referring to a recent decision not to buy Simmons data for the coming year, which the trade publication Inside Media estimated will cost Simmons nearly $1 million in lost revenue.
Mr. Bowles, however, is dedicated to regaining departed clients, declaring, "If I didn't believe that, I wouldn't be here."
Ms. McPheters said she was "particularly excited" by the Simmons's measures "to further develop magazine audience research." For instance, in another change, Simmons will part company with Mediamark in compiling and reporting readership and marketing data in single reports by separating them into a "New Study of Media and Markets" along with the "Survey of American Readership."
Ms. McPheters, 44, joins Simmons after only recently arriving at Gruner & Jahr U.S.A. Publishing, which acquired her previous employer, The New York Times Company Women's Magazines, where she was senior vice president and group executive. Ms. McPheters will succeed Ms. Cohen, who has been president and chief executive for the last five years, on Sept. 26.
Ms. Cohen said she planned to start a consulting company, with Simmons as an initial client. She added that her discussions about leaving started in November, well before the dispute over audience measurement. Mr. Bowles agreed that Ms. Cohen's departure was coincidental and praised her as "a champion of our new products."
The dispute involves a once-confidential draft report by members of a committee of the Magazine Publishers of America, the trade organization representing the magazine industry. It labeled as "perplexing" the basis for compiling certain data -- unrelated to the "through-the-book" methodology -- that reported a steep decline in potential readers of magazines.
The data were "a blip," Mr. Bowles said, adding that in the 1994 survey, the potential-reader figures returned to more historical levels.
The dispute grew unpleasant enough that the American Association of Advertising Agencies -- where Mr. Gray is chairman of the media research committee -- is seeking to defuse it by convening a meeting on Sept. 23 with executives from Simmons, the publishers association, Mediamark and the Advertising Research Foundation.
"I'm anxious we, as quickly as possible, answer any questions they have" about Simmons data, Ms. McPheters said, adding, "We have absolutely nothing to hide."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA;
Barry Victory Reveals Widening Racial Rift

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Even in a city with a long tradition of racial polarization, the split between black and white voters in Marion S. Barry Jr.'s dramatic victory in the Democratic mayoral primary on Tuesday was a surprise.
Not because Mr. Barry swept Washington's poor black neighborhoods and won almost no support in the rich white ones, but because he attracted a surprisingly large number of voters from the city's middle-class blacks. The results only seemed to widen the gulf between the races here. 
 Today, many whites felt isolated by their dislike of Mr. Barry and angered that a convicted drug user will represent the Democratic Party in November's election instead of Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly or Councilman John Ray, who are also black and who had relied heavily in the past on whites and the large black middle-class for a winning coalition.
"I think its a real embarrassment," Barry Stahl, a 44-year-old white supporter of Mr. Ray, said in a typical assessment by white voters of Mr. Barry's victory. "It has got to be bad for the city. A lot of people are already moving out, fearful of the direction the city is going. This is going to make it worse."
Mr. Barry's victory appeared to reflect a sense of anger and dissatisfaction among blacks of all economic classes -- not just with Mr. Barry's rivals, who offered experience but no passion, but also with the circumstances of living in a city where the local government and its budget are largely controlled by Congress.
"This election was not just a validation of Marion Barry," said Councilman Kevin Chavous of Ward 7, Mr. Barry's strongest area of support. "It was a statement against a lot of things, like people being told who should lead them. I heard that all over the city. People don't like being told what to do."
That sort of feeling is only likely to grow more intense if Congress reacts to Mr. Barry's almost inevitable election in November by trying to revoke the limited self-government here known as "home rule."
Representative James H. Saxton, a New Jersey Republican who sits on the House Committee on the District of Columbia, foreshadowed that struggle today, saying, "If Marion Barry does somehow manage to ascend to the mayoral seat, we must examine the D.C. governing process and whether it is a truly effective use of taxpayer funds."
Mayor Kelly, who swept into office four years ago as a reformer on the heels of Mr. Barry's drug arrest and conviction after 12 years as Mayor, was thoroughly rejected, receiving only 13 percent of the vote. Mr. Ray, in his fourth bid for mayor, had his best showing ever, with 37 percent.
Mr. Barry carried all six wards in which blacks are the majority; Mr. Ray carried the two wards with white majorities. In Ward 3, a northwest district that has the city's highest concentration of whites, Mr. Barry won just 3.4 percent of the vote, compared with the 29.4 percent he won in the 1986 primary, 34.3 percent in 1982 and 46.8 percent in 1978.
Mr. Barry was asked at a news conference today what he would say to the city's white voters.
"Get over it," he answered. "Get over whatever personal hangups you got. I am the best person for Washington. I know best how to protect their home, their investment. I know best how to balance this budget. I know best how to save our city from financial collapse, I know best how to get us moving."
Despite a widespread belief before the primary that Mr. Barry would have difficulty moving beyond his base of lower-income supporters, his victory showed that his campaign themes cut across economic lines among blacks. In Ward 4, where many professional blacks, including Mayor Kelly, live, Mr. Barry won almost 50 percent of the vote. He won more than half of the votes in Ward 5, a middle-class area where Mr. Ray lives.
Like lower-income blacks -- but unlike many whites -- they were drawn to the notion of revival and redemption. Throughout his campaign, Mr. Barry tried presenting his problems with the law, which included six months in a Federal prison, as an advantage. He portrayed himself as better now than before, for overcoming drug and alcohol addiction and rehabilitating himself.
"God bless him," Adrian Alexander, a 40-year-old black correctional officer, said today on a cluttered sidewalk in Ward 8, the poorest in the city, and where the vote was 10-to-1 for Mr. Barry over Mr. Ray. "This proves he can come back from adversity."
But another theme appeared to emerge, too: a strong, almost angry signal by blacks, which make up nearly 70 percent of Washington's population, that voters are weary of being controlled by a predominantly white establishment.
Councilman Chavous and others suggested that themes of revival and control might not have held such sway, were it not for a general disaffection with Mrs. Kelly and a failure to connect with Mr. Ray.
Also, Mr. Barry put together an aggressive corps of staffers and volunteers, who registered thousands of voters, plastered the city with posters and criss-crossed streets on election day, driving voters to the polls.
"I got my first job in one of his summer youth programs," said Darlene Chaney, a 28-year-old unemployed black Barry supporter. "I know he fell when he got busted. But that has nothing to do with it. Everybody has their problem. I don't look at his problems; I look at what he did for the city."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The notion of redemption was a strong theme in the surprise victory of Marion S. Barry Jr. in the Democratic primary race for mayor of Washington. Mr. Barry was embraced by a supporter on Tuesday night. (Kirsten Bremmer for The New York Times)
