HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN WITH HAITI: THE WHITE HOUSE;
Clinton Plans Speech to Head Off Clash With Congress

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Running out of time to make the case that restoring democracy to Haiti is worth the costs of invasion, President Clinton plans to address the nation Thursday not so much to persuade the public as to head off an ugly clash with Congress, Administration officials said today.
It was plain today that Mr. Clinton remains a reluctant warrior. As Administration officials disclosed that he had approved a plan to offer Haiti's military leaders a comfortable life in exile, the image of fortitude that he sought to convey to visiting reporters was tempered by one of a man searching for a way out of a political quandary. 
 Aides to Mr. Clinton said today that he recognized that he might not change many minds about an invasion that, according to polls, two-thirds of Americans regard as unwise. But he has decided that his 20-month-old standoff with Haiti's junta must not continue, they said, and he hopes that the power of his office will persuade the junta that he means what he says. He also hopes to prevail upon Congress not to stand in the way.
The President could still order an invasion of Haiti even if Congress formally advised him not to. But no one at the White House seems eager to risk such election-year defiance, and aides to Mr. Clinton are working with Congressional leaders in hopes of putting off any vote on the issue or making it merely symbolic to minimize the political complications.
"It is not time for a divisive debate about this," Dee Dee Myers, the White House spokeswoman, said today. "It is time to present a unified front."
Mr. Clinton's aides remain skeptical that anything short of force can push the Haitian leaders from power. But as the White House stepped up the tempo of its warnings, saying the time for the junta was running "very, very short," the President and his aides were trying harder than ever before to find a resonant argument that an invasion would be just and proper.
In a preview of his Oval Office address, Mr. Clinton told a group of news agency reporters today that the situation in Haiti was a kind of watershed. If left uncorrected, he said, Haiti's slide back to dicatorship would bode ill for fledgling democracies elsewhere in the Western Hemisphere. He portrayed Haiti as a killing field in which the United States has a moral obligation to halt human rights abuses.
And having threatened since May to stage an invasion unless Haiti's military leaders stepped down on their own, the President warned that the credibility not just of his Administration but also of the United States would be at stake unless he made good on his threats.
Saying he had already shown "extremely good faith and forbearance," he added, "The United States must not be in a position to walk away from a situation like this."
"I know it is unpopular," Mr. Clinton said of a possible invasion. "I know the timing is unpopular. I know the whole thing is unpopular. But I believe it is the right thing."
Since Mr. Clinton first threatened to use force to oust Haiti's junta, his aides have said he recognized that he was on a path in which he would see no option but to go forward with an invasion if economic sanctions alone did not force it from power.
Administration officials said any effort to persuade Congress and the public that a relatively insignificant country like Haiti was worth American blood and dollars was bound to be an uphill struggle.
"Inevitably, there was going to be a large controversy about sending troops to a place that most American people regard as peripheral to our interests," a senior official said.
But some officials acknowledged that the White House had also squandered some chances to win public backing for forceful action. They said they had failed to anticipate the degree to which the liberal Democrats who were the most vocal proponents of an invasion would remain at odds from mainstream Democrats as well as Republicans. And they said they had underestimated the opposition from groups like the American Legion, which can usually be counted on to support military operations abroad. Today, the Legion wrote Mr. Clinton expressing its opposition to an invasion.
The officials also said they had failed to call sufficient attention to the magnitude of human rights abuses in Haiti.
"Could more have been done to condition the public?" a senior Administration official said. "Yes, but we were also heavily involved in health care and crime and Cuba and a lot of other issues. Now we have a clear field of vision."
As part of the effort to build support in Congress, especially among wavering Democrats, senior officials have been meeting at the White House every day this week to devise the new public relations campaign. They include David R. Gergen, a special adviser to Mr. Clinton, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Mark D. Gearan, the White House communications director.
The group has recommended that the President seek in his speech on Thursday night "to put a graphic face" on human rights violations there, an official said tonight.

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Drops

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus fell 18.8 percent in August as imports rose sharply. The figures provide some evidence that the steep appreciation of the yen in the last year and a half may finally be working to cut the huge trade imbalance.
However, Japan's politically sensitive surplus with the United States continued to rise, to $3.49 billion in August, up 2 percent from $3.42 billion a year earlier. That is because the strong American economy continued to soak up such Japanese products as semiconductors, liquid crystal displays, autos and auto parts and machine tools. 
 While the overall trade surplus declined when measured in yen, it has not decreased when measured in dollars because each yen is worth more in dollars now.
The latest figures were announced by the Finance Ministry as a deadline set by the Clinton Administration approaches for Japan and the United States to reach trade agreements in several areas by the end of the month.
Japan's overall trade surplus, on a customs clearance basis, narrowed to $6.08 billion in August. In June and July, Japan's surplus increased over the same months a year earlier.
Imports in August soared 23.6 percent, more than offsetting a healthy gain of 12.2 percent in exports. Analysts said the import figures were increased by special factors that might not be repeated, such as large imports of crude oil to generate electricity during an unusually hot summer and some airplane purchases.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The not so clear and present danger of inflation.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
"STOCK up on canned sardines and ammo for the deer rifle, mama, and spend those greenbacks while you can. . . ."
Inflation hysteria has not yet brought the survivalists out of the woodwork, and news this week that consumer prices rose at an annual rate of less than 4 percent in August may keep them there a while longer. But as Van Doorn Ooms, the chief economist for the Committee for Economic Development, puts it, "there's an edginess out there" that is rubbed a little rawer by every ambiguous Government report on inflation and every passing remark by a member of the Fed that does not begin and end with a genuflection toward the gods of price stability. 
 The most sensible view, many economists argue, is that this glass is at least half full -- that while the American economy is operating near the limits of noninflationary growth, price changes to date reflect little more than the recovery of profitability in commodities and other cyclically sensitive industries. The tricky moment will come if and when wages begin to catch up with prices: "I'm amazed it has taken so long," allowed Robert J. Gordon of Northwestern University.
The inflation scare of the month was August's unexpected jump of six-tenths of a percent in what used to be called wholesale prices. That followed a five-tenths of a percent increase in July, implying that the annual rate is pushing 7 percent. Look closer, though, and it is apparent that much of the inflation has been in raw materials, whose prices have been depressed for much of the last decade. "It's classic," said David Hale, an economist at the Kemper Financial Group. "First commodity prices rise, then intermediate goods, then finished products."
Indeed, said Richard Cooper, an economist at Harvard, it is not only classic but desirable. Producers of everything from aluminum ingots to paper have to be highly profitable on the up side of the business cycle to compensate for anemic margins or even losses on the down side. By the same token, if demand does not continue to grow faster than the capacity, producer prices should level off.
So why is everyone so touchy? Remember, for starters, that bond dealers are obsessed with prices because higher inflation translates into lower bond prices. And for reasons unclear, the ranks of opinion leaders who have confused the interests of a handful of Wall Street businesses with those of the nation seem to have grown in recent years.
But there is more at work here than bond dealers' inclination to let Joe Sixpack drink Dom Perignon. While cyclic increases in prices don't bother economists, the prospect of an inflationary spiral -- one that is self-reinforcing and independent of actual shortages -- surely does.
The widely accepted mechanism, known as the "natural rate hypothesis," goes like this: Ordinarily, competition prevents workers from making wage demands in excess of productivity gains stick. But once markets become overheated, producers try (and succeed) in passing higher costs to buyers. Most disturbing, the process is not self-limiting; once unemployment is below the natural rate, the inflation tiger is fated to chase its tail at ever-increasing speed.
In a speech earlier this month, Alan S. Blinder, the new vice chairman of the Fed, pointed out that no one truly knows what the natural rate is. Hence the eternal job of the Fed is making trade-offs between the risk of embedding expectations of inflation and the risk of accepting unnecessarily high unemployment.
That restatement of what virtually every economist considers obvious apparently did not win Mr. Blinder any friends among those accustomed to Fed governors who talk about inflation the way Jimmy Swaggart talked about sin. Nor is what Mr. Ooms dismisses as "a tempest in a teapot" likely to increase Mr. Blinder's chances for promotion to chairman of the Fed when Alan Greenspan's term expires.
But the trade-off really, truly is the primary task of the Fed -- and one that could become increasingly difficult in coming months. For one thing, Mr. Hale points out, world markets for commodities are likely to continue to tighten because of the European economic recovery and boom in East Asia. More important, labor may begin to flex its atrophied muscles.
At a comparable point in the 1987-90 upturn in the business cycle, Mr. Gordon notes, wage demands were running two percentage points higher than today. And while there has been much chatter about the brave new world in which everyone is afraid to ask for a raise lest their jobs end up in Indonesia, there is little hard evidence that global labor competition makes much difference outside of a dozen high-profile manufacturing industries.
Most business cycles, it seems, end in a flurry of shortages and a screech of the monetary brakes. And if history is any judge, said Charles Schultze, an economist at the Brookings Institution and veteran of the Carter Administration, "we'll probably do it again." That is a long way from saying, though, that inflation is a clear and present danger.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Assessing the Exxon Valdez trial, analysts are divided.

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas 

 BODY:
AS the jurors deliberate on whether Exxon should pay punitive damages for the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989, should investors worry? Responding to that question, Wall Street analysts are in conflict.
Some analysts say avoid the stock until the damages are awarded. Others advise waiting even longer, because Exxon's bill could be reduced after appeals. 
 Others say that investors should hold on to their stock, and some even suggest buying it now, since it is almost 13 percent below this year's high of $67.375. These analysts argue that there is a good chance that the jury's award will be moderate, paving the way for a quick rise in the stock price. In addition, they argue that Exxon's earnings outlook is improving because some of the company's businesses, including the huge European operations, are on the rebound.
The jury, meeting in United States District Court in Anchorage, is expected to reach its decision soon. Even if the jury awards the full $15 billion that the plaintiffs' lawyers are seeking, analysts say that Exxon, the world's second-largest publicly traded oil company, after Royal Dutch/Shell, has the financial strength and legal stamina to suffer only limited damage.
"Exxon has deep pockets," said Frank P. Knuettel of Prudential Securities, and it is sure to appeal, he added, which will buy time. There is also a good chance it could negotiate the amount down. Exxon has put together a legal team that was able to convince the jury on Aug. 12 to award commercial fishermen $286.8 million in damages for the 1989 spill, less than a third the $895 million that had been sought.
In addition, Mr. Knuettel predicted that the jury would reject the plaintiffs' main argument that a huge settlement would teach Exxon a lesson.
Frederick Leuffer, an oil analyst for Bear Stearns, calculated that if Exxon borrowed to pay a $15 billion award, its interest cost would reduce earnings about 55 cents a share a year. He expects Exxon to earn about $3.35 a share this year and $4.50 next year, compared with $4.21 a share in 1993 on net income of $5.28 billion.
"It's certainly not life threatening, but the dividend growth rate could fall below that of its competitors," he added.
Mr. Leuffer, who advised investors to avoid the stock as the trial neared, predicts that Exxon could manage to pay an award on the high end without a major impact on its long-term earnings potential. He is sure, however, that there will be an impact on the stock. "If the jury can come back with $5 billion," he added, "the stock will still get hit. Who needs the headache?"
He favors avoiding the stock until it becomes clear what Exxon will have to pay, which could mean waiting out a long appeal process. Only then, he said, will it be clear whether Exxon can keep paying its high dividend, which now equals about 5 percent of the stock price.
But Mr. Knuettel argues that if investors shun Exxon now, they could miss a nice rally.
Exxon stock dropped about $8 to $59 a share in the weeks before the jury found that Exxon's "recklessness" had caused the grounding of the Exxon Valdez. The stock closed yesterday at $58.75, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Thus, if the jury awards a reasonable amount, he said, it could send the stock up.
"You are going to see some good increase in production and a rebound in the European economies," added Mary Quinn, an oil analyst for the S. G. Warburg Group. Uncertainty about the trial has given investors an opportunity to buy Exxon "relatively cheap," she said.

HEADLINE: Biedrusko Journal;
The Cold War Armies Meet, Just to Link Arms

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BIEDRUSKO, Poland, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Sgt. Timothy Britt came off the target range at the military training field in this small Polish village brimming with relief.
"They're more disciplined than I thought," said the American soldier, who is based in Germany, as he looked toward the platoon of Polish soldiers. "To put it bluntly, I'm glad they are our friends now. I wouldn't want to go against them." 
 Nearly 1,000 soldiers from 13 countries on opposing sides of the cold war gathered on Polish territory this week for exercises that were billed as the first practical demonstration of how former enemies can work together.
The exercises were conducted under the Partnership for Peace begun by NATO in January to encourage former Warsaw Pact countries to come closer to the Western alliance without becoming full members.
Troops from the United States, Germany, Britain, Denmark, Italy and the Netherlands, all NATO countries, and from Poland, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Lithuania, Romania and Ukraine, all part of the former Warsaw Pact alliance, worked together on peacekeeping tasks like escorting food convoys, dealing with refugees and changing guard at observation posts.
An important part of the exercises, which were kept fairly modest in part not to antagonize Russia, a late-joining member of Partnership for Peace, was political. The presence on Polish soil of 105 friendly German soldiers set the tone.
"Anyone who knows even a little bit about history knows this is not a routine event when Polish and German soldiers are working together," the German Defense Minister, Volker Ruhe, said as he sat alongside the Polish Defense Minister, Piotr Kolodziejczyk, at a joint news conference. "It shows how well German-Polish relations are developing."
The participation of German troops here was particularly symbolic because this area of Poland, 80 miles east of the German border, was once part of Germany.
In the post-cold-war era, Germany has become one of the biggest advocates of the admission of Poland, as well as Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovakia, to the European Union and NATO. "I personally think this will happen before 2000," Mr. Ruhe said of their joining NATO.
After Poland becomes a member of NATO, Polish and German military cooperation could become as close as that now between France and Germany, Mr. Ruhe said.
Beyond the political symbolism, the operations were an eye-opener for the soldiers. They inspected one another's weapons, looked over tanks and helicopters.
"How is this grenade fired?" asked Capt. Robert Burns, who was visiting as an observer from Fort Leavenworth, Kan., as he handled a Polish soldier's rocket-propelled grenade. "It's an inertia type switch motor," the Pole replied.
Captain Burns said he learned a lot from the exercise. The Americans use disposable launchers with such equipment; the Poles reload their launchers, making such equipment more like a bazooka. The close inspection of each other's weapons was fascinating and also essential if these former enemy armies were ever going to operate together, the soldiers said.
The Americans said they also confirmed in the open what they had known for years through intelligence and books: that Western rifles were designed for more accuracy and Warsaw Pact rifles for shooting at shorter range.
There was a certain amount of American chauvinism about weapons. "They're just as curious as we are, if not more," said Sgt. Kenneth Cook, who belongs to an American platoon from Kirch Gons, Germany, taking part in the exercise. "They were really curious about our Bradley antipersonnel carrier, how far it can shoot and how much steel it can penetrate. Their APC's penetrate up to 14 centimeters of steel. Our Bradleys can fire through 18 inches of steel."
An American helicopter, a Black Hawk, and a Polish helicopter, a Falcon, stood at the ready, side by side, for any medical emergencies. "The difference? Porsche to Volkswagen," said Sgt. Gilberto Vallejo of the same American Army unit, giving the Black Hawk the upper hand even though it was several years older.
But the after-hours socializing in the evening and the sharing of living quarters helped deflate prejudices.
"Before we came here, the opinions of the Polish Army and the Warsaw Pact countries were not so high among my soldiers," said Lieut. Jeremy Nathan, who headed the American platoon. "Now they realize they are soldiers who are quite capable and quite human, too. I'm sharing a room with Polish Lieut. Jaroslaw Strozyk. His wife is pregnant and is expecting in one month's time. But she might deliver early and he is on the phone to her twice a day."
What did Lieutenant Strozyk think of the Americans? "The American soldiers are very noisy, very talkative, a little bit crazy," he said with a smile, listening to the American platoon shouting back to a command in language largely indecipherable to a non-American soldier. "This is a very interesting technique. Perhaps we should get the Americans to instruct the Polish soldiers to say these things."

GRAPHIC: Photo: An American and a Pole had a friendly chat at joint military exercises in Biedrusko, Poland, this week that brought together nearly 1,000 soldiers from 13 countries on opposing sides in the cold war. (Witold Krassowski for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Prudential To Buy Back Investments

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Prudential Securities Inc. plans to buy back more than $70 million worth of mortgage investments that were improperly sold to hundreds of retail investors as being less risky than they actually were, executives with the firm said yesterday.
The investments were improperly sold during the spring and early summer of this year, the executives said, and they are showing large losses. Prudential believes customer losses on the investments totaled at least $10 million. 
 A mortgage trader for the firm has already been dismissed in the incident, said Charles Perkins, a Prudential spokesman. He declined to identify the trader. The firm said the trader provided inaccurate data to Prudential's retail sales force in documents that understated the true risk of the investments, known as collateralized mortgage obligations, or C.M.O.'s. The brokers selling the investments unknowingly passed that false information on to buyers.
In the documents, the analysis of how the mortgage investments would perform in various interest-rate environments was apparently adjusted to minimize their true risk. The trader "was rejiggering the calculations," Mr. Perkins said.
Mr. Perkins declined to speculate on the trader's motivation. But other Prudential executives noted that decreasing the stated risks would result in higher sales.
The problem comes at a particularly difficult time for Prudential Securities. Last October, the firm settled charges with Federal and state regulators that it fraudulently misrepresented the risk of more than $8 billion worth of limited partnerships in real estate, oil wells and other assets sold throughout the 1980's. The cost to the firm from that scandal, both in settlements and legal costs, is more than $1.1 billion.
A criminal investigation by the United States Attorney in Manhattan has resulted from the partnership scandal. In a recent meeting with a group of about 20 top firm executives, Hardwick Simmons, the chief executive of the firm, said Prudential expected to hear from prosecutors in the near future what the next stage of that investigation might be.
Although on a much smaller scale, the latest problem with the mortgage investments is reminiscent of the same troubles that led to the partnership scandal. Marketing materials given to brokers of the firm misrepresented the highly risky partnerships as safe and secure investments. But eventually, most of the partnerships collapsed, resulting in losses of billions of dollars for the firm and of customer relationships for many of its top brokers.
The improper sales of the mortgage investments were detected internally by Prudential, and the firm has not received any customer complaints on the matter, Mr. Perkins said. "We are proactively reaching out to investors and offering to buy their bonds back," he said. The bonds will be repurchased at their original sales price.
C.M.O.'s are pools of mortgages that have been cut into separate pieces called tranches, which are tailored to suit different investors' tastes for risk and return. A given tranche may include only principal or only interest, and may mature anywhere from three to 30 years. Its value may move with prevailing interest rates or against them.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE GOVERNOR'S RACE;
SWIPING AT CUOMO, PATAKI GIVES OUT PLAN ON GOVERNING

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
After campaigning for 10 months on hazy promises to cut taxes, fight crime and reduce spending, State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor, yesterday issued the first of what he said would be a series of detailed plans for changing state government. And he used the occasion to attack Gov. Mario M. Cuomo as the author of "failed liberal policies" that had caused great problems for the state.
On the day after both Mr. Pataki and Mr. Cuomo easily won their primary races, the Governor, a three-term incumbent, kicked off his general election campaign by announcing a new state-financed transportation program in Buffalo. 
 Later in the day, Mr. Cuomo scoffed at Mr. Pataki's contention that he would be an agent of change. "The only changes these guys are good at is change of position," he said after accepting the endorsement of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union in Manhattan.
Mr. Pataki's campaign began broadcasting three new statewide television commercials that underscore his support of proposals with strong anti-incumbent appeal: term limits and citizen initiative and referendum. All the commercials end with a new slogan: "Mario Cuomo: too liberal for too long."
"We will be reminding people of his liberal record, and that it's been a failed liberal record," said Robert Ryan, Mr. Pataki's campaign manager.
There were also signs yesterday that Mr. Pataki was still having problems uniting the Republicans. Though he has won the endorsement of his primary rival, Richard M. Rosenbaum, he has yet to pin down support from the Mayor of New York City, Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican who again yesterday left open the door to endorsing Mr. Cuomo and said he had not yet scheduled a meeting with Mr. Pataki.
"My support, lack of support or degree of support is going to turn very very much on where I believe each of the candidates is going to help New York City," Mr. Giuliani said at City Hall.
In a move that was considered beneficial to the Cuomo campaign, the State Board of Elections invalidated petitions submitted by the Rev. Al Sharpton's Freedom Party to be on the Nov. 8 ballot. The party's ticket would have included Colin Moore, the lawyer, running for governor and Mr. Sharpton running for United States Senate. Mr. Sharpton lost to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in Tuesday's Democratic primary.
If left on the ballot, the Freedom Party likely would have drawn black voters away from Mr. Cuomo, whose political fate could rest on the depth of his support among blacks, women and liberals. Beverly Alston, director of Mr. Sharpton's Manhattan operations, said the Freedom Party would appeal the decision in State Supreme Court.
Three of the tickets in the general election -- the Republican, Conservative and Tax Cut Now parties -- will feature Mr. Pataki and his running mates: Betsy P. McCaughey for lieutenant governor, Herbert London for comptroller, Dennis C. Vacco for attorney general and Bernadette Castro for Senate.
The Democratic and Liberal lines will be identical: Mr. Cuomo, Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, Comptroller H. Carl McCall, Karen S. Burstein for attorney general and Mr. Moynihan.
In addition, the Right to Life Party, which won 4 percent of the vote in the 1990 gubernatorial race and could cut into Mr. Pataki's conservative base, will field a full ticket led by its candidate for governor, Robert Walsh.
Mr. Cuomo, who has yet to accept Mr. Pataki's challenge for five one-on-one debates, suggested yesterday that he would insist on having minor-party candidates present at any forums featuring him and Mr. Pataki. "How do you leave out the Right to Life candidate?" he said in Manhattan.
In releasing what he called an "agenda for change" on a day of intensified media attention to the race, Mr. Pataki seemed intent on doing two things: quickly putting Mr. Cuomo on the defensive while answering critics who have said he has dithered in defining his programs. Mr. Pataki said the plan was just the first of several, and that later policy papers would deal with cutting taxes, stimulating the economy and combating crime.
Mr. Pataki called for five things that he said would make government more responsive to citizens. He would impose limits of six two-year terms on state legislators and two four-year terms on all statewide elected officials. He would support initiative and referendum, allowing citizens to place legislative proposals on the ballot through petitions.
He would require public debate on budget proposals and prevent the all-night sessions that have traditionally enabled the Legislature to pass bills without public scrutiny. And he would reduce by 20 percent the number of patronage appointments made by the Governor. Mr. Cuomo controls 3,831 jobs, his press office said, though Mr. Pataki said the figure was much higher.
"We have a system that has become insulated from the will of the people," Mr. Pataki said in announcing his proposals at his Manhattan campaign headquarters.
Mr. Pataki said he was confident that he could persuade New York's lawmakers to accept term limits. But of the 17 states that have term limits for state or Federal officials, only in Utah did state legislators impose limits on themselves, said Tommy Neal, a policy specialist for the National Conference of State Legislatures. In the other 16 states, term limits were approved by voters in referendums.
While Mr. Pataki's aides said term limits could be imposed by the Legislature itself, Mr. Cuomo said it would require a constitutional amendment, which would first have to be passed by two consecutive Legislatures and then approved by voters.
Mr. Cuomo has opposed term limits on the grounds that they can prevent the best candidate from serving. But he has also said that he might endorse term limits if the Legislature does not approve campaign spending limits and other measures.
Though he has not endorsed full initiative and referendum, Mr. Cuomo has proposed legislation that would enable citizens to force the Legislature to vote on existing bills that have been bottled up in committee. And he has long advocated having term limits, initiative and referendum and other ideas debated at a constitutional convention.
In Manhattan yesterday, Mr. Cuomo accused Republican lawmakers, including Mr. Pataki, of blocking his proposals on government ethics and campaign spending.

HEADLINE: Stocks Gain Ground, With Dow Up 15.47

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In the second consecutive day of advancing prices, the stock market yesterday gained back about three-quarters of the ground it lost when it received a clear and unambiguous signal of wholesale inflation on Friday.
Since then, the inflation data have returned to being unclear and ambiguous to the market, with the Consumer Price Index appearing mild on Tuesday and the Federal Reserve's "beige book" report yesterday showing a slowing economy. The specter of the Fed again raising interest rates has receded somewhat, although many economists say that the inflationary pressures seen in the producer price report on Friday have not yet worked their way to the consumer level. 
 So stock prices have moved higher in active trading, and the sideways market of the summer, in which prices oscillate within a wide range, seems to have returned.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 15.47 points, to 3,895.33, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 1.28 points, to 468.80. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 2.78 points, to 768.61.
The Dow so far has made up about 35 points of the 48-point drop on Friday and Monday.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 298.5 million shares changing hands, about 4 percent above this year's average of 286 million shares. In five of the last six sessions, the trading volume has been at or near 300 million shares, perhaps signaling a return to active trading by professional investors who had spent much of the summer on the sidelines.
But bond prices, which rose for the day, may have also affected stock prices to some extent for nearly four hours. A power blackout at the Chicago Board of Trade, the Midwestern hub for fixed-income trading, led to a de facto national trading halt in bonds because traders could not call up prices on their computer screens. Stock traders often take their cue from the bond market.
Whether the Chicago problem, attributed to a power-related computer problem, helped or hurt stocks was not completely clear yesterday. But a surge of bond buying when Chicago trading resumed probably helped to lift stock prices, which had been drifting upward during the bond halt.
In addition, financial instruments for agricultural commodities are traded in Chicago and both stock and bond traders scrutinize such prices for clues to inflation.
For example, the Commodity Research Bureau futures price index yesterday was flat for much of the day because price components like wheat and soybean meal were knocked out in Chicago. For the day, the C.R.B. index of 21 commodities closed down 2.14 points, to 230.39, but the number was probably invalid because platinum prices were still unavailable at the end of the day.
The most notable stocks yesterday were General Electric and Walt Disney. Walt Disney is in discussions to buy General Electric's NBC television network for as much as $5 billion, according to several executives close to the negotiations. Disney's stock fell 1 point, to 41 3/8, and shares of General Electric rose 3/4, to 50 1/4..
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.64 point, to 258.48, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks, 1,108 to 1,058. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.52 point, to 457.33.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 20 stocks rose, led by Caterpillar, which rose 1 1/2, to 55 1/8, after its announcement of sharply higher heavy-equipment exports to Mexico.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Weaker vs. Mark But Gains Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in thin, volatile trading yesterday.
The dollar briefly hit a two-year low against the Swiss franc, which also strengthened broadly against leading European currencies as investors pulled out of German marks ahead of federal elections on Oct. 16, analysts said. Many currency dealers consider the Swiss franc and the mark to be the so-called safe-haven currencies. In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.2810 Swiss francs, from 1.2855 on Tuesday. The dollar was also weaker against the mark, falling to 1.5415 marks, from 1.5435 marks on Tuesday. 
 With a dearth of significant news or economic data to guide the market, currency dealers focused on technical factors. Unconfirmed reports of intervention by the Bank of Japan and other central banks prompted traders betting on a lower dollar to buy dollars, said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Paine Webber Inc. "A nervous market was overextended and forced to cover," he said.
A report that foreign semiconductor makers' share of the Japanese market rose to a record 21.9 percent in the second quarter helped limit pressure to sell dollars for yen, Mr. Flanagan said. So did optimism for a trade agreement between Washington and Tokyo.
Recent signs of progress in trade talks between the United States and Japan, he said, "is keeping the market hopeful that something will be accomplished and the dollar will trade higher."
In New York trading, the dollar rose to 99.21 yen yesterday from 98.85 yen on Tuesday.
Currency traders largely shrugged off a Government report that retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, a number that was in line with expectations and had little impact on the inflation-sensitive bond market.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Is Brisk

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
After a brief respite, shoppers flocked to stores and showrooms again in August and spent freely for a surprisingly broad range of back-to-school and other consumer goods, Commerce Department figures showed today.
Retail sales, which account for about one-third of the economy, jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $186.56 billion for the month, solidifying expectations that personal spending in the July-September quarter will more than double its second-quarter growth pace of 1.4 percent. That could mean the overall economy may not be slowing as much as the Federal Reserve would like. 
 "The impressive thing is that it was across the board," said L. Douglas Lee, chief economist at NatWest Markets, a Washington investment firm. It is no longer quite as clear as earlier in the summer, he added, that the consumer is throttling back.
Although the retail sales increase in August was well within the range of expectations, the composition was somewhat different in a way some analysts found a bit unsettling. Spending at automotive dealers, though posting a robust 1.2 percent gain, was not as high as predicted, while spending on nondurable goods like groceries and clothing exceeded expectations. Nondurable goods account for about 61 percent of the total, while durable goods make up the remaining 39 percent.
Automotive sales might have been held back because of temporary shortages associated with summer production shutdowns, analysts said. And unlike durable goods, which have traced a saw-toothed pattern since spring, nondurables have now climbed four consecutive months, with July's gain revised upward today.
"There are signs of strength in all major segments except for restaurants," including a 2 percent jump in spending last month at apparel and specialty stores, observed Daniel Seto, economist at Nikko Securities in New York.
Despite the retail vigor, most analysts held to the belief that the Federal Reserve would wait until its November policy meeting, after Election Day, to move short-term interest rates up another notch in its effort to help the economy glide back to a growth rate of about 2.5 percent. During the first half of the year, growth averaged just over 3.5 percent, widely seen as unsustainable without rekindling inflation.
A minority, however, is reassessing this assumption.
"The economy is picking up speed as it rides a tail wind," Brian S. Wesbury, chief economist at Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson in Chicago, said today after digesting this week's inflation and sales figures. He put the odds of a Fed tightening before mid-November at 50 percent, up from from 10 to 20 percent previously.
In a separate assessment of economic conditions, the Federal Reserve found activity expanding through the summer in most of its districts, with lagging areas "doing better" and the stronger areas now in a "growth plateau."
The central bank's so-called beige book, prepared for the Sept. 27 policy session, described consumer spending as "healthy, albeit decelerating," and merchants' expectations for holiday sales "generally favorable."
The survey, published today, was based on responses before Sept. 6 to Fed inquiries.
The Commerce Department's tally of retail sales, which is adjusted for seasonal and holiday variations but not for price changes, showed sales of durable goods up 1.3 percent in August after falling six-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes rang up a 2.2 percent increase, while those selling furniture and other equipment for the home took in 1.7 percent more revenue than in July.
Among nondurables, which posted an overall gain of four-tenths of 1 percent, the 2 percent jump for apparel was by far the largest. But sales also rose 1 percent at gasoline service stations (aided by price increases), four-tenths of 1 percent at stores selling general merchandise, three-tenths of 1 percent at drug and proprietary stores and two-tenths of 1 percent at food stores.
For restaurants and bars, a nine-tenths of 1 percent drop followed a very strong 1.5 percent burst in July when the World Cup soccer tournament was being played.
"This is quite a good report," said Steven H. Katz, a researcher at Sanford C. Bernstein in New York.
Over the June through August period, retail sales were 7.1 percent above the comparable 1993 period, the Commerce Department also reported.
Without seasonal adjustment, sales jumped last month by 3.8 percent, to $193.02 billion from $186.04 billion.

HEADLINE: Japanese Taking to Wide-Screen TV

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 8

 BODY:
With its once vaunted high-definition television set meeting disappointing acceptance from consumers, Japan has begun moving toward another new system that promises to make home viewing more like going to the movies.
Japanese consumers have been flocking in recent months to buy television sets with wider screens than the conventional boxy ones, heralding what could be a permanent shift in shape of television pictures here and eventually worldwide. 
 Sales of wide-screen televisions in Japan are expected to soar to between 1 million and 1.5 million units this year, from 300,000 sets last year and 44,000 in 1992, the first year of sale. This means that wide-screen units could account for at least one of every eight television sets bought by Japanese this year.
The sales could receive an even bigger lift next year when television stations here begin broadcasting for a wide format. And sales of the new sets are under way in the United States, Europe and Asia.
The screen shape matches that of movie frames, so that films can be shown without clipping off the edges, as happens on conventional TV screens. Proponents say the wider picture fills the field of vision more completely, giving the viewer a sense of being on the sidelines of a sporting event.
"It's more natural" for human eyes to view a wide scene, said Tadao Kubodera, general manager of the Japan TV department for the Sony Corporation.
The new sets are best when used with wide-format broadcasts or videocassettes. They can also handle conventional broadcasts or tapes by stretching the picture across the screen, distorting it a bit.
Yoichi Morishita, the president of Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, predicted that wide-screen television sets would eventually become commonplace in the home. Executives of the Sanyo Electric Company forecast that 15 percent of Japanese homes would have wide-screen television sets by the end of this year, with penetration rising to 80 percent by the year 2000.
The prices for wide-screen sets here range from about $600 for a small, basic model to $4,000 for a large, deluxe model, while high-definition sets still cost over $6,000. With an adapter, wide-screen sets can receive high-definition broadcasts, but with only normal resolution.
The boom in "wy-doh terebi," as wide-screen television is called here, has cheered Japan's consumer electronics companies, which have been suffering from an economic slump, maturing markets and a dearth of popular new products.
Mr. Morishita and other executives said that wide-screen television would not be the blockbuster that alone could rescue the electronics industry. It is an improvement on existing television sets, but not a new product as the videocassette recorder was. But wide-screen television is one of several potentially profitable new products, along with the mini-disk audio system and the car navigation system.
The spreading popularity of wide-screen television could hammer another nail in the coffin of Japan's high-definition television, which has failed to catch on because of high prices and a shortage of programming. Many industry experts feel that Japan's HDTV system also faces a limited future technologically because it uses an older analog transmission system, rather than the computer-like digital technology being developed in the United States.
High-definition television offers both a wider picture than existing sets and an image that is twice as sharp. But the popularity of wide-screen television suggests that consumers might be satisfied with the wider picture alone and unwilling to pay more for higher resolution.
"That's a very big problem," said Masayuki Uematsu, a manager in video product development for Hitachi Ltd.
Other industry executives argue that wide-screen television will only whet the appetite of consumers for the high-definition format. "Eventually, HDTV sales will surpass wide television," said Shoji Inatsugu, business group executive in charge of television for Matsushita, best known for its Panasonic brand.
That, he conceded, will take a long time. Last year, only 10,000 HDTV sets were sold in Japan, compared with 8 million or more conventional sets. A total of 130,000 high-definition sets have been sold since high-definition broadcasting began in the late 1980's. Matsushita itself has sold 8,400 high-definition sets and 150,000 wide-screen ones.
In the United States, wide-screen television sets are available from two European manufacturers, Thomson Consumer Electronics and Philips N.V. In May, the Sharp Corporation became the first Japanese company to sell such sets in the United States, offering a 34-inch model with a list price of $4,000, about twice the price of a regular 35-inch set. Some other Japanese companies sell wide-screen projection television sets.
But only about 5,000 high-definition sets of all makes have been sold in the United States so far this year, Jon Lezon, product marketing manager for television sets at Sharp Electronics in Mahwah, N.J., estimated. "The software is just not there," Mr. Lezon said.
One reason wide-screen television has not caught on in the United States is that projection television, even without a wide screen, has fulfilled the need for cinema-like viewing at home. Projection television has not been as popular in Japan, where homes are smaller.
Another problem in the United States, Mr. Lezon of Sharp said, is that only about 100 pre-recorded videotape titles and 800 laser disk titles have been made for wide-screen television, far fewer than in Japan. Only DirecTV, a California-based direct broadcast satellite service of Hughes Electronics, offers wide-format television programming to American viewers.
Sony, which has introduced a video camera in the wide format, is also promoting wide-screen television for playing video games. The wide screens stretch the video image so the game characters cover more ground and seem to move faster across the screen.
The ratio of the width to the length of the wide screens is 16 to 9, a third wider than the 4-to-3 aspect ratio of conventional television sets.
When the wide-television sets are used to watch conventional broadcasts or videos, the picture expands to fill the wider screen. Like a picture drawn on a rubber band, everything in it becomes a little fatter.
Another method leaves the center of the image alone so it is free of distortion and stretches out the edges, creating more severe distortion at the sides. This might work best for shows like newscasts, where the viewer's attention is concentrated on the mid-screen.
Yet another method is to expand the 4-by-3 picture until the picture fills up the screen horizontally. This avoids distortion but means losing the top or bottom of the original picture. Sony's television set squeezes the top and bottom of the picture to avoid cropping it.
Next year Japanese television stations will begin broadcasts designed for wide-screen televisions. The system, known as EDTV-2 or enhanced definition television, will provide better quality pictures than conventional television, although not so good as high-definition television..
EDTV-2 is compatible with the existing television system, but wide-screen television sets now sold in Japan require a special decoder to receive the higher picture quality.
Such enhanced definition television, an intermediate step toward high-definition television, is also being developed in Europe. But American engineers are going directly to digital high-definition television.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: Japanese consumers have flocked to buy wide-screen television sets, which could account for one in eight sets sold in Japan this year. A store in Tokyo's Akihabara district displayed some wide-screen sets this week. (Kaku Kurita for The New York Times) (pg. D1)

 Manufacturers have developed several options for showing the images designed to be seen on conventional sets. Diagrams provide briefings on four such options. (pg. D3)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: THE CONGRESS;
Senate Ponders Antitrust Legislation

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
With the remainder of the baseball season canceled, two Senators are still hoping to pass a floor amendment, tacked on to other legislation, that would remove part of baseball's antitrust exemption should the club owners decide to unilaterally impose new labor conditions.
If the amendment is passed, Donald Fehr, the baseball union leader, has indicated to Senator Howard Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, that he would recommend that players end the strike, Metzenbaum said. The floor amendment is co-sponsored by Metzenbaum and Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah. 
 Despite the cancellation of the season, Metzenbaum said if the amendment was passed early next week, he thought there still might be baseball played this season. "Maybe that's wishful thinking on my part, I don't know if it's probable," Metzenbaum said. "The owners are very proud of themselves for having shut down the season. It indicates their power, but not their good judgment."
The Senate Judiciary Committee voted down a bill in June that would have brought baseball's labor relations under the antitrust law. Among other things, such as control over the movement of franchises, the exemption allows the owners to impose new labor conditions in the event of an impasse in collective bargaining and not be subject to legal challenge that it is anticompetitive.
The Metzenbaum-Hatch amendment is an attempt to focus on that situation and the one that created the strike, the owners' demand for cost certainty by placing a limit on player payrolls. The owners could unilaterally impose a salary cap for next season. Under the amendment, the players could challenge the move in court.
"There is an imbalance between the owners and the players and this amendment would even up the bargaining positions of the two parties," Metzenbaum said. "In the current context, this would allow players to take owners to court and challenge a salary cap as collusion to restrain trade. It should be before the court rather than on the picket line."
Metzenbaum said he was "fairly sure" he would be able to find legislation he could attach the amendment to next week. He also said he thought he had enough support to pass the amendment.
In the House, Judiciary Committee Chairman Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, has scheduled a hearing of the Subcommittee on Economic and Commercial Law on Sept. 22 to discuss the antitrust exemption.
President Clinton said today that although he had not had time to study the issue in detail or to seek advice on it from the Justice Department that if baseball has "just turned into another business in America" then the antitrust exemption was an issue that needed to be examined.
"I don't see how we can avoid a serious examination of it in light of what has happened now to the American people," he said, lamenting the end of what he called "what could have been the best baseball season in 50 years."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: THE IMPACT;
A Cash Cow Transforms Itself Into a Dead Horse

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Baseball's labor mess is a case study in dreadful marketing. The 34-day-old players' strike, compounded yesterday by the cancellation of the remainder of the season, has transformed a monthlong blunder into a disaster.
"I'd give it Hall of Fame status for bad decisions," said Jack Trout, a marketing strategist with the Trout & Ries firm in Greenwich, Conn. "It's a classic. Up there with New Coke and Edsel." 
 The losses transcend the owners' losing revenues of about $442 million for a season that will end 52 days and 669 games early, or players losing $229 million in salaries. Or the revenues and pay from playoff and World Series play.
It goes beyond the 30 layoffs of Mets ticket and clubhouse staff, similar layoffs by the Yankees and early joblessness for thousands of ushers, ticket takers, security workers and vendors at both Shea and Yankee stadiums.
"The strike creates a real feeling of helplessness," said Leigh Steinberg, a player agent.
The impact will be felt in the tarnished image of major league baseball, which will lose further ground to more stable, better marketed sports such as football, basketball and hockey. "Baseball will never get some of its advertisers back," said Marty Blackman, an advertising and marketing consultant. "They'll find other places to put their money."
The impact will be felt by local and network TV, manufacturers of athletic merchandise, retailers, cities, charities and baseball card makers.
"I'd say it's hurt us by $7 million to $10 million in post-season business" said Tom Shine, the president of Logo 7, the Indianapolis-based athletic apparel maker. "Baseball will lose its share in the marketplace. Baseball has become the weak link in the chain of sports."
A person familiar with business at Major League Baseball Properties said its licensed product sales are down 23 percent because of the strike and the lack of leadership atop the properties division, which has been without a president since last winter. Many retailers have stopped accepting shipments of licensed baseball goods and won't accept other sports' merchandise until manufacturers take baseball goods back. Spring orders are in jeopardy.
"Retailers are feeling that baseball is tough to sell," said Marianne Bhonslay, editor of Team Leader, a trade magazine. "They're putting money into other sports that support their product better than baseball does."
Ian Gomar, vice president of marketing for New Haven, Conn.-based Starter, the headwear and outerwear manufacturer, said: "Look at all my concession business. It's gone. People aren't going to the ball parks."
Gerry Cosby's, the sporting goods store at Madison Square Garden, figured players would strike and heavily reduced its baseball inventory. "We believed apathy had set in and with the strike on the front burner, we cut our stock 50 percent," said Jim Root, a vice president. "We're lucky. We could have been dying if they'd settled early."
The financial noose is tightening at The Baseball Network, the joint venture of baseball, NBC and ABC. It will lose about $24 million from unplayed regular-season games, perhaps $30 million from strong prime-time advertising spending for September and October, and another $100 million from the scrubbing of the playoffs and World Series. "Opportunities for money have passed us by," said Mike Trager, TBN's executive vice president.
The end of 1994 baseball means TBN will have logged sales of $30 million and needs $300 million next year to meet its two-year renewal target.
TBN had lured numerous sponsors, ranging from Anheuser-Busch to Gillette.
"If there's no baseball," said Eric Kraus, a Gillette spokesman, "we'll evaluate the viability of The Baseball Network. We advertised with them anticipating baseball." A Gillette promotion with consumers trying to slug homers in playoff and World Series stadiums will be done in an empty ball park.
Steve Disson, president of the D & F Group, a marketing consultant, said, "Companies we've had who've sponsored baseball locally are gun-shy about doing it nationally, like the United States Postal Service."
In local TV, the MSG Network and SportsChannel, the cable homes of the Yankees and the Mets, have not yet toted up their losses. On one side of the ledger, they don't have to pay the rights fees ($300,000 per Yankee game and $150,000 per Mets game). But they've lost ad sales and cable system fees.
Doug Moss, MSG's president, said, "We make money on Yankees games."
In other areas:
*New York City estimates that each Yankees and Mets home game generates about $2 million in economic impact. Losing 26 Mets' and 24 Yankees' games would reduce the impact by about $100 million, from ticket sales, concessions, hotels, restaurants, taxis, parking, luxury boxes and subway fares. According to a survey of 22 teams by the United States Conference of Mayors, an average $1.16 million in economic activity is lost per game, and an average of 1,250 full- and part-time workers have been idled by the strike.
*Baseball card sales will probably suffer, starting with update sets that would have been released about now. "My feeling is the update market is dead," said Tom Mortensen, editor of Sports Collectors Digest.
*Charitable contributions based on player performance will be hurt. Although Matt Williams of the San Francisco Giants will still make contributions to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, "charities lose the benefit of fans inspired by players to contribute money," said Steinberg, Williams's agent.
*Baseballs made by Rawlings -- 96 per game, or 64,224 for each of the regular-season games missed -- will not be used, said Scott Smith, a company spokesman. "Those balls are sold but maybe we'll have that many fewer orders for next season," he said. World Series balls, which are sold in the two cities, will languish in Rawlings's warehouse.
*About one-quarter of the 80,000 bats that Hillerich-Bradsby manufactures for major league players have not been shipped. "Orders for next year's bats usually come in as early as November and December," said Bill Williams, the batmaker's spokesman. "If this thing's not settled, will the equipment managers be calling us with orders?"

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Biggest Loss For Baseball: Do You Care?

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

 BODY:
EVEN before the baseball season was proclaimed dull and void by Bud Selig yesterday, some people's reaction had been clear.
"I don't care," you heard more and more people saying. 
 Of all the sad words about the absence of a World Series this year, the most painful are "I don't care," because those same people had once cared about baseball.
Cared if their team won or lost. Cared if it were in first place or in last place. Cared when it signed a free agent. Cared when it made a trade. Cared when a hot rookie suddenly arrived. Cared when it changed managers.
But many of those same people no longer seem to care. Or say they don't. And that's baseball's biggest loss.
When the ballplayers go back to work, whenever that is, many of those same people suddenly will care again. But maybe not as much as they once did. And some might never care again.
It's like lovers who quarrel. After too many of those quarrels, maybe you decide not see each other anymore.
It's the same for all those people saying, "I don't care." Especially if there's no World Series to watch.
Until now they could depend on the World Series always being there. To them, the Fall Classic has been a weeklong religious experience in October even if their favorite team wasn't in it.
But if a labor dispute can delete one World Series, future disputes could delete two or three more.
Maybe the Yankees would have won this year's World Series on a Don Mattingly home run, but now you'll never know.
All those people who are saying, "I don't care" really mean they don't trust baseball anymore.
Trust it to be there when it's supposed to be.
Trust it for what it promotes itself as: "The National Pastime."
Trust it to punctuate its season with the usual World Series exclamation point.
Maybe the Montreal Expos would have kept the World Series trophy in Canada, but now you'll never know.
By undermining the public's trust in a World Series, the 28 major league club owners have also undermined their antitrust exemption.
Several Congressional voices are shouting, rightfully, that baseball no longer deserves the antitrust exemption that has prevented litigation by the players' union.
Baseball was granted its exemption in 1922 by the United States Supreme Court. But in 1972, when the Supreme Court rejected Curt Flood's bid for free agency, Justice Harry Blackmun described the exemption as an "anomaly," an "aberration" and suggested that "it be remedied by Congress," not by the Supreme Court.
Now that the remainder of the season and the entire post-season has been canceled, the club owners are expected to impose their last contract offer as baseball's new economic system, like it or not. But if the owners' antitrust exemption is revoked, the union could take the owners' system to court.
Maybe the Atlanta Braves finally would have won the World Series after three years of frustration, but now you'll never know.
Dreamers talk of organizing a Third League, of suddenly signing free agents for the 1995 season. Yes, some players would be available. But with the current teams owning or leasing all the major league stadiums, where would the Third League teams play? It's not as if other acceptable stadiums are out there waiting for new tenants.
Maybe the Cleveland Indians would have emerged as the first wild-card World Series champion, but now you'll never know.
For all those people who profess, "I don't care," there are just as many, if not more, who do care. But they will survive.
Except for the few whose employment is attached to the teams or the stadiums, it's not as if the shutdown of the baseball industry (don't call it a game) directly affects the lives of those who do care.
Those who do care will get through the last two weeks of September without any pennant races. They will get through October without the Fall Classic.
When they do, maybe then they will realize they also don't care anymore.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: An Encouraging Signal From Quebec

 BODY:
The narrowness of the popular vote that has restored the separatist party to power in Quebec is heartening news for North America. Splitting Canada in two would be wrong, but the vote count suggests Quebecers are not ready to do it. For the U.S., and for continental stability, it is a reassuring indication that our northern neighbor -- closest ally, biggest trading partner and best friend -- will continue to be all of those things.
The victory of the separatist Parti Quebecois was expected. The party will have a solid majority in the provincial parliament, but pre-election polls predicted it would be significantly larger. Moreover, the separatists' failure to win 50 percent of the popular vote, and their slim margin over the Liberal candidates -- less than one-half of 1 percent -- say voters are less than enthusiastic about their new government's aim to create a sovereign nation. Indeed, the Liberals' defeat had more to do with high unemployment and low regard for the party after nine years in office. 
 The United States has political, economic and neighborly interests in keeping Canada whole, as well as a desire to avoid the chaotic unknown. As a global superpower, America wants stability on its borders, not neighbors engaged in a testy divorce. Considering also that the U.S. and Canada are each other's and the world's largest trading partners, the value and reliability of this relationship is far preferable to the barriers likely to rise in the wake of a split. Finally, long-term friendship says that if the great majority of Canadians prefer unity, which they do, the United States should support them.
Canada has been through several Quebec crises already and, alas, this one may not be the last. Jacques Parizeau, the Parti Quebecois leader, promises a referendum on sovereignty next year. But even if the majority vote to stay in Canada, as they have before, the cultural split between English Canada and the French in Quebec will not fade away. It is part of Canada -- a humane, multicultural society, albeit sometimes quarrelsome.
Meanwhile, one way or another, Mr. Parizeau promises to stir up trouble with the Federal Government in Ottawa. On matters where provincial cooperation is called for, such as social reforms, he says Quebec will refuse to participate. On local matters, he has ideas for public projects to cut unemployment and prove that his government is better than Ottawa's.
On sovereignty, the party has laid out three steps: an immediate parliamentary resolution saying Quebec should split, even before a referendum to determine the popular will; preparation of a new constitution, a huge task itself, and negotiations with Ottawa on arrangements for separation, which Ottawa would surely reject before a referendum and would fight if the referendum carried.
All three steps looked less certain the morning after the election, but this battle is far from over. In power, the Parti Quebecois may yet convince the majority of Quebecers they would be better off as a nation apart. That would be unfortunate for all concerned, including their neighbor to the south.

HEADLINE: Zoning, Sex and Videotape

 BODY:
With his stringent proposals to curb New York City's sex-oriented adult entertainment business, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is operating on his campaign pledge to improve the quality of life in city neighborhoods.
His plan to regulate the location and concentration of adult video stores, topless bars and other such establishments is a response to legitimate community anger. That anger has grown as these businesses have spread into residential areas from Rego Park in Queens to Manhattan's Upper East Side, provoking realistic concerns about neighborhood ambiance, property values and crime. 
 Mr. Giuliani's basic approach of using the city's zoning authority to control the number and locations of these shops is sound. Indeed, his multi-faceted plan incorporates several strategies that have worked and won court approval elsewhere. Yet the Mayor's proposal for exiling the bars and shops to a few isolated industrial districts may go too far in limiting legal businesses that cater to a varied clientele and are also forms of free expression, with claims to First Amendment protection.
The city's present zoning laws treat adult businesses like any other businesses, allowing them to open in areas zoned for commercial or manufacturing uses. But both the New York City Planning Commission and the Times Square Business Improvement District, of which this newspaper is a member, cite evidence that such establishments can discourage economic growth, lower property values and exacerbate crime.
In a variety of rulings, courts at several levels have permitted municipalities to impose limitations through zoning upon proof of such harmful economic and public safety effects. However, there is an important caveat: The zoning rules must not unreasonably restrict accessibility. Also, courts have long held that sexually explicit videos, books and dancing are forms of constitutionally protected free speech, and zoning laws must be carefully drawn.
Like similar legislative proposals in the City Council, Mr. Giuliani's plan would bar adult businesses from opening in a residential area. But the Mayor takes a much stricter tack by including in his total ban not just purely residential districts but also "mixed-use" areas that are zoned for both commercial and residential use.
In effect, sex-oriented businesses would be banned from even heavily commercial areas and be pushed to the city's industrial fringes. Even there, such establishments would be prohibited from opening within 500 feet of residences, schools, houses of worship or one another -- a sensible dispersal strategy to avoid turning the city's industrial sections into unappealing "combat zones."
Some details remain fuzzy. It is unclear precisely how the Mayor would phase out existing adult stores and theaters in newly restricted areas once an owner has recouped his or her investment. Such matters remain to be clarified during the upcoming land-use review process. Meanwhile, the City Planning Commission understandably seeks a one-year moratorium on new adult establishments.
Translating Mr. Giuliani's policy into zoning changes will not be easy. The last serious effort to limit adult entertainment in New York City, in 1977, died largely because of objections from the neighborhoods where sex-oriented businesses would still be allowed. Right now there is strong support for the Mayor's initiative in the City Council, which must approve the final zoning plan. But that support could erode if, to make the plan constitutionally safer, it is revised to allow sex-oriented businesses in mixed-use areas. One compromise might be to permit them only if spaced, say, 1,000 feet, or about five blocks, apart to avoid a harmful concentration.
Mr. Giuliani's initiative now challenges the Planning Commission to devise zoning that is fair to free expression and considerate of the public.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Showdown Ahead

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After the President has addressed the nation about his need to make good on his stream of threats to the Haitian junta; after partisans in Congress do their mutual somersaults on the War Powers Act; after we hail a victory over a pipsqueak principality in a war of nerves or forces -- then a real foreign-policy crisis will have to be faced.
The Bosnian clock now stands at one month to midnight. Being put to the test is the credibility of NATO and the strength of the new relationship between the U.S. and Russia. 
 Much good diplomatic work has been done. The U.S. brokered the renewal of the alliance between Bosnia's Muslims and Croats to strike a balance of power and a division of territory with the Bosnian Serbs. After a shaky start, the marriage is solidifying, which shores up the victims of Serbian aggression.
Meanwhile, the economic squeeze put on Belgrade has had the desired effect of splitting the Serbs. Belgrade is now willing to accept monitors to watch Serbia cut off aid to its rogue compatriots in Bosnia, in return for a U.N. lifting of sanctions against Serbia. That isolates the local aggressors.
The only trouble: It's not working. The Bos-Serbs refuse to accept the peace deal that the U.N. persuaded their victims to swallow. They snipe at civilians, murder U.N. soldiers and threaten to shoot down the Pope's plane if he visits besieged Sarajevo. Their goal is never to compromise but to conquer and "cleanse."
Thus has the world learned that the way to make peace with the Bos-serbs is to put guns to their heads. But the U.N. has embargoed the sale of guns to Bosnians. That leaves the well-armed aggressors with the firepower advantage.
President Clinton has been unable to persuade the British and French, who have peacekeeping troops in Bosnia, to lift the embargo and even up the power balance. They prefer to dither than to hunker down or get out; in effect, they are "protecting" the Muslims out of their country.
Clinton's impotence with our allies led the Senate to propose -- and the President to embrace in an Aug. 10 letter to Sam Nunn -- an ultimatum with a deadline. "If the Bosnian Serbs have not accepted the contact group's proposal of July 6, 1994 . . . by October 15, 1994," reads the Senate's amendment to the defense appropriation bill, not yet voted on by the House, "the President . . . should formally introduce and support a resolution in the U.N. Security Council . . . to terminate the international arms embargo. . . ."
If that U.S. proposal is vetoed, says the Senate, the President should submit a plan to lift the embargo by ourselves; Clinton's letter would not go beyond pledging to seek a vote on "multilateral termination" of the embargo.
The clock has been ticking. On Sept. 28, Boris Yeltsin arrives for his fifth Clinton summit. That meeting's success depends on Clinton's ability to persuade the Russian President to support the U.S. resolution to arm the Bosnian defenders.
The two have worked well together before: Clinton helped Yeltsin make a deal with Ukraine to give up its nukes, and the Russian kept his word to pull troops out of the Baltics. Moscow has been helpful with Belgrade; now comes the crunch.
A New York Times editorial suggests linking the lifting of economic sanctions on Belgrade to the lifting of the arms embargo on Bosnia. Good idea; that would enable the Russians to go along, and put the issue to Britain's John Major and France's Eduard Balladur: Who wants to veto the U.S. resolution?
Such a veto would split the Atlantic Alliance, invite a radical drawdown of U.S. troops in Europe and undermine what would be left of NATO after its failure in Bosnia.
That would be an isolationist's dream, brought about by the intransigence of the Bos-Serbs compounded by the shortsightedness of Major and Balladur. But the British and French are not so foolish; they'll vote with us and withdraw their peacekeepers, selling the Bosnians their on-site equipment.
If Clinton is steadfast -- rejecting the defeatist counsel of General Shilly-shally and the C.I.A. -- he can bring along the allies and level the field of fire in Bosnia. Success in such high-stakes diplomacy would be remembered long after the brouhaha in Haiti is forgotten.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CUNY's Open Admissions Fail Miserably;
Setting Priorities

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Two and a half cheers for "The Trashing of CUNY" (Op-Ed, Sept. 8) by Blanche Wiesen Cook and Sandi E. Cooper, their eloquent reply to Heather Mac Donald's misguided attack in the City Journal. 
 My only reservation is the contentions about "Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds's reorganization plan," the academic program planning begun two years ago to improve the link between resources and student needs and to insure quality in a difficult fiscal climate.
The goal was never to impose a single profile of academic programs on CUNY or to reorganize the system of colleges, but to stimulate campus-level planning and priority-setting when city and state resources were severely curtailed and enrollment was soaring.
Some colleges received additional resources in professional and career fields like physical therapy and nursing, for which employer and student demand far exceeded the university's capacity to supply trained graduates. But that expansion did not occur at the expense of the liberal arts and sciences, which remain central to all higher education at CUNY.
As a result, CUNY hired 59 full-time faculty members from redeployed resources in 1993-94. Forty of those were in the liberal arts and sciences, including philosophy, history, Spanish, English, economics and sociology at City College; and biology, chemistry, mathematics and physics at Bronx Community College. Academic program planning continues to strengthen the mix of higher learning CUNY has offered New Yorkers for the last century and a half.
 
RICHARD M. FREELAND
Vice Chancellor, Academic Affairs
City University of New York
New York, Sept. 8, 1994

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Climb; 'Beige Book' Stirs Hope

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were slightly higher yesterday after two economic reports met the market's expectations.
Trading was slowed by a computer glitch at the Chicago Board of Trade, where trading in bonds futures contracts was halted for nearly four hours. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 1/16 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 7.67 percent, from 7.68 percent on Tuesday.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that retail sales surged eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $186.56 billion for August. Despite the strong showing, analysts still see little reason for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates before its November policy meeting.
A report by the Fed, its so-called beige book survey of economic conditions, said that competition among companies was keeping retail price increases subdued as the economy slowly expanded.
"There's reason for optimism that inflation is not going to accelerate dramatically," said Steven Nothern, who manages $3.5 billion at Massachusetts Financial Services. Even so, "the inflation process is starting to move in fits and starts through the pipeline," he said.
Fed policy makers will consider the beige book report in deciding whether to push interest rates higher at their Sept. 27 meeting. The report suggests the Fed will not raise rates again until November, said Michael Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International (America).
"We have seen a cyclical change in inflation," Mr. Strauss said. "Is it dramatic? No."
The Government reported on Tuesday that consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, matching increases in June and July. Inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index was at a 2.9 percent annual rate through August, up from 2.8 percent for the first eight months of last year and 2.7 percent for all of last year.
In its survey, the Fed said wage inflation was possible amid "more reports of tightening labor markets than before, though wage pressures are still described as modest."
Today, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia is scheduled to report on prices paid by 150 manufacturers in Pennsylvania, Delaware and southern New Jersey. Bonds tumbled after last month's Philadelphia Fed report, which said the bank's prices-paid index surged to a five-year high.
In the corporate bond market, seven businesses sold a total of $1.78 billion in bonds yesterday.
The Nissan Motor Company sold $642 million in bonds. First National Bank of Boston, a unit of the New England bank holding company the Bank of Boston Corporation, sold $200 million of 10-year notes. Bear Stearns Companies sold $200 million of five-year notes.
Other sales included a $175 million offering by the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Government-owned utility, and an $80 million sale by the Michigan Gas Corporation. TCI Communications Inc., a unit of Tele-Communications Inc., sold $300 million of 10-year debt. Chevy Chase Savings Bank sold $181.9 million of floating-rate securities backed by home equity loans, according to MCM Corporate Watch.
Bonds backed by mortgages of the Government National Mortgage Association, or Ginnie Mae, led mortgage-backed securities higher, following news of programs that will make the securities easier to trade.
Ginnie Mae 8 percent pass- throughs for October delivery rose as much as 1/4, to 985/32 , to yield 8.41 percent, three basis points less than yesterday. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Ginnie Mae and the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, said yesterday that they would begin bundling mortgage-backed bonds for investors.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 16, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday, with an article about the credit markets, included incorrect figures supplied by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, for the average weekly yields on participation certificates. The yield for the 15-year certificate is 7.83 percent, not 8.18 percent, and the yield for the 30-year certificate is 8.31 percent, not 8.66 percent.
