SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 416 words

HEADLINE: The Mystery of Flight 427

 BODY:
The remarkable safety record of America's airlines is marred once again by the horror of U.S. Air Flight 427's plunge into the woods near Pittsburgh last week, killing all 132 passengers and crew. It was the most devastating toll for any U.S. carrier in seven years, and its cause is still a mystery. The chief of the Federal investigators on the scene offers the most sensible comment so far: Don't jump to conclusions about what went wrong.
It was U.S. Air's fifth fatal crash in as many years -- none similar to the others -- and its second in just three months. Given the airline's string of financial losses, there has been speculation it might have cut back on aircraft maintenance. That can happen when an airline is strapped for cash. But a reputation for safety is key to financial recovery, and U.S. Air insists there have been no cutbacks. Moreover, the Federal Aviation Administration stepped up its surveillance of U.S. Air operations after the earlier crashes, and has pronounced those operations satisfactory. 
 While U.S. Air's losses have been heavy -- close to $2 billion since 1988 -- the recession has hurt the whole industry. Still, air safety has continued to improve. The National Transportation Safety Board counted 31 fatalities among major U.S. airlines' passengers in 1992, or .0006 deaths for every million miles in the air.
One scholarly study of the causes of air crashes found no clear correlation in modern aviation between crashes and the financial health of the airline involved. Commonly, there is no single cause of a crash but a combination of factors. Whatever caused the U.S. Air jet, a Boeing 737-300, to lurch into a nosedive on its approach to Pittsburgh International Airport is the proper concern of the safety board's investigators.
Armchair analysts are aware of the "black boxes" that record flight data, but perhaps not aware that the boxes themselves have been improved. Those aboard U.S. Air 427 may tell more than the ones in the unexplained crash of another Boeing 737 near Colorado Springs in 1991. In all the thousands of accidents the board has investigated, the Colorado crash is one of only four crashes whose cause has never been determined.
The mystery of U.S. Air 427 may not be solved for months. If its cause can be fixed, it will be. But whatever the cause, there is no new reason to fear flying. The risks do not seem to have changed. There is still more danger on the road to the airport than in the airlanes above.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Crime And Politics

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
In apartheid South Africa, at times when political prisoners were subjected to harsh treatment, they were still allowed to earn university degrees by correspondence.
For the United States Congress in 1994, that idea is too enlightened. One section of the omnibus crime bill just signed by President Clinton forbids the awarding of Pell grants for higher education to anyone in prison. That will just about end the possibility of prisoners, who are mostly poor, earning college credits. 
 Is that provision of the bill a blow against crime? To the contrary. Studies show that prisoners who do college work are less than half as likely as other inmates to commit new crimes after their release.
No, Congress inserted the provision to show the public how "tough" it could be -- how mean, how nasty. The realities of fighting crime had nothing to do with it -- or with many other parts of the crime bill.
Consider what the bill does about mandatory minimum sentences, which prison officials and judges and other experts regard as a distorting and self-defeating trend in our law.
Congress in recent years has fixed minimum sentences for many drug offenses. Judges have lost their right -- their duty -- to consider the particular facts of the crime and the offender. They are required to put many non-violent, first-time drug offenders away for 5 or 10 years.
More than 100,000 new drug offenders are being committed to state and Federal prisons every year. The inevitable result is overcrowding of those prisons. Some states solve the problem by releasing other prisoners -- including those the public rightly fears most, men who committed violent crimes.
The new bill moves to lengthen state prison terms as well. It does so by offering states large sums to build new prisons -- but only if they promise to make serious offenders serve at least 85 percent of their sentenced times. Most states now release prisoners after they serve a far smaller portion of their sentences. To get the Federal money the states will have to make their prisons even more overcrowded.
As the crime bill first came out of a Senate-House conference, it had a provision exempting non-violent drug offenders who cooperated with the prosecution for mandatory sentences -- and applying that exemption to similar offenders already in prison.
A freshman Republican Congressman from Long Island, Rick A. Lazio, demanded elimination of the retroactive clause. To get his vote for letting the bill come to the floor, the Democrats gave way to him. As a result, someone who sold a small amount of crack last year may be in a penitentiary for 10 years while someone newly convicted serves 2 years.
These are small examples of benighted provisions that make this crime bill not just a flawed but a wrong-headed piece of legislation. Others can be briefly indicated.
Representative Susan Molinari, Republican of New York, got into the bill a section allowing Federal prosecutors to disclose at the trial of sex crimes the fact that the defendant was previously charged (not convicted) with a sexual offense, civil or criminal, no matter how long ago. So someone falsely accused -- and that does happen -- would be branded.
Another provision narrows the circumstances in which Federal courts can find that conditions in a prison are cruel and unusual, in violation of the Constitution. Another waters down the present rule against executing people who are so mentally ill that they cannot understand the proceedings against them.
The better-known provisions of the crime bill, such as "three strikes, you're out," have their own flaws. How did such a misbegotten piece of legislation become law?
The answer is simple: politics. Democrats wanted to take the crime issue away from Republicans. Republicans responded by sounding "tougher." The Justice Department did not work effectively against the worst features because President Clinton wanted something -- anything -- labeled "crime bill."
Since 1970 the number of inmates in American prisons has quadrupled. We have now passed South Africa for the title of most prisoners per capita in the world. None of this has had a measurable effect on our shockingly high level of crime. But our Government has decided, as The Economist magazine put it, "to take this failed approach to crime policy and extend it."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: EXXON IS ORDERED TO PAY $5 BILLION FOR ALASKA SPILL

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:
A Federal jury in Anchorage yesterday ordered the Exxon Corporation to pay $5 billion in punitive damages to about 34,000 fishermen and other Alaskans who said they were harmed by the Exxon Valdez oil spill more than five years ago.
The 11-member jury also ordered the former captain of the Exxon Valdez, Joseph J. Hazelwood, to pay $5,000 in punitive damages. Lawyers for Exxon and Mr. Hazelwood said that the punitive damages, which are meant to punish defendants for harmful behavior, were unfair and that they planned appeals. 
 The jury's award, ending a 20-week trial that began in early May, is the largest ever in a pollution case and the second largest in a civil case in the United States. The largest award in a civil suit was the $10.5 billion verdict against the Texaco Corporation in a contract dispute involving Pennzoil in 1985. The case was later settled for $3 billion. The largest civil award ever in an environmental case was the $470 million that Union Carbide paid in a court in India in the poisoning deaths and injuries of thousands of residents of Bhopal, India, in 1984.
After the verdict, Exxon stock, which had dropped during the trial, rose $1.50, to $60.25, within minutes. Analysts said the company could pay the $5 billion award without suffering significant harm; the plaintiffs had asked for $15 billion. Exxon last year reported net earnings of $5.28 billion on revenue of $111.2 billion for all of 1993. [Page 10.]
In the moments after the verdict was announced by Judge H. Russel Holland in Federal District Court in Anchorage, lawyers for the fishermen and other Alaskan plaintiffs said they were elated.
"That is enough money that when it gets distributed among the fishermen and native Alaskans, it will allow them to make a new start on their lives," said Brian O'Neill, a 47-year-old lawyer from Minneapolis who led the plaintiffs' trial team. Depending on the precise number of plaintiffs, which is still unclear, each could receive about $100,000, if the money was evenly divided.
Patrick Lynch, a lawyer from Los Angeles and one of Exxon's lead trial lawyers, said the verdict would fuel debate about the fairness of huge punitive damages.
"I think it's a common experience in the law right now that punitive damage awards by juries are a problem, because it is difficult to give a jury meaningful standards to determine in money what will constitute punishment or deterrence," said Mr. Lynch, noting that Exxon had already spent $3.4 billion cleaning up Prince William Sound in Alaska and taking other measures to respond to the Valdez spill.
The verdict against Exxon and Mr. Hazelwood came after 13 days of deliberation by the jury of eight women and three men in the last of three phases of the civil lawsuit. The trial, which began on May 2, became a test of endurance for everyone involved, especially for the jury.
In the first phase, which ended in June, the jury determined that Exxon and Mr. Hazelwood were reckless, setting up the third phase of the trial, which ended yesterday.
The second phase, to determine compensatory damages, ended in August with the award of $286.8 million to the plaintiffs.
The huge jury award could mean that the 80 law firms working for the plaintiffs could share roughly $1 billion and perhaps more, although the award of legal fees will be decided in part by Judge Holland, said Gerry Nolting, a 39-year-old lawyer from Minneapolis who has worked on the case for over five years. The rest will be shared by some 10,000 fishermen, 4,000 native Alaskans, and perhaps 20,000 other clients.
If the award were divided equally, those plaintiffs would receive roughly $100,000 each. "The actual amount will depend on the total number of plaintiffs, which isn't known yet, and the judge will have to approve all allocations," Mr. Nolting said.
The punitive damages award caps a legal and economic battle that began when one of the world's most modern supertankers ran aground after midnight on March 24, 1989, on Bligh Reef in Prince William Sound, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil. The spill was the largest ever by a tanker in North American waters and killed thousands of otters, birds and other creatures.
Mr. O'Neill said the punitive damages judgment was enough money to indicate to both Exxon's stockholders and its senior executives that changes in the company's way of doing business were warranted.
"We've done half of the work, and that was to uncover what happened in this incident and to expose Exxon for what it is -- uncaring, reckless, and greedy," said Mr. O'Neill. "Now it's up to Exxon shareholders who ought to be saying: 'Why did our company do these things? Why didn't our company tell us they did these things, and why haven't they been frank about telling us about the trouble they were in with this lawsuit? Why did the chairman of the board and the president get bonuses the year of the spill?' There is a whole series of questions that stockholders ought to be asking about the way Exxon treats people."
Exxon said the largest damage award in its history was in 1983, in a case involving overcharging on crude oil sales during a period when a complex formula of Federal price controls was in effect. The award was $1.6 billion, the company said, but Exxon has recovered part of that from other companies that shared an interest in an oil field Exxon managed.
In explaining why he thought the verdict was unfair, Mr. Lynch said: "I think it is common sense that any business that has suffered over a $3 billion payout will do everything in its power to avoid having a similar occurrence. The record of Exxon's diligent effort to avoid anything like this recurring is very strong. Adding a $5 billion award on top of that doesn't serve any of the purposes that punitive damages were intended to serve."
To make the case easier for the jury to understand and consider, Judge Holland had divided the case into three phases. But both sides introduced so much economic, biological and legal information that a computer and video system was installed in Judge Holland's courtroom to help the jury keep track of it. So many television monitors were perched on tables and desks that the courtroom looked like a network news studio.
Mr. O'Neill's primary tactic was to turn the trial of the world's richest energy company into a statement about the behavior of the company's top executives, among them Lawrence G. Rawl, the former chairman, and Frank Iarossi, the former president of Exxon Shipping Company.
In the first phase, the jury sided with Mr. O'Neill and determined that Exxon and Mr. Hazelwood had acted recklessly.
But in the second phase, the jury seemed to accept Exxon's evidence that skimpy supplies of herring and salmon in the region could not be entirely attributed to Exxon. They awarded some 10,000 fishermen $286.8 million in damages, about a third of what Mr. O'Neill had sought.
Just before the jury's decision in the second phase, Exxon and the plaintiffs' lawyers announced that they had settled one part of the case and that Exxon would pay $20 million in compensatory damages to native Alaskans.
In the third phase, the jury was to decide punitive damages not only for fishermen, but also for some 4,000 native Alaskans, and for several thousand more Alaska residents who contended they had been harmed by the spill.
After the verdict, Exxon's chairman, Lee R. Raymond, issued a statement. "It is excessive by any legal or practical measure," he said. "We will use every legal means available to overturn this unjust verdict, which is not a final judgment. It will be reviewed and we trust it will be modified by the trial court or by appellate courts."
Michael G. Chalos, the lawyer for Mr. Hazelwood, said he also was disappointed in the verdict against his client and planned to appeal. He noted that in August, Mr. O'Neill had urged the jury to award only $1 against Mr. Hazelwood.
"Captain Hazelwood is substantially worse off financially and emotionally than he was before the spill," Mr. Chalos said. "The jury should have followed the recommendation of the plaintiffs or our recommendation to award nothing against him simply because he's been punished enough."
Other trials still await the defendants in the oil spill. A fourth phase in the Federal trial before a new jury is scheduled for the fall. It will hear evidence from crab fishermen and other plaintiffs not included in the larger trial who are seeking $300 million in compensatory damages.
In addition, a jury in state court is deciding whether to award compensatory damages to Alaskan native corporations that have contended they lost $120 million because of the oil spill.


GRAPHIC: The Exxon Valdez ran agound on March 24, 1989, spilling 11 million gallons of oil. By May 18, the oil slick had spread 470 miles southwest.
 
Chronology: "For The Record: A Disaster's Trail . . . And Exxon's Repayment"
 
1989-94: Exxon pays $2.1 billion in the cleanup effort, plus and additional $1.3 billion in civil and criminal penalties and settlements of claims filed by 11,000 residents and businesses in the Prince William Sound region.
 
July 1993: Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, of which Exxon is a part owner, agrees to pay fishermen and Alaskans involved in the Federal trial $98 million in damages.
 
June 13: Federal jury finds that Exxon acted recklessly in the Valdez spill. This verdict clears the way for the jury to award punitive damages later in teh summer.
 
July 25: Exxon agrees to pay $20 million in damages to a group of 3,500 villagers who said the oil spill ruined their food supply. These villagers represent about a quarter of the plaintiffs in the Federal trial.
 
Aug. 12: A Federal jury orders Exxon to pay $286.8 million in compensatory damages to more than 10,000 Alaskan fishermen who said they lost hundreds of millions of dollars of income after the spill. This ends the second phase of the Federal trial.
 
Sept. 16: In the thrid phase of the Federal trial, the jury orders Exxon to pay all the plaintiffs - about 34,000 fishermen, natives and others - punitive damages of $5 billion. The former captain of the Valdez, Joseph J. Hazelwood was ordered to pay $5,000.
 
Still to be decided: A jury in Alaska's state courts is considering whether to order Exxon to pay $120 million in damages to Alaska native corporations and municipalities. Finally, in the last phase of the Federal trial, a new jury is expected to decide this fall whether to award $300 million in damages to crab fishermen and other specialized groups who did not fit in any of the larger groupings from earlier phases in the Federal trial. (pg 10)

HEADLINE: With Factories Near Their Limits, Inflation Fears Are Rising Again

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Industrial production and factory operating rates rose sharply in August, the Government reported yesterday, raising the possibility of a new surge of growth in the American economy, and with it higher inflation.
The latest reports, suggesting that the manufacturing sector is operating nearly at full throttle, came despite the Federal Reserve's efforts to keep a lid on economic growth -- and on inflation -- by raising interest rates five times since February. 
 The bond market, where interest rates are set, reacted with fright to the new threat of inflation. Traders quickly pushed the yield on long-term bonds to 7.77 percent, the highest level in more than two years. And stock prices fell. [Page 37.]
For some economists, the August industrial production report signaled that there were pockets of strength in the economy that might keep the pace of growth moving ahead, if not this year then next. These pockets, mainly exports and automobile sales, could raise economic growth to a level that would push the inflation rate steadily higher. It is now less than 3 percent.
"When Europe and Japan are both expanding briskly, as is likely in 1995, then their purchases of American goods and services are likely to make our economy surge," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant.
That view did not go unchallenged, however. "I think this is the last surge of industrial production," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "We have been surveying our members. About half are building up inventories because of strong demand, mostly in autos, and half find themselves stuck with goods they cannot sell."
Cutbacks in production would get rid of the unwanted inventories. But in August, instead of cutbacks, industrial production rose seven-tenths of a percent, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday, and the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 84.7 percent of their capacity, the highest level since August 1989. That was up from 84.3 percent in July and 84.2 percent in June, numbers that were themselves revised upward yesterday.
In the last two weeks, conflicting Government data have been cited as evidence one day that the economy and inflation are on the rise, and evidence the next day that they are not.
The Government reported on Sept. 9, for example, that producer prices had jumped six-tenths of a percent in August, a huge increase that aroused great concern about inflation. That concern subsided on Tuesday, when the Government reported that the Consumer Price Index had risen mildly, by three-tenths of a percent, in August. Then on Wednesday, a Federal Reserve survey of the nation's various regions suggested that economic growth was nearing a plateau and that pressure for higher wages, while rising, was still moderate.
This view prevailed again on Thursday when the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia released its latest survey of manufacturers in the region. The survey showed modest price increases. But the tranquillity was again dispelled with yesterday's reports on industrial production and capacity utilization.
"The bond market has been torn between do we need to worry about inflation or don't we," said Nicholas Sargen, chief investment officer for the Prudential Insurance Company's Global Advisers, a fund that invests heavily in bonds. "The new numbers were higher than anyone had anticipated, so the bond market concluded that we are in for more economic growth and rising inflation."
Whatever the truth, most forecasters expect slower economic growth in the short run, if not next year. The gross domestic product, which measures the nation's total output of goods and services, grew by a robust 4 percent in the 12 months that ended in June. Fifty prominent forecasters estimate, in the latest monthly survey by the Blue Chip Economic Indicators, that the economy is currently growing at an annual rate of only 2.2 percent.
But that growth rate will rise next year to 3 percent or more, Mr. Bernstein and some other economists predict. That much sustained growth is beyond the nation's capacity to expand without more inflation, many economists believe.
Attention focused yesterday on the latest capacity utilization number, which measures how close factories are to operating at full capacity. While Mr. Jasinowski and others insisted that economic growth and industrial production were beginning to slow, many people in the financial markets have long held that when capacity utilization reaches 85 percent, shortages develop and manufacturers and retailers find they can raise prices.
That rising inflation, in turn, erodes the purchasing power of the money that has been invested in bonds and other loans. Just the prospect that this might happen prompts these investors to push up interest rates, so that they earn more and thus recover some of the lost purchasing power.
"There is a threshold in capacity utilization through which you move and kick off inflation pressures, and that threshold is 85 percent and we are virtually there," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a bond trading firm. He predicted that the inflation rate would rise above 4 percent next year, unless the Federal Reserve held economic growth below 3 percent by raising interest rates again. Interest rate increases tend to discourage lending in an economy that thrives on credit.
Bond traders in general also concluded that the new capacity utilization figure would help to convince the Federal Reserve's policy makers to raise interest rates at their next meeting, on Sept. 27, Mr. Jones and others said. Before yesterday, the consensus view among bond traders was that the Fed would wait until its Nov. 15 meeting -- after the Congressional elections -- if it acted at all again this year.
"The markets clearly associate high capacity utilization with a jump in inflation," said Mickey Levy, chief financial economist at Nationsbank.
But manufacturers took a very different view. The case for a new surge in economic growth, and with it higher inflation, rests on strength in auto sales as well as rising exports. Indeed, the August jump in industrial production came largely because of a rebound in auto and truck production and a jump of nearly seven percentage points, to 87.2 percent, in the capacity utilization at auto and truck plants.
Auto industry executives, however, insist that capacity is more flexible and expandable than the Federal Reserve's figures suggest, and therefore less inflationary than the bond market's behavior yesterday would indicate.
"These capacity utilization rates don't relate very much to anything we know," said Wynn Van Bussman, an economist for the Chrysler Corporation. "We know each plant's capacity on two shifts, with and without overtime, and what it would be on three shifts, and the Federal Reserve's numbers don't take account of this, so we don't pay attention to them."
The capacity measurement also does not take adequate account of overseas production, Mr. Van Bussman and Mr. Jasinowski argue. Chrysler, for example, is starting production in Graz, Austria, of its popular Jeep Grand Cherokee. That plant will make 45,000 Grand Cherokees a year for European buyers, allowing Chrysler to divert vehicles to American buyers that are now made in the United States and exported to Europe.
Finally, the Big Three -- General Motors, Ford and Chrysler -- insist that they are seeking to hold onto market share won back from the Japanese and that they have therefore held back sticker price increases on 1995 models to roughly the inflation rate, although demand exists for greater increases.
"We are able to stretch capacity, and we have made the decision not to take full advantage of the pricing opportunity," Mr. Van Bussman said.

The Economy

The formula of a popular coding system used for protecting data sent over computer networks has been circulated on electronic bulletin boards in an act of business espionage. [37.]

Private banks in Taiwan have been kept on a short leash, not only by the Government, but by business conglomerates that bought into many of the banks and now exploit them as cash cows. [49.]
 
 
Your Money
 
More investors are buying variable life insurance, which allows policyholders to direct premium dollars into mutual fund investments of their choice. Sales of variable life insurance have surged this year, while life insurance sales over all have declined. [35.]
 
Tax consciousness has grown at investment companies. At Schwab, Vanguard and J. P. Morgan, new strategies make taxes a day-to-day concern, not just a one-time tactic like buying tax-free bonds or realizing a flock of capital losses at year-end. [35.]
 
As corporate takeovers mount, charities may benefit. Some shareholders in companies being acquired are donating their stock to a charity rather than pay taxes on windfall profits. [35.]
 
Some secured credit cards have lured savers instead of borrowers because of their high rates on the amount on deposit. [36.]

HEADLINE: Consumer Optimism Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for early September rose to 92.2 from 91.7 in August, people with access to the report said yesterday. The University of Michigan index is based on 100, set in 1966. When the monthly reading increases, consumers are becoming more optimistic about the economy. Since 1966, the record high for the sentiment index is 101, set in March 1984. The record low is 51.7, set in April 1980. The university also said its index of current economic conditions fell to 102.9, from 108.7 in August. The index of consumer expectations, a component of the Government's index of leading economic indicators, rose to 85.3, from 80.8 in August. "It's a surprising mix," said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "People seem to be less confident about the present and more confident about the future." The university delays public release of the information for one month.

HEADLINE: Stocks and Bonds Plunge on Inflation Specter

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

 BODY:
In 30 minutes of trading frenzy, the stock and bond markets plunged yesterday morning in response to a Government economic report that raised the specter of accelerating inflation. Both markets calmed by 10 A.M., but the damage was done.
As bond prices dropped, the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 7.77 percent, the highest since the end of June 1992 and up from 7.63 percent on Thursday. The spurt in the yield also pushed it out of a trading range it had been in since July. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 20.53 points, to 3,933.35, after climbing 58.55 points Thursday.
Although traders and analysts predicted a more steady mood in the bond market next week, several said that yesterday's economic report, which showed that manufacturing production jumped more than expected last month, would increase pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates after its policy meeting Sept. 27. Before yesterday, many analysts had expected the Fed to wait until its November meeting, which is after this year's elections, to raise interest rates again.
The markets were jolted, traders and analysts said, by the Federal Reserve's report on industrial production. The Fed said that factory use reached a capacity of 84.7 percent in August, up four-tenths of 1 percent from the previous month, and matching the highest operating rate since March 1989. Many traders and investors contend that when the production level of America's factories gets this close to full capacity prices begin to rise because manufacturers cannot meet demand.
In the same report, the Fed said that industrial production jumped seven tenths of 1 percent in August, the 15th consecutive monthly advance. This increase was more than many analysts expected.
"I think the reaction was so strong because the conventional view had been that the economy was decelerating," said Richard Berner, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "These numbers today shocked that view."
A strengthening economy, Mr. Berner and other analysts said, would almost inevitably spur inflation and encourage the Fed to raise interest rates again in the coming month.
"The economy is growing faster than the markets seem to be comfortable with," Mr. Berner said.
John Lispky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, agreed. "There is no convincing, broad-based sign of any slowdown in the economy at all," he said.
In the bond market, the selling spree began seconds after the Fed released its report at 9:15 A.M., and lasted about 15 minutes, said Jay Goldinger, market strategist at Capital Insight of Beverly Hills, Calif.
"This was a slaughter today," Mr. Goldinger said. "It wasn't painful; it happened so quickly."
The stock market, flush from Thursday's big gain in the Dow, followed suit. The Dow plummeted 40 points in about 15 minutes after the opening of trading at 9:30 A.M., then recovered slowly over the remainder of the session.
Trading was unusually heavy, with 410.8 million shares exchanging hands on the New York Stock Exchange for its sixth-busiest day ever and second-busiest day this year. On March 18, the exchange saw more than 461 million shares traded. Yesterday's decliners outpaced advancers by 1,418 to 739.
A contributing factor to the high turnover, traders said, was the coinciding expirations of equity and index options and index futures, known on Wall Street as a day of "triple witching."
But the talk of the bond market was the surprising jump in industrial capacity utilization. Several analysts said they regarded 84 percent to 85 percent as a threshold that marks new inflationary pressures.
Yesterday's report brought an extra surprise, traders said, by revising July's rate of capacity utilization to 84.3 percent -- the highest level since August 1989 -- from 83.9 percent. The additional four-tenths of 1 percentage point increase in August meant a total increase of twice that, or eight-tenths of a percentage point -- far higher than the three-tenths of a point increase that many traders had expected.
"There's no magic number," Mr. Goldinger said, noting that capacity utilization reached 84.8 in 1988, and went as high as 89.2 percent in 1973. But as usual, expectations, and not history, were what drove the market, he said.
Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg in New York, said: "It was much, much higher than the market expected. It just reached into all those fears about inflation that were there already."
Mr. Liro said he believed that the Fed would act by mid-October to raise interest rates. He said he thought the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, might decide soon after the Fed's Sept. 27 policy-making meeting to shift rates.
The Fed has already raised interest rates five times this year to stave off inflation, and the Federal funds target rate has climbed to 4.75 percent from 3 percent.
Mr. Liro and other analysts said they expected relatively calm trading in the bond market next week, in part because the economic data scheduled to be released -- new housing starts and trade figures -- did not usually push bond prices significantly.
"I think it will be a consolidation week," Mr. Liro said.
The stock market slide may have been touched off by the bond market's selloff, but it also followed Thursday's gain that was attributed mostly to a computer-driven surge in the last minutes of trading.
At the market's close on Thursday, the Dow reached 3,953.88, its highest level since Feb. 3, and within reach of its peak of 3,978.36, set on Jan. 31. After yesterday's fall, the Dow was still ahead for the week by 58.54 points.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 3.62 points, to 471.19. The small-stock Nasdaq composite index dropped 0.75 point, to 777.91.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index was off 1.65 points, to 259.77. The American Stock Exchange was one of the few indicators that rose yesterday. It gained 0.12 point, to 459.86.
General Motors led the Dow industrials down, losing 1 1/8, to 50 1/2. Caterpillar fell 1 3/8, closing at 56 3/8.
But not all stocks fell. I.B.M. rose 1 1/4, to 71, in active trading after Goldman, Sachs set an $80 target within 6 to 12 months for the computer giant. ITT rose 1 7/8, to 82, after saying it planned to seek buyers for its ITT Financial unit.
American Income Holding jumped 3 7/8, to 34, on news that a unit of Torchmark would acquire it for $35 a share. Torchmark ended up 3/4 at 43.
McGraw-Hill Inc. was heavily traded with shares up 2 7/8, to 76 1/2, a high for the year. The New York Stock Exchange said it had asked the company if it had any news to report and that it had declined to issue a statement. Analysts have speculated that a large European publisher, possibly Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany, might be interested in taking over McGraw-Hill.

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks In Hartford If Cars Use Clean Fuel

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Two months ago, Connecticut staked out a new position among states with air pollution problems: it opened up its checkbook.
 Under a new law that energy experts say is only the second in the nation, Connecticut announced that any commercial fleet operator that wanted to convert vehicles from ozone-spewing gasoline to cleaner fuels like natural gas or electricity would get a big tax break. For every dollar spent on conversion or on building alternative fueling stations, fleet owners could deduct 50 cents from their corporate profits tax. After the conversion, the new fuel would be exempted from the 31-cents-a-gallon state fuel tax.
 
 Only Oklahoma, a natural-gas-producing state with few smog problems, has done anything similar. It also gives the 50 percent deduction.
 Connecticut's move has paid off. The nation's largest commercial fleet operator, United Parcel Service, said in August that it would convert more than half its 925 vehicles in Connecticut during the next 24 months to compressed natural gas. The highest proportion of converted U.P.S. trucks elsewhere is 15 percent, in Oklahoma. A coalition of environmental and gas industry groups has also formed to push next year for a similar law in New York, using Connecticut's as the prototype.
 Connecticut officials said that they would not know how many companies were using the program until tax receipts had been counted, but they estimated that the tax breaks might cost $1 million in revenue.
 The story behind this law reveals how business, government and environmental concerns can occasionally line up in surprising and enthusiastic agreement. The law also underlines the deep policy differences between Connecticut and some of its neighbors that have been at the heart of the long regional debate about carrying out provisions of the Federal Clean Air Act.
 New York and Massachusetts, for example, have both passed laws that will require certain percentages of low- or zero-emission vehicles to be sold over time. Connecticut officials have repeatedly rejected the idea of mandates, arguing that the market, if encouraged and prodded, can and should carry the freight.
 "They obviously believe it's good for their respective states, but we in Connecticut have a little bit different philosophy," said Timothy R. E. Keeney, the State Commissioner of Environmental Protection. "From the Governor on down, we don't believe that a sales mandate is a productive way to proceed."
 Cooperation with businesses is at the root of the new Connecticut law. In fact, it was proposed by U.P.S., which told lawmakers in Hartford this spring that it wanted to accelerate its use of alternative fuels, but needed help defraying the costs.
 It can cost up to $8,000 to convert a typical U.P.S. truck to compressed natural gas, said Robert K. Hall, the company's automotive engineer. He said that total would take nine or 10 years to recoup without incentives,
 "It takes about 50 percent to put a dent in the cost of the project, to make it feasible," he said.
 Lawmakers completed the rest of the economics equation themselves: if a big company like U.P.S. was ready to leap, could a local industry perhaps be fostered in converting vehicles and making alternative-fuel equipment? And if Connecticut acted first, might it gain an edge?
 The result was an environmental bill that even a chamber of commerce president could love. It sailed into law with bipartisan support.
 "It shows that these clean-air technologies are not pie in the sky, that they're doable," said Senator Michael P. Meotti, a Democrat from Glastonbury who, as co-chairman of the Transportation Committee, is a sponsor of the bill.
 Some applause about the new law has been cautious, however. Several environmental and energy groups said they feared that the new law could encourage politicians to say that the state was now doing enough in dealing with ozone problems.
 "Someone might say that, and I suspect someone will," said John R. Garrison, chief executive of the American Lung Association. But Mr. Garrison added, "I wouldn't do anything to discourage implementation of this law because it is an important first step."
 Whether the Connecticut law will in fact be an economic boon is also uncertain. When the legislature was debating the bill this spring, the prospects of jump-starting an alternative-fuels business seemed bright: the state was courting a Massachusetts company that planned to expand in Connecticut, building electric cars in Waterbury. The company later backed out, however.
 New York, where at least 2 percent of all vehicles offered for sale must be zero-emission cars by 1998, was able last month to attract a California electric car company, U.S. Electricar, that said it would assemble its vehicles in the Syracuse area. The company's president said that the prospect of a guaranteed market was a major factor.

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN WITH HAITI;
Aristide's Offer: A 'Vision of Democracy'

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of the address today in the White House by the exiled President of Haiti, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to a group of leaders from 24 countries whose troops would join in a peacekeeping operation in Haiti:
President Clinton, Mr. Vice President, distinguished Prime Ministers, Mr. Secretary of State, Mr. Secretary of Defense, honorable ministers and ambassadors, Mr. Secretary General of Caricom, General Shalikashvili, Mr. Gray, special adviser to President Clinton, in the name of our nation, I extend to you my warm and sincere greetings. Honorable Prime Ministers of the Caribbean, may I say that we are indeed happy and proud to be surrounded by you. 
 I thank you, this microcosm of the world community, for traveling with the people of Haiti on our long and difficult journey toward democracy, for the commitment of the world community to help us end the suffering and oppression of the people of Haiti, and to restore democracy.
President Clinton, thank you for an historic message last night. Your words were an eloquent testimony to the suffering endured by our nation during these past three years. Your homage to our friends and fallen heroes, Father Jean-Marie Vincent, Minister Guy Malary and, to the thousands of victims of the coup d'etat echo deeply in our heart. By understanding this suffering, you nurture our great hope, the hope for peace, the hope for reconciliation.
Standing with the people of Haiti in this vision for democracy, you affirm the great sense of patriotism buried deep in the souls of all Haitians. Listening to your message, we as Haitians are reminded of a shared history rooted in dreams of liberty and freedom. Thank you and the people of the United States once again.
We thank also the international community for embracing our hope for peace and reconciliation. In your remarks last night, President Clinton, you documented well the history of the international support for Haiti, diplomatic efforts of the United Nations and the Organization of American States to secure the sovereign rights of all Haitians to decide the future of our nation.
 
'Reconciliation Among All'
 As you said, there is no question that the people of Haiti want to embrace democracy. It is the restoration of democracy that will bring peace for all, reconciliation among all, respect and justice for every single citizen. With the implementation of the Governors Island Agreement, we will realize this vision. That is why we fully support United Nations Resolution 940, the ultimate vehicle to achieve the goals of democracy outlined in that agreement.
We thank the people of the United States for taking the lead in this multinational effort under Resolution 940. The solidarity that the international community has expressed in this effort through the participation of our dearest neighbors in the Caribbean and our brother nations representing the continents of Africa, South America, Europe and Asia is the solidarity that will be needed tomorrow as together we work to uplift Haiti.
As we move towards democracy and toward this new Haiti, we move democratically, we move justly, fully aware that peace and stability will return to our nation only because we have pledged to reconcile our society. This is why I granted the political amnesty authorized by Article 147 of our Constitution. This amnesty is part of the reconciliation and rebuilding process. Let our commitment to peace be our contribution to democracy. We will not allow artificial lines to divide us.
Members of political parties, members of Parliament, civilians, members of the military, all Haitians, let us stand to rebuild our nation. How great will it be to in future days to begin our education program to reduce our 85 percent illiteracy rate. Already we plan to build one new school in each of the 565 rural districts of the country, restore and resupply 1,000 of the existing schools, and train 3,000 teachers.
How great will it be to in future days to begin implementation of emergency health measures in a nation where there are only 1.8 doctors for every 10,000 Haitians, and 1.5 hospital beds for every 1,000 people.
How great will it be to in future days to begin planting trees to ward off a total ecological disaster that threatens the nation. Since the onset of the political crisis, an additional 7,500 trees are cut down each month. In 1978, our forest acreage stood at 7 percent; by 1989, that number was reduced to 1.3; and if this way continues, by next year all of our forest may disappear.
How great will it be to in the next few days begin with our plans for the professionalization of the army, to no longer suffer under a 7,000-person army controlling 45 percent of the national budget.
 
'We Say No to Vengeance'
 Members of the military, we will create jobs for you. You will not be isolated. You are the sons of the land, the nation's citizens. Stop the violence. Do not be afraid. We say no to vengeance, we say no to retaliation. Again and again, day after day, we will continue saying no to vengeance, no to retaliation. Let us embrace peace. When? Now. Is it too late? No, the time is now. The restoration of democracy will bring peace for all, reconciliation among all, respect and justice for every single citizen. Stop the violence. Do not be afraid. We say, and we will be saying again and again, no to vengeance, no to retaliation. Let us embrace peace. When? Now. Is it too late? No. The time is now.
In a new and democratic Haiti the rule of law is indispensable. In a few days after the restoration of democracy we will start to reform our judiciary with the assistance of a separate civilian police for this reformed judicial system; we will offer a constitutional avenue for recourse to equity, national academies to train our magistrates, our 83 judges, 348 justices of the peace, 43 court clerks, and 147 officers of the Bureau of Vital Statistics, will restore confidence in these beleaguered institutions.
With political stability will come economic rebirth. The decline in national production by over 10 percent in 1992, the alienation of foreign investment, the accelerated depreciation of our currency, and the 60 percent rise in inflation must be reversed. The security and stability that will come with the restoration of democracy will create the environment where growth is possible.
The 140,000 jobs lost in the industrial sector will be restored. In this environment of political stability, commitments from the international community will allow us to advance an economic policy that ensures an open market and opportunities to prosper.
As during our first seven months in office, we will again close the floodgate of Haitian boat people. Our refugees will stay at home happy to participate in a prospering economy, to share in the resources contributed by our vibrant diaspora. They will work to rebuild the nation. Once again, we will move from misery to poverty with dignity. Yes, indeed, we will move from misery to poverty with dignity. The restoration of democracy will bring peace for all, reconciliation among all, respect and justice for every single citizen.
 
True Test of Democracy
 The swift and determined action of the international community pursuant to Resolution 940 will lead us quickly towards creating this climate of peace as the December legislative elections approach. A successful election to which the world is invited to observe will set the scene for an historic event: the December 1995 elections.
As I have said before, the true test of a democracy is its second free election when power is transferred freely and constitutionally. Therefore, I will not be, and cannot be, a candidate. We anxiously await the international community to support that effort as they presently support the restoration of democracy today.
On February 7, 1991, the day of my inauguration as President, I said that not another drop of blood must fall in Haiti. Today, again, I repeat this call to peace and reconciliation, which will flourish with the restoration of democracy.
President Clinton, last night in your historic and vibrant message, you told the people of my nation that you come in peace. With you and with every individual participating in the international effort in Haiti, we share the desire for peace as together we move towards Haiti, a Haiti where, like in South Africa, we will celebrate a new beginning.
A new day is coming for Haiti. May it come soon.

HEADLINE: In Korea, Fears of North Bring Crackdown on Left

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
There is great anticipation of Saturday night's premiere of one of South Korea's most expensive films, "The Taebaek Mountains," the movie version of a best-selling novel.
But what in most countries would be an occasion to admire stars and starlets has been transformed into a dramatization of the growing anxieties over the possible opening of North Korea.
Right-wing groups have threatened to bomb the theaters that show the film, which takes a sympathetic look at a band of Communist guerrillas before and during the Korean War, and the police have sought an indictment of the novel's writer, Cho Jung Rae, on charges that his 10-volume epic is pro-Communist. 
 The South Korean Government has repeatedly cracked down on Communist sympathizers. But this attack is against a novel that has been on the market eight years, and it comes from a Government led by President Kim Young Sam, who built his career fighting authoritarian rule and stormed into office 18 months ago on a campaign of reform and democratization.
The attempts to silence Mr. Cho are just part of a broader crackdown on left-leaning professors and students that began after the death in July of Kim Il Sung, North Korea's Communist leader.
Students have been arrested for possessing allegedly pro-North Korean literature. Two professors were nearly indicted for writing a popular textbook that looks at South Korea through a Marxist lens, but a judge rejected the prosecutor's charges. Government officials are expressing worries that the United States may provide concessions to a North Korean Government still bent on military conquest of the South.
On the surface, this represents an odd shift in policy. Some experts see the death of the man most responsible for the division of the Korean peninsula as a potentially hopeful sign. North Korea, whose economy is crumbling amid its isolation, has accelerated its discussions with the United States on opening its nuclear plants to inspections and has even taken steps toward establishing diplomatic relations with Washington.
The outcome of the talks remains uncertain. But these events have unsettled rather than soothed the South Koreans, prompting what some see as a return to the old, repressive policies. "I think it is unimaginable in a democratic society to put something that is the product of one's imagination on trial," said Mr. Cho, the novelist. "You have to remember that this is fiction. It is stupid to mistake it for reality."
But to hear political leaders in South Korea tell it, Kim Il Sung's death exposed conspiracies to overthrow one of the most prosperous and stable countries in East Asia.
"The Government was simply reacting to the shock of the people, who were surprised to see the large body of students with leanings toward North Korea," said Lee Sei Kee, chairman of the governing Democratic Liberal Party's policy committee. "We were actually being very careful. But then people started to say, 'Why are you being so soft?' Then the media took up this view. That was why we changed our position."
To some degree, of course, North Korea is a real threat. It has not launched any military forays across the demilitarized zone for years, nor has it initiated terrorist attacks like the bombings of the early 1980's. But it still has nearly a million troops along the 151-mile demarcation line.
There is also evidence that the Pyongyang Government has spent the last decade trying to develop nuclear weapons and that it has stockpiled enough plutonium to build one or two bombs.
The weapons would most likely be used against South Korea, yet it is the United States that is negotiating with Pyongyang on halting the program. Despite the presence of 37,000 American troops here, many South Koreans see this as a Korean issue. Yet the North Koreans have refused to meet with South Korea on the matter because they do not recognize the Government.
Thus, what lingering fears the South Koreans have about American intentions have come into the open, at times in the form of anger at Robert L. Gallucci, the senior State Department official leading the American delegation in the talks.

HEADLINE: U.S.-German Group Plans an American Academy for Berlin

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Sept. 16

 BODY:
A group of prominent Americans and Germans has announced plans to build an American Academy here, part of a web of new projects intended to assure that this city's ties to the United States do not weaken over the years ahead.
The academy, which is to open in 1996, would be a center for scholars from the United States, Germany and Central Europe. Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, and Richard von Weizsacker, the former President of Germany, are the honorary chairmen. 
 "By sparking an American rediscovery of Berlin's treasures, the academy can tap a rich, centuries-old tradition of cultural and scholarly interaction between Americans and central Europeans that was cracked by World War II and the cold war," organizers of the project said in a statement.
The withdrawal last week of the last United States troops here has unsettled many Berliners, some of whom do not realize that the Americans are not bringing their troops home from all of Germany. To show that the United States intends to remain active here, American officials have begun projects that are envisioned as the basis of a new and stronger economic, political, cultural and strategic relationship.
"We have got a massive effort under way to demonstrate to Berlin, to Germany and the world that we are not pulling out in any real sense," Richard C. Holbrooke, the outgoing United States Ambassador to Germany, said in an interview. "All that is leaving Berlin are a couple of hundred soldiers who are no longer needed.
"There's a real strength and a real emotion in the feeling that Germans, and especially Berliners, have toward the United States. Logically, these ties will gradually attenuate and become more distant. Memories of the airlift and 'Ich bin ein Berliner' will fade like Gettysburg and the Battle of the Bulge. What we are doing now is building a series of institutions that will guarantee that this relationship doesn't fade along with the memories."
Recently, an exhibition documenting the United States role in Berlin opened at an American cultural center in downtown Berlin, and a new Allied Museum was dedicated in a building that was once the American military's movie theater.
Senior government and business leaders from both countries held a two-day conference last week that was billed as the one of highest-level meetings of German and American business and political leaders ever. A smaller-scale meeting in Leipzig next weekend is intended to allow American, German and central European business executives to discuss prospects for cooperation.
Among other programs that are about to begin here are several aimed at eastern Germany, where during the Communist era many people were given only a partial view of the American role in Germany. A center is being planned in Dresden to train eastern German schoolteachers in methods of teaching English.
Over the coming months, as Germans observe the 50th anniversary of various events leading up to and following the end of World War II, the United States will sponsor discussions in eastern Germany intended to present fuller historical background than was available to most people there during the decades of Communist rule.
"The American role at the end of World War II was never explained in East Germany," said Dan Hamilton, an American scholar who is working as an adviser to the United States diplomats here. "Or it was explained in a way that just wasn't true."

HEADLINE: Private Banks on a Short Leash in Taiwan

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
For years, Chao Yuan-chi stood patiently in long lines to cash his checks at one of Taiwan's big state-owned banks. Once a banker in the United States, he was convinced that there had to be a better way.
"I was so mad," he recalled. "The service was so bad. They made us wait a long time. I said to myself, when I open a bank, we would not let people wait. We'd have a clean lobby, very efficient." 
 Now Mr. Chao has had his chance. Five years ago, in a first effort to liberalize the country's highly regulated and heavily state-dominated banking sector, the Taiwan Government decided to grant licenses to any new private banks that could demonstrate assets of at least 10 billion Taiwan dollars, then a bit less than $400 million. The Government expected a handful of applications. It received 20 and approved 15 immediately, and one more thereafter.
"Nowhere in this world in a small economy like Taiwan's would you see 15 new banks with $400 million in equity opening at the same time," Mr. Chao said. "When that happens, the pie is only so large and the competition becomes much fiercer, and services become much better."
But for all their purported independence, the private banks in Taiwan have been kept on a short leash, not only by the Government, whose heavy-handed regulation extends down to approval for individual automatic teller machines, but also by the major business conglomerates that bought into many of the banks and now exploit them as cash cows.
The Pacific Group, a manufacturing, construction and retail conglomerate, provided much of the assets behind the Dah An Commercial Bank, where Mr. Chao now works as executive vice president.
"Most of the new banks were invested in by conglomerates," said Norman Yin, a professor of banking at National Chengchi University. "Even though each investor was supposed to be limited to 5 percent, many of these groups used a variety of street names to put in money. So as a result, one group can own 50 percent of the capital and so have control of the bank."
Though banking regulations were designed to prevent it, the private banks have sometimes been used by their conglomerate parents as easy sources of funds, according to banking analysts. And many private banks were forced into more marginal, and problematic, lending.
By contrast, the state banks benefit from long-term relationships with customers. The Bank of Taiwan, the country's second-largest bank, enjoys the free use of money as the depository for local government funds on which it pays no interest. As a result, the state banks remain highly profitable, if still inefficient, with an average return on equity of more than 20 percent, while the private banks have averaged a meager 4 percent.
Still, Wu Rong-i, the president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, a private research group with both government and private sector projects, said the new private banks were the seed of more aggressive competition.
"It's very strong pressure on existing banks," Mr. Wu said.
During a recent boom in Taiwan's property market, the private banks were making loans for construction projects, usually accepting real estate as collateral. But banking analysts say the valuations of the property often overstated actual worth.
Professor Yin referred to one bank, which he declined to name, that had lost nearly $100 million on a bad loan when the bank found itself with real estate not worth its collateral value.
"Many of these banks have marginal customers and nonperforming loans," Professor Yin said, though Dah An Commercial Bank has largely avoided the problems afflicting many other new private banks.
Mr. Chao of Dah An said that Taiwan's central bank was concerned about the loan portfolios of private banks and intended to exercise closer controls over them.
"Right now they think too much of our money goes into the construction industry and not enough into manufacturing," Mr. Chao said. "We have already received some letters from them asking us to put more emphasis on loans to manufacturers."
Both the Ministry of Finance and the central bank exert stringent controls over the private banks, determining how many branches they can open each year and where, dictating the number of cash machines they can install across the island and approving the qualifications of all managerial personnel. Mr. Chao said such regulations on the private banks seemed to be growing.
"If we want to put in a new A.T.M. machine," Mr. Chao said, "we have to apply to the Ministry of Finance a year in advance. If I want to get a computer terminal in my customer's office so they can do wire transfers on their own terminals, that's not allowed here."
But the governor of the central bank, Liang Kuo-shu, defended the tight controls.
"The Ministry of Finance is very concerned about the concentration of power because these banks are owned mainly by big business groups, so they are putting on more and more regulations," Mr. Liang said.
As for the Government's control over growth of the private banks, he said, "If they have too many branches in the early stages, they will lose money."
Mr. Chao acknowledged that he was frustrated by the Government's impulse to retain control over the private banking sector, but he said that Dah An's banking assets had nonetheless increased. "We are changing things slowly," he said. "We cannot change things overnight. They want to liberalize the financial system here in Taiwan and they are doing it step by step."
At the main branch of Dah An here, next door to the newly opened Hard Rock Cafe, tellers sat, not behind little windows so common at many state banks, but at low counters. A single line of customers, moving rapidly, fed toward the tellers.
"You see," Mr. Chao said, as he headed out to a lunch of soupy noodles, "it's pretty quick now. No one is waiting forever. I think our service here is indeed better than the state banks. They are improving, but there is a difference."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chao Yuan-chi, executive vice president of the Dah An Commercial Bank, outside its main branch in Taipei. Five years after they were allowed to open, Taiwan's private banks remain under strict Government controls. (Cheryl Sheridan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Tumbles on a Report Indicating Strong Economy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against most other leading currencies yesterday, following bonds lower after a Federal Reserve report convinced many investors that factory use was rising fast enough to spur inflation.
Bonds suffered their biggest one-day loss since May after the Fed said yesterday that factories, mines and utilities operated at 84.7 percent of capacity in August, the highest level since 1989. The Fed also said industrial output jumped a bigger-than-expected seven-tenths of 1 percent in August. 
 "A lot of people are shocked at the strength of the economy, and the inflation that goes along with it," said David Durst, a currency-options trader at Bear, Stearns & Company.
For many traders and analysts, the Fed report confirmed a belief that the central bank had not raised interest rates far enough or fast enough to control inflation.
While higher interest rates in the past have tended to bolster the dollar, declines in the bond and stock markets in recent months have dragged down the dollar, as traders see demand for American assets weakening.
"Strange though it seems, what the dollar needs is weaker figures," said Nick Parsons, with the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in London.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5445 German marks from 1.5460 marks late Thursday. It fell to a three-week low of 1.5315 marks, before recovering amid speculation, apparently unfounded, that the Federal Reserve was buying dollars to stem the slide. Banks that do business with the Fed said the central bank made no purchases yesterday. The Fed declined to comment.
The dollar fell to a two-year low of 1.2700 Swiss francs, from 1.2848 Swiss francs on Thursday. The British pound jumped to a 16-month high of $1.5869, from $1.5628 on Thursday. The dollar fell to 98.95 Japanese yen, from 99.50 yen on Thursday.
The small recovery by the dollar, even though bonds remained lower, indicated to some traders that the currency's eight-month slide might be coming to an end.
"If the dollar hasn't bottomed yet, it's close," said Marc Chandler, director of research at Ezra Zask Associates, a Norfolk, Conn., hedge fund with $180 million of assets.

HEADLINE: More Police for Same Taxes In Suffolk's Proposed Budget

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 16

 BODY:
The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, proposed a $1.6 billion budget today that he said would hold county property taxes at their current level through next year.
The budget includes money to hire more than 100 police officers, increasing the size of the county force to 2,701, the highest level since 1989, said Mr. Gaffney, a Republican in the third year of a four-year term. 
 But he said the county would have to ask the State Legislature for permission to extend the part of the sales tax that expires at the end of 1995 to insure future financial stability.
An added percentage point in taxes was approved in half-point increments in 1991 and 1992, producing revenues that allowed Mr. Gaffney to avoid major property tax increases while closing a budget deficit that exceeded $99 million three years ago.
The 1 percent tax will produce $138 million in revenues in 1995, according to a projection released today.
The Democratic leader of the county legislature, Maxine S. Postal, said Mr. Gaffney's claim that he was not raising taxes was "an absolute misrepresentation" because of continued dependence on the higher sales tax. "Whether it comes out of your left pocket or your right pocket, it's still taxes," Ms. Postal said.
Suffolk retains 4.25 percent of the 8.5 percent sales tax collected in the county. The state gets 4 percent and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority gets a quarter of 1 percent. The combined rate is one of the highest in the nation and is matched only by Nassau County in the state.
Sales tax revenues will rise 3.8 percent this year and 4.4 percent in 1995, the county executive's budget officials projected. Mr. Gaffney said the increased rates showed the county was "recovering slowly from the recession."
Mr. Gaffney said the county had reduced the number of welfare recipients to 16,941 cases as of last month, from 18,600 cases in August 1993. He said this continued a downward trend at a time when other counties, including Nassau and Westchester, were reporting higher caseloads.
He said the trend showed the success of a Suffolk program requiring able-bodied recipients to work in assigned jobs as a condition for receiving benefits. "People must understand that the rule in Suffolk County is if you can work, you must work," he said.
Mr. Gaffney said he was dropping a controversial plan to lease the county's fleet of some 8,000 cars from a Maryland company. He said he and county legislators were now discussing "a blend" of bought and leased cars to replace the aging fleet.
In a public split with Mr. Gaffney, Republicans in the county legislature said the leasing plan would waste millions of dollars. Mr. Gaffney said he was forced to consider leasing because the legislators would not appropriate money or sell bonds to buy cars.
Donald R. Blydenburgh, a Republican and the presiding officer of the 18-member legislature, declined today to comment on the proposed budget or on Mr. Gaffney's revised position on car leasing.

HEADLINE: BANKING;
Secured Credit Cards Are Attracting Savers

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo 

 BODY:
LOOKING for a high rate of return on their savings, some people with stellar credit histories are using what has been known as the credit card of last resort.
The cards, called secured credit cards, were designed for people with a bad credit record (or none at all) who failed to qualify for a conventional card. For a minimum deposit, generally $300 to $500, a Visa or Mastercard is issued with a matching line of credit. 
 But a growing market for secured cards has heightened competition and created what can be attractive deals. Some card issuers are offering such high rates on the amount on deposit that they have lured savers instead of borrowers.
"A good number of our card holders admit getting a Key Federal secured card primarily to earn the high interest on savings deposit," said Robert M. Bouza, senior vice president of Key Federal Savings Bank in Havre de Grace, Md., one of the largest issuers of secured cards. "Even if they don't need our secured card to rebuild or establish a good credit record, these people are using our program as a high-interest savings vehicle -- and getting a major credit card as a bonus."
Ruth E. Susswein, executive director of the Bankcard Holders of America, a nonprofit group in Salem, Va., said that restoring credit was still the main use of secured cards, but "using a secured card for savings is becoming more common."
Card holders in the Key Federal program currently receive an annual yield of 4.06 percent on up to $1,000 on deposit and 4.57 percent on amounts of $1,000 to $5,000. Interest is compounded and credited quarterly. On the down side, the bank requires a $400 minimum deposit, charges a $35 annual fee and 18.9 percent interest on balances.
The Associates National Bank of Dallas pays 5.1 percent on deposits above $250 and charges a $45 annual fee for its card. The Orchard Bank, in Portland, Ore., pays 5 percent on deposits of $2,500 to $15,000 and charges no fee.
For comparison, the average money market account had an annual yield of 2.45 percent this week and the average one-year certificate of deposit had an annual yield of 4.39 percent, according to Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla.
The number of secured cards in circulation grew to 925,000 last year from just 145,000 in 1988, and is expected to reach 1.2 million by the end of this year, largely because millions of Americans damaged their credit records in the recent recession and want to rebuild a credit history.
No longer the province of shady finance and credit repair companies, the cards are issued by many major banks. The number of issuers has grown to 400 from 35 in 1992.
Robert K. Heady, the publisher of Bank Rate Monitor, said that the cards were a good deal for issuers, who take little risk because the line of credit is secured by the deposit. Card issuers also get income from application and late fees, and usually charge high interest on purchases, often 18 to 21 percent. Moreover, many secured cards have no grace period, meaning interest accrues from the date of purchase.
"Secured cards make sense for people who pay off their credit card debt every month or don't use the credit line and just use it for savings," said Robert B. McKinley, the president of RAM Research, a credit card researcher and publisher in Frederick, Md. "They can pay better rates than bank accounts, even when taking an annual fee into account."

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Taylor and Chavez: Old Soldiers Who Keep Fighting

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 16

 BODY:
For his comeback, Meldrick Taylor hired an unemployed Philadelphia street vendor to impart an Eastern spiritual approach to his daily training regimen, which now includes isometric exercises, yoga and whole-grain foods.
The former world champion also enlisted the services of the man who trained him as an amateur, Willie Rush, to help him return to his professional roots, when he utilized blinding hand speed and effective counterpunching. 
 "I've done everything I've had to do to prepare for this man," he said today.
Taylor (32-3-1, 18 knockouts) resumes his rivalry with Julio Cesar Chavez (91-1-1, 77 knockouts) Saturday at the M-G-M Grand.
If Taylor is prepared, the same might not be said for his opponent. Chavez was fined $500 by the Nevada State Athletic Commission for being 25 minutes late to today's weigh-in. When he finally arrived, Chavez appeared woozy and afterward guzzled a bottle of Gatorade as if he hadn't had anything to eat or drink all day, raising speculation that he had struggled to make the 140-pound limit.
Commission officials said he weighed 140 -- the same as Taylor -- but would have to be checked by a doctor.
Although Chavez's World Boxing Council superlightweight title is for the taking, he and Taylor's reputations have taken a beating the past two years, and as such it has dulled the luster of the rematch.
Taylor is a 3 1/2-to-1 underdog according to most Nevada betting lines, yet Chavez's trainer, Emmanuel Steward, likens their rematch to other rematches between legends gone south.
"Ali and Frazier were past their primes, and yet they put on a war," Steward said. "Same with Tommy Hearns and Sugar Ray Leonard. They brought out the best in each other. Meldrick never forgot what Julio did to him."
Pop in the tape of their fight four years ago and watch as Taylor had Chavez's number for much of 11 3/4 rounds. That one quarter of a round was costly for Taylor, though. Chavez unleashed a flurry of blows in the final 20 seconds, backing Taylor into his corner and finally sending him to the canvas.
He rose slowly and responded even more slowly to Referee Richard Steele's count. Steele stopped the fight amid chaos with two seconds left, and Chavez remained unbeaten and Taylor's career was set back a millenium.
Taylor was knocked out twice in 1992 vying for world titles, and this year Chavez was beaten by Frankie Randall. Questions surrounding this fight have more to do with whose career is over than who is stronger:
*Is Chavez nearing the end after losing once, drawing once and going down for the first time in his career against Randall this year? Or can he find one last great performance before a partisan gathering in the M-G-M Grand Garden Ballroom?
*Will Taylor's new-found discipline remove the stigma attached to him as a fighter whose weight balloons between bouts? That's where Shiloh Bey comes in. Bey, who has worked as a street vendor in Philadelphia, has provided spiritual and nutritional guidance to a few lesser-known fighters and convinced Taylor to follow his advice.
*Should either keep fighting?
"I'm older, but I am still good," the 32-year-old Chavez said through his interpreter, Gladys Rosa.
Taylor, who is 27, said: "I was never a shot fighter. I don't know why people said that."
 
PUNCH LINES
 EVANDER HOLYFIELD disputes reports that he was denied medical clearance to fight again. "I plan to fight by the end of the year," he said. It's not like Reggie Lewis, where I'm trying to find someone to let me fight. It's not that serious a problem." Although he has not applied for a boxing license, he said he planned to do so after planning his comeback strategy. Holyfield, a two-time heavyweight champion, was told by a physician not to fight again after discovering a heart ailment shortly after his loss to MICHAEL MOORER.
