HEADLINE: In 'Prince Igor,' a Lesson in Western Ways

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

 BODY:
For five singers from the former Soviet Union and its satellites, appearing in the New York City Opera production of "Prince Igor," Alexander Borodin's pageant of Russian nationalism and pagan temptations, carries the echo of once-learned lessons, lately discarded.
"We were taught, we were raised, to be poor," said Dejan Miladinovic, the director of the Belgrade National Opera, who is directing "Prince Igor." "And when nothing worked, we blamed the capitalists, the Americans, the wealthy people." 
 These days, the director and the singers from the former Eastern bloc, who tonight are to appear in the second of their four performances at the New York State Theater, are eager for the coveted chance to earn hard currency. And yesterday's villains have become today's role models.
In many of their home countries, opera is in disarray, struggling to survive. Ticket prices are up to the equivalent of $1, a small fortune in economies where a monthly salary may run from $5 to $10, and audiences are down. Governments that once guaranteed careers, that spent freely on productions and coddled performers, have all but eliminated subsidies, while their economies lack the tradition and tax laws to promote private philanthropy. "And we haven't got the wealthy people to do that," Mr. Miladinovic noted.
"Please God," interrupted Vladimir Grishko, a tenor from Kiev, Ukraine, crossing himself like any number of medieval Christians portrayed in "Prince Igor," "I'll become wealthy and healthy."
"Me, too," Mr. Miladinovic added quickly.
With the rules of the game having changed on them in mid-career, opera singers like Mr. Grishko and Sergei Zadvorny, a bass who plays the Polovtsian warrior Khan Kontchak, have found their lives in upheaval, for better and for worse. They now have to scramble for auditions and bookings in the West; hire language and voice coaches, who were once supplied by their opera companies, and school themselves in the cost effectiveness of agents and publicity people.
And they must wrestle with the travails of international careers and constant travel. Mr. Zadvorny's arrival from Odessa, Ukraine, was delayed for two weeks because of his difficulty in obtaining a visa, an all too common experience that prompted Mr. Miladinovic to propose a special passport that would grant artists, like diplomats, special travel status.
"Before, when our opera was under the tight control of the government, I wasn't known in Europe and America," said Valery Alekseyev, a baritone who sings the title role. As one of the more fortunate singers, Mr. Alekseyev spends most of his time away from his home base at the Kirov Opera in St. Petersburg. "If I had no tours here, I couldn't live on the salary I have in Russia alone. I wouldn't have enough money for food."
Valentin Peytchinov, a Bulgarian bass who portrays the barbarous Prince Galitzky, noted that the time and the money once devoted to staging an opera in his country were something "companies here could only dream about." Still, Mr. Peytchinov, who left Sofia in 1988 to study at the Juilliard School, has no plans to return to Bulgaria, for which he harbors a fair store of resentment.
His musical education came free, compliments of the Communist Government, but when he received an invitation in 1987 to study in the United States, he was denied permission to leave Bulgaria. A friendly diplomatic official finally arranged his departure the next year; it was a hasty escape, just before his wife gave birth to their first child, and began a forced three-year family separation while he attended Juilliard. "Can you imagine how I suffered?" the singer asked, his eyes filling.
Mr. Grishko, who has been on the road for the last six months or so, said he would not bother singing in the cash-poor cities of Eastern Europe. "What would be the interest of a singer going to my country?" he asked. "Ten dollars a month? No thank you. I will not sing."
Next year, he will appear in "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera. Asked which role he would sing, the tenor crossed himself once again and looked skyward. "Alfredo, thank you God," he said.
It is perhaps a measure of the economic desperation and rise of nationalism in Eastern Europe that, apropos of nothing, Mr. Peytchinov hastened to point out that many American singers perform regularly in Europe. "That's why you shouldn't feel we are taking anybody's place by performing here," he said.
Christopher Keene, the general director of City Opera, said he had recruited the singers from Eastern Europe, collectively referred to as "the Russians" by the City Opera's American members, through a series of coincidences after he had decided to stage the opera in the original Russian. The last time City Opera did "Prince Igor" was in 1969, and the production was in English.
Mr. Grishko and Oksana Krovytska, a Ukrainian soprano who has sung with City Opera for more than two years, were already known to Mr. Keene. Mr. Alekseyev's agent happened to call Mr. Keene to say the baritone would have some time free before appearing across the Lincoln Center plaza in the Metropolitan Opera's production of "Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk." Mr. Zadvorny, who was in New York visiting a friend, asked to audition on a whim, and was accepted. The same day, Mr. Peytchinov also auditioned successfully, Mr. Keene recalled.
Guido Ajmone-Marsan, who is conducting the music for "Prince Igor," noted that the performers were happy for the chance to work in the West, and brought authenticity to the company's first Russian-language performances. But he noted that because of the ample rehearsal time they were used to back home, the singers were not in the habit of arriving for rehearsals with music memorized and entrances and exits charted.
On the first day of rehearsals, Mr. Ajmone-Marsan recalled, only the American cast, which will take over for the first of its three performances on Oct. 4, and Ms. Krovytska were present. "We did all the ensembles, and there were no mistakes," he said. "Everyone knew their entrances and their pitches. And then the Russians came in. At their first rehearsals, a lot of mistakes were made, even by the people who had sung it before."
The longtime cocoon of Eastern Europe was artistic as well as political, and left opera untouched by the naturalistic dramatic style that evolved in the West, he added. The result is often performances that come across as stilted, what one American singer called "stand up and deliver your aria" singing.
"I think an opera like this could gain by more up-to-date acting," the conductor said. He suggested, though, that perhaps ignoring the dramatic demands of their roles allowed for more heartfelt musical interpretations. "Maybe because they don't pay such clear attention to the musical things, they give their personality more free rein in the way they're singing."
When they are not rehearsing, the foreign singers spend much of their time here shopping, in the fine tradition of Europeans East and West. Melanie Sonnenberg, an American mezzo who plays the Polovtsian princess who lures Prince Igor's son from his father, said that CD's and opera scores in the original languages seemed particularly prized by the visitors.
The only East European who reported a full opera house back home was Mr. Miladinovic of Yugoslavia, which has been isolated from the rest of the world under United Nations sanctions. "I suppose it's a normal reaction: the audience is seeking a live word or a live melody," he said. "At this time, people want to establish communication."

GRAPHIC: Photo: East Europeans taking part in "Prince Igor" are the director, Dejan Miladinovic of Yugoslavia, center, and five singers: from left, Sergei Zadvorny of Ukraine, Valentin Peytchinov of Bulgaria, Vladimir Grishko of Ukraine, Oksana Krovytska of Ukraine and Valery Alekseyev of Russia. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Far Away From Home, But Not Far From CNN

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR 

 BODY:
Some images linger from a recent vacation in Berlin:
Sad faces of children, often crying, fleeing places like Rwanda and Bosnia. Commercials for contour pillows and shiatsu-massage devices. Weather reports covering the globe in 150 seconds or less. Larry King tenaciously pursuing every new tidbit in the O. J. Simpson case and badgering guests for assurances that this is really one helluva story. 
 Welcome to the world as packaged by CNN or, more precisely, CNN International, the Ted Turner-owned service that aims to reach each and every one of those satellite dishes sprouting up across Europe, Africa and Asia. As something of a news junkie, I must confess that having CNN International available 24 hours a day at the flick of a switch was bewitching. If nothing else, I could take my time about picking up that day's copy of an English-language newspaper.
In the United States, CNN has profoundly altered the basic dynamics of television news, most notably by ending the virtual monopoly that the three commercial networks had on supplying news clips to local stations. CNN has forced the news divisions of ABC, CBS and NBC to scurry to keep up. And now, just about every hour on the hour, CNN International can provide travelers and other interested viewers with a fairly good sense of what is happening around the world. But the old problems of television news remain. What too often emerges is little more than a headline, tied precariously to "visuals" that are repeated to the point of stupefaction.
Perhaps the most blatant example during my several weeks in Berlin was the story of political unrest in Nigeria, with the military rulers keeping in prison the man who a year ago had evidently won a democratic election to lead the country. Each time the story came on, as the military accelerated its general crackdown, CNN International viewers were treated to a file clip of the election victor surrounded by smiling and triumphant supporters. The image, far from the reality of the leader's being imprisoned, had the unsettling effect of being almost lulling.
Of course, the daily logistics of CNN International are daunting. I had to keep reminding myself that the 9 A.M. "World News Report" with Ralitsa Vassileva was coming out of CNN headquarters in Atlanta at 3 A.M., a time when hard news is generally not breaking. But even seemingly straightforward reports at that hour can be confusing. On one segment dealing with developments in Northern Ireland, Brendan O'Leary, an author and a professor at the London School of Economics, appeared to be interviewed live by Ms. Vassileva. Yet in the next hour, another anchor, Stephen Cole, opened his Ireland report saying, "Earlier, I spoke to an expert, Brendan O'Leary," whose remarks were then repeated.
Confronted with the challenge of covering the world, complete with some sort of appropriate pictures, CNN International can get trapped in silly decisions. One sports roundup, running the standard three minutes, reported the auto-accident death of a Portuguese soccer star with a long shot of two teams, no player clearly discernible, on an unidentified field.
The CNN conundrum is most dramatically reflected in weather reports. We all know they are notoriously unreliable, even on local newscasts. What are we to make of genial weather forecasters skipping blithely over the world's continents in two and a half minutes with a few general trends and temperature readings? One complete report for the United States (which for some reason never includes temperatures): "Storming around the Great Lakes; hot in the Midwest." Talk about useless.
One of CNN's in-house commercials states, "It began with a simple idea: keeping the world informed 24 hours a day." It's obviously not that simple. Ratings have been slipping for the past year or so, buoyed briefly this year only by the Simpson story, which might explain Mr. King's ferocious persistence in pouncing on every new detail.
And then CNN frequently finds itself in the familiar damned-if-you-do, damned-if-you-don't bind. It is sometimes criticized for going live with news conferences that turn out to be less than newsworthy. But that is apparent only after the fact. If CNN failed to cover something that turned out to be significant, the same critics would wail indignantly. In fact, the live special reports this summer, from a Clinton news conference to the Cuban Ambassador meeting reporters at the United Nations, proved to be among CNN's more valuable offerings.
Sitting in Berlin, I watched the extensive local and national television coverage of President Boris N. Yeltsin's arrival in the city to preside over the historic departure of Russian troops. On CNN, the event was for the most part reduced to a brief shot of Mr. Yeltsin arriving at Tegel Airport and smiling exuberantly at well-wishers. Of course, CNN can't cover every story around the world in depth. But a more judicious balance, not to mention a more helpful perspective, certainly isn't out of the question.
Meanwhile, not a day went by without a trip to the local newsstand. All right, I'm prejudiced. Any better suggestions?

HEADLINE: The Ad Campaigns;
Race for Governor: Cuomo Goes After Pataki

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
Candidate: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo
Producer: The Garth Group, New York 
 Visual The 30-second advertisement begins with footage from one of State Senator George E. Pataki's early commercials showing Mr. Pataki, the Republican candidate, walking toward the camera. His image freezes, and the word "Untrue" is superimposed across it in bold red letters. Below that is a New York Times headline that reads, "Pataki's Grim Statistics Collide With the Facts." The ad cuts to a shot of Mr. Pataki being interviewed on television. It ends with the words, "George Pataki. Politics as Usual," stripped in white letters across the screen.
Script Announcer: "George Pataki. He's running commercials attacking Mario Cuomo using statements he claims are factual." George Pataki (quoted from his own commercial): "It's a fact." Announcer: "But The New York Times says Pataki's statistics often collide with the facts. And in this commercial, none of Pataki's claims were true. Why say something that just isn't true?" Mr. Pataki (quoted from a June 6 interview with New York 1 News): "In the course of campaigns, people want to win and they say things about their opponents that they may or may not believe." Announcer: "What was that, George?" Mr. Pataki: "That they may or may not believe." Announcer: "O.K. George Pataki. Politics as usual."
Analysis: The commercial marks the third time in two weeks that the Cuomo campaign has sought to use Mr. Pataki's own statements to question his integrity. In this case, the Cuomo camp focuses on a Pataki commercial contending that New York State is No. 1 in taxes, wasteful spending and job losses -- none of which are true, according to Federal labor and census statistics. The Cuomo ad then quotes from a television interview in which Mr. Pataki seems to suggest that distorting facts is a valid campaign weapon. The effect is apparently a double play: Mr. Pataki uses incorrect information, then is heard rationalizing it. The ad's subliminal question seems to be, who could possibly trust such a man?
The Cuomo camp accurately depicts Mr. Pataki's commercial as factually wrong; the Times article shown in the ad pointed out that New York does not actually rank first in any of the categories cited. But the truth is not much rosier for Mr. Cuomo, since New York still ranked high among states in combined state and local taxes, jobs losses during the recession and government spending.
Furthermore, the ad portrays Mr. Pataki's comment that candidates say things "they may or may not believe" as a statement of personal ideology. But in fact, it was offered as a defense of Herbert London, who ran an acrimonious campaign against Mr. Pataki for the Republican gubernatorial endorsement. He lost and then joined Mr. Pataki's ticket as the candidate for state comptroller. JAMES DAO

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
The Face-Saving Invasion

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN 

 BODY:
It is an inexact art, psychoanalyzing the President of the United States. But with the Administration threatening to enter a military conflict both senseless and unpopular, there is nowhere to look for possible explanations but inside Bill Clinton's head.
Certainly there was precious little enlightenment in the President's speech Thursday on why we could see our way clear to invade Haiti. With a listlessness at odds with his usual sidewalk-preacher oratorical style, Mr. Clinton couldn't drum up one compelling reason that a tiny nation whose economy is in shambles and whose military is a shadow of our own posed a risk to national security. He was reduced to quoting George Bush and referring to Grenada as though it were Guadalcanal. It evoked the movie "Dave," in which the President is impersonated by someone else after he falls ill. Who was that man playing Bill Clinton? 
 From the isolated perch of the Presidency Mr. Clinton has become a leader reviled not only by the Republicans but by many liberal Democrats as well. He is seen as a man who would bargain nearly any principle away. From an unworkable "don't ask, don't tell" resolution of the issue of gay men and lesbians in the military, to the slow erosion of the promise of universal health care from all to many to some, Mr. Clinton has negotiated much and satisfied few.
This perception may have reached its zenith when Garry Trudeau, whose cartoon strip "Doonesbury" is frequently the country's most revealing and most punishing social commentary, began recently to portray the President as a floating waffle.
If George Bush was at least partly motivated in his mano-a-mano with Saddam Hussein by a powerful inner urge to show that he was not a prep school wimp, it seems just as likely that Bill Clinton was trying to show the world Thursday night that the waffle can stand fast. The problem is that he has chosen the wrong time and the wrong place to do so.
The atrocities and deprivation he described in Haiti are horrible and real, it is true. But if they justified military action, we should long ago have sent troops into Bosnia and even Rwanda. (And when Mr. Clinton intoned "executing children, raping women," it sounded as much like New York or Chicago as Port-au-Prince.) The recalcitrance of the military junta is unarguable. But that argues not for military intervention but for continued diplomatic pressure, sanctions that target the well-to-do, humanitarian aid for the poor and economic assistance when the tyrants are overthrown by the Haitian people.
Like the gulf war, fought largely for access to Middle Eastern oil, the Haitian invasion has also been styled an economic necessity. Mr. Clinton said in his speech it would stanch the flow of Haitian refugees, an expensive result of both the political terror and the economic embargo the United States has imposed. A return to democracy would stop the flight, the President suggested, which does not explain why citizens living in peace under the duly elected President of Mexico keep pouring over the border into Texas and California.
Evoking Panama and Grenada, two other foolish mini-wars, Mr. Clinton said that any incursion into Haiti would be "limited and specific." But soldiers would die, and civilians too, particularly if riots spread through the streets of that deeply anti-American island and we were, once again, forced to destroy the village in order to save it.
Perhaps if that was done, Mr. Clinton would have saved face in some fashion. That was the theme of his speech: that he had told the military junta over and over to get out and now he had had enough. American credibility was at stake, he said, although it seemed more Bill Clinton's credibility than the nation's. Besides, to whom must we prove our mettle? The former Soviet Union? North Korea? St. Croix?
The President of Haiti has accused the President of the United States of planning an invasion to assure a Democratic victory in midterm elections. His political instincts are as bad as Mr. Clinton's. With public and political opinion so arrayed against intervention, the very best result from an invasion would be a wash -- no gain, no harm. The best case is that Haiti, like Grenada, would become a bit by Leno, a throwaway line by Letterman, Bill Clinton's little war, remembered less as an exercise in foreign policy than a crisis of self-confidence.

HEADLINE: Calpers Chooses a Less Adversarial Voice

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Sept. 16

 BODY:
The huge California pension agency, which has been a prime force putting pressure on corporations in recent years to improve their financial performance, appears likely to become less active on that front.
Today the California Public Employees' Retirement System, also known as Calpers, named a new chief executive, James E. Burton, a top aide to several former California politicians. In an interview, Mr. Burton said the fund's role as corporate governance watchdog would become a less adversarial, less public one in keeping with the strategy adopted by the fund and his predecessor of the last two years. 
 "We've matured; we've found a more effective way to handle communications," he said.
With $80 billion in assets, Calpers is the nation's largest pension fund. It has been a leading voice for restive shareholders unhappy with management decisions that held down company stock prices, and in recent years has helped force leadership changes at Westinghouse Electric, I.B.M. and General Motors.
Mr. Burton, the sixth chief executive in the system's 63-year history, made clear that he intended to be a less strident voice for change. That stance also reflects a shift within the shareholder-rights movement.
His appointment to the Calpers post, which pays $110,000 a year, is effective Oct. 1, when he will succeed Richard H. Koppes, the fund's general counsel. Mr. Koppes has served as interim chief executive since the July 11 resignation of Dale Hanson.
Mr. Hanson, who is 51, served for seven years, became a leading shareholder-rights advocate and gained a voice in managing some poorly performing companies whose shares are held by the fund. He left to start his own venture capital fund.
While thoroughly familiar with the corporate governance issues that Mr. Hanson championed, Mr. Burton, who is 43, said, "My intent is to stay focused a little closer to home."
His immediate goal is better service for the fund's one million beneficiaries by improving the use of automation and telecommunications. Planning for future fiscal constraints and a lower interest rate environment is another priority, he said. Another aim is more investment in the state's laggard economy, along the lines of the $1 billion invested in home building the fund made in the last two years.
"His really big job is how to harmonize the state's needs and that of the retirees' legitimate entitlements," said Robert A. G. Monks, a founder of the shareholder-rights movement and now head of the Lens investment fund.
The vast resources of Calpers will be an alluring source of reinvestment capital for politicians eager to replace the military contracting industry, and will force Mr. Burton to walk a political tightrope. "He's in a position to wield a tremendous amount of power," Mr. Monks said, adding that Mr. Burton was particularly well qualified for the task. "My prophecy is he will make as large a contribution to the corporate-governance movement as Dale Hanson."
Since 1992, Mr. Burton had served as the fund's assistant executive officer for investments. Previously he had served on its board as a deputy for the state treasurer and controller. His wife, Suzanne, was appointed in 1991 by Gov. Pete Wilson as the state's deputy director of finance.
Shareholder advocacy has evolved as proponents now frequently win victories and gain a voice in how companies are managed, Harry DeAngelo, a finance professor at the University of Southern California, said, citing the defeat by shareholders of Kmart's plan to spin off part of its specialty-store units. "It's a different world," he said.
The ability of Calpers to influence management is tempered by its keeping half its assets in index funds, A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, said. Without the latitude to sell shares, which a typical dissatisfied shareholder can exercise, "that ties their hands in relation to what they don't like," he said.

HEADLINE: THE BIG CITY;
Color blind

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
It is a mysterious annual ritual. First the nation's fashion arbiters determine the new fall colors and explain why America desperately needs clothes in these hues. Then they make sure not to wear any of these clothes themselves. After all, they live in New York. They don't do colors.
At this fall season's Seventh Avenue shows, the runways featured dresses in shocking pink and lemon chrome and bright mango, but the audience, as usual, looked like a convention of Amish undertakers. Vogue and Harper's Bazaar are proclaiming that "color and shine have returned" and "all signs point to neon," but in the Conde Nast and Hearst buildings, the women who put out those magazines are still wearing coal-colored leggings and miniskirts -- the timeless Elf Angst look. At Charivari, the clothing stores that tout their Manhattan hipness with the slogan "Never Coming to a Mall Near You," the company president, Jon Weiser, explains New York's fundamental law of fashion by paraphrasing Henry Ford: "We like every color as long as it's black." 
 This can't be a genetic trait or a result of childhood deprivation, because many New Yorkers come from multipigmented homes. A friend of mine who moved here from Maine endured repeated gifts of pastel sweaters from his family until he finally went home one Christmas and announced: "No more colors!" Even members of New York's fashion establishment have occasional pangs of discomfort when they leave the city. The editor in chief of Allure, Linda Wells, who grew up in St. Louis wearing Fair Isle sweaters, recalls an unsettling trip back there: "I was wearing a long, austere black dress, nothing unusual. I didn't think anything of it until I got off the plane. I started walking through the airport, and I suddenly realized what I must look like to everyone in St. Louis -- a nun. I kept my hands at my sides. I was afraid people were going to start giving me money."
The black fetish is obviously an adaptive trait, a response to peculiar cultural and environmental conditions. But what exactly is it about black that makes it go so well with New York? There are several theories.
Black is practical. New Yorkers claim they're just being sensible and economical. Black wears well because it hides the chief component of the city, dirt. It flatters most skin tones and makes people look thinner. It can go from the office to an opening to a dinner party. These explanations make sense, but there's a fatal flaw in this theory. If you really cared about being economical and practical, why would you live in New York?
Black is elegant. Eddie Rodriguez, a designer known for his downtown look, sees his clothes as a reflection of urbanity. "New York is America's most sophisticated city," he says, "and black is the most sophisticated color." Certainly black has an elegant history: the classic simplicity of Chanel's "little black dress," the quiet dignity that centuries of aristocrats conveyed by wearing black for their portraits. "The most agreeable color is black," observed Federico Fregoso, a 16th-century Italian courtier. "Who of us when he sees a gentleman passing by wearing a gown quartered in various colors . . . does not take him for a fool or a clown?"
This explanation, though, is also problematic. Black may convey understated sophistication, but how many New Yorkers are understated? And when you consider the black-clad crowd at a downtown club, what's elegant about the earrings piercing their tongues?
Black is unnatural. "Black suits the inorganic quality of the city," says Scott Omelianuk, the fashion writer at GQ. "The only place more inorganic than New York is Tokyo, and there they wear even more black. When you see people in Southern California doing a version of what they think New York hip is, somehow the black doesn't work -- out there they have trees and lawns and sunshine." Although you can quibble with this theory -- industrial towns are fairly inorganic, too, yet the people in them still wear colors -- it's a step in the right direction. The unnatural, lifeless, sinister aspect of black points toward the true explanation for its popularity in New York:
Black is Satan. Anne Hollander, an art historian who has analyzed fashion in "Seeing Through Clothes" and the new "Sex and Suits," believes that her fellow New Yorkers are the spiritual heirs of alienated 19th-century artists like Byron, Baudelaire and Poe. "For the Romantics, wearing black represented the dandyism of the depraved, the mark of an unhappy, solitary person who was possibly in league with the Devil," she says. "New Yorkers are plugging straight into that bohemian tradition because New York is officially an unhappy place. When you get dressed up here, you're dressed for rage."
Like Satan, New Yorkers combine their rage with terrifying lust for power, which makes black all the more appropriate. Like Darth Vader's uniform, black is frightening as well as protective. Even the most kindly New Yorkers recognize its essential function as urban armor against their evil neighbors. When researchers at the Pantone Color Institute did a survey asking New Yorkers what adjective they associated with black, the most common answer was "powerful."
That answer gibes nicely with the research of David B. Givens, an anthropologist whose forthcoming book, "Why Humans Are," analyzes the evolution of behavior. He likens the dark suit to a gorilla's chest-beating display for intimidating rivals. The flair of the lapels and the length of the jacket serve the same function as the gorilla's posture -- making the shoulders and chest look as big as possible -- and the color adds to the effect. "Black makes you seem mysterious and unapproachable," Givens says. "It's the equivalent of putting on sunglasses."
What's worn with the suit is also telling. Exposing the neck is a common courtship ritual in vertebrate species -- from humans to wolves to crocodiles -- because it's a sign of vulnerability. Covering it makes you look more powerful, nastier, which is why downtown New Yorkers who shun the bourgeois tie or scarf have adopted substitute coverings, like the black turtleneck or the air tie look -- a shirt, preferably black, worn without a tie but buttoned to the top.
If you have any remaining doubts about the satanic essence of New Yorkers' clothes, consider one final bit of empirical evidence: an experiment conducted by Linda Wells of Allure a few years ago. She decided to actually wear the fall colors. "I had a pink and orange-sorbet-colored suit," she recalls. "It made me feel happy in the morning when I put it on, but all day long I felt like I was in the wrong place. I felt like I was in a Halloween costume. I felt I had to be nice."
She learned her lesson. This fall season you'll find her in black.

HEADLINE: ART;
The Granddaddy Of Disorder

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: GAETA, Italy

 BODY:
THE SUMMER HAS BEEN STIFLING, too hot, Cy Twombly said, for painting, too full of distraction and diversion. For this American artist, long viewed as a reclusive and elusive self-exile, has been preparing for a major retrospective in New York with what, for him, is a star burst of publicity.
 "You know, this really isn't a thing I do," the 66-year-old Mr. Twombly said in his slow, Southern drawl, gesturing vaguely toward a reporter's notebook and a photographer's lights during one of a series of interviews he has given recently. It was not a grumble or a rebuke. Rather, it was more a shrugging acceptance of the way things seem to be done these days.
The preparations were for Mr. Twombly's largest American retrospective ever, opening next Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art. It will include 50 paintings, 37 works on paper and 10 sculptures, embracing his entire career, from 1946 to a few weeks ago. Twombly's is not a household name in the United States, although he gained a certain notoriety when one of his works was singled out by Morley Safer during an attack on modern art on "60 Minutes" last year as a "canvas of scrawls done with the wrong end of a paintbrush." On the other hand, those deceptively childlike scrawls have earned him many devoted followers among artists, critics and collectors. 
 Kirk Varnedoe, head of the department of painting and sculpture at the Modern and curator of the exhibition, thinks Twombly's "purposeful disorder" and "juicy treatment of paint in relation to the body" will appeal to young artists unfamiliar with his work. After all, says Mr. Varnedoe, "he is the grandfather of that approach." And Mr. Twombly provides a living link with the New York School tradition of Pollock, de Kooning and Kline. Like those Abstract Expressionists, who transformed American art after World War II, he deals with heroic subjects -- mythology, history, nature; but he does it in graffiti-like lines and splotches that also link him to as contemporary a phenomenon as the 80's graffiti artist Jean-Michel Basquiat.
For many years he was regarded as a remote figure in Europe, less interesting than his friends Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns, who were thought to have embraced Pop Art. But this is a Cy Twombly moment. Europe has come back into favor in American art circles, and the admiration accorded him by painters like Anselm Kiefer, Francesco Clemente and Julian Schnabel has only enhanced his reputation.
Today, Mr. Twombly is at a time of his life that is in some ways both turning point and homecoming. The New York retrospective will help determine whether he has laid the critical ghost of his last, poorly received, American retrospective, at the Whitney in 1979. And it virtually coincides with his decision, after almost 37 years in Italy, to take up an American residence again in his hometown, Lexington, Va.
Not that things ever seem to be cast in such literal light in conversations with a man whose sentences sometimes halt abruptly, as if an inner caution had warned him to go no further toward exposing a private core that like his paintings and drawings, does not yield itself to casual scrutiny. One senses a person who has always pursued and fulfilled a largely inscrutable and private agenda.
"I hope it's not much of anything," he said of the retrospective at the Modern. The comment might seem ingenuous if it did not also seem a form of protection against the sometimes hostile art world in New York. "Why would I want more? Why would I want an escalation or something? I have kept my own pace. I think it's a pace the paintings show. I have my pace and way of living, and I'm not looking for something. I'm not looking for taking on something else."
MR. TWOMBLY WAS SITTING in the sunlit courtyard of his hillside house in Gaeta, a coastal city 80 miles south of Rome. He bought the house eight years ago and renovated and rebuilt it, but it still seems slightly unlived in, with dust covers swathing the furniture. Its gray-painted steel door on an unpaved road seems almost monastic, reflecting a desire to control access to his privacy. But the master's sense of humor alters the perspective, breaking through the patrician sternness of facial line that he tends to adopt in photographs. And it makes his spoken words seem far less austere than they sometimes seem in print.
 Mr. Twombly's pace is less hectic than it was. He worked intensely earlier this year -- "I almost made myself sick," he said -- completing a spectacular, four-canvas series called "The Four Seasons" and a huge, 50-foot triptych initially called "The Anatomy of Melancholy" and now untitled. (The former, four large canvases alive with Mr. Twombly's characteristic combination of scattered incidents of drawing, painting and writing, will be at the Modern; the latter will be on view next month at the downtown Gagosian Gallery in New York and will eventually go to the Cy Twombly Gallery, a new museum opening in February near the Menil Collection in Houston. The retrospective will stop there and in Los Angeles and Berlin after closing in New York.) In his studio here, a second version of "The Four Seasons" is taking shape, but it is incomplete and the palettes and paints on trestles and tables around it are dry.
"It's too hot to paint anyhow," he explained. In any event, he added, he was not a "programmed" person and tended not to paint to any kind of fixed routine.
The publicity surrounding the retrospective has recalled some biographical detail about a painter who, by choosing to live in Italy, made himself more obscure in New York than his peers and probably slowed his success. ("If that's the cost" of moving to Italy, he said with a smile, "I'm glad I did it.")
Mr. Twombly was born in 1928 in Lexington, Va. He was christened Edwin Parker Twombly Jr. but inherited his nickname from his father, a professional baseball player who was called Cy in memory of the pitcher Cy Young. Early training as an artist came primarily from Pierre Daura, a Spanish artist who came to Lexington when Mr. Twombly was 12 and introduced the young painter to the modern European tradition in which he eventually came to feel most comfortable. The first painting Mr. Twombly recalls making was a copy of Picasso's portrait of Marie-Therese Walter.
From then on, at art schools in Boston and New York and, in 1951, at Black Mountain College, the fabled avant-garde enclave in North Carolina where he studied under Ben Shahn and Robert Motherwell, Mr. Twombly absorbed expressionist influences and developed interests in Dada and Surrealism. He wrote much later that the main challenge of progressive art "lies in the complete expression of one's own personality through every faculty available."
In the 1950's, Mr. Twombly, along with Mr. Johns and Mr. Rauschenberg -- with whom he traveled to Italy and North Africa -- came to epitomize what seemed at the time a reaction against the Abstract Expressionists, who had become the dominant force in American art. The fact that the other two achieved success more rapidly than he does not seem to rankle.
"I don't know what success is," he said. "I don't know if it means notoriety, acceptance or what. I know Jasper Johns was an immediate success. That to me was very clear. Whereas Bob Rauschenberg in reality had a success but more like a notoriety. Sometimes you are a success but not financially.
"It's something I don't think about. If it happens, it happens, but don't bother me with it. I couldn't care less."
(Such sentiments are easier to acquire from a perspective of financial independence. Although Mr. Twombly recalls the days in the late 1950's when his works sold for $100 or so, things are different now. In recent years, Twomblys have brought between $2 million and $5 million.)
Mr. Twombly moved to Italy in 1957 at the age of 29, when the focus of the art world had shifted from Europe to New York. Within two years he had married Tatiana Franchetti, a member of a rich and aristocratic family. The couple had a son, Cyrus Alessandro, who is also a painter. Mr. Twombly casts his move to Italy in the simplest of terms: "Rome in the 1950's was a pretty nice place to come to." But the story seems more complicated. He had visited Italy in 1952 with Mr. Rauschenberg, but on this trip his association with the Franchetti family -- Giorgio Franchetti as well as his sister, Tatiana -- brought with it a distinctive life style among people with a long history of patronage of the arts.
"HE HAD NOT PLANNED A lengthy stay but found Italian life seductive," Mr. Varnedoe wrote in his introductory essay to the catalogue for the retrospective. "He found himself caught up in an unexpected and powerful tide of personal and art-world circumstance, centering on a new nexus of friendships."
That was the beginning of what has frequently been described as a self-exile in Italy, where Mr. Twombly owns houses not only in Gaeta but also in Rome and Bassano, along with his wife's family castle in the Dolomites. In fact, said Mr. Varnedoe, the notion of exile is inaccurate. "He's been back and forth more than one thinks," he said. "The myth is that he left in 1957 and is living in self-exile."
Some of Mr. Twombly's returns to the United States have been singularly unfortunate. A 1964 showing at the Castelli Gallery in New York of the nine-painting series "Discourse on Commodus" was a fiasco. Not a single painting sold. The Whitney retrospective, Mr. Twombly acknowledged, was "not what one would call a success."
Those memories seem to have left an abiding mistrust of what, viewed from Italy, seem the vagaries of the New York art world. "In the 1980's, certainly, art became part of the economy, the entertainment world," he said, and New York "was like General Motors."
"If you really are interested in being in the art world, in getting ahead," he continued, "you are in New York, not in Gaeta."
Clearly, Mr. Twombly has a sense that this time things will be better. "From not caring at all about American painting in the 1950's, Americans think about nothing but American paintings," he said. "I'm the last thing to grab at: that's why they are making something of it."
In conversation, Mr. Twombly seems as much interested in hearing other people's stories as in telling his own, content to listen or to talk about travels in Egypt or Yemen or Greece or the intricacies of the Roman aristocracy or the works of D. H. Lawrence -- just about anything short of the details of his life.
The whole question of his secretiveness seems a puzzle. "I haven't answered my phone in years," he said. "If I want to talk to someone, I call them." Yet he insists he is not secretive: "They use the word, but I'm not secretive. It's not like I'm closed in here. It's not like I'm just with four or five people."
Perhaps the riddle at this period of Mr. Twombly's life is why he has chosen to spend spring and fall in his native Virginia. Up until now, his life, friends, family and work have been in Italy. His persona was built around the Mediterranean. His travels were usually to exotic places, like the Tangier of Paul Bowles in the 1950's or Asia Minor, and he still harbors an urge to visit the ancient sites of Iran. Against all that, Lexington, where he bought a two-story, 19th-century brick house last year, might seem prosaic, though he insists it is "quite a sophisticated little town."
Possibly, it is a sense of advancing years and frailty that has induced the feeling that often surfaces among expatriates -- although he hates the term -- that the adoptive home is no final substitute for native soil.
In two recent interviews, he has compared himself to an old dog going home to die -- a metaphor articulated with an exaggeration of his already pronounced Southern drawl.
"Well, I did say that," he said with a vaguely embarrassed laugh when asked about the remark. "I have taken a house in Lexington, Virginia. After 35 years in Europe and Italy, it was a nice change."

HEADLINE: Queens West Begins With a Park

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
MOST major construction projects begin by digging a large hole in the ground. The Queens West project in Hunters Point began by filling one in.
Earlier this month, in the middle of his campaign for a fourth term, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo formally inaugurated Queens West, which was authorized by the State Legislature during Mr. Cuomo's first term. He was joined by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. 
 The ground breaking was not for the plazas and piers that are to skirt more than a mile of East River shoreline one day. Nor was it for the first apartment tower, which is to rise 42 stories over the 74-acre waterfront site, eventually to be joined by residential buildings on 13 other parcels -- a total of 6,385 apartments -- plus a four-block hotel and office complex that may become the linchpin of efforts to keep United Nations agencies in New York.
Rather, ground was broken for a sliver of a park two blocks from the river's edge.
The park is being created atop 30,000 cubic yards of sand, loam and broken-up concrete now being dumped into an abandoned Long Island Rail Road cut along 48th Avenue, between Vernon Boulevard and Fifth Street. (To visualize that volume, it may help to know that garbage trucks carry 18 to 25 cubic yards.)
With the park under way, the next step will come in late fall with the laying of storm and sanitary sewers, water lines and utility connections to the first development sites.
Also in the fall, Arthur Imperatore's NY Waterway company is to begin rush-hour ferry service between the foot of Borden Avenue on the Queens West site and 34th Street in Manhattan. Plans call for a 500-car parking lot at the landing, near which is the Long Island City station of the L.I.R.R.
In January or February, while surrounding infrastructure is installed, ground may be broken for a co-op apartment building between 48th and 49th Avenues, designed by Cesar Pelli & Associates and Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron. Its developers say the 521 units will be affordable to people earning between $30,000 and $70,000.
Next, work is to begin on a waterfront park called Gantry Plaza, designed by Weintraub & di Domenico and Thomas Balsley Associates. Its centerpiece will be the long-legged gantries over four abandoned float bridges that were once used to transfer freight cars from river barges to the tracks of the L.I.R.R.
It was, however, at the site of the Hunters Point Community Park that officials declared Queens West a reality.
They did so, in part, to demonstrate to Washington that the first apartment tower will not stand isolated. The developers of that building, an American and Japanese group called M. O. Associates, are seeking $89 million in mortgage insurance from the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
"H.U.D. wanted assurances that it was not funding a building without connections or amenities," said Rosina K. Abramson, president of the Queens West Development Corporation, a subsidiary of the New York State Urban Development Corporation.
Another reason they started with the park was to demonstrate that Queens West would not turn its back on those who already live and work in Hunters Point, a place of modest homes, small business and industry, open sky and a panoramic view of mid-Manhattan.
"The strength of the existing community is very important for the success of the project," Ms. Abramson said.
There are neighbors who believe this vision. Terri Mona Adams, executive director of the Hunters Point Community Development Corporation, said Queens West would revitalize the area with new homes, jobs and businesses on Vernon Boulevard and elsewhere. "And for the first time in years," she added, "the community will have access to the waterfront."
But not everyone has been won over.
"The people who live in the shadow of this proposed project are going to suffer a negative impact," said Joseph Conley, the chairman of Community Board 2, which voted overwhelmingly against the project in 1990. "They're concerned about their life and future existence, especially those who are renting space -- not only residents, but businesses. There's a real fear of secondary displacement."
Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, a Democrat who represents the area, said that the six voting members of the Queens West board -- from the state, the city Economic Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey -- "do not know this neighborhood."
"They don't walk the streets," he said. "They don't know the impact of their proposals on the viability of the community."
"The attitude has always been that the agencies coming in are like the old Christian missionaries bringing civilization to the Hottentots," the Councilman said.
THE board of the Queens West Development Corporation (often referred to as QWDC, pronounced "KWI-dic") does include Peter Magnani, representing Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens. Although Queens has no vote, Ms. Abramson said Mrs. Shulman's "desire and interest and input are listened to very carefully."
"Nothing can happen here that she doesn't like," Ms. Abramson said.
And Mrs. Shulman said "anybody who wants to participate is certainly more than welcome" to do so through a task force in her office. "I don't believe the thrust of the project will change," she said, "but the intermarriage between the project and the community can improve. And that's what we're really hoping will happen."
Members of Community Board 2 are hoping that the entire plan is re-evaluated, Mr. Conley said. "We're looking to build sensible projects that are going to integrate with the existing community," he said. "We're concerned about height, bulk and density."
A four-year-old group called the Hunters Point Community Coalition has prepared an alternate plan that calls for buildings no higher than 20 stories, about 35 percent more open space and 75 percent less office space than the official version, and a different street grid to preserve more views to the waterfront from inland blocks.
There seems to be little chance that state and city officials would back off now from a plan that was approved in 1990, during the final hours of the Board of Estimate. The master plan was devised by Gruzen Samton Steinglass and Beyer Blinder Belle.
That plan prescribes the size and use of each site, specifying the maximum floor area and building height, among other things. Three residential towers, including the M. O. Associates project, may rise 390 feet and one of the commercial buildings may reach 400 feet, with 800,000 square feet of space.
"One thing we have to sell to developers is predictability," Ms. Abramson said. "Other than the Buildings Department, there are no other permits a builder needs to get."
"Obviously, we are building big buildings," she said. "But I don't know that that needs to be disruptive or destructive."
"If New York ever breaks the mold," she said, "the place to do it is on the waterfront because the waterfront is unique. After all, this was manufacturing. How consistent was that with a residential neighborhood?"
At the same time, if experience is any guide, the plan will take many years to implement. It will necessarily evolve in that process. "The coalition is going to position itself to be around as those changes get instigated," said its chairman, Tom Paino.
The inevitability of change may be one of the few things about Queens West on which Mr. Paino and Ms. Abramson would agree.
"We're constantly doing mid-course adjustments," Ms. Abramson said. "We're very conscious that while the city and the development community need the certainty of an appoved plan, an evolving city also needs an assurance that there are adjustments that will reflect changing times."
As an example, she cited the creation of the park along 48th Avenue, which was added to the project at the community's request during land-use review. Originally, the railroad cut was to have been used for a below-grade roadway leading into the new development, bypassing neighboring blocks.
Councilman McCaffrey recalled his fear that the roadway would isolate Queens West from the rest of Hunters Point. In contrast, he said, the community park is a "means of integrating the two interests, new and old."
The park plan also calls for the demolition of the Vernon Boulevard Bridge, a small truss span that was recently refurbished by the city. Urging its preservation, the Hunters Point coalition described the "visually pleasing" bridge as a "symbol of the community."
But Mr. Conley, of the community board, said that "in fairness to Rosina and QWDC, that's something the community asked for." As for the preservationists, he said: "It's the 11th hour. Where were you before?"
Construction of the park is related to construction of the first apartment tower, whose site is now luxuriant with chest-high weeds and a few sunflowers growing over rubble.
The developers, M. O. Associates, must demonstrate that they are not building in an abandoned industrial wilderness before they can obtain Federal Housing Administration mortgage insurance from the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
HERBERT J. STURZ, president of the Trotwood Corporation, a general managing partner in M. O., said the park project had "reassured and pleased" Federal housing officials, as had the commitment by the Giuliani Administration to keep $30 million in the capital budget for Queens West infrastructure.
Should the mortgage application be approved by December, Mr. Sturz said, construction could begin in early 1995 and be completed in about a year and a half.
With Federal insurance, the developers expect to be able to get a 40-year mortgage. Frederick S. Harris, the vice president of Trotwood, said such financing could not be obtained as a rule in the commercial market, where 10-year mortgages are considered long-term. The developers also expect to attract lenders who would not ordinarily be inclined to finance such a project.
"Pension funds, which have zero appetite for risks, have a high appetite for F.H.A.-insured mortgages," Mr. Harris said.
Mr. Harris said a two-bedroom apartment with 900 square feet and a terrace would cost about $180,000 to build. But it would be sold for only $20,000 -- that portion of the cost not met by the Federally insured mortgage. Paying off the mortgage then becomes the responsibility of the co-op owners.
In the case of the two-bedroom example, Mr. Harris said the monthly cost would be about $1,450. Of that, $1,100 would go to pay off the mortgage (and would therefore be largely deductible), $300 would go to operating expenses and $50 would go to taxes and fees. A family with an annual income as low as $52,200 might qualify for the unit.
The developers also have tentative plans for a site south of the first building, between 49th and 50th Avenues: a seven-story building for the elderly and a 32-story tower with market-rate units.
M. O. Associates includes the Trotwood concern, which is owned by the Mellon Bank Corporation; the Zeckendorf Company and the Tekken Construction Company and Tobishima Corporation, both of Tokyo.
Although M. O. owns the property on which both buildings would stand, it must be designated as developer of the second project, as it was for the first, by the Queens West Development Corporation.
Should it be chosen for both sites, M. O. would deed its entire 9.9-acre property to the Queens West corporation and then lease back the development parcels, which together amount to some 3 acres. About 2.7 acres of the site would be used for streets and public space, including Gantry Plaza. The rest, about 4.2 acres, is under water.
Ms. Abramson visited the site of Gantry Plaza the other day with two of the landscape architects, Lee Weintraub and Thomas Balsley. They scrambled with considerable agility over the ruins of the old L.I.R.R. transfer bridges, standing under tall black gantries that framed a postcard-perfect view of the turquoise U.N. Secretariat.
"The strongest marketing tool I have is to make people come out here," Ms. Abramson said, as a fresh wind blew along the shoreline.
Like the recently rebuilt Pepsi-Cola sign at the north end of the Hunters Point site, or the four 275-foot-high smokestacks of the former Long Island City Power Station, the gantries straddling the transfer bridges are emblematic of the industrial waterfront and are to be preserved as a reminder of that history.
"We're doing everything we can to celebrate those structures," Mr. Balsley said.
LOOKING farther down the road, officials envision the site as a campus-like setting that might attract United Nations agencies or the biotechnology industry. Mrs. Shulman said she was having talkes with the Mount Sinai Medical Center about a hospital on the site with housing for medical workers.
In a recent study sponsored by the Ford Foundation and Dag Hammarskjold Foundation, "Renewing the United Nations System," Erskine Childers and Brian Urquhart urged that the U.N. examine the possibility of establishing a common seat for the organization, noting the "evident practical limitations" of the present headquarters site.
"They've always had problems with housing the staff affordably, with security and proximity," Ms. Abramson said. "We can come up with a package so the U.N. can stay exactly where it is and expand. And we can provide more than office expansion. We can provide a community for living."
Mrs. Shulman said the new ferry service would probably increase the interest of the U.N. in Queens West "because they would then have quick access to the mother lode."
For the time being, however, the ferries are intended not for Queens West but for commuters who use the Long Island Expressway or the half dozen L.I.R.R. trains that serve the Long Island City station.
A spokesman for NY Waterway, Vince Baglivo, said service was to begin in the fall but that no specific date had been chosen. He said the ferries would probably run every 15 to 20 minutes between the hours of 7 to 10 A.M. and 4 to 8 P.M. No firm price has been set yet, Mr. Baglivo said.
Opposition to the plan is already evident. "In light of the fact that the community is already an environmental hot spot," Councilman McCaffrey said, "the idea of drawing 500 people into parking their cars in Long Island City is mind-boggling."
One well-known local figure who welcomes the service is Freddie Botur, owner and operator of Tennisport, on the site of what is to be the commercial center of Queens West, just a few steps away from the landing. "The ferry will be tremendous," he said.
Tennisport has 29 tennis courts (13 outdoors, 11 indoors and 5 under a bubble), a restaurant and art gallery. It is soon to get a small golf driving range. Mr. Botur said he could do much more with the property if not for the specter of condemnation.
But even that possibility seems remote today, Mr. Botur said, given the commercial real estate market. "There's about 60 million square feet available in Manhattan and so there is no demand," he said. "I think we're going to be there quite a while."

HEADLINE: Primaries Over, Now Watch the Elbows Fly

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

 BODY:
THE day after Republicans and Democrats settled on their nominees for Governor in the primaries last Tuesday, Lieut. Gov. Eunice Strong Groark moved to secure a prominent place of her own in the race by putting two radio advertisements on the air.
In one, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. growls out his endorsement of Mrs. Groark, warning that "the same old parties and politicians are back at the trough." 
 "Eunice Groark has done the tough business," he says, "while other candidates promise monkey business."
In the second advertisement, John G. Rowland, the Republican candidate, is clubbed over the head with his own quote, "I'm not talking about the past," while a narrator muses over his 108 overdrafts on the House bank when he was in Congress and his highly paid but vaguely described work as a consultant ever since.
"Kind of makes you wonder what other things are in John's past that he doesn't want us to know about," the narrator says.
And so began the main event, an eight-week campaign by four candidates, all of them capable, as Mrs. Groark was serving notice, of throwing sharp elbows to gain room in the crowded field. Elbows will be thrown, for the stakes are enormous for the parties as well as the candidates, especially for A Connecticut Party, the self-proclaimed alternative to politics as usual, as Mr. Weicker departs.
But voters could be pardoned for thinking there are enough differences to debate on their merits among Mrs. Groark; Mr. Rowland, the easy winner of the Republican primary; William E. Curry Jr., the State Comptroller and upset winner of the Democratic primary, and Tom Scott, an anti-income-tax crusader.
Mrs. Groark, after all, is wholeheartedly, almost defiantly, defending the Weicker administration's record, including the personal income tax, which shifted much of the state's tax burden from business to individuals in 1991. That shift, she says, made Connecticut more competitive and helped it emerge from recession, and any future tax cuts should also benefit business.
 
Some Firsts
 She is also offering Connecticut not only its first all-female top ticket, with Audrey Rowe, Mr. Weicker's Commissioner of Social Services, as her running mate, but also, in Ms. Rowe, its first African-American candidate for Lieutenant Governor.
"John Rowland's talk of repealing the income tax does not help business," Mrs. Groark said, "and Bill Curry's talk about cutting property taxes doesn't help either. There are two ways to run a race. You can run to win or you can run to win to govern. I'm doing the latter."
Mr. Rowland has promised to eliminate the income tax in five years, cutting the $9.3 billion state budget to do without half of the $2.8 billion annual income tax revenue, and counting on an improving economy to make up the rest through increased revenue from other taxes.
Having first won public office as a 23-year-old Reagan Republican in 1980, he now is trying to reach beyond the party with a theme of lost values and lost freedoms awaiting Republican redemption.
Describing his childhood in a Waterbury neighborhood on primary night, he said the smell of burning autumn leaves symbolizes for him "the way this country used to be. Now you can't burn leaves in your backyard, you can't talk to your neighbor, you can't go downtown at night."
 
Reducing Government
 Why? "The government is telling us what to do all the time," he said, not quite promising to legalize leaf burning, but pledging to reduce government regulation. He also vows to make streets safe by executing the worst criminals and putting two-time violent offenders in prison for life.
Mr. Curry, meanwhile, is proposing to keep the income tax but to find $1 billion in property-tax relief for homeowners and businesses. He also offers himself as a reformer, opposed by his party leadership in the Democratic primary, who can cut the cost of government by restructuring and making it more efficient, and who doesn't want politics as usual any more than Mrs. Groark.
The public voted for that kind of change in 1990, he says, but Mr. Weicker hasn't delivered it.
"My strategy is to go and do what we have been doing," he said on primary night, "putting on the table what people want, a concrete blueprint for dealing with the problems of a stagnant economy, unsafe cities, an unresponsive bureaucracy and a political system that is driven by money."
Winning a primary challenge, however, has its untidy side. Mr. Curry opposes permitting casinos outside Indian land. But his running mate, chosen by party leaders at the convention, is Joseph P. Ganim, the Mayor of Bridgeport and a vocal advocate for a casino there.
The fourth candidate is Tom Scott, a former State Senator and radio talk-show host who has crusaded against the income tax. His campaign is based on a promise to repeal the tax within four years, but he also attacks government in general, without the soft glow that Mr. Rowland cultivates.
 
Confusion Ahead
 With so many people in the race, confusion about who stands where may be inevitable. "Right now you've got three Republicans and a Democrat," State Senator John Larson said Tuesday night, pledging his support to Mr. Curry after losing the Democratic primary to him. Both Mr. Scott and Mrs. Groark were once Republicans.
Mrs. Groark, however, sees the Curry victory splitting the Democrats "wide open; he becomes the spoiler." And Mr. Rowland, she says, has been wounded by Mr. Scott, who will draw off diehard Republican income-tax foes, and by his primary opponent, Secretary of the State Pauline Kezer, whose attacks on his integrity Mrs. Groark has now taken up.
Mrs. Kezer, in her campaign, also contended that Mr. Rowland was too conservative to win a statewide election, too much like Mr. Scott.
But Republican leaders say they see Mr. Rowland squarely in the center with Mrs. Groark. Mr. Scott is isolated on the "extreme right fringe," said the Republican state chairman, John Mastropietro, and Mr. Curry, a liberal supported by labor unions, is on the "extreme left fringe."
No wonder elbows are likely to fly, when the greatest danger on a crowded political spectrum can come from being associated with the candidate right next to you.
And this is the year that Democrats hope to recover from their 1990 disaster, that Republicans hope to win the Governor's office for the first time since 1970, and that A Connecticut Party will learn whether it has life beyond the singular term of Lowell Weicker.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Going Public;
A Veteran Realty Company Takes the Market Plunge

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT took longer than anyone expected -- the offering was postponed three times -- but on Aug. 25 the Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust that includes Cali Associates' 12 office buildings and one apartment complex, hit the market.
Cali, based in Cranford, N.J., sold 10.5 million shares at $17.25 a share -- a mild disappointment to a company that had hoped to sell 9.179 million shares at $18 to $20. Still, the offering, combined with the proceeds of a separate financing supplied by Prudential Securities, the new REIT's lead underwriter, yielded enough to pay down much of Cali's debt and have cash left over. 
 By forming the REIT, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, Cali has done more than just follow the real estate industry stampede to the equity markets. It has, in effect, taken the company public. Instead of owning a dozen buildings and a company, Cali's top executives now own about 25 percent of the REIT. And at an old-line company like Cali, the willingness to make that sort of switch is a sure sign that a new generation of management has taken over.
The three men who started the company -- John J. Cali, his brother Angelo and their boyhood friend Edward Leshowitz -- are all in their 70's and ready to step, if not out, then to the side. The new management team is Brant Cali, 40, John J.'s son; John R. Cali, 47, Angelo's son, and Thomas Rizk, 37, a lawyer and old friend of Brant's who is the company's chief financial officer.
The REIT was clearly their idea.
"When Cali was built," Mr. Rizk said, developers could get rich bank loans using nothing but the planned building as collateral. Today, he said, "only well-run REIT's provide good access to capital."
It is this desire for fresh growth funds that trumpets an impending strategic change. One of New Jersey's largest real estate developers, Cali Associates has, in its 45 years, developed nearly four million square feet of commercial and industrial space, 2,000 one-family homes, 1,800 rental apartments and 1,000 condominium town houses. But over the last decade it has been divesting more than growing.
When it became clear that rent control was not going away, it converted most of its rental units to condominiums. (The only rental building left, a 325-unit complex in Delran, N.J., is the REIT's only residential property.) It sold numerous office buildings to other developers wanting to get in on the booming New Jersey market. When Schering Plough, originally slated to be a tenant in Cali's 150,000-square-foot building in Union City, offered to buy the building, Cali agreed, even though other tenants were ready to move in.
The divestment strategy hasn't kept the recessionary wolves totally at bay -- the company posted a net loss of $ 1.06 million in 1993. But Cali did not lose any buildings to its lenders, its cash flow has remained high and it could have continued servicing its debt.
"The three seniors could have lived happily on the incomes from the buildings, but we want to take this company forward," John R. Cali said. "The real estate market is on the way up, there are properties we have an eye on, and it was either do the REIT or lose all the opportunity the market is offering."
In one sense, taking in outside investors brings the company full circle. Back in 1949, John and Angelo Cali and Ed Leshowitz invested some money in a residential development company. When they started scrutinizing the company's operations they did not like what they saw.
"They were not delivering good quality homes," Mr. Cali recalled.
As passive investors there was little they could do. So the three established Cali Associates and built homes themselves. For each new project, they insisted that the project managers they hired invest some of their own money in the projects. That way, they figured, each project would be run by someone with a vested interest.
AS Cali grew, it hired its own architects, leasing agents, accountants, lawyers. Only two things stayed the same: It insisted that project managers act as equity partners. And it held its focus to northern and central New Jersey, a market the partners felt they could monitor.
And monitor they did. In 1969, responding to a regional scarcity of good office space, Cali built its first office property, 13 Commerce Drive in Cranford, N.J. In the early 1980's the Calis built housing along the relatively new Interstate 280, assuming -- correctly -- that the highway would ease the area's commuting nightmare.
Cali soon mastered the art of synergy, using its residential business as a feeder for its office business and vice versa. When it realized that many of the people moving into Cali homes were self-employed professionals commuting to Newark, Cali built office buildings closer to their homes. When it noticed that people in its office buildings had long commutes to work, it built housing nearby.
It also kept a close eye on the competition. If a potential tenant seemed to be eyeing a competing building with favor, Cali would pounce with news that the rival did not have enough security guards, or didn't have insulated glass on its windows. If the competing building was owned by a syndication or partnership, Cali would stress its hands-on personal management. If the competing building was in the control of its lenders, Cali stressed its financial stability.
"We know the area, we know our tenants, we know the competition," the elder John Cali said. "We know what to stress, when."
In fact, many Cali buildings are tangibly different from the competition. Most are energy-efficient. And many were designed with fancy atria, waterfalls, manmade lakes, parks and other amenities.
"We always tried to differentiate ourselves from competitors who specialized in dullsville," the senior John Cali said.
But Mr. Cali's taste is not universal.
"I had a tenant refuse to move into their building in Roseland because they thought the waterfall was too loud, and I've had others who say they really prefer the more staid leather-and-wood look," said Seena Stein, president of Newmark Partners, a New Jersey brokerage.
Indeed, some tenants move in despite, not because of, the design amenities. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which occupies half of 95 Christopher Columbus Drive, Cali's flagship building in Jersey City, moved in five years ago when the building was still under construction. The soaring atrium, the indoor plantings -- none of that impressed the firm.
"Because of the atrium, our technology group doesn't have a window to the west," said Gates Hawn, the financial firm's chief operating officer. "Our people are here to work, not sit in the lobby, and we don't have one customer who cares about trees."
STILL, Mr. Hawn is not looking to move out. He notes that the building is a "smart" building, where every floor is raised, and where complicated wiring and cables can be changed in an hour. The location, with its easy access to midtown and downtown Manhattan, is a major plus. And, he says, "the Calis are good, responsive landlords."
Indeed, brokers who deal with the Calis say their renewal rate is high.
"Even in the recession you just never thought, 'Oh, the poor Calis, they have all this empty space,' because they didn't," Ms. Stein said. Donald Eisen, manager of Cushman & Wakefield's New Jersey branch, reacts similarly. "Their buildings are built well and they have good tenant relations, and that's all that's important," he said.
What happens at the buildings now remains uncertain. Inevitably, tenants and brokers who are loyal to the first generation will be dealing with the second. And now that the company, through the REIT, is publicly held, Brant and John R. Cali and Thomas Rizk will be responsible not only to its tenants and its lenders, but to shareholders as well.
Culturally, that will be a sea change at Cali. After 45 years of operating privately, the company will be managing in a fishbowl, with shareholders scrutinizing every move.
The new generation professes to be unworried. "You can't allow a remote collective consciousness to destroy your ability to make decisions," said Brant Cali. But veteran Cali-watchers are waiting to see how the younger Calis and Mr. Rizk perform under the new ground rules before they make any predictions.
"The older men have stood the test of many years, but the new generation has not earned its spurs yet," Mr. Eisen said. "And until you give young people their head, you don't know what they can do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At 95 Christopher Columbus Drive in Jersey City, from left, Brant Cali, John J. Cali, Thomas Rizk. (Lenore Davis for The New York Times)
