LENGTH: 1140 words

HEADLINE: The Soup Kitchen Is Not Just a Phenomenon of the Cities

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
THE center of scenic Old Saybrook, a popular shore town that more than doubles its population in summer, is always busy on Saturdays no matter what the season. Cars pass in endless streams along both sides of its wide and divided Main Street, a pattern only broken when one veers swiftly into a just-vacated parking space. The street has an aura of late 20th-century commercial bustle and prosperity coupled with the earlier American charm of three stately churches and some homes that date to the 18th century.
It also has two soup kitchens. 
 That fact would probably amaze casual visitors to the town, and even some of its residents. The soup kitchens do not receive a great deal of publicity and certainly do not fit into a Chamber of Commerce image of the community.
Soup kitchens in Old Saybrook? Next thing you know, there will be one in Essex, the even more upscale town just up the river. As a matter of fact, there are four soup kitchens in Essex now. And another in quaint little Chester, also upriver, where some residents proudly display a bumper sticker: "Chester, We Know Where It Is." And another in Clinton, a town down the shore a piece from Old Saybrook.
The soup kitchens are modest affairs compared to those in cities like Hartford, New Haven and Bridgeport. None of them operate full time and they have clientele that differ in major respects from those in the cities. But they do illustrate a major point about life in Connecticut today: In the midst of plenty, there is also poverty.
"The people who come to us are not homeless or addicted, although we have a few who are alcoholic," said Robert P. Little. "A lot of them are just unemployed, or unemployable. Thirty percent of them are senior citizens, mostly women whose husbands did not leave them well enough off to survive without help. We have single mothers, some with many children."
And some, he said, are the people who are hurt first when the economy goes bad: the undereducated, the illiterate, the untrained, the poor who just get poorer. Towns like Old Saybrook and Old Lyme do have, he said, pockets of poverty tucked here and there, out of sight.
Mr. Little is a retired executive from the Southern New England Telephone Company. For the past two years, he has been the volunteer, unpaid chairman of Shoreline Soup Kitchens. The board is made up of four Protestant clergymen, a rabbi, six lay people and Mr. Little, who is Catholic. "We're an interfaith group and we have a simple aim. We chose to feed the hungry," he said.
Shoreline Soup Kitchens began five years ago, said Eleanor LaPlace who has been one of its leaders from the start, when First Baptist Church in Essex solicited suggestions on programs the church should undertake. The only one that survived, she said, was for a soup kitchen, to be held once a week, on the theory that some people might be hungry in a town with a reputation for affluence. "And people actually were hungry," she said. "These are the poor that people ignore because they don't see them."
The first meal served at the church only attracted seven or eight people, Mrs. LaPlace recalled. But the need was obviously there and the figures kept growing.
 
A Hot Meal Every Day
 Today, anyone who is hungry can get a hot meal every day of the week at one of the eight churches in the area that participate in the soup kitchen program: Sunday at 5 P.M. at Church of Christ in Chester, Monday at 5:30 P.M. at First Baptist in Essex, Tuesday at 5 P.M. at St. John's Episcopal in Essex; Wednesday at noon at Grace Episcopal in Old Saybrook and at United Methodist in Clinton; Thursday at 5 P.M. at Our Lady of Sorrows in Essex; Friday at noon at Trinity Lutheran in the Centerbrook section of Essex; Saturday at noon at St. John's Catholic in Old Saybrook.
About 350 meals are served in all during the week. Some people eat every day at one of churches. Some, particularly those without cars, only eat out one day of the week at the nearest participating church.
 
Distributions Made
 Saturday is the big day for the soup kitchen organization. After the meal is served in Old Saybrook at St. John's, bags of food are distributed. At this time of the year, about 200 people arrive each Saturday to get bags of food, Mr. Little said. Demand goes up radically in the heart of the winter.
No one is asked questions about need, Mr. Little said, either at the church meals or when bags of groceries are distributed. The only question is about how big a family is. Bigger families get more bags of food. "The 200 people who come each Saturday for bags of food represent 900 family members," Mr. Little said. "We distribute about $100,000 in food a year now." Forty percent is donated, by residents and local stores, he said. The other 60 percent must be paid for by church revenues.
On any Saturday at noon, the soup kitchen operation continues at the grammar school in back of St. John's Church where three rooms have been used for food storage and for meals for the past two years. The building has been mostly unused but this fall it will reopen as a parochial school. Mr. Little said he had been assured that the soup kitchen operation could stay.
People, mostly in family groups but occasionally by themselves, filter in quietly for lunch. Most have come by car, some sharing rides. Mothers with toddlers join people well into their 80's or more. All are dressed perhaps not stylishly but certainly cleanly. Certain people stand out. One is an older man, impeccably groomed, who looks as if he could be a resident of Fenwick, Old Saybrook's enclave of old money. Two little girls look as if they were dressed for a recital.
The face of the needy in Old Saybrook does not have the face of defeat of a more urban soup kitchen. It would be impossible to separate the volunteers serving food from those getting food and sometimes, indeed, they are both. "Some of the volunteers are also clients," Mr. Little said.
But he is very conscious that some people regard the Saturday meals as a demeaning experience. "Some wait outside and send their kids in for their bags of food," he said. "We try to ease people in, and then they find out that others here are in the same boat."
 
A Social Occasion
 Some seem to regard the Saturday lunch as a social occasion. Two old brothers come each Saturday from a nursing home in Essex, complaining that the food is terrible there. Children play with other children they see each week.
Mr. Little says grace, then the chatter starts. It is more like a church supper than a soup kitchen and a visitor is likely to forget the reason people are there is that they need, really need, the food. It is a quiet drama that unfolds each Saturday. And a few hundred feet away, the cars pass by in a steady stream on Main Street, in another world.

HEADLINE: County in Push to Cut Trash-Collection Need

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN 

 BODY:
WHILE public and private organizations have advocated recycling in recent years, a campaign this fall will stress waste reduction. Three meetings and conferences will be held to help individuals and businesses reduce the amount of waste they put on the curb for collection.
"There has been a terrific response to recycling and conservation efforts," said James J. Hogan, director of the County Recycling Office. "People are cooperating when they have the opportunity, but we have to move to the next level of effort and that involves an understanding of waste-generation reduction." 
 Simply put, waste-generation reduction means keeping garbage out of the waste stream completely, through a variety of methods, from composting and using durable goods to developing better shopping habits and getting residents' names removed from mailing lists. Other methods include cutting down on the size of facsimile machine cover sheets and using both sides of a piece of paper to write on.
"Waste generation reduction is a difficult concept to grasp," Mr. Hogan said. "When I speak with educated municipal officials, I sometimes observe a misinterpretation of what it is. They think if we expand the recycling program, it is waste reduction, and that is not the case. The example I use is backyard composting. If you put your leaves this fall in a compost heap, you're not putting them at the curb and the collection crew doesn't pick them up. That is waste-generation reduction."
 
Leave Clippings on Lawns
 Between January and July of this year, 31,623 tons of refuse were recycled in Westchester. The total refuse generated for this period was 351,728 tons. The county is trying to comply with the state's goal of 40 percent recycling and 10 percent waste-generation reduction by 1997. The other 50 percent is garbage that must be incinerated or otherwise disposed of.
The problem is that the amount of waste generated is increasing by about 1 percent a year, with 616,058 tons produced in the county last year while 51,361 tons were recycled.
Because 17 to 20 percent of the county's waste consists of organic matter, Mr. Hogan suggested that it can be reduced by leaving grass clippings on lawns and starting small compost piles for leaves and vegetable matter.
Individuals can eliminate potential garbage by getting their names and addresses taken off mailing lists. This can be done by writing to the Mail Preference Service, Direct Marketing Association, Post Office Box 9008, Farmingdale, N.Y. 11735. More waste can be avoided by donating old household items, furniture and cleaning to charitable organizations.
In addition to individuals, businesses will be targeted in this fall's campaign. The county recycling office has joined with the Westchester County Association, a business group, to form the Business Recycling Organization. This group will hold its first meeting on Oct. 13 at the County Center in White Plains. "The Recycling Organization is going to be an informal network of executives whose job responsibilities affect recycling and waste reduction," said Richard D. Schaab, vice president of the association.
 
Use Smaller Fax Sheets
 "We're trying to get maintenance managers and those in charge of purchasing, recycling and waste disposal to come together on a regular basis to share ideas on how to expand or start recycling and waste generation reduction programs," Mr. Schaab said, adding that he expects the group to meet four times a year.
Companies can cut down on waste by eliminating the 8-by-11-inch transmission sheets used with faxes and replacing them with 4-by-1 1/2-inch sheets. Reports can be put on both sides of a piece of paper, instead of only one. And cafeterias can replace disposable good with durable ones.
Mr. Hogan said: "This is an economic issue for both homes and businesses. Businesses have to look for every advantage in today's competitive market. By using these simple habits, they will save money on both the purchasing and waste-disposal ends."
For information on the business-recycling meeting, call the County Recycling Office at 637-3030.
On Nov. 16, the Cornell Waste Management Institute and Cooperative Extension of Westchester will hold a Train the Trainer workshop for consumers and environmental groups from the seven-county Hudson Valley region. The workshop will train volunteers on waste-prevention strategies and provide educational materials on environmentally sound shopping.
"The environmental choice is the economic choice," said Martha Shortlidge, program leader for home economics at the Cornell Extension Center in White Plains. "People have long thought that it costs more to be environmentally conscious. It is possible now to do both."
While the location of the November conference has not been chosen, those seeking more information can call Ms. Shortlidge at 285-4630.
Ways in which large organizations can save money through waste reduction will be the topic of "A Waste Wise Westchester" conference on Jan. 12 at the County Center in White Plains. In addition to companies, this conference will be for hospitals, schools, municipalities and the general public. The conference is sponsored by the county League of Women Voters, the county recycling office and the Gannett Suburban Newspapers.
As with the Recycling Organization meeting next month, the conference in January will target decision makers of those organizations and try to get them to practice waste reduction.
"We start with the fact that we produce too much garbage," said Carol Gardner, conference coordinator and president of the Hastings-on-Hudson chapter of the League of Women Voters. "But if you tell people that, they yawn. So why will they come to this conference? To save money. How can they do that? By purchasing differently. People think if they have separated their glass and papers they have done enough. But that is not the case."
For information on the January conference, call 478-7559.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Salomon's Hong Kong Hangover

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla 

 BODY:
THE derivatives meltdown of 1994 hasn't been much fun for any of the small investors who got caught in the whirlwind of what should have been solely a big players' game. Just ask the buyers of short-term bond funds who have lined up to sue managements of their "safe" mutual funds.
Better yet, talk to the investors who would never have imagined that their ultra-safe money market funds could fall below $1 a share -- "breaking the buck" in Wall Streetspeak.
But bad as those debacles may have been, few individuals felt the sting of derivatives as badly as those who used brokers in a Hong Kong office of Salomon Brothers Inc. 
 With the guidance of Salomon, customers in San Francisco, Hong Kong and Singapore purchased millions apiece in securities typically reserved for Wall Street's professional investors: inverse floaters, mortgage pass-throughs, and collateralized mortgage obligations.
Different ways to play the housing market, these complex securities rise and fall in conjunction with interest rates. When interest rates rose in February, Salomon's customers faced huge losses without the comfort of an image-conscious fund company that might provide a bailout.
But why did retail investors buy the risky stuff that wound up toppling Wall Street giants in the first place?
For one thing, Salomon told investors that the potentially volatile investments were safe. Marketing material sent to clients said that collateralized mortgage obligations were "very liquid" and that there was no market risk -- a wild claim to make about a rate-sensitive investment.
Today, a half-dozen wealthy Hong Kong investors who bought the pitch are attempting to settle with Salomon after having filed with the National Association of Securities Dealers to arbitrate against the firm. (The investors have withdrawn that claim in the meantime.)
Another four in San Francisco -- including one who borrowed on his credit cards to make the investment -- have filed a separate arbitration complaint. And an attorney for a Singapore investor was readying yet another arbitration complaint against Salomon last week when Salomon contacted the client to suggest settlement talks.
Ray Peffer, the lawyer for the San Francisco investors, estimated that $100 million in mortgage-backed securities may have been sold to retail investors through the Hong Kong office. While not all those investors would have incurred losses, Mr. Peffer questioned whether they were appropriate investments for individuals.
Robert Baker, a spokesman for Salomon, declined comment on the Singapore investor's complaints. "We won't divulge a client's confidential information in order to respond to the claims of a plaintiff's attorney," he said, referring to Jonathan Kord Lagemann, lawyer for the Singapore investor.
The complaints of the Singapore investor are of particular interest because of the timing of the trades. The investor, who requested anonymity through Mr. Lagemann, had purchased $11 million in derivatives on margin in February, and by March, was already being dunned an additional $1.2 million because the securities were under water.
But even as the Singapore investor was awaiting settlement of his trades, a Salomon executive from New York was poring over the books of the troubled Hong Kong office to better understand the firm's liability in dozens of other problem accounts containing derivatives. Mr. Lagemann contends that the executive was thus in a position to have canceled his client's pending trades or warn him about the risk he was taking.
"The Hong Kong problem," as it has become known in the halls of Salomon's New York headquarters, is worrisome enough that it has captured the attention of William Heyman, managing director of the Private Investment Division and a former director of market regulation for the Securities and Exchange Commission. Craig Palmer, a director in Mr. Heyman's department, spent months in Hong Kong, accompanied for part of that period by George Garvey of Munger Tolles & Olsen, law firm for Warren Buffett, a former chairman of Salomon, and Harold Levy, a Salomon lawyer. Mr. Baker declined to make Mr. Heyman available.
Despite their efforts at fence-mending, Salomon is still worried enough about possible repercussions that it is apparently pushing to reduce what is known as "counterparty risk" -- the risk of being stiffed by angry customers who refuse to pay their margin calls.
When the Singapore businessman wanted out of his positions, his Salomon broker suggested that he might get a better price than the one on his monthly statement by going to another brokerage firm. Morgan Stanley, in fact, found a buyer willing to pay 10 percent more than Salomon was valuing the securities. Mr. Baker said that, given the volatile markets of earlier this year, "it is not surprising that there would be significant price variation." But Mr. Lagemann believes Salomon has an incentive to low-ball the value of customers' derivatives so that it can accelerate margin calls and reduce its own financial risk as a lender to its customers.
Then again, it just may be that Salomon is so befuddled by derivatives that it simply can't determine values. In a March 7 form letter to customers, Salomon admitted that "some of the market values appearing on your statement for February 28" failed to properly factor in market declines. By April, another form letter warned clients that March's monthly statements were a "best assessment" of prices, and that customers should regard prices as "approximate."
Indeed, not even Mr. Palmer could get it right when he shipped off a two-page letter to the Singapore businessman on April 15, noting that "based on market prices at this writing, further posting of $896,000 is necessary." A week later, Mr. Palmer would be signing a corrective letter lowering the earlier values and demanding $1.069 million from the investor. It's tough to nail down a price when a stable, liquid investment neglects to act as the sales literature dictates.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Heyman, a managing director for Salomon. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: How G.E. Plays for Keeps in Diamonds

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
A LEISURELY dinner in Brussels two years ago might seem harmless enough. But next month in a courtroom in Columbus, Ohio, the Federal Government will argue that what happened there was a crucial act in an elaborate international conspiracy in violation of American antitrust laws.
The meal in question took place one January evening in 1992, when Peter Frenz, the General Electric Company's industrial diamond sales manager for Europe, sat down with Phillipe Liotier, a Belgian business executive, at the Royal Windsor Hotel. 
 Mr. Liotier worked for Diamant Boart, a company that regularly bought industrial diamonds from G.E. A routine meeting with valued customer? Perhaps, but what the Justice Department's investigators found intriguing was who owned Diamant Boart and what transpired at the dinner and afterward.
The Belgian company was owned in part by De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the South African conglomerate best known for dominating the market for the gem diamonds found in rings, necklaces and other jewelry. But De Beers is also G.E.'s largest competitor in industrial diamonds -- the rougher, gravelly stones, which are now mainly synthetic and used in everything from oil-well drill bits to high-precision cutting tools for manufacturing.
During the meal, Mr. Liotier provided Mr. Frenz with a list of upcoming De Beers price increases for industrial diamonds. The G.E. sales manager scribbled them onto a piece of hotel stationery and faxed them to the Ohio headquarters of G.E.'s diamond business.
After receiving the fax and other information about its competitor, G.E. raised its diamond prices in concert with De Beers. Since the two companies dominate the business, the prices for industrial diamonds went up worldwide.
To the Justice Department, the Brussels episode is a damning piece of evidence. To G.E., it is nothing of the kind. Their dispute will soon move to the Columbus courtroom and a trial that is expected to be one of the most far-reaching and bitterly contested criminal prosecutions in the annals of antitrust. In court, the two sides will be represented by expert trial lawyers. Yet each camp is headed by well-known personalities, one a Washington activist and the other one of corporate America's leading executives.
Anne K. Bingaman, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, has revived that unit since the start of the Clinton Administration -- a sharp break from the more laissez-faire stance taken during the Reagan-Bush years.
Her high-profile pursuit of the Microsoft Corporation ended recently with a settlement that seemed a draw at best. The software giant agreed to change some practices the Government claimed were unfair, but analysts say the settlement really will not dent Microsoft's dominance of the market for personal computer operating software.
John F. Welch Jr., the chairman and chief executive of General Electric, is one of the most respected managers in America. Recently, however, he has been stung by questions raised about his managerial acumen because of a trading scandal at the company's Wall Street subsidiary, Kidder, Peabody.
Earlier this year, Mr. Welch met with Ms. Bingaman in Washington. He tried to convince her that the Government had no case. She offered a settlement. Both left dissatisfied. So now the case goes to trial.
"The antitrust division will not tolerate anticompetitive acts by two firms who dominate their worldwide markets, or sophisticated schemes that are used to fix prices and disguise criminal activity," Ms. Bingaman said in announcing the indictment of the two companies.
For his part, Mr. Welch believes his company has been unfairly targeted. In an internal memo, he denounced the indictment as "outrageous," and he criticized it again in a recent interview.
"No one who has looked at it, other than them, thinks it has any element of criminality," Mr. Welch said in angry tones. "Look, we could have settled this case. When we have an issue, we go down and we settle up. We believe we are so right on this one."
THE antitrust case is also focusing attention on the once-quiet, profitable world of industrial diamonds -- an unglamorous but vital product necessary for doing things that range from drilling for oil to making jet fighters. For General Electric and De Beers, the business has generated a steady stream of cash, with high margins and no real competitors. At G.E., while industrial diamonds account for only a fraction of the $60 billion in annual revenues, they have been a consistent source of profits -- $167 million in the years from 1986 to 1989 alone, for example.
But in the last few years, competitors have sprung up in Germany, Japan and South Korea as others have figured out how to manufacture diamonds. So General Electric and De Beers have watched their absolute dominance gradually erode, with their market share slipping from 90 percent in 1991 to about 80 percent.
 
Aggressive Competitor Or Beyond the Pale?
 To some familiar with G.E.'s diamond operation, the question is just how far the company, with its intolerance for weak businesses, stress on hitting the numbers and Mr. Welch's absolute desire to win, has been willing to go to defend its once-secure franchise. Has G.E. simply been an aggressive competitor or did it go too far?
It has certainly been aggressive in guarding its diamond business. In a recent campaign against a foreign company suspected of using stolen G.E. technology, for example, the company began what its general counsel described as "trench warfare."
G.E. enlisted the services of everyone from private detectives who sifted through the trash of a former G.E. scientist to top American trade officials, and even former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger.
Although wide competition is new to industrial diamonds, controversy is not. During World War II, the Justice Department accused De Beers of refusing to sell the American Government enough natural diamonds for war-time weapons production, where they were used in precision grinding and cutting tools. The department also said De Beers overcharged the Government for the diamonds it did sell.
In 1945, the Justice Department filed an antitrust case against De Beers, charging the cartel with restricting distribution and fixing prices of diamonds. A judge threw out the case, concluding the United States lacked jurisdiction because De Beers conducted its business outside this country.
After the war, scientists in several countries raced to develop a way to produce man-made diamonds. Working in strict secrecy, G.E. engineers in a laboratory in Schenectady, N.Y., won the contest in 1954. Its first synthetic stones were small and discolored, too rough for the jewelry business, but they were true diamonds and their unparalleled hardness made them perfect for industrial uses.
Still smarting from the wartime shortage and concerned about Soviet weapons advances, the Eisenhower Administration clamped a lid on the technical details until 1959, when General Electric was finally allowed to file for a patent.
But the impact of the discovery was immediate at the offices of De Beers Consolidated Mines, the South African cartel that controlled every aspect of the world diamond trade. Alarmed at the threat to its monopoly, De Beers embarked on a crash program to match G.E. But the company was unable to duplicate the American alchemy.
By the early 1960's, however, De Beers was supplementing its natural diamonds with manufactured versions, too. G.E. sued De Beers for patent infringement. De Beers settled the suit by paying $8 million and royalties to license the G.E. technology. The two companies then proceeded to divide the world market into a duopoly that stood for three decades.
DE BEERS's lurking fear was that G.E. would turn its efforts to producing gem-quality diamonds, which could devastate the $4 billion-a-year gem business that generated the vast bulk of the cartel's profits.
"Among people in the diamond business, the feeling has always been that De Beers made an arrangement where G.E. would not produce gem diamonds and De Beers would not undercut G.E. in industrial diamonds," said Edward Jay Epstein, author of "The Rise and Fall of Diamonds," a book about De Beers.
G.E. and De Beers executives say there was no such agreement. After years of experimenting, the company determined that producing gem-quality diamonds was not economical, said Joyce Hergenhan, a G.E. spokeswoman.
Since the 1960's, synthetic diamonds have replaced mined diamonds for most industrial uses. Production of diamonds now outstrips mining of diamonds three to one. But gem-quality manufactured diamonds remain only an unfulfilled promise.
In the early 1970's, De Beers again attracted the attention of the Justice Department. Investigators suspected the South Africans were trying to gain control of American distributors for industrial diamonds. But the cartel again proved to be outside the reach of the Justice Department.
"We hired a solicitor to serve some papers on De Beers in South Africa and the company representative tore them up," said Joel Davidow, a Washington attorney who was a senior Justice Department lawyer at the time.
G.E. makes diamonds in Worthington, Ohio, in a single-story building surrounded by an eight-foot fence. Employees must sign confidentiality agreements not to disclose the technology. But in the summer of 1989, G.E. suspected a security breach.
The resulting drama opened on May 25. Joe Elliott, a G.E. technician, was watching television at home when his telephone rang about 9 P.M. A caller, who identified himself as Larry King, wanted to hire Mr. Elliott to oversee diamond production for an unnamed foreign manufacturer. He offered $50,000 a year and $50,000 in bonuses.
 
Bringing In The Private Detectives
 Suspicious the deal was too sweet to be legitimate, Mr. Elliott alerted his superiors. They advised him to play along to discover the name of the company, according to later court testimony, and they sought help from the Fairfax Group, a corporate investigations firm.
Under a scenario devised by Fairfax, Mr. Elliott recorded his phone calls and set up a meeting to discuss the job at the Marriott Marquis hotel in Manhattan. A private detective would accompany Mr. Elliott, posing as his lawyer and carrying a tape recorder concealed in a briefcase.
Part of the mystery was solved before the meeting. From the return address on an employment contract mailed to Mr. Elliott, the detectives discovered that Mr. King was Chien-Min Sung, the manager of G.E.'s diamond operations from 1977 until he resigned in 1984.
In mid-June, Mr. Elliott and the detective arrived at the hotel expecting to find Mr. Sung. Instead they met the president of a subsidiary of the Iljin Corporation, a major Korean manufacturing conglomerate. After some discussion, Mr. Elliott agreed to visit Korea to examine Iljin's plant before deciding on the job, although he never went.
G.E. now suspected Mr. Sung had sold its technology to Iljin. The trick was proving it. For seven weeks, private detectives sifted through trash bags left outside Mr. Sung's home in a Boston suburb. Among the garbage were documents shredded methodically into tiny strips. When painstakingly reassembled, the papers proved to be G.E. technical plans for manufacturing diamonds, according to court testimony.
G.E. lawyers had a secret meeting with a Federal judge and persuaded him to take a highly unusual step. Convinced by G.E. that any warning might cause Mr. Sung to flee, the judge approved a search warrant that allowed the company to search its former employee's home.
At 9 A.M. on Sept. 18, 1989, about 10 lawyers and private detectives arrived at the home. Mrs. Sung, who spoke little English, was the only person there. For six hours, she watched as virtually every scrap of paper was boxed up and carted off. Around noon, the searchers paused to eat lunch at her dining room table.
G.E. sued Iljin and Mr. Sung for return of its technology. It also turned over the evidence to the United States Attorney's office in Boston, leading to Mr. Sung's quick indictment for selling G.E. trade secrets to Iljin for $1 million.
William D. Crowe, Mr. Sung's attorney, argued that G.E.'s actions were intended solely to eliminate a competitor to the monopoly it shared with De Beers. But in the end, Mr. Sung struck a deal with prosecutors and pleaded guilty to one count. The Government recommended leniency, and Mr. Sung was given six months home detention.
Iljin fought the suit, arguing that it had developed much of its own technology and denying knowing Mr. Sung's plans were stolen.
G.E. responded with a campaign to pressure Iljin out of the business, an effort outlined in internal G.E. documents. A G.E. lawyer warned in one memo that Iljin had captured three big G.E. customers, with $100,000 a month in combined sales.
Even if G.E. won in court, the lawyer wrote, it faced difficulty enforcing a verdict in much of the world, where American intellectual property laws are not recognized.
Recognizing that something more was needed, G.E. took its case to Washington. The company persuaded the two top American trade officials at the time, United States Trade Representative Carla Hills and Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher, to argue its case in talks with Korea. G.E. also brought in Henry Kissinger, a consultant to the company, to warn Korean officials that they faced retaliation unless Iljin returned the technology.
"He should sound very threatening" about how the use of stolen information would threaten Korea's and Iljin's relations with the United States and G.E., Benjamin W. Heineman Jr., the G.E. general counsel, wrote in a memo.
A year ago, the civil suit went to trial in Boston. Iljin lawyer Michael B. Keating accused G.E. of trying to wipe out a competitor and G.E. lawyers countered that Iljin should have known the technology was stolen. The jury agreed with G.E., and last January the judge banned Iljin from making diamonds for seven years as punishment. Enforcing the ban remained problematic and, after Iljin filed an appeal, the companies reached a settlement in which Iljin will pay a licensing fee to G.E. and continue producing diamonds.
 
Origins of a Criminal Investigation
 It was Edward J. Russell, once one of G.E.'s 127 corporate vice presidents worldwide and the head of its diamond division, who helped to put General Electric at the opposite end of the table from the Government.
After record profits in the late 1980's under Mr. Russell, division earnings flagged in 1990 and 1991. In late 1991, Mr. Russell was fired on orders from Mr. Welch.
Mr. Russell responded by filing a lawsuit against the company claiming he was dismissed for complaining about price fixing by G.E. and De Beers. The F.B.I. and Justice Department opened an investigation in Columbus, near the G.E. plant.
THOUSANDS of G.E. documents were subpoenaed, yet the inquiry was hampered because many witnesses and records were in Europe.
But the F.B.I. was not deterred. In the spring of 1993, agents learned that an official of a De Beers affiliate was attending the Master's golf tournament in Georgia as a G.E. guest. After the tournament, the executive was taken into custody, flown to Columbus and put before the grand jury.
In early February of 1994, the Justice Department was about to indict G.E. and Mr. Welch went to Washington to argue his case before Ms. Bingaman. He said G.E. and De Beers were fierce competitors and he described Mr. Russell as a disgruntled executive fired for poor performance.
Mr. Welch said later that he rejected a plea bargain offer and he left the meeting believing G.E. would be indicted -- as it was a few days later.
Mr. Welch had better luck with Mr. Russell. On the eve of the indictment, the two men met in Cincinnati with their lawyers. Settlement talks had been under way since January. Finally Mr. Russell agreed to dismiss his suit and sign an affidavit swearing he had no "personal knowledge" that G.E. had fixed prices or broken any other law. His lawyer signed a similar statement.
 
A Final Bid To Stop Indictment
 Still hoping to stop the indictment, G.E. faxed the surprise Russell statement to the Justice Department that night. By this time, however, the inquiry had gone beyond the initial allegations and the Government felt its evidence was strong enough to support criminal charges.
G.E. and De Beers Centenary A. G., a De Beers affiliate in Switzerland, were indicted on Feb. 17, along with Mr. Frenz, the G.E. sales manager, and Mr. Liotier, who has since left Diamant Boart. The basic allegation was that G.E. and De Beers, through Mr. Frenz and Mr. Liotier, swapped information in 1991 and 1992 in a scheme to coordinate price increases. One of the central acts in the alleged conspiracy was the January 1992 dinner the two men had in Brussels.
THE Government and G.E. differ sharply over the role played by Mr. Liotier. The Government claims that he was exchanging the information on behalf of De Beers, with Diamant Boart as a convenient subterfuge. But G.E. argues that Mr. Liotier was operating solely as an executive of Diamant Boart and that there was no agreement with De Beers to fix prices.
"All the contacts we had with Liotier were contacts with him as our customer, Diamant Boart," said Dan K. Webb, a former United States Attorney in Chicago, who represents G.E. "We never believed that Diamant Boart was acting for De Beers. And if Liotier is not an agent of De Beers, there is no crime here."
De Beers also has denied wrongdoing, but it will not contest the charges in court. "We are not involved in the mainstream of American business in any sense at all, so we won't be appearing in court in Ohio," Brian Cullingworth, an official with De Beers in Johannesburg, said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Frenz, a German, and Mr. Liotier, who is French, are not expected to appear in court. Mr. Frenz was questioned for six days in London last July by attorneys for both sides and his videotaped testimony will be played. His lawyer, Carl S. Rauh, said Mr. Frenz denied any wrongdoing. Attempts to reach Mr. Liotier and his lawyer were unsuccessful.
While the other defendants will be absent, General Electric will be there. Said Mr. Welch, "We want to go all the way with this one."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1393 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: September 11 - 16

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Week's Scorecard: No Inflation, 2; Inflation, 1; Baseball, 0
This gets dizzying. Just a week ago, the inflation cops were blowing their whistles again after an unexpected jump in producer prices. But then came last week's report that consumer prices were nice and tame, and everyone quickly said, "Never mind." And after a second batch of data reinforced the low-inflation script -- a report by a regional Federal Reserve Bank, a drop in jobless claims, a rise in business inventories -- the stock market gleefully took off, with the Dow industrials hitting their highest level since this whole merry-go-round started with that first Federal Reserve rate increase on Feb. 3. It was a short party, though, because the next day came word of a sharp rise in industrial production, the inflation warnings were trotted out again, and the Dow slumped. But this week, who knows? Perhaps these reports should be allowed to age so people can sip them a little more soberly. 

Immigrants: Now, Some Facts
The reason Cuba and Haiti get so much attention is simple: we have a morbid fear of having our economy eroded by a flood of immigrants. But an Urban Institute study out last week presumes to replace hysteria with facts. For one thing, in the seven states with the most illegal immigrants, those immigrants pay $1.9 billion in state and local taxes. True, they cost states even more, for education and the like, but those taxes are often conveniently forgotten when states wail for Federal relief. Another note: immigrants overall, legal and otherwise, are a plus for the economy.
 
And the Earth Still Spins
This will be interesting. Some diehard baseball fans, twitching in their sweaty recliners in the agonies of withdrawal, surely predicted civilization's fiery end if -- yes, we've got to say it -- there was no World Series. So now we'll see, now that team owners have spoken the unspeakable -- that for the first time since 1904, you'll be able to ride an elevator at World Series time without hearing some grim-faced soul say "What a play!" or "They blew it!" Did baseball itself blow it? Yes, everyone lost millions -- the clubs, the players, the baseball-card makers, the hot dog vendors. But what if fans kick the habit and don't show up in the spring? Back to the sandlot.
 
Banking Enters the Big Mac Age
It had to happen. You can buy identical Big Macs anywhere in the country -- and much of the world, for that matter. In USA Today, the nation's news is all one, and state lines exist only as adornments on the weather map. But banking got left behind somehow, stuck in horse-and-buggy-and-green-eyeshade days, with state lines remaining barriers to many banking operations. Last week, though, the Senate passed a bill allowing banks to operate branches in any state. President Clinton called it a "historic step -- one that has been delayed for much too long." Smaller banks that could be hurt by the bill got one concession: for now, big banks must buy a bank in a state before launching an invasion.
 
DRIVERS WALK! (Just Kidding.)
On Sept. 8, if the averages held, more than 100 people were killed in auto accidents nationwide. They got no coverage in the national press. If others, in reaction to this appalling carnage, refused to drive the following day, this too got no coverage. That same day, 132 people were killed in a USAir crash near Pittsburgh; this got a lot of national press. And last week, throughout the land, fears of flying gushed to the surface: trips were canceled, long drives replaced flights, travelers avoided Pittsburgh altogether. How to explain it? That's a tough one.
 
He Could Sue (If He Had Cash)
Suppose you thought someone had swindled you out of millions, got caught and then asked you to advance cash for his legal bills. That's the problem Kidder, Peabody faces with Joseph Jett, a bond trader accused of being adept at pulling millions of phony rabbits out of hats. The trouble is, Kidder has a bylaw obligating it to pay those bills. And it is paying bills for two executives who were found, in its own inquiry, to have been grossly negligent for not keeping tabs on Mr. Jett. It appeared last week, though, that Kidder would close its checkbook to Mr. Jett -- perhaps, some said, to try to starve Mr. Jett out and keep him from dragging Kidder through any more legal mud. But there is that bylaw.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Britain Tries a U.S. Tactic
Europe has been lagging behind the United States in bouncing in and out of recession, but it still seems to be moving through the same cycles. Last week -- in a move reminiscent of the Federal Reserve's actions early this year -- Britain raised a key interest rate for the first time since 1989, following similar moves in Italy and Sweden. And the reason rang a loud bell: to squash inflation without hindering growth. But here's where Europe diverges from America's pattern: unemployment remains near record levels.
 
Bayer Goes Home
First the Berlin wall, now Bayer aspirin: things are gradually reverting to old ways. It was a Bayer chemist who developed aspirin in 1897, but during World War I the United States confiscated Bayer's American aspirin business, later selling it to Sterling for $5.3 million. For years afterward, Bayer struggled to get it back, and last week it finally did so, by a circuitous route: SmithKline bought Sterling's over-the-counter drug lines from Kodak, but then sold the Bayer business to its original owner for $1 billion. The rain on this homecoming parade, though, is that Bayer is regaining its birthright at a time when aspirin has been shoved to a corner of the shelf by Tylenol, Advil and their no-name cousins.
 
COMPANIES
 
Suddenly, Borden's Popular
Why would anyone want Borden, which has done so badly in recent years? That's what Wall Street asked itself last week when Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts made a $2 billion deal to buy it. But for Kohlberg, Kravis, the reason soon became clear: as part of the complex deal, it will dump much of its stake in RJR Nabisco. But then, in another surprise, came talk of a new bidder: Paul Kazarian. Mr. Kazarian, though, may have trouble getting financing, because even though he's a turnaround whiz, he's also been called irrational and erratic -- reportedly the reason he was ousted as head of Sunbeam-Oster last year.
 
Stepping Off the Treadmill
It shouldn't be called strange, said Stephen Friedman, that "I don't want to spend half of my day on the telephone and the other half on an airplane." But Wall Street doesn't get it when someone fairly young, who's on top of the game, bails out. So there was surprise last week when Mr. Friedman, at the tender age of 56, descended from a Wall Street pinnacle, as head of Goldman Sachs. There were inevitable murmurs that he was leaving because profits were plunging. But there was no clear reason not to accept what Mr. Friedman said, that the job was "more than a little tiring."
 
Time Inc. Opens the Club Doors
In the beginning there was Henry Luce, who started Time magazine in 1923 and was its guiding force for decades. Only three other people have run Time Inc.'s magazines, all of them insiders. But today's corporate realities often make such inbreeding obsolete -- even the company itself has melded personalities with a stranger, becoming Time Warner. So last week Time Inc. snapped that insider tradition by naming Norman Pearlstine, former executive editor of The Wall Street Journal, as editor in chief. But does this break with the past, an open secret for weeks now, portend basic changes at Time? No, says Mr. Pearlstine, "magazines as we know them" will remain Time's core.
 
Nobody Pushes United Around
After that skinny kid called Southwest Airlines charged into the playground and stole everyone's marbles, the big guys just stood there gaping. No more. One of the big guys, United, has rolled up its sleeves and challenged the kid to a one-on-one. In California -- a corridor almost twice as busy as Washington-Boston -- United is taking on Southwest at its own game: low fares, fast boarding, keep the planes moving. One United innovation: board window seats first, keep people moving. And one frill Southwest lacks: reserved seats. Now, the sparks should fly -- and air travel may never be the same.

PUB-DATE: September 18, 1994

SECTION: Section 13; Page 13; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1305 words

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
Enough, Already!

BYLINE: By JILL EISENSTADT; Jill Eisenstadt wrote "From Rockaway" and "Kiss Out," two novels set in the boroughs outside Manhattan.

 BODY:
SHE'S the gum crackin', chain-smokin' Bay Ridge/Woodside/Richmond/Woodlawn hairdresser/secretary who tells it like it is and don't take no crap from no one. Only her best friend has bigger breasts and hoop earrings, a thicker accent and make-up job. Only her Pops gets to call her his "little girl" and slap her can when she serves his eats. Her mother makes a good sauce, the best, and crosses herself frequently. Her boyfriend? Well, all's he ever wants is to hang out with his loser buddies: flashy mobsters, unemployed home boys or blue-collar toughs.
Sure, she loves him but, ya know, like she's got dreams as symbolized by The Bridge, which looms in the near distance, majestically back lit. It's her ticket outta this lousy neighborhood, her chance to finally become someone. Could it be that underneath her helmet of hair lies a C.E.O.'s brain with the potential for appreciating literature and painting? Or will she just win Lotto and get to shop at Saks? It's the genuine article, The Outerborough Chick. Coming soon to a theater near you! 
 Wait a minute, I think I've seen that movie. Annabella Sciorra? Rosie Perez? She calls off the wedding and dates the college professor? Or is it that other one, where she gets pregnant and the two possible dads smash up the pizzeria? I'm confused. I'm amazed. I'm amused by the way Hollywood portrays us New York City females if we happen to live outside Manhattan.
 
1. WE'RE COMIC
 Whaddya need speech class for, ya tawk fine. -- Cindy to Tess in "Working Girl"
Yes, many of us come from large, loud ethnic families and have learned to squawk rapidly to be heard. But this accent has been so played up that whenever I tell anyone I'm from Brooklyn and Queens, they say, "But you don't have that funny accent," or more interestingly, "But you're not funny."
Even if I did have "that funny accent" (which, for the record, differs from borough to borough) would it necessarily follow that I was as funny as "Funny Girl" and "Arthur" would suggest? Are we, as a group, really funnier than women from other places? I don't think so. I've seen only two truly sorrowful female outerborough characters -- Annette in "Saturday Night Fever" and Vicky in "Raging Bull" -- and a third who actually manages to rise or sink beyond sadness to the level of tragic. Then again, this third, Tralala, the gang-raped prostitute in "Last Exit to Brooklyn," was created by a novelist, Hubert Selby. He'd never buy the myth that . . .
 
2. WE'RE ALL ITALIAN
 Out of the roughly six million people who live in the boroughs, a scant 10 percent have their roots back in the boot. But you'd certainly get a different impression after seeing "Mr. Wonderful," "Angie," "Moonstruck," "Raging Bull," "29th Street," "Cookie," "Married to the Mob," "Wise Guys," "Queens Logic," "True Love," "My Cousin Vinny," "The Wanderers" and "Mac" to name a few. Maybe what we have is a disproportionate number of Italian-American directors or screen writers. Certainly, what we have is an audience that never tires of Mafia hit men and large gaudy weddings. Of course, there's Woody Allen, but usually only mothers dwell in his cinematic outerboroughs. (Even when she's a disembodied head in the sky above Manhattan, we know she's really back in Midwood). Of course, there's Spike Lee, but even he highlights Italians in films like "Do the Right Thing" and "Jungle Fever." And I'm not sure he's entirely innocent when it comes to perpetuating the idea that . . .
 
3. WE'RE CRUDE
 To his credit, Spike Lee questions and plays with this stereotype. The women in "She's Gotta Have It" neither speak in shrieks nor dress clownishly. There's a musician, an artist, even, gasp, a lesbian. The film's protagonist, Nola, is sleeping with three men. But instead of being branded a slut, she's celebrated as liberated. Instead of worrying about her reputation (another outerborough theme), she's proud to thoughtlessly pursue sex. In short, she's a man in a woman's body, which is to my mind just another way (albeit an updated and roundabout one) of portraying the outerborough chick as crude, as macho.
This is not to say coarse, tacky outerborough chicks don't exist. Growing up in Rockaway our favorite sport was ridiculing the Canarsie girls who'd sashay down to the beach in six-inch heels, bikinis and belly chains. We called them "hitters" (for hitting on our boyfriends, I guess). Now they're more commonly labeled The Bridge and Tunnel Crowd. But don't forget, three of those bridges and tunnels lead to Jersey. Visibility a majority does not make. Some of us might even take issue with the notion that . . .
 
4. WE'RE BLUE COLLAR
 I know, I know, this is only movieland. Viewers expect their New York City professionals to live in fabulous uptown doorman buildings. Their writers in picturesque Greenwich Village squalor. It doesn't matter if all the painters actually live in Greenpoint, the Wall Streeters in Brooklyn Heights, the writers in Park Slope, the lawyers in Forest Hills. We're comforted by the gossipy manicurist, entertained by the foul-mouthed, hard-luck waitress;it's what we're used to. Why complicate a simple Mafia movie by giving the wife an interior life or, God forbid, career aspirations? If by chance, one of our ilk should have a glimmer of ambition, class or talent it's artistically superior if . . .
 
5. WE'RE ASPIRING TO LIVE IN MANHATTAN
 You have no idea how it changes right over there across the river. It's different. It's beautiful. People are beautiful. Offices are beautiful. Lunch hours are beautiful, too. -- Stephanie in "Saturday Night Fever"
 In fact, I (and most of my friends out here) had similar delusions. But after 5 or 10 years of cramped, expensive apartments, we came to our senses and retreated to a saner, greener, more spacious existence. Hopefully, it won't prove true that . . .
 
6. WE'RE ABUSED AND ABUSIVE AND IT SHOWS
 They looked beat up. And the stuff they wore was thrown together and cheap, a lot of pantsuits and double knits. And they talked about how rotten their kids were and about beating them with broom handles and leather belts but that the kids still wouldn't listen. -- Karen in "Goodfellas."
I have no idea how accurate this image is but it's certainly been around a long time. After all, what's a Mafia movie without at least one wife-battering scene? Would we still laugh with Ralph Kramden if he didn't threaten to send Alice to the moon? Early in "Raging Bull," Jake La Motta's first wife is browbeaten for cooking the steak wrong. In"Saturday Night Fever," Annette is gang raped for worshiping the disco king. In "Goodfellas," Karen gets a lamp thrown at her for confronting her husband's infidelities. True, we put up a fight but . . .
 
7. WE'RE NEVER HEROINES
 "Working Girl" is the one of the few exceptions -- if you consider lying your way to the top noble behavior. Otherwise, you have to go way back to that old classic, "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn."
But it's worth it, if only for a glimpse of where our image originated. For like any cliche it has its basis in the truth.
Kate, the tactless, uneducated wife of a charming but unstable alcoholic makes no apologies -- "My kids are gonna be somebody if I gotta turn into granite rock to make 'em." Her hardness may take its toll -- "Funny, sometime, you forget you are a woman" -- but it also insures the family's financial survival just as her sister, Sissy, though tacky and crude, uplifts it through humor. The Tree is really no different than The Bridge, a symbol for her daughter, Francie, of a brighter, more artistic future. But like all the outerborough chicks who succeed her, she's smart enough to know that the first requirement for making it out of the neighborhood is to tell it like it is and take no crap from no one.

LENGTH: 1287 words

HEADLINE: Swissair Plies the Unfriendly Skies of United Europe

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ZURICH

 BODY:
For Swissair, based in this trim city in the heart of Europe, the biggest problem these days seems to be how to become a European airline. And its European dilemma helps explain why, despite a stellar reputation for punctuality, service and tasteful cuisine, Swissair is losing money in its airline business.
Even though its flights are often filled, Swissair had a pretax loss of about $50 million during the first half of this year on its air service, analysts estimate. Only Swissair's profitable hotels and catering divisions enable the company as a whole to remain profitable. Last year, it reported earnings of $46 million on operating revenues of $4.9 billion. 
 Like many airlines trying to prosper in today's increasingly competitive skies, Swissair has embarked on a cost-cutting program. Jobs are being cut, perhaps as many as 4,000 of a total payroll of 25,000 workers. Services like food and aircraft cleaning are being contracted out. The goal is to bolster productivity by trimming labor costs, which now amount to 36 percent of revenues, estimates Susanne Borer, an analyst at Bank J. Vontobel & Company in Zurich. By contrast, industry analysts say airlines with a handle on labor costs are in the 25 to 30 percent range.
Yet streamlining operations may do little good in the long run unless Swissair can find a solution to its biggest challenge: gaining a secure niche in the rapidly-changing European market. The Swiss voters certainly haven't helped their flagship airline. Last December, they decided by a margin of 51 to 49 percent to reject membership in the 11-nation European Union. So Swissair risks being left on the sidelines in a revolution that is unfolding among the airlines within the European Union.
The European upheaval is a deregulation of air travel similar to the overhaul that began in the United States in the 1980's. It is an evolution that will steadily lift barriers until Jan. 1, 1997, the target date for fully open skies in the European markets. It means carriers can fly into more markets, more often and offer lower ticket prices to lure travelers.
Already, airlines from the European Union's 11 countries are moving into markets once banned to them. British Airways, Europe's most profitable airline, has established subsidiaries in France and Germany, and announced direct flights from Rome to Paris.
Last month Germany's Lufthansa announced a package of cut-rate one-way fares, some as low as $65, to match those offered by British Air on flights between German cities. Italy's Alitalia has forged a link with British Midland, in what appears to be a bid to bring the battle to British turf.
Another byproduct of the deregulation has been to shift the ownership of many European carriers from governments to private hands. With privatization has come a new breed of more aggressive business managers.
Britain led the way in the 1980's, selling shares in British Airways. This fall, Lufthansa will raise fresh capital on the stock market in the first of several transactions aimed at reducing the German Government stake to a minority one by the end of this year. Alitalia and Air France are next in line for privatization.
For a carrier like Swissair, the European Union's deregulation is a twin threat. It means that the Swiss airline is not only facing a more vigorous group of competitors, but also that it cannot compete on an equal footing. The new opportunities from opening the skies are available only to the 11 members of the European Union club. Barriers are not so much being dismantled as moved, from national borders to the boundaries of the European Union.
And the European Union states tend to act as one when keeping carriers from nonmember nations out, but not when letting other carriers in. This means that Switzerland must negotiate air traffic agreements with individual governments, all of them fiercely protective of their skies, in addition to reaching an accord with the Union. The least competitive airlines have been particularly effective in lobbying the European Union in Brussels to retain extra barriers against outsiders.
"The European Union has taken a step forward, and today restrictions are becoming the exception," said Paul Maximilian Muller, an executive vice president at Swissair. "But the weaker carriers have a tendency to request as many exceptions as possible."
There are also real doubts about how serious Brussels is about fostering free-market competition in the skies. National emotions, as well as economics, are involved. Will national governments allow the role of national carriers to be scaled back, as competition sorts winners from losers? Will they let one or two airlines fold?
"If you take an American airline, its role is to produce a profit for shareholders by carrying passengers," said Keith McMullan, the director of Avmark, a London-based airline consulting company. "In Europe, it's a combination of things, often linked to history."
The crunch confronting Europe's weaker carriers is illustrated by Alitalia, whose six straight years of losses, coupled with a growing net debt now set at about $1.2 billion, have pushed the airline to the brink of bankruptcy. Renato Riverso, a 60-year-old former I.B.M. executive who was installed by the Government in February to turn Alitalia around, says the airline is "structurally organized to produce losses."
Alitalia is not alone. Over the last nine months, the European Union has approved government aid totaling $7.4 billion to state-run carriers, including Portugal's TAP, Olympic in Greece, and Ireland's Aer Lingus. The biggest chunk, however, $3.7 billion, went to Air France, the ailing French airline that went into 1994 with $6.2 billion of debt, having failed to turn a profit since 1992.
Government subsidies to ease the adjustment to harsh competition are a luxury not available to Swissair, which is privately owned.
TO succeed in the long run, Swissair must gain greater access to markets in Europe. Even its strategic alliances with Delta in the United States and Singapore Airlines for Asian routes depend on Swissair having a strong European base. For Swissair to remain an attractive partner, it must be able to deliver markets in Europe.
"We're convinced that the future belongs to efficient carriers that can avail themselves of sufficient market influence," explained Mr. Muller of Swissair. "We're too small here in Switzerland. After all, even Milan belongs to Italy."
But efforts to extend its reach in Europe, much beyond the Alps, have so far faltered on national interests.
Last year, a project called Alcazar intended to link Swissair with three other European carriers -- KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Austrian Airlines and Scandinavian Airlines System -- collapsed after national governments failed to agree on a headquarters site and on the apportionment of the job cuts that would have made the merger pay off.
This year, during the summer, Swissair shares were buoyed by the news that the airline was negotiating with Sabena to acquire a 49.5 percent minority stake in the Belgian national airline by buying a 37.5 percent stake now held by Air France, plus 12 percent now in the hands of several Belgian financial companies. Sabena is now 62 percent Government-controlled.
Yet with Air France in the midst of a major overhaul, discussions to disentangle the various holdings are stalled, Mr. Muller said. In the meantime, Swissair is talking with other airlines, including Alitalia, Austrian Airlines, Olympic in Greece, in an effort to enhance its position in Europe.
"But at the moment there are no negotiations," Mr. Muller said. "There are a series of problems of a European nature to resolve."
