SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3462 words

HEADLINE: Inspiration, Frustration, You're in Business!

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
INSIDE a rumbling, clanking factory in a rundown quarter of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, the air is fragrant with peanut oil as Dana Sinkler runs through the creation of a typical Terra Chip. In the hushed refrigeration room, crates of earth-dusted parsnips and well-traveled taro roots await their trip to the slicer. Once sliced, they are bathed in boiling fat, tossed about the salting and seasoning division, and sent through a series of mixing and measuring points before being sealed inside colorful foil bags that will be trucked as far away as California or as nearby as Balducci's to satisfy the public's craving for non-potato chips -- a market that Mr. Sinkler and his partner, Alex Dzieduszycki, seem to have created with their own hands.
This quick walk down the line is about as close as the proud but fearful partners will let an outsider get to the production cycle of the Terra Chip itself (trade secrets, hypercompetitive market and all that). But they are eager to talk in detail about the development of the Terra Chip business, and about their journey through the tangle of inspiration and frustration that New York bestows on companies that come to life here. 
 "It's been the best education in business," is the way Mr. Dzieduszycki puts it.
Four years into that education, theirs is the somewhat accidental success story of a product that just cruised into a nice little marketing niche: Thanks to the public preoccupation with things healthy, and the easy association of what's healthy and what's "natural," these deep-fried, hardly low-calorie root-vegetable slices (which New Yorkers frequently mispronounce as "Taro Chips" or even "Terra Cotta") have become widely perceived, and emulated by several competitors, as junk-food alternatives that are good for you.
The creators started out simply, two men with a mandoline, seeking to distinguish themselves in the Darwinian world of fancy-food catering. Now they lead a $10 million company with 45 workers, turning out 5,000 to 10,000 pounds of chips a day that are sold in six-ounce portions for a lofty $3.99 (recommended retail). And they envision a nation -- even an entire planet -- in which every supermarket has a vegetable-chip section, dominated by theirs, in the snack food aisle.
Along the way, they have been alternately propelled and pummeled by the city, an erratic third party that has acted as a generator and disseminator and threatened at times to turn into their terminator.
To be sure, this still-fledgling entry in the big-time snack-food industry would not exist without New York. The city's dense mix of rich and poor, ethnic and mainstream, sophisticated and mundane, brought the company's creators together, furnished the initial market for their product and helped mold an image that has made it a success far beyond the five boroughs. At the same time, though, the city drove the owners up the wall from time to time and now looms as a potential threat to their continued operations here.
Just how many small businesses start up here each year, and how many survive, is not known. But the makers of Terra Chips are in the vanguard of what economists say is a measured manufacturing renaissance in a city that has lost more than two-thirds of its factory jobs in the last 30 years.
Many of these new businesses are spinoffs from service industries like publishing and restaurants, explained Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. A study he recently completed also found that small manufacturers had a better rate of survival in New York than in the suburbs or the rest of the nation, mostly because of the relative ease of finding a market here.
New York, said Hugh O'Neill, an economic development consultant, "is simultaneously the best and the worst place to do business. You have the greatest opportunities here, but you also have some of the greatest hassles to overcome."
 
Starting Up

In the beginning, there was Restaurant Lafayette on East 56th Street, a now-closed showcase for Jean-Georges Vongerichten, whose Asian-infused classical cooking drew raves from critics and resumes from aspiring chefs like Mr. Dzieduszycki (pronounced JED-due-SCHITZ-key) and Mr. Sinkler. They started work at Restaurant Lafayette within a few months of each other in 1987 and worked together on the fish station and elsewhere in the kitchen.
Mr. Dzieduszycki -- who is 34 years old, grew up in Ann Arbor, Mich., and trained in Europe after graduating from the American Culinary Federation -- left first. He was followed a few months later by Mr. Sinkler, also 34, a native of Charleston, S.C., who studied at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y.
In March 1989, they decided to go into business together as Dana Alexander Inc., a catering company aimed at big spenders and their entertaining habits.
They were determined to be different.
"There are millions of catering companies, so to compete, you have to be special," Mr. Sinkler said. "Every party you'd go to, without fail, you'd see crudites and dip, crudites and dip."
Both chefs had learned to make fried vegetable chips at Restaurant Lafayette. Now, in pursuit of an alternative to crudites and dip, they began experimenting with various vegetable chips, with various levels of success. Beets were too sugary and lacked "vascular integrity"; rutabagas were no better. Taro worked especially well and could be colored with beet juice to make a highly desired red chip. They scraped and sliced the vegetables themselves and cooked them painstakingly in a wok.
For inspiration, they explored Asian greengroceries in Chinatown and Hispanic markets in East Harlem. What ended up as Terra Chips is a mosaic of international vegetables -- yuca, batata (a kind of tuber), parsnip, sweet potato, taro and beet-colored taro -- that are largely ignored by American manufacturers.
Mr. Dzieduszycki recalls what happened when they put out the chips at a Christmas party in 1989: "Forty people devoured a basket in seconds flat. It was just rather obvious that we had something there that deserved more attention than we were giving it."
 
Name That Chip
 For one thing, there was the matter of a name. It came from Willi Jones, a singer and Mr. Sinkler's wife at the time. "Terra," Mr. Sinkler explained. "Of the earth."
Then, in September 1990, without ever really looking for retail clients, they landed a big one: Saks Fifth Avenue. "If we could come up with five cases a day, that was great," Mr. Sinkler recalled. "But then Saks placed an order for 50 cases."
Terra Chips were in the mainstream; now they had to be mass-produced.
A few months earlier, Mr. Sinkler and Mr. Dzieduszycki had leased a 1,200-square-foot factory space at 410 East 13th Street, between First Avenue and Avenue A, to keep up with the demand for their catering. It was set up for food products; it had been used to make cheese sticks. Now, they shelved the catering business and invested $50,000 in the space, devoting half to offices and half to production. Mr. Dzieduszycki recalls the neighborhood as convulsed with crack dealing.
But the chips took off. Packaged in a silvery foil bag, they were labeled with a sticker that featured line drawings of the chips. Back then, the mix included lotus root (since dropped because it was too expensive) and cost $8.99 for an eight-ounce bag.
The company had no advertising budget (and still doesn't, Mr. Dzieduszycki says), but the chips -- eaten in restaurants and at parties, in club dining rooms and at gallery openings -- began to generate interest on their own. When they did try to promote them with demonstrations at department stores and food markets, they focused not on nutritional advantages but on social ones.
"We've always tried to promote them as a wonderful product for entertaining," Mr. Dzieduszycki said. "You open the bag and pour the chips out and you've got an instant conversation piece."
Part of the appeal, to be sure, was a widespread misconception that they are healthful, which can be attributed, at least partly, to a convergence of the natural-food and fancy-food markets.
"We don't make any claims of being a health food," said Jack Acree, a former lifeguard who joined the company in 1990 as sales director and now owns 1 percent of its stock. "But we are all natural. No preservatives or additives."
And, Mr. Sinkler pointed out, they are healthier than potato chips: The fat content, for example, is 7 grams an ounce, compared with 10 for Wise potato chips; the same portion contains 70 milligrams of sodium, as compared with 190 for Wise's chips.)
Meantime, Terra Chips were also thought to be very cool, very New York -- in part because of price, in part because of packaging and in part just because they are different.
Nadia Donato, a spokeswoman for the Royalton, a midtown hotel that stocks one-ounce bags of Terra Chips in its minibars, said: "Our hotel is very up to date and into everything, and Terra Chips is pretty much top of the line and up to date."
Mr. Acree added: "We had a clientele that could support that kind of price. And people would come through the city, buy our chips, go home and we'd get calls from store owners in Shaker Heights, Ohio, asking, 'Can we get your product?' "
 
A Big Problem

By 1991, the partners needed more space. They searched the city and settled on an old Greenpoint pickle factory that already had refrigeration and other costly equipment. That October, they signed a lease for 9,500 square feet.
Then they hit a real hurdle. The high-pressure gas-fired equipment they had bought required an unusual gas line: two pounds of pressure and 1.1 million B.T.U.'s of volume. They were sold a $10,000 piece of equipment known as a booster, designed to enable them to use a regular gas line.
"They never should have made the sale," Mr. Dzieduszycki said, explaining that the company, Eclipse Combustion, had sold them a machine that was not approved for use in New York City.
A back-and-forth ensued between Dana Alexander, the city's Department of Buildings, Brooklyn Union Gas and Eclipse. And that discussion led to expensive delays. In all, the application and approval process took from April 1992 to November of that year. In the end, an entire new gas line was installed, and the booster was relegated to the dustbin of chipmaking.
A spokesman for the Buildings Department, Vahe Tiryakian, said that most of the delay came from Dana Alexander, which had to submit reports and other paper work. The gas line itself took about three months to approve and install, said Bob Loftus, a spokesman for Brooklyn Union Gas.
"We're here for public safety," Mr. Tiryakian said, adding that efforts were under way to eliminate some of the paperwork that clogs his bureaucracy.
Mr. Moss of New York University believes that such processes contribute even more to the demise of small businesses in the city than high taxes do. "The greatest single burden firms face are the regulatory hassles," he said, listing environmental, transportation and building-code requirements as chief among them.
To Mr. Dzieduszycki, "the city's criteria are correct as far as safety is concerned." But, he added, "even our architect didn't know how to answer half these questions."
While the partners waited for the city to approve their equipment, orders kept coming in. They converted the Manhattan office space to production, and brought as much other work as they could to Brooklyn.
"We were cooking and packaging on 13th Street," Mr. Dzieduszycki recalled. "We had a little office on 11th Street, and then I was over in Brooklyn, trying to get the place on line and get through all these logistical issues. We knew in the back of our minds that the competition was going to be beating on our door any minute. It was very, very stressful."
It turned out to be a good thing that the new factory was just across the East River from the original one.. At one point, vegetables were being sliced in Brooklyn and trucked to Manhattan, fried there and driven back to Brooklyn for distribution.
To help finance the expansion, Dana Alexander raised capital by selling 5 percent of itself to "friends and family," said Mr. Sinkler, who is the company president. (He and Mr. Dzieduszycki, the vice president, share the other 94 percent equally.) The partners also looked into getting money and tax breaks from various city programs, but they were told that they didn't qualify, since they had been operating their factory for less than two years.
"We just never really fit the bill exactly, and it was difficult to get the information about the programs and difficult to get the answers to your questions," Mr. Dzieduszycki said. "You have to know how to work the system."
In May 1992, the company was approved for a $125,000 loan from the State Urban Development Corporation at an interest rate of 1 percent for the first year, followed by 4 percent for the remaining three to five years of the loan. This was at a time when commercial rates were 8 or 9 percent. But it was 17 months from when they first applied before the money showed up, Mr. Sinkler said, glowering.
Steve Vitoff, a spokesman for the development corporation, said nine months elapsed between the approval and the awarding of the loan, because of the way the program, known as Small and Medium-Sized Business Assistance, is set up. Approval meant that the partners could go to a commercial lender and get a loan, at commercial rates, with state backing. The state loan was then used to repay the commercial lender.
"Basically, they would have received the loan upon satisfactory completion of the construction," he said, calling the loan "an excellent example of how this process is supposed to work." However, he added: "These programs are under consistent review with extensive input from business people on how to expedite and accelerate them. It's an important and legitimate goal."
The company also borrowed $150,000 from Citibank and has a $250,000 line of credit, which it tries not to use, Mr. Dzieduszycki said. He would not say how much was raised in teh stock sale.
Finally, last November, Dana Alexander completed its move. It has grown from 17 to 45 workers and supervisors; everyone who was employed in Manhattan made the move. They arrive in staggered shifts starting at 5 A.M.; work stops around 7 P.M. The workers, many of them from the neighborhood, include Poles, Dominicans and Chinese. They wear white uniforms and are paid a minimum of $6 per hour. They have paid holidays and health insurance.
As a souvenir of the company's maddening move, Dana Alexander is suing Eclipse Combustion, now known as Eclipse Inc., which is based in Rockford, Ill. The partners are seeking $590,000 to cover losses and costs stemming from the troublesome booster, Mr. Dzieduszycki said. John Myers, a vice president at Eclipse, said the company would have no comment on an unresolved legal matter.
 
What Comes After Success?
 Since Terra Chips started being produced on an industrial scale, Mr. Acree said, sales have doubled every year. (These days, only about 10 percent of the chips are sold in New York City, with the rest scattered across the country.) This year, sales are expected to total $10 million, with net profits of about $1 million this year. The owners still bicycle to work, and dress casually around the office, in ponytails and shorts and running shoes.
The story of Terra Chips underscores what some economists say is an end to the retreat of manufacturing in the city. According to recent figures from the state's Labor Department, a modest expansion seems to be underway, especially in Brooklyn and Queens.
To Professor Moss, the company epitomizes a successful city start-up, 90's-style. He cited a recent study of 7,500 city manufacturers, conducted by his center, that, using data from 1984 to 1987, foundthat start-up companies in New York City had a 95.6 percent survival rate three years later, compared to 66 percent in the suburbs. In recent months, Terra Chips have gone on sale in single-flavor bags. For the partners, who say the want to license production "in every corner of the globe," the next stage of growth will be far more complex. Should they take on investors? Should they stay in the city? Should they add new products?
The answers, the experts say, will tell as much about the resilience of the new signs of manufacturing life as about the future of Dana Alexander.
"That is one of the most critical transitions, and when it comes time to make that leap, it's very hard to do that in New York," said Mr. O'Neill, who runs Appleseed, a Manhattan consulting group.
The city's discouraging factors, he said, include high costs, from rent to parking tickets to taxes, and the physical difficulties of getting around. In addition, he said, the city often fails to recognize the strength that small companies lend to the economy.
"A common complaint is that the economic-development management is too cumbersome, especially for small businesses," he said. "There's much more emphasis here on procedural requirements. From the point of view of a small businessman, it's just maddening red tape."
At the Urban Development Corporation, officials defend their conservatism as being in the public interest. "The U.D.C. directors need to scrutinize the applicants to make sure they are worthy beneficiaries of a public sector investment," Mr. Vitoff said.
At City Hall, the Giuliani administration says it is working "to create an environment in which small businesses can flourish." To that end, said Forrest R. Taylor, a spokesman, "the Mayor has instituted and is planning a number of initiatives to make New York City more business-friendly."
Among these efforts, some of which have already begun, are the Bid-Match program, which allows entrepreneurs to find out about potential city contracts on a computer database; the creation of borough offices to deal with small-business problems "door to door," and the scaling back of the often-criticized commercial rent tax, with the aim of eliminating it entirely by 1997, except in Manhattan south of 96th Street.
For their part, the owners of Terra Chips say they are weighing alternatives and have made no major decisions. Yet. But they acknowledge, somewhat nostalgically, that their most exciting days in business are probably behind them.
"We were chefs. We were just winging it," Mr. Dzieduszycki said. "We had a tremendous amount of common sense, but that doesn't answer all your questions."
 
Have a Dream? Need Some Advice?
You're thinking about starting your own business, fulfilling your American dream. Here are some organizations in New York that make it their business to help, with information, loans or both:
*The New York City Regional Office of the New York State Department of Economic Development, One Metrotech Center North, Suite 1002, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201. (718) 596-4120. Everything you always wanted to know about small business, from where to find an opportunity zone to how to design your facade. Generally a New York City small-business owner's first stop.
*New York State Urban Development Corporation, which has money set aside for various grants to small businesses. (212) 930-9000. Aid includes Small- and Medium-Sized Business Assistance loans, known as SAMBA, and loans to minority- and women-owned businesses.
*Industrial Technology Assistance Corporation. (212) 240-6920. Private, nonprofit group that works with companies seeking grants and other forms of assistance. Funded in part by the state Department of Economic Development.
*New York City Department of Business Services. 110 William Street, New York, N.Y. 10038. (212) 513-6300. For general information about programs and services, (212) 696-2442. Provides technical and other forms of assistance, including tax and utility savings and help in obtaining government contracts. One program is the Business Relocation Assistance Corporation, 110 William Street, New York, N.Y. 10038. (212) 513-6459. It helps companies relocating within the city with various subsidies.
*New York City, Economic Development Corporation. (212) 619-5000. Provides financial services and development strategies for businesses in the city. Runs the Industrial Development Agency, which authorizes tax-exempt financing for manufacturers, other industrial and not-for-profit corporations.
*United States Small Business Administration. (212) 264-1318. Financial and technical assistance on getting started and expansion and on obtaining Government contracts. Financial assistance includes direct loans, under special circumstances, and guaranteed financing.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UNION SQUARE;
Flatiron Map: Jigsaw Puzzle of Competing Claims

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE 

 BODY:
Six months ago the Flatiron district -- named for its 22-story, triangular skyscraper -- was relatively low-profile. Now, it is the newest -- and one of the better publicized -- of the city's up-and-coming business districts.
Problem is, the area the district claims is already home to all or parts of three associations (including a Flatiron District Neighborhood Association) and one business improvement district. And some of their leaders are not at all pleased by the new territorial claims. 
 "There's no need for another organization in this area," said William L. Haines, head of the Lower Fifth Avenue Association.
Rob Walsh, director of the 14th Street Business Improvement District, said: "I hope its a rookie mistake by an enthusiastic volunteer organization." He added: "I hope we won't trip over one another; a turf war won't do any good."
It started early this year, when Brian Moss, who has owned and operated Better Bodies gym on West 19th Street since 1982, realized he did not know anybody in the neighborhood. "It was very frustrating," said Mr. Moss, who wrote letters to a score of other businesses in the area, inviting them to meet and discuss local concerns.
His Good Neighbor effort caught on, and in June, the Flatiron District Business Association was born. It has 120 members, paying dues that range from $50 for a resident to $200 for a ground-floor business.
"We grappled with ourselves to define what is the Flatiron District," said Claudia Strauss, executive director. In the end, she said, the map was "architecturally driven," emphasizing the unity of the grand old department store buildings in the Ladies' Mile Historic District.
The tension takes place amid a confusing welter of similar-sounding terms. District business associations, business improvement districts, associations and partnerships are all nonprofit organizations that generally share a basic aim: improving the quality of life. What differs is the nature of their financing and services -- and their clout.
"A B.I.D. is a legal entity that levies assessments on all property owners in its designated area and provides regular services, such as sanitation and security, to supplement city services," said Bruce Cohen, a press representative who has worked with several business improvement districts.
Associations and partnerships, which sometimes become B.I.D.s, have voluntary members that pay dues or donations, providing a variety of services on an irregular basis.
Some of the businesses that fall amid the twice- or thrice-claimed territories are simply paying their dues and hoping it is all worthwhile. ABC Carpet and Home, at 888 Broadway between 18th and 19th Streets, belongs to the 14th Street Business Improvement District, the 23d Street Association and the new Flatiron association, paying a total annual fee of less than $1,000 a year.
Is it worth it? "Absolutely, yes," said Kevan Cole, ABC's president. MARVINE HOWE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: 34TH STREET;
New Merchants Make It a Resurrection on 34th Street

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
The remake of "Miracle on 34th Street" will head to theaters in November. But among business watchers, something of a miracle has already happened: after a decade of the domino deaths of its department store giants, 34th Street is re-emerging as the midtown heart of middlebrow shopping.
"It's hotter than hot -- there's so much demand for 34th Street there's not enough space to fill it," said Faith Consolo, a partner in Garrick-Aug, the nation's largest retail leasing agency. 
 As the geographic and economic midpoint between the 57th and 14th Street shopping strips, 34th serves a broad band of tastes and budgets. Macy's and stores to the east have an uptown flavor, while the south side and west end of 34th are more bargain basement, with many open-air storefronts.
Many new arrivals are of the mega-store, discount variety -- the ones Mayor Giuliani is most interested in tempting to the boroughs. Kmart is coming, the district's first new big department store in five years. And Daffy's clothing, Sports Authority and HMV Music are on the way. More big money is moving into the street's infrastructure: about $500 million has gone into renovations for Madison Square Garden, the Long Island Rail Road terminal and a new library.
Some changes are invisible at street level: the Garden and its Paramount, Knicks, Rangers and MSG TV were just sold for $1 billion. Macy's and Federated Department Stores are merging for $4 billion.
Macy's merger could lead Federated to close A&S. But there is interest in that and nearby sites from Sears, Penney's, Nordstrom, Lord and Taylor, Bradlee's and Caldor. Retailers viewed A&S as a high-risk gamble when it opened in 1989, but Mark Finkelstein of Retail Strategies, a brokerage, said, "Now there are many stores eager to take that over."
All this is a stunning turnaround from the street's near-death experience when Gimbels, Altman's, Korvettes, Orbachs, Saks 34th and Herald Center went under as suburbia flourished with new-style speciality and discount stores. Even more ominously, Macy's -- the sole surviving big store and cornerstone of the district -- fell into bankruptcy. Norman Sturner of Murray Hill Properties recalled, "That was a disaster -- 34th could have completely collapsed."
But Macy's hung on, and its drawing power is part of the street's inherent strength. In a two-block radius of 34th and Seventh Avenue are 698 retailers with yearly sales of $612 million, 109,000 workers earning $3 billion, and tourist meccas like the Empire State Building and Madison Square Garden. From Fifth to Eighth Avenue are 11 bus routes, 13 subways, Amtrak, New Jersey Transit and the Long Island Rail Road, and both ends of 34th connect with tunnels, ferries and heliports -- an unparalleled combination.
And the more the street thrives, the more allure it has for business. GHI, the insurer, has taken over an entire building, part of the district's 31 million square feet of offices.
Reinvestment helped, as did a belated economic recovery, better terms in the battered real-estate market, improvements in the garment industry north of 34th and thriving Koreatown to the south. So did the 1992 Democratic National Convention, with a local cleanup and Bill Clinton's televised stroll from Macy's to Madison Square Garden.
A business improvement district, the 34th Street Partnership, began that year. It painted lampposts, picked up litter, scrubbed off graffiti, hired security patrols and even cracked down on garish signs. Streets brightened and crime plummeted.
The crowds all that brings are 34th Street's essence. In July, counters at the southeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas saw 8,186 pedestrians from 5 to 6 P.M. Ms. Consolo said, "Retailers who try traffic studies there give up -- they get trampled." BRUCE LAMBERT

GRAPHIC: Photo: Retail stores, new and old, are the heartbeat of an ever-more vibrant district. (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1394 words

HEADLINE: Present Arms;
Clinton Corners Himself, Along With His Quarry

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEREVER he is, the late Lyndon Baines Johnson surely is shaking his head in wonderment at the current plight of his onetime critic, Bill Clinton, who is now President. No, Haiti is hardly Vietnam, not as a foe; not as a moral dilemma; probably not as a military quagmire. Yet 26 years after Mr. Clinton took to the streets to assail Mr. Johnson's war, he now finds himself, eerily, starring in its revival on the small stage: the principled President, drawn ever deeper into an unpopular battle by his own policies and a fear that retreat equals humiliation.
 So it was that a superpower threat to invade one of the world's weakest nations ballooned last week into a do-or-die test of the President's political manhood and diplomatic respect. It is not that Mr. Clinton lacks for intelligent arguments that his course, morally and historically, is right. But even many of those Democrats who believe Mr. Clinton is right to threaten military action suspect that he has arrived at that choice not by design, but by default. After repeated bluster in Bosnia, Somalia and Haiti -- followed by repeated retreat in each instance -- Mr. Clinton simply cannot afford to rattle another empty scabbard if he is to maintain the status of a world leader, they say.
 
 "Now they're faced with the stark reality that they have got to invade," a Democrat on the Senate's Foreign Relations Committee said last week in an interview. "They'll never be able to make a bluff anywhere in the world if they threaten to invade Haiti and back down."
 Few in Washington disagree with the President's broad goals: to end the dictatorship of Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, to halt the political torture and murder, to restore to office Haiti's first democratically elected president, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. No one disputes his ultimate aim, to sweep back the tide of refugees fleeing Haiti for economic or political salvation in the United States. And Mr. Clinton could credibly argue that his ultimatum to Haiti's dictators effectively continued a policy wielded against dictatorships in Grenada and Panama by Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
 Mr. Clinton's quagmire is not strategic, however, but acutely political. In Port-au-Prince, the military appears to have concluded it could step over Mr. Clinton's latest line in the sand because it had crossed others in the last 18 months with such impunity. The White House appears to have miscalculated General Cedras's stamina -- and, as a result, to have drawn furious new demands for tougher steps from hunger strikers, from blocs in Congress, from Florida politicians, from Father Aristide.
 And on Capitol Hill, Mr. Clinton is seen as having placed American credibility on the line without bothering to bring voters or lawmakers along -- a key to making any threat convincing.
 Mr. Clinton seemed to make a bow to that argument Friday, sending Jimmy Carter, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and retired Gen. Colin Powell to make a final pitch for General Cedras' peaceful departure. They were sent after Mr. Clinton's backers in the Capitol warned he was rushing into battle without having rallied political support or exhausted all options.
 Yet even his supporters allowed that Mr. Clinton had moved the crisis to such a pitch that, should that last plea fail, he had no choice but to invade or lose all credibility. "What we're trying to prove," said Representative Lee Hamilton, of Indiana, "is that we mean what we say."
 That has not always been so clear.
 When General Cedras ousted Father Aristide in September 1991, President Bush called it a threat to American security and vowed that the coup would not stand, but did little else. When Mr. Bush ordered the military to intercept Haitian refugees at sea and return them home, Presidential candidate Clinton vowed to reverse it and return Father Aristide to power.
 
The Power-Sharing Solution
 President Clinton quickly broke that pledge. For one thing, he realized -- as had Mr. Bush -- that accepting the boat people would encourage a greater exodus. For another, he adopted the early view of his aides that Haiti would never be stable unless its ruling military and business elite were part of any political settlement. So he began to bargain with General Cedras not for the restoration of Father Aristide, but for a power-sharing accord. But for this to work the generals had to be persuaded that they had no other choice. They had already shown they could withstand sanctions almost indefinitely. Without a convincing threat to oust them, they proved extraordinarily difficult to persuade.
 For a while, Father Aristide lashed out at his erstwhile White House allies. Then he proved sufficiently pliant about the need to reassure the wealthy that the White House succeeded in brokering a United Nations accord in mid-1993 under which General Cedras agreed to cede power. But there was a critical flaw: The general faced no punishment if he reneged.
 And he did. Then, when the White House sent the U.S.S. Harlan County that October to enforce the deal, a gang of Cedras thugs met it at the Port-au-Prince dock.
 It was a crucial moment, perhaps the last opportunity to persuade General Cedras that he, like Father Aristide, had no choice but to compromise. Instead, the ship steamed away, and Mr. Clinton's credibility sank in its wake. So negotiation had produced only a humiliation, and this strengthened the belief that Washington, whatever its threats, would not move beyond economic punishment to the use of force.
 
Then Came the Protests
 There matters rested, until black lawmakers in Congress began suggesting last spring that Mr. Clinton's apparent indifference to Haiti's travails was racist. An activist, Randall Robinson, began a 27-day hunger strike to underscore the point. Astonishingly, Mr. Clinton publicly endorsed the strike, saying that "we ought to change our policy." In May, Mr. Clinton did change it -- again -- persuading the United Nations to impose a total trade and travel embargo.
 Since then Mr. Clinton has eased the ban on processing Haitian boat people, tightened it again, won United Nations permission for an invasion, and moved warships offshore. He declared on Wednesday that the time for negotiations had passed. But on Friday, he elected to allow American emissaries to talk with General Cedras.
 In the end, the President appears to have returned to his position as a Presidential candidate: that returning refugees to Haiti is inhumane, and that the United States should return Father Aristide to power. But it is a course that even allies judge to be tentative and wracked by indecision.
 "The Clinton Administration has not made its case very well," said Robert White, a former ambassador to El Salvador who is president of the generally liberal Center for International Policy. "The lack of discipline inside the Administration hasn't only been notable; it's sent all kinds of mixed messages, conflicting messages to the military." Mr. White, who strongly favors military action to oust General Cedras if need be, says the Administration is bereft of an effective advocate for its position.
 So is Mr. Clinton's party in Congress.
 "There's no lack of consultation," said one Central America expert, an adviser for decades to Senate Democrats. "What's missing is the kind of relationship in which the Administration says, 'This is what we're going to do, and we need your support.' What's missing is what, in the insurance business, they call a closer."
 Foreign policy is nominally bipartisan, but in this case, should any military action go poorly, Mr. Clinton will be utterly alone.
 There is a good likelihood that it will not go poorly, however. Mr. White, a longtime scholar on Caribbean issues, suggests that Haiti's citizens will welcome American liberation, making pacification an uncomplicated task. "We're going to be surprised, if we don't tie Aristide's hands too tightly, at how quickly Haiti starts to function," he said.
 Perhaps so, with a wing and a prayer. But whatever happens on the ground, Mr. Clinton's credibility gap on foreign policy seems destined to yawn wide as ever. "Clinton could say tomorrow that he's decided not to invade Haiti," said another aide to a senior senator on the Foreign Relations panel, "and you know what? Not one senator would care."

LENGTH: 1062 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Blessed Are the Forgiven, For They Shall Run Again

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Mayor returned triumphantly to office after serving nearly six months in jail. He blamed his troubles with the law on his political enemies who, threatened by his power, had set out to get him. But now, the Mayor was as powerful as before.
 That sounds like the story of Marion S. Barry, who last week staged one of the most audacious comebacks in political history: four years after the former Mayor of the District of Columbia was caught on videotape smoking crack and convicted on drug charges, he won the Democratic Mayoral primary.
 
 But it is the story of James Michael Curley, who was a Mayor of Boston in the early 1900's and one of the most resilient politicians of his time. Despite several brushes with the law, including his conviction for mail fraud, Mr. Curley was elected Mayor four times over four decades.
 Mr. Barry's nomination, which almost insures his election, is the latest in a rich, yet quirky, American tradition of elected officials disgracing their offices and then turning their transgressions to political advantage. Like Mr. Curley, Mr. Barry did not apologize for his offenses. Both blamed their predicaments on the established power structure. Mr. Curley, the tribune of Irish immigrants, lashed out at the prominent Brahmins of Beacon Hill; Mr. Barry's venom was at the powerful white institutions that he said plotted to bring him down.
 "There's a striking similarity in their appeals," said Jack Beatty, author of a biography of Mr. Curley, "The Rascal King" (Addison-Wesley, 1992). "Both had a grasp for the politics of revenge; striking back at the respectable people, at the people who haven't been to jail, at the people who are outraged that this affront to the municipal consciousness should still be on the stage."
 But history shows that lack of discretion, or downright flouting of the law, does not always kill a political career. A term in jail, as Mr. Barry and Mr. Curley demonstrated, can be worn like a badge of courage.
 Representative Thomas J. Lane, a Democrat from Lawrence, Mass., was the first congressman re-elected, in 1956, after serving jail time -- four months for tax evasion. Voters did not seem to mind his criminal record because, like Mr. Barry and Mr. Curley, he was known for tending to the concerns of constituents.
 
Local Hero
 Another congressman who, like Mr. Lane, died earlier this year was Representative Daniel J. Flood, a debonair Democrat from northeastern Pennsylvania who was known for his villainous-looking mustache. To some, he was a crook who pleaded guilty to conspiracy in 1980. But he was a hero to the coal miners and flood victims in his district. Though forced to resign after his guilty plea, Mr. Flood was re-elected between two trials.
 Mr. Barry's resurrection is also reminiscent of the case of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., who was charged several times but never convicted. His fellow members of Congress excluded him for assorted financial improprieties, but the voters thought otherwise and re-elected him.
 David S. Bositis, a senior analyst for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, said that Mr. Powell's constituents cared more about what he could do for them than his own legal troubles.
 "People do not elect their leaders to be upright," Mr. Bositis said. "They want them to do something. If someone serves in office for 20 years and all they can say is they're honest, you can also say they were a lousy, ineffective leader."
 An important reason that Mr. Barry prevailed was that among the poor and disenfranchised, he was remembered as an effective leader. His two major opponents, Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly and Councilman John Ray, are both black, but they were viewed by poor blacks as too close to the white power structure. Of the three, only Mr. Barry was active in the civil rights movement, and only he was viewed as an advocate for the poor.
 Like Mr. Curley, Mr. Barry is known for appealing to peoples' self-interest; both reached out to help the down-and-out, even if it meant bloating the city budget with patronage appointments and public works jobs.
 Paul Costello, a former communications director for Mayor Kelly, said Mr. Barry's drug conviction is not startling to voters in poor neighborhoods to whom drug arrests are a daily part of life; and they think he was set up anyway.
 "So he went to jail for smoking crack; he gave my kid a summer job, he provided a job in city government for my parents, he touched my grandparent at a senior center," Mr. Costello said. "He enables people in the poorest, most devastated part of the city to believe in someone. But I think it's a charade."
 Charade or not, it seems to be working. Perhaps in an era when people are more contemptuous of their politicians than ever, voters have developed a new sense of morality: Since they are all bad, I'll vote for the politician who can do the most for me. In the case of Mr. Barry's supporters, it may not be so much a matter of forgiveness as much as a refusal to forgive the powers-that-be for doing him in.
 Another recent comeback was made by Representative Daniel J. Rosentkowski, the influential Chicago Democrat. Despite his indictment for defrauding the Government, Mr. Rostenkowski managed to win a contentious primary early this year. It was not because people were certain of his innocence, but because what mattered most was that Mr. Rostenkowski had a record of dispensing pork to his district.
 
Just Following Orders
 On the other end of the political spectrum, Oliver L. North, in his bid for Senate from Virginia, is playing the same politics. He has refused to apologize for the Iran-contra scandal, and instead has lashed out at the power structure in Washington -- Democrats and Republicans -- for conspiring against him. The message clearly has some appeal -- at least enough that Mr. North won the Republican nomination to take on Senator Charles S. Robb in November.
 Just as Mr. Barry's supporters overlooked his drug conviction, Mr. North's supporters overlooked his admission that he lied to Congress -- and prefer to focus on his talk of shaking up Washington and ending the Democratic hold on Congress. Todd Wilkowski, a 27-year-old student, put it this way after hearing Mr. North speak at a rally in Norfolk, last week: "Sometimes, you have to follow orders."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
The Economist's 'Just So' Story

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON 

 BODY:
It didn't quite pack the wallop of Demi Moore posing nude and pregnant, but the cover of The Economist -- with a photo of an evidently impassioned pair of humped beasts to illustrate the magazine's lead editorial, "The Trouble with Mergers" -- caused a bit of a stir on Wall Street last week. Not all of the talk was negative.
"Reaction has been roughly divided 50-50," said Bill Emmott, the editor of the very serious but rarely somber international news magazine, which is based in London. "Fifty percent disgusted and 50 percent highly amused." 
 The controversial cover appeared in The Economist's North American edition (circulation about 275,000) and the Asian-Australian edition (about 60,000), not in its European edition (250,000). Readers in the Old World were deprived or spared, depending on one's perspective.
Mr. Emmott was mildly surprised at having rubbed American sensibilities against the grain.
"Actually, a story on mergers is not that easy to illustrate," he observed. "We looked at a lot of pictures of copulating animals, I tell you, and this was the funniest." JOHN DARNTON

HEADLINE: Word for Word: The Health Care Papers;
Now It Can Be Told: The Task Force Was Bold and Naive and Collegial

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BILL CLINTON'S 20 months in the White House have been dominated by health care: the Administration's secretive efforts to write a health plan, followed by the agony of watching Congress tear it apart.
 The urgency, boldness, creativity, political naivete, confusion and frustrations of the Administration are revealed in rich detail in thousands of pages of documents made public this month. The Administration fought for 18 months to keep the records secret. But, rather than defend its position in court, the White House voluntarily released the documents by turning them over to the National Archives in College Park, Md.
 
 The documents come from the staff of the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, which included more than 500 experts on health policy, medicine, insurance and taxes. Many of these experts never expected their memorandums to become public. The memos that follow show that the policy-making process was often like a big, free-wheeling college seminar which considered dozens of policy options without reaching a clear consensus. ROBERT PEAR
 
Anticipating Criticism
 From a "preliminary work plan" sent on Jan. 26, 1993, by Ira C. Magaziner, coordinator of the task force, to members of the panel. The White House correctly anticipated criticism of the President's plan, but did too little to satisfy or disprove the critics.
 The United States is in the midst of a health care crisis.
 Health care costs are high and growing rapidly (14 percent of G.D.P. in 1992, expected to reach at least 18 percent by 2000). Rising health care costs are placing a tremendous burden on individuals, businesses and governments and are erasing gains in living standards. . . .
 
Likely Criticisms
 Any comprehensive health reform plan will be controversial. Some criticisms would apply to any plan; others are specific to the type of managed competition with global budgets proposed by President Clinton. Criticisms are likely to center on the following arguments:

1. Cost containment would be ineffective and have perverse results.
 *Little evidence exists that managed care networks will produce efficiencies and thus deliver the cost containment we require; the result will be reliance on existing perverse behaviors (e.g., risk selection, claims denials) to meet global ceilings.
 *Limiting spending on health care through global budgets will lead to service rationing, and interfere with quality improvements and consumers' traditional freedom to spend.

2. Universal coverage would involve redistribution of income and disrupt satisfactory arrangements for many Americans. The result would be to increase rather than reduce many Americans' costs of care.
 *Community rating of insurance premiums would raise costs for currently insured populations who are young, male and healthy. . . .
 *Requirements to purchase coverage would lower disposable incomes for individuals who have gone without health insurance.

3. The plan would be cumbersome.
 *Consumers would have to deal with new and unfamiliar agencies ("purchasing cooperatives") and choose from among plans they feel ill-equipped to evaluate.
 *Unanticipated barriers to service would be erected when people are sick.
 *Unanticipated financial obligations would be imposed on people who wanted to use providers not included in their plan.

4. Many small businesses may fiercely resist the proposal.
 *Even with subsidies for low-wage or newly insuring employers, our plan would impose premium requirements that small business groups and other critics will challenge as:
 -- A "payroll tax."
 -- A threat to current jobs.
 -- A threat to small business development and job creation.
 In designing our reforms, we must take cognizance of these potential criticisms. We need to allow states flexibility to use alternative models that may make sense for them.
 
Treasury Concerns
 From a confidential memorandum by James R. Ukockis, a senior economist at the Treasury Department, to Alicia H. Munnell, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Economic Policy, and Marina Weiss, her deputy, on Feb. 23, 1993.
 In short, the primary focus is now definitely on budget savings. Total savings to the economy is only a distant second, and improving total social benefits from the health sector is not even a consideration. . . .
 It appears the worst fears about the short-term cost containment efforts are coming true. The process is being driven by a narrow focus on the need for budgetary savings. The imperative for such savings is viewed as so strong it is used to justify risking major dislocations in the health care system. Those risks are dismissed with a vague assurance any problems caused will be taken care of by the phasing in of the (as yet undefined) long-term reform program. . . .
 If, in fact, we go forward with a price control program justified by, and designed to obtain, maximum budgetary savings, we may well find ourselves in the position of the general in Vietnam who declared with a straight face, "We had to destroy the village in order to save it." It was not a successful formula in Vietnam, and it will not be a successful formula in health care.
 From a memorandum by Mr. Ukockis to Ms. Munnell and Ms. Weiss on March 10, 1993.
 My reading of the matter is we have a massive case of policy constipation. We are halfway through the 100-day period, and I am unaware of any policy choices having been made to narrow the focus of the work. Issues of increasingly peripheral character are still being targeted for further study, with the output doing little but postponing and clogging up the policy decision process.
 It may be the problem is the presence of too many academics, whose intellectual interest in the policy issues far exceeds their understanding of the needs of a successful policy-making process.
 
'Not Good Policy'
 From a memorandum to Mr. Magaziner by Leonard Abramson, chief executive of U.S. Healthcare, which operates health maintenance organizations, on May 10, 1993. Mr. Abramson served on one of several "audit teams" that reviewed the task force's work.
 After some additional reflection on the elements of the reform proposal which our auditing group considered last week, I want to reiterate the following:
 The proposal needs a focus and identity that is presently missing. It tries to straddle the line between free-market competition and governmental bureaucratic regulation, but does neither one well. This is not good policy, nor will the merits of such a plan be easy to communicate to the American people or Congress.
 The bureaucratic route is not a desirable course. The additional bureaucracies now envisioned will take time to set up and even more time to function adequately, will be fraught with the problems that beset any bureaucracy, and will only add another layer of expense and inefficiency to the health care system. The health alliance concept, if it is to be successful, should aim for structuring competition, not stifling it.
